SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Money Can't Buy Happiness. Er, Can It?

BYLINE: By Paul Krugman; Paul Krugman is an economics professor at M.I.T. and the author, most recently, of "The Return of Depression Economics."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
A few weeks ago my wife and I finally gave in to the pressures of modern life and acquired a cell phone. But it turned out that once we had the thing we had a few questions -- questions we couldn't get answered, because customer service was swamped with similar calls from the thousands of other people who had recently signed on.
Meanwhile, my parents started calling contractors about some minor work on their house -- only to be told that every carpenter and plumber in the area was booked well into next year. 
 Talk to almost any middle-class American, and you will hear similar stories -- about poor service, excessive traffic, overpriced housing and so on. In fact, there seems to be a sort of rising chorus of complaints about the annoyances of prosperity -- complaints, in effect, that spending lots of money isn't as gratifying as people expected it to be. Most of this is petty stuff, but it is just possible that the chorus of complaints marks the beginning of a broader shift in attitudes -- a shift that will be healthy if it doesn't come too quickly.
Of course, people don't complain about the disappointments of prosperity unless they are prosperous, and in a way all this whining is a symptom of a remarkably successful era in American economic history. Still, you don't have to be an ascetic to wonder if there isn't something a bit manic about the pace of getting and -- especially -- spending in fin-de-siecle America.
Even the dry statistics suggest that something a little strange is going on. Consider: we are now eight years into an economic expansion. Consumer spending traditionally lags behind the economy as a whole in boom times, because families figure that times will not always be that good and that they should save for a rainy day.
This time, however, consumers are leading the charge: while the economy expanded an impressive 4 percent between the first quarter of 1998 and the first quarter of 1999, consumption grew 5.5 percent, and spending on consumer durables -- cell phones, bathroom fixtures, S.U.V.'s and home entertainment systems -- surged an incredible 12 percent.
There are at least two reasons to question whether America's consumption boom is really a good thing.
One is that by conventional standards, the typical American family is being a bit, well, imprudent in spending so much -- indeed, personal savings, never high in this country, have now disappeared almost completely. True, millions of families have seen their wealth surge because of a soaring stock market, but while more people than ever own stock, most still have no significant personal stake in the market.
You might argue that ordinary families are spending freely, despite sluggish wage growth, because they believe that prosperity is here to stay. But survey evidence suggests that many workers remain nervous about job security, a nervousness that manifests itself in a surprising reluctance to demand wage increases.
So why is spending so high? Much of the surge is driven by those families that do own a lot of stock and have been willing to treat recent capital gains not only as durable but as likely to continue. And at least some of the rest is the result of what Robert Frank calls luxury fever: families with annual incomes of $30,000 try to emulate the consumption of those with $60,000, who try to emulate those with $120,000, and so on. Ultimately we are all trying to keep up with the Gateses, and some of us really can't afford it.
And this leads to a deeper concern: there is good reason to think that even those consumers who can afford all this spending will eventually find that they can't get no satisfaction. It is hard to talk about this without sounding either moralistic or supercilious, but it turns out that the folk wisdom is backed by hard statistical evidence: you really can't buy happiness, certainly not for society as a whole.
Partly this is because of congestion effects like the ones my family is experiencing: when few people have cars, the one-car family is king, but when everyone has two, a lot of time is spent in traffic jams.
A more important point, probably, is that human beings are hard-wired to judge themselves not by their absolute standard of living, but in comparison to others. It may be true that in material terms today's borderline poor live as well as the upper-middle class did a few decades back, but that does not stop them from feeling poor. And consumer spending ultimately disappoints because of habituation: once you have become accustomed to a given standard of living, the thrill is gone.
But there is one very powerful argument that can be made on behalf of recent American consumerism: not that it is good for consumers, but that it has been good for producers. You see, spending may not produce happiness, but it does create jobs, and unemployment is very effective at creating misery.
Better to have manic consumers, American style, than the depressive consumers of Japan -- a country where the only consumer durables that have sold well the last few years are home safes, the better to hoard cash in.
This attempt to keep up with people richer than ourselves, however ineffectual it may have been on its own terms, has allowed the United States economy to sail through a global financial storm unscathed, and arguably made the difference between a global wobble and a repeat of the 1930's.
There is a strong element of rat race in America's consumer-led boom, but those rats racing in their cages are what have kept the wheels of commerce turning. And while it will be a shame if Americans continue to compete over who can own the most toys, the worst thing of all will be if the competition comes to a sudden stop.
Now there are faint hints in popular culture -- though certainly not yet in the spending numbers -- that Americans are starting to become disillusioned with high consumption, that in years to come the American consumer will become wiser and more prudent. Let's hope it really happens -- but not too fast.

HEADLINE: An Aria for the Arts at a Harlem School;
Rigorous Training Fills a Void and Nurtures Dreams

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Up to now there have been no musicians in the family of Willie Boy Morales Medina, an aspiring singer from Queens who is 17, husky, almost 6 feet 3 and still growing. His mother loves music but can't sing a note. "She's the only female bass I know," he said recently.
Mr. Morales Medina's voice is still shifting around. For now, he seems to be a baritone, but his heroes are tenors, especially Luciano Pavarotti and Andrea Bocelli. He dreams of a career as a singer. Getting accepted by the La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts was a step toward that goal. 
 But where he finally found the courage, support and, most important, training to potentially realize his dream was the Harlem School of the Arts on St. Nicholas Avenue near the corner of West 141st Street, in the Hamilton Heights section of Harlem. He spends a lot of time there after school and on weekends.
The Harlem School was founded in 1964 by the soprano Dorothy Maynor in the basement of St. James Presbyterian Church, next to its current modern building. Today the school serves some 3,000 students, from youngsters who take elementary classes in music, dance, art and theater to young adults with hopes of artistic careers.
Along with similar schools in New York -- Greenwich House Music School, Turtle Bay Music School, Third Street Music School Settlement and Brooklyn Music School -- the Harlem School has taken up the slack for the virtual abandonment of arts education in the city's public schools since the mid-1970's.
"The arts programs in the public schools are more or less window dressing," said Darryl Durham, executive director of the Harlem School and a North Carolina-born clarinetist and conductor. "Our work here is much more in-depth."
For example, in addition to taking theory classes, singing in the chorale and taking part in the opera workshop, Mr. Morales Medina receives one-on-one voice lessons, something beyond the resources of even a special public high school like La Guardia. Before the cuts during the fiscal crises of the 1970's and the 1980's recession, most of the 1,100 New York City public schools had at least one art or music teacher. By 1991 two-thirds of the elementary schools had none. In this decade, public school arts programs have gained ground with some major help from private sources, like a $12 million challenge grant from the Annenberg Foundation in 1993, and from public programs like New York City's Project Arts, which provided $75 million over three years. But getting the arts financing and programs into economically deprived neighborhoods has been difficult, and Harlem has historically been one of the least well served.
"We went so many years without arts funding at all," Sharon Dunn, the school system's special assistant to the arts, said recently. "We have come to a new thinking about how to deliver the arts, and partnerships with places like the Harlem School of the Arts are the best way to go."
Indeed, the Harlem School gives special attention to a tuition-free program dating from 1974 called Opportunities for Learning in the Arts. It enables about 225 students in the first through third grades from three neighborhood public schools to study percussion, dance, recitation, the visual arts and scene and monologue writing. Each public school contributes $10,000 to the program, but the Harlem School makes up the rest of the cost, which can be $150,000 annually.
"This is what it means to exist as a community arts organization," Mr. Durham said. "And once these kids get hooked, we have programs to take them further into the disciplines of their choice."
 
Teaching Discipline Through the Arts
Maynor believed that arts education could stimulate a child emotionally and intellectually, teach discipline, cooperation and good behavior, and empower families through a commitment to their children's education. All of the private arts schools in the region share this philosophy.
The fine arts can be a hard sell, especially for families struggling to get by. But for teachers at the Harlem School, many of whom have broken the color line in orchestras and on stages throughout the United States, a more nettlesome challenge is the confounding perception among some members of minorities that the fine arts are elitist.
Betty Allen, 69, the former mezzo-soprano who was executive director of the school for 13 years and is now president emeritus, understands how the elitist stigma came about but finds it dismaying.
"I grew up in a low-income neighborhood in Campbell, Ohio," she said. "The families were mostly of Greek and Sicilian heritage. Walking down the street on Saturday afternoons you would hear the broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera coming from every window. Nobody told these people that the fine arts were not for poor people like them, just for rich snobs."
It upsets her that any black child would shun the fine arts after all the efforts by black artists to dismantle racial barriers to professional participation. Ms. Allen's first prominent engagement came in 1952 when, at 22, she was chosen for the all-black cast for the New York revival of Virgil Thomson's opera "Four Saints in Three Acts." (Singing a tiny role was a young soprano just out of Juilliard named Leontyne Price.) This was three years before Marian Anderson broke the color line at the Metropolitan Opera.
"You can speak articulately and be black," Ms. Allen said. "You can have a good education and be black. The arts teach timeless disciplines and we practice those disciplines at the school. When a student tells me he wants to study African dance, I tell him, first you must take basic ballet. We don't play pitty-pat here."
 
A Place to Release Emotional Intensity
For Ms. Allen, the best way to win over children to the fine arts is by providing an example of a disciplined, fulfilling artistic life, and, of course, by teaching. She is the artistic director of the Opera Theater Workshop, which recently presented a program of opera scenes in which Mr. Morales Medina took part. She sat right up front in her own row of one watching over her charges, sometimes mouthing silently the words to opera scenes by Handel, Beethoven, Massenet and Menotti.
Many black educators and artists share her belief in the discipline the arts can impart, for one, the playwright and director George C. Wolfe, whose play "The Colored Museum" was being performed by students at the Harlem School the same afternoon that Ms. Allen's opera workshop was presented.
But Mr. Wolfe thinks Ms. Allen and others may be overly worried about the elitist stigma.
"That just comes from some people's small perceptions," he said recently. "Any art form involves discipline, rigor, consistency, passions, all of these skills that also give you a release for your feelings." And as recent events show, he added, "a lot of young people with intense feelings have no place to release them."
Arguing over what it means to be black is pointless, said Mr. Wolfe. "It means 8,000 things at the same time," he said. "I don't place much value on improving other people's false perceptions. It's a waste of time. The more fully I manifest who I am, the more I sharpen other people's perception of what I am."
To Mr. Durham, the simultaneous performances of Mr. Wolfe's play, which "emphasizes African-American culture," and Ms. Allen's opera workshop, which "emphasizes what people would call European or Anglo culture," represented a perfect fulfillment of the Harlem School's mission.
Still, Mr. Durham must deal creatively with the repercussions from false perceptions among his students. "For example, the biggest problem I face as conductor of the orchestra here is trying to keep the interest of over 200 violin students in an instrument that they perceive to be very limited musically," he said. So he started a jazz string ensemble. Recently he conducted a program of Motown hits in his own arrangements and taught the students about the use of string tracks in Motown and other pop music. To fight the stigma among boys that dance is "not a guy thing," Mr. Durham organized an all-male dance class.
Because the Harlem School primarily serves African-American (about 65 percent of the student body) and Latino students (about 33 percent) from low-income neighborhoods, it faces problems realizing its goals. For one, the school must keep fees low and provide ample scholarships, which requires intensive fund-raising because only 15 percent of its $2 million budget comes from tuition.
 
'Something Good Is Happening'
 The irrepressible Ms. Allen is a particularly good fund raiser. "I do it by telephone, and by talking with people from the boards I serve on," she said. These include Carnegie Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the New York City Opera, the Theater Development Fund and until recently, Unicef. "Most people sooner or later ask me about the school. Then I tell them to come up and see us. When they watch us interact with the students and see the improvement, they know something good is happening."
On a recent bright Sunday afternoon, Mr. Morales Medina participated for the first time in a presentation of opera scenes offered by the school's Opera Theatre Workshop. Until then his mother had never heard him perform with costumes, choreography and an instrumental ensemble. He sang with the chorus in several scenes and had one aria to himself, "Hush, Be Silent," from "The Fairy Queen" by Purcell.
"My mother's respect is much greater now, which is great," he said. "Singing is what I want to do."
Right now, Mr. Morales Medina doesn't want to hear about the odds against a solo career. But turning out professionals was never the primary goal of the Harlem School. Some students do go on to professional careers. The jazz clarinetist Don Byron is an alumnus, and 14-year-old Kai Braithwaite, who is alternating in the role of Young Simba in "The Lion King" on Broadway, attended the school.
Kevin Maynor another graduate, is a busy operatic bass who will be covering roles in the forthcoming San Francisco Opera production of Wagner's "Ring" cycle.
But Mr. Morales Medina -- Willie Boy, to his friends -- is the kind of student who keeps Mr. Durham excited and optimistic about the school and the community. "If you consider the saying 'It takes a village to raise a child,' " he said, "we are an important part of that village."

HEADLINE: Conrail Chugs Off Into the Sunset;
CSX and Norfolk Southern Take Over

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The companies about to divvy up the huge Conrail system have certainly tried to do their homework.
They bought extra locomotives, laid hundreds of miles of new track, tested computer systems and settled with a multitude of unions. They hired thousands of Conrail workers and managers and spent long hours teaching them what the future would hold. 
 That future arrives today, as Norfolk Southern and CSX, which already dominate commercial rail traffic in much of the East, take over chunks of Conrail. The switchover will herald the most sweeping change in a generation in the Northeast's commercial railroads -- especially in the New York area.
If the transformation goes smoothly, the effects will be felt far and wide. With more competition, shipping costs should fall, a benefit that could ripple throughout the region's economy in the form of lower prices for all manner of goods. And increased rail traffic could take business from truckers, which would have a marked impact on traffic and pollution.
Some of this bonanza, however, could well come at the expense of commuters. Many commuter lines in the Northeast share tracks with Conrail, and increased commercial traffic could put a squeeze on them -- and increase the risk of snags that would delay everyone. Both railroads have had extensive meetings with local transportation authorities to address these concerns.
At the moment, though, the focus is on the long-awaited transition, and executives at the Norfolk Southern Corporation and the CSX Corporation say they are doing everything they can to make it go smoothly. For no one -- not the railroads, not the thousands of companies that rely on them to ship raw materials and finished products, not the consuming and traveling public -- wants a repeat of the nightmare that followed another recent railroad merger.
After taking over Southern Pacific in 1996, Union Pacific, the nation's largest railroad, was mired in chaos for months, with thousands of rail cars lost or misrouted and its major rail lines clogged with traffic. Shippers faced such frustrating delays that some, in desperation, had to go to Union Pacific's rail yards themselves to search for their goods.
At the height of the debacle, in late 1997, the extra cost to manufacturers, utilities and retailers along the Gulf Coast and on the West Coast ran to an estimated $100 million a month.
Union Pacific did finally manage to restore service to normal, but the experience left many shippers nervous as the joint takeover of Conrail drew near. So a group of companies put pressure on executives of both Norfolk Southern and CSX to meet with Union Pacific executives to try to find out what went wrong and what they could do to avoid a chaotic encore.
"We wanted to make sure they didn't repeat the same mistakes," said Edward H. Rastatter, director of policy at the National Industrial Transportation League, a trade group that represents many of the nation's largest rail shippers.
Before the group would support the takeover, he said, it insisted that the two railroads meet monthly with a group of shippers to report on their progress. The group also urged the railroads to avoid Union Pacific's mistakes by having all labor agreements in place, testing information systems and completing the training of workers and managers well before they began running Conrail themselves.
The top executives of both railroads needed little urging, having seen claims and lawsuits from shippers mount against Union Pacific. They met with executives not just from Union Pacific but also from Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which was formed in a 1995 merger.
"We took extra care," said David R. Goode, the chairman, president and chief executive of Norfolk Southern, which is based in Norfolk, Va., and whose reputation for planning carefully and paying close attention to detail has earned it one of the industry's best safety records.
It was in 1997 that the managements of the two railroads, each of which had sought to take over Conrail for itself, ended their bidding war, realizing that even if one of them prevailed, it would face major antitrust hurdles.
That April, they agreed to buy Conrail jointly for $10.3 billion, with Norfolk Southern getting 58 percent and CSX 42 percent.
But both railroads bided their time before taking over. They also agreed to spend the money to buy new equipment, including locomotives, and to train extra engineers so they would have a reserve if they ran into trouble.
"We've taken longer than we expected," Mr. Goode said.
Michael Ward, an executive vice president at CSX Transportation Inc., the railroad subsidiary of CSX, based in Richmond, said Union Pacific's troubles proved to be an advantage in the transition.
"It made us pause and not rush the savings," he said. "It gave us the patience to do this properly."
The change was a long time coming. Back in 1976, Congress, with much fanfare, created the Government-controlled Consolidated Rail Corporation out of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad and five other struggling lines in the Northeast.
By the early 1980's -- after a huge infusion of public funds to rebuild its aging trains and tracks, over $7 billion all told, and repeated rounds of cost cutting and job cuts -- the railroad showed stirrings of life.
In this period, various attempts were made to sell Conrail, either to a private company or to the public. Norfolk Southern was once close to a deal, but it lost out when Conrail's unions and managers fought back and forced a sale through a public offering.
The Government's 85 percent stake was finally sold to the public in March 1987 for $1.9 billion, while its unions kept 15 percent. Since then the railroad and its shareholders have prospered, with hefty profits and a sharply rising stock price. It has been a major force in getting shippers to send their freight on intermodal trains -- which carry containers or easily transferable truck trailers -- rather than trucks.
Thus CSX and Norfolk Southern will be dividing up a robust competitor, one that has played a big role in helping sustain some basic industries in the Northeast economy.
A major goal of shippers and other groups in the Northeast was to have two railroads compete for Conrail's customers, and the breakup achieves that.
Cruz Russell, director of policy and planning for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said his agency had favored dividing Conrail to insure "that the region not end up with another monopoly."
He said the agency and other groups were also able to persuade both railroads to help revive some rail service in the various marine terminals in the port of New York.
Right now there is practically no way to get goods across New York Harbor except by truck or barge. A short line called the New York Cross Harbor railroad has reached an agreement with Norfolk Southern to help it build up the use of barges, which will move containers from rail cars between the Greenville yards in Jersey City and the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.
Also, some tracks on Staten Island's North Shore Line are being restored with the help of the New York City Economic Development Corporation. This will enable containers to be moved by rail, by both railroads, between New Jersey and docks in Staten Island. It will also link the docks with trains that can go anywhere in the nation.
The New York region now lags behind other major cities and ports in moving freight by rail. But these changes, Mr. Russell said, will help change that. Huge containers now moved by truck will soon be carried by rail, easing road congestion and lowering costs.
Some shippers have already seen their rates fall by about 5 percent, he added, as the two railroads compete to sign up customers.
Mr. Ward, of CSX, estimated that of Conrail's $3.5 billion in annual revenues, about $1 billion came from what the railroads term "jump-ball customers" -- which, because of track layout, could theoretically be served by either railroad.
The two rivals have been fast off the mark. Between them, he estimated, their sales staffs have signed up shippers representing about 80 percent of that $1 billion by offering discounts of roughly 6 to 8 percent. And in the push to compete with trucking, many others could get discounts, too.
Even after such rate cuts, he said, the railroads will be able to turn a profit. That would be good news for stockholders, since both railroads added greatly to their debt load to buy Conrail. CSX stock is roughly where it was two years ago, while Norfolk Southern shares are up slightly. CSX closed at $46.9375 on Friday, and Norfolk Southern closed at $32.875.
One big change is that with more extensive track networks, both railroads will offer more routes on which a single train can make the whole journey -- from, say, Atlanta to Chicago or Bangor, Me.
While containers generally arrive about a day later by rail than if they were moved by truck, the rates offered by railroads are about 15 percent lower, creating a strong incentive to switch.
Even though Conrail did provide some competition for trucks, in many cases "there will be competitive service where none existed before," said Tom Finkbiner, the vice president for intermodal trains for Norfolk Southern.
There has been little outcry from truckers, and some, seeing rate cuts as inevitable, are even cooperating with railroads.
Meanwhile, everyone has been poised for today, when one of the most complex transitions in railroad history will take place.
"We're satisfied that they have done a superhuman effort of planning," Mr. Rastatter of the transportation trade group said. "We're waiting with our fingers crossed."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A little-known way to profit by playing yen against dollars is again tempting the risk takers.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
ONE of the main culprits in the global financial crisis of 1997 is sneaking back into the financial markets.
The spread between Japanese and higher American interest rates has recently been widening, tempting speculators to borrow yen at bargain-basement prices, convert them to dollars and invest them in United States Treasury bills. The idea is to sell the bills later on, pocket most of the interest payments and then repay the low-interest yen debt. 
 If the yen does not turn against the borrower -- and most forecasts are saying that it will not -- it is an easy, if perhaps esoteric way to make money.
But the play, known as a "carry trade," has not caught fire yet the way it did two years ago, traders and analysts say, in part because speculators are still smarting from their losses after it backfired in 1997 and again in 1998.
If this bet does go mainstream again, though, it could weaken the yen and buoy the United States bond market, helping keep interest rates lower than they would otherwise be.
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, argues that if the yen carry trade does catch on again, it could make the Federal Reserve's goal of slowing economic growth here more difficult. "The yen carry trade shows that global capital flows can be at odds with domestic economic circumstances," he said.
The key to the trade -- besides a large enough difference in interest rates -- is the performance of the currency that the borrowing is done in. It has to remain stable or weaken against the currency that the bonds are bought in. If the borrowing currency suddenly rallies, the cost of paying off the loan rises. A sharp currency rally can quickly make the carry trade a big loser.
In 1997, Asian investors took low-interest loans in yen or dollars and invested at higher rates at home, for example, in Thailand. Last year, the carry trade was focused on borrowing in Japanese yen and investing in United States Treasuries.
But when the yen suddenly rallied against the dollar and other Asian currencies in May 1997, that carry trade blew up in the speculators' faces. The rush to get out involved the selling of local currencies, like the Thai baht, to convert to yen and dollars to pay off the loans. And that selling marked the beginning of the rush that forced the devaluation of the Thai currency in July, which in turn marked the beginning of the Asian, and eventually broader, financial crisis.
Last year, speculators began to get out of the yen carry trade as the Russian financial crisis came to a head in August. The flight accelerated after the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the American hedge fund. The selling of dollars to buy yen and pay off the yen loans helped send the yen soaring 29 percent against the dollar in two months. After that the interest-rate spread narrowed, closing the door on the carry trade.
But in the last two months, the spread between American and Japanese interest rates has widened again -- to a high of 4.42 percentage points on 10-year notes, a big enough difference to make the strategy attractive once more. With yields that much higher in this country, as long as the yen does not significantly strengthen against the dollar, it will be very profitable to borrow in Japan and invest the proceeds in the bond market here.
"There is no question that it is now the time to put the trade back on," said Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston. Yet he said he did not think there are nearly as many bets on now as there were in 1998.
One reason for this reluctance, in addition to the memory of recent losses, is that market players realize there is much more risk of an adverse currency move. In 1997, for example, the Thai baht's value was pegged to the dollar, making the trade appear much less risky. In contrast, given the sharp fluctuations of the yen against the dollar over the last year, the currency risks are much greater. The yen, after falling 8.6 percent this year, has gained almost 3 percent in the last week and a half, trading on foreign spot markets late yesterday around 121.50 to the dollar.
Another factor is investors' wariness about the prospects for emerging markets and United States stock markets in the wake of the Federal Reserve's announcement that it would now lean toward a policy of higher interest rates. With stock selloffs still fresh in their minds, some traders may be reducing their exposure to risky bets, including the yen carry trade.
James Kemp, the head of foreign-exchange sales and trading for North America at Citigroup, suggested that the yen's recent rise reflected this cautiousness. "People are in risk-reduction mode," he said.
A strategist at a prominent hedge fund, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, agreed. "People are playing, but they are taking their profits right away," the strategist said, adding, "That is why you are going to see a lot of spikes up and down in the yen."
Still, the rally in the yen could set up another run into the carry trade. While the interest rate spread has narrowed a little, to 4.17 percentage points on Friday, the last day of bond trading before yesterday's holiday, the yen, many forecasters think, is most likely to reverse course, weakening to a level of perhaps 130 to the dollar. And if that turns out to be true, the lure of the yen carry trade could prove irresistible.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russian Arrears Deepening On Debts to Foreign Group

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 31

 BODY:
On Wednesday, Russia will default on roughly $900 million in interest payments on debt it owes the so-called London Club, a group of major foreign banks and investors that lent money to commercial entities of the former Soviet Union.
Reneging on debt may be a grave transgression, but most London Club lenders have shown little rancor or surprise at Russia's failure to pay. 
 Although a splinter group of United States creditors is threatening to sue Russia, the London Club as a whole seems hesitant to act. It could restructure the debt with the Russians, or it could get tough and call in the full amount, accelerating a default. Yet because of a host of considerations, the creditors have instead chosen to look the other way as Russia falls deeper into arrears.
"What's likely to happen after June 2 is that Russia will remain in default and not get called on it," Charles Blitzer, the chief international economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said.
When its economy collapsed last August, Russia unilaterally annulled obligations on a range of debt, including a default on $40 billion of treasury bills. Besides its own loans, Russia had also inherited the former Soviet Union's debts to foreign governments and private lenders. After the crisis, Russia said it would honor foreign debt it had accumulated after the fall of the Soviet Union, which includes Eurobonds, loans from the International Monetary Fund and a few other instruments. But the Russian Government maintained that it lacked the resources to pay the Soviet debt.
In fact, the June 2 default surprises few people because Russia is already in arrears on $300 million it owed the London Club in December 1998. All told, Russia has fallen behind on about $1.2 billion of about $30 billion in Soviet-era debt it owes the London Club.
When Russia did not pay last year, that debt was automatically rolled over under the terms of its London Club contract. But some creditors also called for a vote to accelerate default, which means the whole sum comes due immediately. That measure failed, but it is likely that a newly formed association of investment funds, the United States-based Russia London Club Portfolio Managers Inc., may again demand such a vote once a 15-day grace period passes after the June 2 deadline.
"I think the commercial banks in the London Club are mistaken about the sentiment among creditors this time," said Marc Helie, managing director of the New York investment management firm Gramercy Advisors and chairman of the association, whose members hold about 10 percent to 15 percent of the total London Club debt. "I think now many other creditors will vote for an acceleration of default."
Whatever the outcome of the vote, the emergence of the investor association alone shows how fractured the London Club is, which may help explain its hesitancy over Russia. About half of those holding London Club debt are investment funds, according to Mr. Helie. Yet the bank steering committee that actually negotiates with the Russians is drawn from major lenders like Deutsche Bank A.G., J. P. Morgan & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company. Mr. Helie and others say that because these banks want future business with Russia, they may be unwilling to pressure the Government on the London Club arrears.
"The London Club has objectives beyond Soviet debt, such as bilateral debt, underwriting of new securities, all of which would tend to dilute their focus on these debt securities," Mr. Helie said.
The varied business goals of the creditors and their access to the Russians themselves affect how they view Russia's ability to pay. Some argue that Russia could pay, at least partly, but is unwilling to, because it knows that for the time being it can get away with delaying tactics. They note that in mid-May, Russia scraped together about $330 million in interest on bonds issued against another package of Soviet-era debt. But those bonds are held mainly by Russian investors.
Yet others on the steering committee who are in regular contact with the Russians say Moscow wants to pay but cannot, which necessitates patience. "Russia has been paying its debts incurred since 1992, but only by borrowing from the Central Bank," one London Club banker said. Russia's hard currency reserves are about $11 billion now. "It shows you that they have no further funds to pay old debts," the banker said.
The London Club is forming a subcommittee to do the preliminary economic research to begin talks with Russia on restructuring, tentatively scheduled for late June. Russian officials have said repeatedly that they would like 75 percent of their debt forgiven, which is unlikely. In fact, some observers think the London Club should stay in its holding pattern, without restructuring or calling a default, until the Russian presidential elections in mid-2000.
"This isn't the right time to get into serious negotiations, because there won't be a stable government until there's a new president," Mr. Blitzer said. "The London Club is best advised to agree to nothing and wait."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Quick Recovery Undercuts South Korea's Quest to Bail Out Banks

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31

 BODY:
South Korea's efforts to enlist foreign capital and expertise in an overhaul of its rickety financial system have become bogged down in, of all things, the country's stunning recovery from economic crisis.
Today, the Financial Supervisory Commission, the financial watchdog charged with cleaning up South Korea's debt-laden financial institutions, announced that it had extended negotiations over the final terms of the sale of Seoul Bank to HSBC Holdings P.L.C. until June 30. 
 "Both parties agreed that more time was needed, as due diligence of the bank took longer than initially expected," the commission said in a statement, referring to the need for the buyer to do more research.
The tortured negotiations stand in stark contrast to the rest of the optimistic news sweeping the country and are thus fast shaping up as a litmus test of the Government's resolve to continue to push reform now that pressure in the form of imminent economic collapse, a sinking currency and a crashing stock market has faded.
The commission also delayed for a third time the sale of Korea First Bank to a group of investors led by Newbridge Capital Ltd., a private equity group backed by two United States financiers, David Bonderman and Richard C. Blum.
Both banks were nationalized as part of a $57 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund in December 1997 when Korea teetered on the brink of default.
Conditions have changed markedly since then. Today, Korea's economy is growing beyond all expectations, and its stock market hits post-crisis highs nearly every day, as foreign investors register their approval of the Government's reform efforts.
"The economy is improving, people are feeling better and the sense of urgency is not as great," said Jeffrey D. Jones, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea.
What is more, Mr. Jones said, the economic improvements do in fact reduce the need for foreign capital, although Korea is still eager to obtain it. "When you don't see that sense of urgency, that can be seen as a step back," he said.
Maintaining the drive to change ways of doing business that are decades old, however, is critical, not only in Korea but across Asia. Japan's seemingly intractable economic decline stands as a stark reminder of the perils of staving off the problems rather than moving aggressively to eradicate them.
"It's maybe the biggest challenge Korea in particular and the rest of Asia in general faces, not lapsing back," said Wilbur Ross, a high-profile turnaround strategist at Rothschild Inc. He was recently appointed by the Korean Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy as the "Honorary Economic Ambassador" to the APEC Investment Mart being held in Seoul this week, an offshoot of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum that is aimed at enticing foreign investors to Asia.
He remains bullish on the region, as he will demonstrate in a speech to the conference tomorrow that will stress the importance of following up capital enhancements to financial systems with a complete overhaul of management practices.
Nonetheless, Mr. Ross, like many other foreign executives who have shuttled between their home countries and South Korea over the last year, said he had definitely encountered changes in attitude among people there. "The first place you see it is in the cab drivers," he said. "They're more abrupt, less courteous than a few months ago."
In other words, at least in so far as the demeanor of cabbies is any indicator, there has been a pronounced swing back to old habits.
There may be some political motivation for today's delays. Parliamentary elections are coming up on Friday, and the Government is afraid of a public backlash against the ruling party should it conclude the deals before voters go to the polls.
The Financial Supervisory Commission has spent 43.9 trillion won of taxpayer money (about $37 billion) so far to recapitalize financial institutions, and politicians from the ruling party are worried that voters will be shocked to see how comparatively little money the Government gets for the two banks.
The delays, however, raise the taxpayers' bill. After it postponed the deal for Korea First, the Government was forced to put in another $2.5 billion of capital -- in addition to the intangible costs of dampening investor sentiment.
Both bank deals have foundered over price, with the Government insisting that the banks' assets are worth more than the prospective buyers are willing to consider. However, Mr. Jones said that he believed that HSBC's acquisition of Seoul Bank would ultimately be completed.
And earlier this month, price scuttled a deal for Korea Life Insurance, which the commission was trying to sell to a foreign buyer. Metropolitan Life, the big American insurer, spent several months and roughly $2 million poring over the books only to conclude that the Government would never entertain a bid at a price Metropolitan Life considered reasonable, according to one person familiar with the situation.
Axa, a large French insurance company, apparently came to the same conclusion. Neither company even tendered an offer.
"A lot of foreign buyers came to Korea at a very early stage, talked to companies when they were at the very bottom and walked away with plans to buy that were bargains," said Kristine Li, an analyst who follows Korean banks for Lehman Brothers in Hong Kong. "But Korea has recovered so quickly, just in the last four months, and everything, including the perception of the values of assets, has changed quickly, too."
Although its efforts to lure foreign capital into the banking system have been delayed, the Financial Supervisory Commission has pushed through extensive changes in the financial system. Banks are cutting up to 30 percent of their employees, and the number of banks has shrunk to 17, from 27. About 20 percent of bank branches are being phased out, and new managers are gradually entering the top ranks of decision makers. "I don't think any other country has done or could do as much as they have in terms of cleaning up the banking system," Ms. Li said.

HEADLINE: Drawing Plans for Tomorrow's Landmarks

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
ARCHITECTURE is an old man's game," said David M. Childs, 58. "You've got to go convince somebody to spend half a billion dollars to do something you want to do. So they like gray hair. Or no hair, in my case."
Whatever it is -- the hair, the age, the combination of political skills with what critics are calling the finest work of his career -- Mr. Childs is at this moment the man transforming the skyline of New York City with some of the most important buildings of this generation. 
 He is the architect for no less than the new Pennsylvania Station, the new New York Stock Exchange, the new Columbus Circle and part of the new Times Square. And while other architects, like Frank Gehry and Robert Venturi, are more famous, Mr. Childs is in many ways more powerful because of his enormous firm, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and his control over the kind of era-defining projects that everyone is watching.
"It's an extraordinary moment," he said last week in Skidmore's New York office, a sleek white space 25 floors above Wall Street. "You're sort of lucky to be alive."
Mr. Childs seemed only a tad deflated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's boycott of the ceremony unveiling the Penn Station designs two weeks ago. "I worry about the architecture," Mr. Childs said. (Mr. Giuliani skipped the event, attended by President Clinton, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Gov. George E. Pataki, with whom the Mayor is squabbling, saying he was skeptical of its cost and scope. His complaints are unlikely to jeopardize the $484 million project, which is about $134 million short of its estimated cost.)
Mr. Childs is instead focusing on the largely rave reviews for his plan to remodel the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue -- built across the street from the old Penn Station by McKim, Mead & White in 1913 -- and add a soaring metal and glass roof that reflects both the original station and the late 20th century. Herbert Muschamp in The New York Times called the architecture "superb"; Paul Goldberger in The New Yorker said it was "nearly as brilliant" as Mr. Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain.
Meanwhile, Mr. Childs is just beginning the drawings for the new stock exchange, to be built across the street from the current one, and is to break ground by the end of this year on the Columbus Circle project, twin towers that will house the headquarters for Time Warner, a Jazz at Lincoln Center performance hall, retail shops and condominiums.
How can he do all these projects at once? Mr. Childs smiled. "Very awkward question," he said. "You're not one of my clients, are you?"
Mr. Childs, who has a charming, understated and reassuring style that obviously works wonders with government officials, spent the first years of his life in New Jersey, where his father was a classics professor at Princeton, and then moved to Washington where his father became, as Mr. Childs put it cheerfully, "a spook." During World War II, the elder Mr. Childs joined the Office of Strategic Services, the precursor to the Central Intelligence Agency, and later worked for the C.I.A. "We weren't particularly close," Mr. Childs said.
WHEN Mr. Childs was about 10, his parents divorced, and he moved with his mother to Mount Kisco, in Westchester County. Mr. Childs went to prep school at Deerfield and then entered Yale as a premed student majoring in zoology. About the time he realized that "I liked drawing the frog I was dissecting more than learning the names of the veins," he took Vincent Scully's History of Architecture course, but merely to fulfill a requirement.
"He's the one who changed my life," Mr. Childs said, still marveling at the wonders of the course. "It just opened up a world to me." Mr. Childs went on to the Yale School of Architecture, then landed at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in Washington, where he helped redesign Pennsylvania Avenue, the Mall and the renovation of train stations along the Northeast Corridor.
"We did virtually nothing in New York," he said. "It was just this black hole."
In 1984 he moved to New York, where he lives on the Upper East Side. (He is married with grown children.) He designed the Bertelsmann Building in Times Square and the Worldwide Plaza development at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, but spent much time with projects in other countries, particularly when the city's economics were bad. "Many of us were moving around the world while this city was dead," he said. "So it's nice to be here."
Now Mr. Childs says New York is in a golden age of building, similar to the one near the last turn of the century, when Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal were born. But while he thinks the renovation of Grand Central "is great," it would be "kind of sad if the one thing we can do at the end of the century is to repeat the dreams of a century ago."
Because: "When you deal with things like Penn Station, the stock exchange and Columbus Circle, you're building the fabric of the city itself -- the great rooms of the mansion. Building a city is like a long piece of music, and you have a moment to sing you note."
As an architect, he added, "you sort of work your way up from your mother's porch to somebody's wing to your first building."
And now, New York. "I'm just beginning," he said. "This is it."

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: Owner Has Big Dreams for a Newark Motel With a Seedy Past

BYLINE: By ALAN FEUER 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 29

 BODY:
For years, the Lincoln Motel was the scene of the crime, famous for its short stays and constant mentions in police reports.
"Everything went on in there, everything," said John J. O'Reilly, the former Warren County Prosecutor, who worked as a public defender in Newark in the late 1970's. "You had prostitution, allegations of armed robbery, allegations of rape. You had homicides. You name it, they had it." 
 But the Lincoln is on the verge of a startling transformation. As downtown Newark struggles back to life, the Lincoln's owner wants to change the old motel from a seedy haunt where pimps and prostitutes once worked (and now a place where the homeless are sheltered) to a modern inn where baseball fans and business travelers can spend the night.
The motel sits in what was once an isolated stretch of town where drug deals and violent scuffles were as regular as the highway traffic passing on the nearby interstate.
But all of that is sure to change, said Miles P. Berger, who has owned the Lincoln since 1976. With a minor league baseball stadium going up not more than 1,000 feet from the motel's door and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center just around the corner, Mr. Berger believes the time is right to invest in Newark's tourist trade.
"Other than the Robert Treat Hotel and the Hilton Gateway," Mr. Berger said, "there aren't any hotels in central Newark that cater to travelers and tourists. This area is really changing fast, and there's demand like never before for real estate, especially for hotel rooms."
The building that became the Lincoln was erected in 1966 as a Holiday Inn and was pleasant -- and cheap -- enough that many reporters chose it over the older, grander Robert Treat as a base for covering the Newark riots in 1967.
But after the riots, as the city's economy failed, travelers began to stay at the hotels springing up at Newark International Airport, and the Lincoln fell into disrepair. It had closed by the time Mr. Berger bought it for the rock-bottom price of $500,000.
He cleaned up the second-floor ballroom, recarpeted some of the 200 rooms and chose the name Lincoln because local historians told him that Abraham Lincoln had once delivered a speech as President at the train station across the street. Despite the occasional incident -- "Yes, there were arrests," Mr. Berger said -- he insisted that the motel has always been clean, had telephones and televisions in every room and drew a bustling business from local highway traffic, particularly on weekends, for several years.
All of which has not stopped Newark law enforcement officials from remembering a different sort of place.
Mr. O'Reilly said that so many crimes were committed at the Lincoln that the Public Defender's office kept a floor plan of the building tacked to the wall, and lawyers would cross off the rooms with a pen as cases were cleared.
"We actually called it the Wall of Shame," he said. "It was an exhibit you needed preparing for trial. As in, 'So what room did this one happen in? 203? Oh yeah, there it is. Right near the stairs.' "
In the late 1980's, in an arrangement with the city, Mr. Berger converted the Lincoln from a commercial property to a welfare hotel that still serves as a residence of last resort for about 130 of Newark's homeless. Though it earns him about $1,000 a month per person, he said that housing the homeless has sometimes added to disturbances in the halls.
The motel became the focus of an interstate feud in the early 1980's when the Koch administration, faced with an excess of homeless people in New York City, sent hundreds of indigent families to the Lincoln and other New Jersey motels, drawing accusations that they were dumping the poor on New Jersey.
Even today, haggard men and women sit on the curb beneath the stately marquee portrait of Honest Abe, sipping from brown paper bags and mulling over problems at the Lincoln, which they say include the immovable iron bars on the motel's windows and the indifferent security guards.
Most of the current residents have been living at the Lincoln for six months or less and know of its unseemly past only second- or third-hand. But they have stories of their own about rampant drug dealing in the hallways and AIDS victims dying alone in their rooms at night.
"I know a couple of people who have died in there of overdoses, too," said Sam Taylor, 31. "Aside from that, fights is about all you get. I did go down the hallway once and see a trail of blood."
When the motel closes for renovation in the next few months, Mr. Taylor and the other residents will be relocated by the city, but no one is certain yet where they will go. Pamela Goldstein, a city spokeswoman, said they would be sent to one of Newark's other shelters.
One resident, who identified himself only as Earl, said he was certain that he and the others would end up at one of Mr. Berger's other welfare hotels. "He owns the Lincoln, the Carlton and another one called the Lincoln in East Orange, too," Earl said.
Mr. Berger said he and city officials were discussing where to send the residents. But for the moment, he said, he is busy organizing the Lincoln's renaissance.
The plan is to gut the structure, install new furnishings, revive the swimming pool, restore the second-floor ballroom and reopen the motel as a franchise operation, possibly for Holiday Inn, Mr. Berger said. He could be no more specific than to say that it would happen within the next five months and that "the end is near."
In all of this, he is betting that Newark's days of severe poverty and mayhem have subsided -- and by many measures he is right.
The crime rate here has plummeted. Last year, the city posted a 30-year low in the number of reported rapes, burglaries and auto thefts, and in 1997 there were fewer homicides than in any other year since 1967.
There is also the real estate boomlet started by the Performing Arts Center and spurred by the stadium, which the city and Essex County, working together, hope to finish as early as this July. Plans are also under way for a new downtown arena for the New Jersey Nets and a public park along the Passaic River.
All of this has Mr. Berger in an optimistic mood. But some of those who remember the Lincoln's notorious past seem almost attached to its sordidness and feel a bit nostalgic.
"Had the Lincoln Motel never existed, it probably would have reduced the crime rate in the entire city of Newark," said Vincent Nuzzi, a defense lawyer who was first assistant Essex County prosecutor from 1981 to 1986. "But I hope it does become a place where baseball fans can go to watch the Newark Bears. It was so infamous it deserves to make a comeback."

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: June 1, 1999

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1812 words

HEADLINE: No Room to Grow;
With a Squeeze on Industrial Space, Some Companies Look Outside the City

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
There can be a down side to living in a boom time, as Neil A. Mazzella has discovered.
Business is indeed booming for Mr. Mazzella, the president of Hudson Scenic Studio, which builds sets for Broadway shows. There is a constant bustle in the big building in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx where some of his 127 employees are carving, painting, welding, polishing, assembling, sawing, wiring and programming computers. 
 Across the floor stretches a sliver of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge for the Broadway version of "Saturday Night Fever." Off to one side, Cheryl Stewart is carving two griffins for a road show of "Beauty and the Beast." The sparkling ball that drops in Times Square on New Year's Eve lies in pieces on the floor; Mr. Mazzella is constructing the millennial version, which will be made of Waterford crystal.
The place is bursting at the seams -- and therein lies the problem. Despite spending two years -- and thousands of dollars -- Mr. Mazzella has been unable to find space in the Bronx into which he can expand. Imagine it: no room in the Bronx, where a couple of years ago "you couldn't give space away," said Joseph P. Meyerson, the managing director of Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty.
And it is not just the Bronx. Industrial companies around the city, long under siege on many fronts, say real estate problems are squeezing them out of New York City and into Westchester County or New Jersey. Real estate worries "figure more prominently in the minds of manufacturers than taxes," said Adam Friedman, the executive director of the New York Industrial Retention Network, which just released a survey of city manufacturers.
In Queens, the vacancy rates for industrial spaces have been tumbling, and rents have been rising. In Brooklyn, the Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center has been full for more than a year and has stopped keeping a waiting list.
And in Manhattan, home to many of the city's quarter of a million manufacturing jobs, there is so much demand for space for offices, apartments and stores that rents are soaring and buildings are being converted at a rapid clip.
Just ask Bo Parsons, who moved his bakery to Greenwich Street in TriBeCa in 1983.
"We paid $1,000 a month for 5,000 square feet, and they were so happy to have a tenant," he said. Now the bakery, Umanoff & Parsons, finds itself in one of the hottest neighborhoods in Manhattan, and its industrial building is turning into fancy co-op lofts, as have others nearby.
Meanwhile, the company, which has 42 employees, is growing rapidly and needs more space. One deal, to lease a space near the Holland Tunnel, fell apart when the rent went from $6 a square foot to $30 or so, he said. Now he is looking in Brooklyn and Queens.
This space squeeze is not unprecedented; there was a similar situation during the economic boom of the mid-1980's. But there are significant differences this time around, in both the economy and in city policies.
Not only does manufacturing show signs of stabilizing and, in some cases, growing, but new kinds of businesses are proliferating in the city. Jobs in start-up companies jumped to 31,000 in 1998 from 23,000 in 1994, said Frank Lourenso, an executive vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank. "These are high-value jobs in areas like in new media, which will pay higher rents," he said.
And there is simply less industrial space available, because so many buildings have been turned into apartments or offices. While the changes have been most noticeable in lower Manhattan, "there's been widespread loft conversion" in industrial areas of Brooklyn, said David Sweeney, chief executive of the Greenpoint center, which houses furniture makers and craftsmen.
The city used to have a program that taxed loft conversions; the money went to help displaced businesses pay to move to another location within the five boroughs. But the program expired in 1997 and was not renewed.
And no new industrial space has been developed, said Jonathan Bowles, the research director for the Center for an Urban Future, a Manhattan think tank that is about to release a report on the space problems faced by small businesses. Much of the vacant land in New York is owned by the city government, he said.
"One of the biggest tragedies is that the city hasn't gotten behind helping to develop these parcels, and many say it is dragging its feet," Mr. Bowles said. "Once the economy turns south, it will not be possible, so now is the time to do this."
Such criticism irks the Giuliani administration, which credits its policies with helping to stabilize manufacturing employment in the city. "As an administration, we have focused on ways to improve things by lowering taxes, improving city services and safety, lessening regulation and having a robust metropolitan economy," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission. "It has worked. Companies are doing well."
Although some kinds of space are always in short supply in New York, Mr. Rose said, "There is no basis to conclude that the lack of general space" is putting pressure on manufacturing. He disputed the need for areas devoted solely to manufacturing, saying that such businesses do best in mixed areas; different kinds of businesses competing for space, he said, signals a healthy city economy.
Some business people complain that the city is more interested in giving big breaks to major outfits like the stock exchanges than in assisting smaller companies. Charles Millard, who until last week was the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said such criticism is unfair. "We give more in benefits per job to small manufacturers than to large companies," he said, adding that the number of companies that the corporation has assisted with financing has risen sharply in the last four years.
There are fewer manufacturing jobs in the city than there were a decade ago; in 1985, there were about 407,700 such jobs, according to the New York State Department of Labor, while in 1998 there were fewer than 271,000.
But some businesses have found profitable niches and have the capacity to expand rapidly, said Sara Garretson, the executive director of the Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit group that has identified 900 small companies in the city that are growing faster than the national average.
"It's very exciting, but then we lose them when they get a critical mass and can't find space to expand," she said. "Boom, they're across the river" in New Jersey.
That is what is happening to the Bruno Ravioli Company, which has been making pasta in Manhattan for a century. The company now has five stores in the city and is adding a new shop in Gramercy Park that will open in the fall, said James J. Puliatte, who owns the company with Glen Z. Rassam.
But the manufacturing part of the business, which has long been on Ninth Avenue at 45th Street, is moving to a new plant and store in Hackensack, N.J., in July, he said. "It's more affordable -- a bigger space for less money," Mr. Puliatte said, adding that about half of the 10 workers will be moving to New Jersey. Bruno will keep its retail operation on Ninth Avenue, but the manufacturing space will become a store selling housewares.
Some manufacturers say that the city's economic rebound has passed them by. "Times are supposed to be really good, and I guess they are if you have a large amount of money in the stock market," said Marshall Futterman, the president of the Gotham Pen Company, which makes customized pens in special colors. "Times are no good for any manufacturer I know of."
Mr. Futterman, who has been in the pen business for 20 years, has been in the same location on 20th Street in Chelsea for more than a decade. But his landlord wanted to increase his $6,000-a-month rent by $800 a month. Finding a new space has been tough, especially because it needed to be a reasonable commute for his 20 employees, most of whom live in the Bronx.
"For two years, I spent my Sundays driving around under the els looking for places," he said. Now, he is negotiating for a space in the Bathgate section of the Bronx.
But businesses that require really large spaces are having the most trouble. Many of these are not manufacturers, but wholesalers and distributors, like Marjam Supply Company, which was founded in Brooklyn in 1979. Since then, the company, which sells and delivers construction materials, has added eight other locations -- but none of them are in New York City, said James Ortega, who is in charge of the company's location searches.
"We would give our left foot to be in the Bronx," Mr. Ortega said, adding that the company has also been searching in Brooklyn, to no avail.
Mr. Ortega spotted a site off the Cross Bronx Expressway -- but some of the land is owned or leased by state and city agencies, and putting together a deal has been complicated.
And Mr. Ortega's frustrations pale beside those of Michael Nash, the president of Imperial Bag and Paper, which distributes grocery bags, meat trays, deli containers and the like. Though he has 95,000 square feet in Hunts Point, Mr. Nash's buildings are overflowing, he said, and he needs a minimum of 130,000 square feet.
He thought he had finally found it, in an old Alexander's warehouse on Tiffany Street in Hunts Point. It has 400,000 square feet and has been empty for years. With two other companies to split it -- including Hudson Scenic -- he figured the deal would work perfectly.
But the city's Industrial Development Agency would not help the companies buy the place (when companies sell bonds through the city, they pay a lower interest rate). The former owner of the warehouse had a criminal record, and the city did not want to be involved in a transaction that would give him money, according to several people involved in the proposed deal.
So Mr. Nash is moving to Bayonne, N.J., and taking with him his 135 jobs, which pay an average salary of $63,000 a year. He is hoping that the good pay will lead most of his employees to go with him. "I've told my people that if they are willing to move, I would foot the bill," he said.
As for Mr. Mazzella of Hudson Scenic, after the Tiffany Street deal fell through, he decided to move his operation to Yonkers; the deal is set to close next week. By converting an old plastics factory, he will get 73,000 square feet, versus the 49,000 he has today, and he will be able to own his own building, rather than lease.
But after 18 years in the Bronx, he is sad to leave -- and a little frustrated. He is not sure city officials, who he says have done a good job at things like cutting crime, think keeping him in the city really matters.
"I guess when you do a good job at some things, other things get lost in the shuffle," Mr. Mazzella said. "And guys like me got lost."

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Clinton Says Aftermath Will Be Europe's Burden
President Clinton said in a Memorial Day address that Europe would contribute most of the peacekeeping force and would pay most of the cost of rebuilding Yugoslavia. NATO military leaders were expected to finish planning for a peacekeeping force at a meeting in Belgium today. A1
 
NATO continued air strikes across Yugoslavia, despite signs that President Slobodan Milosevic might be prepared to negotiate. NATO jets carried out strikes against Yugoslav units that NATO said were trying to repel an offensive by the Kosovo Liberation Army along Kosovo's southwestern border. A12
 
NATO air attacks killed at least 16 civilians and wounded 43 when four missiles hit a hospital complex in the town Surdulica. The intensifying air campaign is tied to efforts to get President Milosevic to agree to NATO demands. A12
 
Kosovo Update A13
 
Tiananmen Inquiry Sought
More than a hundred relatives of people killed when the Chinese army smashed pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989 have petitioned the Government to open a criminal investigation of the officials responsible. This is the first time that the victims' relatives have tried to use China's nascent legal system for redress. A1
 
China Assails Espionage Report
China issued its broadest attack yet on the Congressional report that says China stole nuclear and missile technologies, calling the document a tissue of half-truths, conjecture and lies. China's Information Minister said detailed information on American nuclear weapons was readily available from public sites on the Internet. A6
 
India Agrees to Peace Talks
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee agreed to hold talks with Pakistan about the "warlike situation" in Kashmir, even as India continued bombing what it called a Pakistani-sponsored band of 700 guerrillas occupying Indian territory. A6
 
Kurdish Leader Apologizes
The rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, on the first day of his trial in Turkey on treason charges, apologized for his past and said he would call for an end to guerrilla violence if Turkish authorities would give him the chance to turn his army into a civilian political party. Mr. Ocalan admitted that he and his fighters were responsible for all the killings and other acts attributed to them. A3
 
New Appointees in Russia
President Boris N. Yeltsin put Viktor Khristenko, left, and Mikhail Zadornov, two familiar and reform-minded fiscal experts, in top economic posts. Both appointments seemed to have been sought by Mr. Yeltsin's latest Prime Minister, Sergei Stepashin, who has been battling rival political forces to place loyalists in senior Government posts. A14
 
World Briefing A10
 
NATIONAL A16-21
 
U.S. Is Investigating A New Medicare Practice
The Government is examining the growing use of part-time rehabilitation clinics in doctors' offices. The doctors rent office space a few days a week to therapists, who are paid by Medicare to treat patients referred by the doctors. Critics say the practice runs the risk of violating fraud, abuse and kickback laws. But one company that runs such clinics, Senior Health Care, said its arrangements were legal because it paid "fair market value" for the space it rented and that doctors were not required to refer patients. A16
 
New Type of Cosmic Objects
New surveys of the sky are surprising astronomers with mystifying discoveries in recent weeks, including an entirely new cosmic category of numerous dim, reddish objects that scientists are calling methane brown dwarfs. The discoveries were announced at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society. A19
 
Fixing Up the Space Station
Astronauts from the shuttle Discovery repaired a radio, replaced flawed battery packs and installed foam mufflers over noisy fans on the international space station. A16
 
Government Net Sites Attacked
Computer hackers vandalized two Government sites on the Internet and left a note threatening to attack more because of an F.B.I. investigation. Last week, hackers disrupted the F.B.I. and Senate sites. The attacks were apparently in retaliation for what the hackers say is F.B.I. harassment of hacker groups. A20
 
Egyptian Collection Reopens
The Egyptian gallery of the Oriental Institute in Chicago, featuring a colossal statue of Tutankhamen, opened last weekend for the first time since 1996. The institute's galleries were closed to the public for a $10.1 million renovation primarily to safeguard artifacts from climate damage. The other galleries are to reopen during the next three years. A20
 
Instilling Values in School
The nation's public schools, which taught the Bible for generations until the 1960's, are under growing pressure to offer ethics instruction as a way to promote safe learning free of harassment. Educators say the recent school shootings and last week's Supreme Court ruling on sexual harassment by students have given the issue new urgency. School administrators are worried about legal protections, but advocates of public moral education say that though the Supreme Court banned prayer in schools it has never insisted that schools be neutral on values. A17
 
Memorial for a Lynching
About 60 people gathered in a white church in Georgia for a Memorial Day service recalling the killings of a black World War II veteran and three relatives in 1946. A Federal grand jury investigation at the time produced no indictments. The case was reopened in 1991, when a witness came forward, but there have been no arrests. A18

A Key to Good Health
Research is showing that social class -- as measured by income, education and other markers of relative status -- is a powerful predictor of health, more powerful than genetics, exposure to carcinogens, even smoking. In other words, the higher the rung on the socioeconomic ladder, the lower the risk to health. F1

President Boris N. Yeltsin placed two familiar and reform-minded fiscal experts in top economic posts, but after a week of brutal infighting among his closest advisers the question of who really controls his latest Government seemed no clearer than before.

HEADLINE: Is Spy Scandal Fueled by Racism or Justified Concern?;
A Setback for China

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "America's Stolen Secrets" (editorial, May 26): 
 Revelations about alleged Chinese espionage efforts should come as no surprise. More than 2,000 years ago, Sun Tzu, a Chinese military philosopher, extolled the value of spying on potential adversaries. With superior information, he argued, a ruler could prevail without war.
However, China's pervasive use of espionage has probably weakened its future security and economic development.
On many occasions since World War II the United States has discovered the incompatibility of spying and diplomacy. The downing of a U-2 spy plane over Russia in 1960 is but one example.
Now China may discover that the law of unintended consequences will severely damage its future diplomatic and economic relations with the United States.
 
HARRY HOWE RANSOM
Nashville, May 27, 1999
 
The writer is professor emeritus at Vanderbilt University.
 
 
http://www.nytimes.com

TYPE: Letter

STATE: TENNESSEE, USA (79%);
