HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE WHITE HOUSE;
CLINTON DECLARES MOST WAR CLEANUP IS EUROPE'S TASK

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
On the eve of a key NATO decision on how to assemble a large peacekeeping force for Yugoslavia, President Clinton said today that Europeans would contribute most of the force and most of the money needed to rebuild the country.
In a Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery, Mr. Clinton said the decision to intervene in Kosovo was aimed at saving lives -- including American ones in the future. 
 At a meeting in Belgium on Tuesday, NATO military leaders are expected to complete the planning for the Yugoslav peacekeeping force. The President stressed that a large majority of the troops in the force will come from other NATO nations and perhaps countries outside NATO like Russia and Ukraine. The force is expected to number about 50,000, including roughly 7,000 Americans.
"I know that many Americans believe that this is not our fight," Mr. Clinton told an audience of active-duty and retired military personnel amid the serried rows of bone-white crosses this morning. "But remember why many of the people are laying in these graves out here -- because of what happened in Europe and because of what was allowed to go on too long before people intervened. What we are doing today will save lives, including American lives, in the future."
NATO continued its relentless bombing across Yugoslavia today. Raids near Albania in effect helped the rebels who are fighting the Serbs. Other missiles apparently struck a hospital complex and an apartment building, causing dozens of deaths.
In his 20-minute speech President Clinton made no mention of diplomatic efforts to resolve the Balkan conflict, which have followed a meandering course over the past month through Moscow, Helsinki, Berlin and Belgrade, the seat of power of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President.
But White House aides said Mr. Clinton spoke for 30 minutes this morning with Sergei V. Stepashin, the new Russian Prime Minister. Officials said the two discussed progress on the diplomatic front and agreed to a meeting on Tuesday in Bonn involving the three principal negotiators: Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott; President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland, and Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the former Russian Prime Minister who serves as special Balkans envoy. The three are expected to brief Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany after their meeting, officials said.
It is likely that Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Ahtisaari will travel to Belgrade later in the week to speak with Mr. Milosevic, an Administration official said.
A White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that Mr. Stepashin had initiated the call to Mr. Clinton and that the President today was "cautiously optimistic" about the talks in Europe this week. He said that some leaders detected "a little movement" by Mr. Milosevic toward accepting the NATO conditions for ending the bombing. The official also suggested that the pressure on Mr. Milosevic might have grown after he was indicted on war-crimes charges last week.
Mr. Clinton used the Memorial Day address to repeat NATO's core demands for ending the aerial bombardment of Serbia, the dominant republic in what remains of Yugoslavia. The President said Serbia must withdraw its forces from the province of Kosovo, where their campaign of "ethnic cleansing" has displaced more than 1.5 million people of Albanian descent. He said the Kosovo refugees must be able to return home in peace. And he said the Yugoslav Government must accept a peacekeeping force in Kosovo "with NATO at its core."
Mr. Milosevic has reportedly accepted broad conditions agreed to at an early May meeting of the so-called Group of Eight nations, which include Russia and Japan, neither of them involved in the Balkan conflict. But he has not yet acceded to the harsher specifics laid down by NATO, including withdrawal of virtually all forces from Kosovo, autonomy for Kosovo and acceptance of a NATO-led peacekeeping force.
The President also replied to domestic critics on both left and right who have complained of excessive American involvement in a regional conflict, now in its 10th week, that does not threaten vital security or economic interests. He also sought to respond to the public, whose support for NATO bombing has begun to ebb.
"In this military campaign," Mr. Clinton said, "the United States has borne a large share of the burden, as we must, because we have a greater capacity to bear that burden.
"But all Americans should know that we have been strongly supported by our European allies; that when the peacekeeping force goes in there, the overwhelming majority of people will be European, and that when the reconstruction begins, the overwhelming amount of investment will be European. This is something we have done together."
About three-quarters of the aircraft on missions over Yugoslavia are American, and much of the weaponry is also American, like the cruise missiles launched from warships and B-52 bombers. Mr. Clinton has asked Congress for $6 billion in emergency money for the Pentagon, most of it to cover the Balkan air war. Congress approved nearly twice that much, using the emergency bill to authorize a militarywide pay increase and other Pentagon spending unrelated to the conflict.
The NATO meeting in Mons, Belgium, will address the composition of the Kosovo force. Military commanders from NATO's 19 countries will decide which nations will contribute which sorts of troops, not only combat forces but engineers, mine-clearing teams, transportation units, interpreters, intelligence officers and medical personnel.
Mr. Milosevic has demanded that any peacekeeping forces be unarmed or lightly armed, and that NATO not dominate the force. But the United States and its allies insist that all units be capable of defending themselves and that NATO will provide the command structure and the bulk of the personnel.
Mr. Clinton said today that the stakes were high in Yugoslavia for Europe and the world. He insisted that the West cannot allow the assault on people's lives there to take place unchallenged.
"We can say 'no' to that," Mr. Clinton declared before the veterans at Arlington today, "and we should."
And he said: "Today there is a new challenge before us in Kosovo. It is a very small province in a small country, but it is a big test of what we believe in."
Mr. Clinton said the American involvement demonstrated "our commitment to leave to our children a world where people are not uprooted and ravaged and slaughtered en masse because of their race, their ethnicity or their religion; our fundamental interest in building a lasting peace in an undivided and free Europe, a place which saw two world wars when that dream failed in the 20th century, and our interest in preserving our alliance for freedom and peace with our 18 NATO allies."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS;
GROWTH SLOWS IN CANADA

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Canada's economic growth slowed slightly in the first quarter, rising 3.4 percent after 4.6 percent annualized growth in the fourth quarter of 1998, according to preliminary data released yesterday by Statistics Canada. Marcel Kasumovich, an economist at Goldman Sachs Canada, said the first-quarter growth was marginally below expectations but could still be revised upward. Official preliminary results for first-quarter growth are due on June 10, a delay to accommodate revisions to the national accounts data. The Bank of Canada, in its semiannual Monetary Policy Report released two weeks ago, predicted first-quarter growth of about 4 percent. "The stimulus of a booming U.S. economy, signs that the worst of Asia's economic crisis may be over, improved consumer confidence and the absence of major work stoppages all played to the Canadian economy's advantage in the first quarter," Statistics Canada said in its daily release.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
GREENE, JEROME L.

 BODY:
GREENE-Jerome L. The President, the Board of Trustees and entire Montefiore Medical Center community deeply mourn the death of our dear friend and supporter, Jerome L. Greene. A devoted and active trustee since 1972, he had an extraordinary impact on the quality of health and life of thousands of Montefiore patients and residents of the Bronx and Westchester. Combining his skills as a lawyer with his belief in Montefiore as an instrument of social responsibility, he led the medical center in the founding, 18 years ago, of the Mosholu Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit community development support corporation that has, with his guidance, saved housing, revitalized neighborhoods and created innovative projects such as moderate income housing, a community newspaper that serves 15,000 households, the first and only NYC business improvement district sponsored under the auspices of an academic institution, a vast program of graffiti removal and a youth job training program-all of which have played a role in the Bronx's nationally recognized resurgence. He believed in the crucial role of academic medical centers such as Montefiore in advancing the health of communities through research, education and provision of high-quality care, and with his beloved wife, Dawn, he helped Montefiore create the Jerome L. and Dawn Greene Medical Arts Pavilion, a state-of-the-art building that opened in 1997 offering a full range of general and specialty services in an ambulatory care setting. More recently, he and his wife have been generous benefactors of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore, scheduled to open in 2001. In 1991, at its annual Celebrate Montefiore dinner dance, the medical center honored this remarkable man of vision and commitment for his exemplary stewardship. This year, Montefiore nominated him for the United Hospital Fund's 1999 Distinguished Community Service Award. The medical center has lost one of its greatest friends. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving wife, Dawn, and their entire family. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center
GREENE-Jerome L. The Board, staff and the entire Lincoln Center family deeply mourn the death of our cherished friend and supporter, Jerome Greene. Jerry was a longtime member of Lincoln Center's Board of Directors and Emeriti Council, and provided guidance and vision for all our activities for many years. He cared about Linconln Center and its programs deeply, especially the Mostly Mozart Festival. His leadership and extraordinary generosity have ensured Mostly Mozart continuity for more than a decade and through his generosity he has left a legacy for hundreds of thousands of music lovers who have enjoyed and continue to enjoy this music series. We will miss his wisdom, warmth, integrity and his loyal friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to Dawn and their entire family. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President
GREENE-Jerome L. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater convey their sorrow and condolences to Dawn and the children upon the sad death of Jerome. Jerry was an advocate of our theater and favored it with his benefactions. An inveterate theatergoer, he praised the work he admired and was forgiving of the plays he didn't care for. He was generous to the arts and education in New York and his genial presence will be missed at Lincoln Center. Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman John S. Chalsty, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Exec Producer

Greene was one of those rare individuals. The Carlyle has long been a part of his life, and he has been so very important to this New York institution. We cherish most and value greatest that we were privileged to know, love and be influenced by him, for he was a very special man. Dan Camp and the Staff of The Carlyle

HEADLINE: For Good Health, It Helps To Be Rich and Important

BYLINE: By ERICA GOODE 

 BODY:
Doctors usually evaluate patients' vulnerability to serious disease by inquiring about risk factors like cigarette smoking, obesity, hypertension and high cholesterol.
But they might be better off asking how much money those patients make, how many years they spent in school and where they stand relative to others in their offices and communities. 
 Scientists have known for decades that poverty translates into higher rates of illness and mortality. But an explosion of research is demonstrating that social class -- as measured not just by income but also by education and other markers of relative status -- is one of the most powerful predictors of health, more powerful than genetics, exposure to carcinogens, even smoking.
What matters is not simply whether a person is rich or poor, college educated or not. Rather, risk for a wide variety of illnesses, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, arthritis, infant mortality, many infectious diseases and some types of cancer, varies with relative wealth or poverty: the higher the rung on the socioeconomic ladder, the lower the risk. And this relationship holds even at the upper reaches of society, where it might seem that an abundance of resources would even things out.
Social class is an uncomfortable subject for many Americans. "I think there has been a resistance to thinking about social stratification in our society," said Dr. Nancy Adler, professor of medical psychology at the University of California at San Francisco and director of the John T. and Catherine D. MacArthur Foundation Research Network on Socioeconomic Status and Health. Instead, researchers traditionally have focused on health differences between rich and poor, or blacks and whites (unaware, in many cases, that race often served as a proxy for socioeconomic status, since blacks are disproportionately represented in lower income brackets).
But the notion that a mid-level executive with a three-bedroom, split-level in Scarsdale might somehow be more vulnerable to illness than his boss in the five-bedroom colonial a few blocks away seems to have finally captured scientists' attention.
In the past five years, 193 papers addressing aspects of socioeconomic status and health have appeared in scientific journals -- twice the number in the previous five-year period. The National Institutes of Health last year declared research on disparities in health related to social class or minority status one of its highest priorities, said Dr. Norman Anderson, associate director of the N.I.H. And a recent conference in Bethesda, Md., on the topic, sponsored by the New York Academy of Sciences and the MacArthur Foundation network, drew more than 250 participants from a wide variety of disciplines.
What first compelled researchers interest was a now-classic study, begun in the late 1960's, of men in the British civil service. The Whitehall study, directed by Dr. Michael Marmot, director of the International Center for Health and Society at University College London, tracked mortality rates over 10 years for 17,530 male civil service employees.
When the data were analyzed, the researchers were astonished to discover that mortality rates varied continuously and precisely with the men's civil service grade: the higher the classification, the lower the rates of death, regardless of cause.
This finding was as perplexing as it was intriguing. The men all had jobs, and equal access to health care under Britain's national health system. But mortality rates for men in the lowest civil service classification, the researchers found, were three times higher than those for men in the highest grade. And a 25-year follow-up of the Whitehall subjects, some results of which were published in 1996, found the social class gradient persisted well past retirement, even among men into their late 80's.
Subsequent studies demonstrated a similar relationship between socioeconomic status and mortality in the United States and Canada.
What could account for such startling findings? One plausible explanation was that lower-ranked men might engage in more risky behaviors, like smoking. But the same health disparity from pay grade to pay grade that was evident in smokers held for nonsmokers, too. And all coronary risk factors combined, the researchers found, accounted for only a third of the differences between grades.
Stress, or other aspects of psychological life that can have an impact on a person's vulnerability to disease, the Whitehall group reasoned, might also play a role in the results. Prolonged exposure to stress, researchers have found, can lead to abnormalities in immune function and glucose metabolism, and destroy brain cells involved in memory. And studies show that the lower one's social status, the more stressed people feel, and the more stressful events they encounter in their lives.
Dr. Sheldon Cohen, professor of psychology at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, has demonstrated a link between social status and vulnerability to infectious disease in male macaque monkeys. In a study carried out in conjunction with primate researchers at Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Dr. Cohen found that males at the lower end of the dominance hierarchy were more susceptible to a cold virus than dominant males.
Dr. Cohen and his colleagues at Carnegie Mellon then replicated those findings in humans. Subjects in the study were asked to rate their relative standing in their community on a social status ladder, then were exposed to mild respiratory virus. People who ranked themselves low on the ladder were more likely to become infected with the virus than those who ranked themselves higher up on the ladder.
In another study, the researchers found that people who had been unemployed for one month or more under highly stressful conditions were 3.8 times more susceptible to a virus than people who were not experiencing a significant stressful situation.
At least in primates, the interaction of stress with social class and illness, however, depends both on the nature of the stress and the context in which it occurs, as demonstrated in a series of studies by Dr. Jay R. Kaplan, a professor of pathology and anthropology at Wake Forest.
In a crowded situation where resources are scarce, for example, male monkeys at the lowest end of the dominance hierarchy, who must scramble hardest to survive, are likely to feel the most stress. And in studies of primates in the wild, researchers find that subordinate animals show higher levels of stress hormones.
But when Dr. Kaplan and his colleagues fed male monkeys a "luxury" diet, high in fat and cholesterol, and moved them each month for two years into a new group of strange males, it was the dominant animals, forced to reassert their position continually, who suffered the most stress. Under such conditions, Dr. Kaplan finds, dominant males show a hypervigilant response, and have higher rates of coronary artery disease than subordinates.
For humans and primates, a sense of control over life events is intimately related to stress. And control seems to have been one factor at work in the Whitehall study.
In 1985, Dr. Marmot and his colleagues launched Whitehall II, a second large-scale study, which included civil servants of both sexes and which collected more detailed information on the participants.
As part of the study, employees were asked to rate the amount of control they felt over their jobs. Managers also rated the amount of control employees had. Job control, the researchers found, varied inversely with employment grade: the higher the grade, the more control. And the less control employees had, as defined either by their own or managers' ratings, the higher the employees' risk of developing coronary disease. Job control, in fact, accounted for about half the gradient in deaths from pay grade to pay grade.
To some extent, people's ability to withstand stress, and the ways in which they interpret and respond to life events, are shaped by early life, the product of what one social scientist, Dr. Clyde Hertzman of the University of British Columbia, calls "the long arm of childhood." Genetics play a role, as does nutrition. (In the Whitehall study, height -- which varies with social class -- was used as a rough indicator of childhood influences on development, and accounted for a small portion of the association between mortality and employment grade.) And scientists have found that early life experiences -- abuse and neglect, for example -- can alter brain development and influence responses to stressful events.
Any discussion of socioeconomic status in the United States of necessity involves a discussion of race, since the two are entwined in complex, sometimes inextricable, ways. Proportionally, far more African-Americans live in poverty than whites: 28.4 percent of blacks fell below the poverty line in 1996, compared with 11.2 percent of whites, according to Government data. Death rates for African-Americans from all causes are 1.6 times higher than for white Americans, Dr. David R. Williams of the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research, said at the Bethesda conference.
Life expectancy for blacks and whites also varies. At age 45, a white man can expect to live five years longer than an African-American man, and white women can expect to live 3.7 years longer than their black counterparts.
If socioeconomic status is taken into account, health differences between blacks and whites decrease substantially: Black men in the highest income brackets, for example, have a life expectancy 7.4 years longer than black men in the lowest brackets, Dr. Williams said. White men at top income levels live 6.6 years longer than their lowest-income counterparts.
But race and to some extent sex still have an impact on health that is independent of social class. The gap in infant mortality rates between blacks and whites, for example, actually increases with higher social status. And being black or female discounts some of the advantages afforded by education: white men accrue health advantages with every additional year of schooling they receive. But black men and women, though they also show gains, show them only through high school, according to an analysis of Federal data by Dr. Adler and Dr. Burton Singer of Princeton University's Office of Population Research. White women, the researchers found, continue to gain in health status through college, but unlike white men, do not receive the gains in health bestowed by post-graduate education.
Social exclusion, residential segregation and other expressions of institutional racism magnify the impact of socioeconomic status. Several studies, for example, have shown higher adult and infant mortality rates for people living in segregated areas.
For both blacks and whites, living in a neighborhood where social bonds have eroded may have negative effects on health. Dr. Robert Putnam of Harvard University coined the term "social capital" to describe the elements that contribute to social cohesion.
Dr. Ichiro Kawachi, director of the Harvard Center for Society and Health, has explored one aspect of social capital -- interpersonal trust -- and its relationship to national and community rates of illness and death.
Dr. Kawachi and his colleagues correlated mortality rates in states with the percentage of state residents who agreed with the statement, "Most people would try to take advantage of you if they got the chance." Death rates, Dr. Kawachi reported at the Bethesda conference, were strongly linked to level of social trust, with the most mistrustful ratings clustering in southern and northeastern states. Another study, of Chicago neighborhoods, yielded similar findings: neighborhoods in which more residents agreed with the statement "Neighbors can be trusted" had lower mortality rates.
Why are neighborhoods or states with higher levels of trust healthier? Dr. Kawachi suggests that in neighborhoods where social trust is high, negative health behaviors -- smoking and alcohol consumption, for example -- might be discouraged through community pressure. Residents in high trust neighborhoods may also share more resources, be more willing to help one another out and offer one another more emotional support. "It is speculation," Dr. Kawachi said, "but probably these little things add up to quite important health differences."
Even so, the relationship between social class and health is unlikely to be entirely explained by social capital, or by any other single dimension of life experience. Said Dr. Adler, "There isn't going to be a single explanation or an easy solution, but we've started mapping out some of the places where we can intervene."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 4, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about social class as a predictor of health misstated the correlation between employees' perception of job control and employment grade. It was a direct correlation, not an inverse one: the higher the grade, the more perception of control, and therefore the better predictor of good health.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Old Bliss, in a New Arrondissement

BYLINE: By RICHARD EDER 

 BODY:

PARIS TRANCE
By Geoff Dyer
274 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.
Centuries ago it was politic for authors to begin with a note to their public or patron disclaiming the virtues of their story. Our post-modern equivalent is to disclaim its reality. Thus the title of Geoff Dyer's novel: "Paris Trance" instead of "France." 
 Mr. Dyer, a wickedly accomplished young Englishman, came out last year with a book about self-consciousness and the impossibility of writing, or even, if you look closely, of living. Naturally, the book, "Out of Sheer Rage" was both well-written and lively. It also did protest too much. Mr. Dyer wrote like a solipsist dragged to a party he knows he is going to be the life of once he stops kicking and screaming.
Among those books that his book found impossible to write was a novel about young expatriates in Paris. Now he has written it, announcing at the start that his finely recognizable Paris is not the real one. He also tells us that his protagonist, a young Werther with a short shelf life, has found it impossible to write a novel about young Parisian expatriates. "Trance" recounts the year or so that two pairs of lovers, Luke and Nicole and Alex and Sahra, spend in blissful camaraderie of the we-were-young-together-in-Paris genre. Mr. Dyer brings it up to date.
For one thing, there is the economics. His novel is an early specimen of what you might call European Community fiction. Luke, the vaguely intending writer, and Alex are British and need no papers to get laboring jobs in a book warehouse. Nicole, a Yugoslav immigrant, and Sahra, an American, are employed more formally: the first as a secretary, the second as an interpreter.
For another (the novel as rolling gentrification), young expatriate bliss has relocated from successively romantic and subsequently unaffordable literary neighborhoods to the 11th arrondissement, out east. Finally, in the blithe mix of cafe-hopping, free-form talk, moviegoing, wine, drugs and sex, the sex and drugs are more insistently detailed than they used to be.
"Paris Trance" is up-to-date social comedy with an implicit minatory shadow. The comedy, for the most part, is brilliantly handled. The doomy implicitness -- as if Don Giovanni's Commendatore had sent an E-mail message instead of arriving by statue -- is hesitant and self-conscious. Mr. Dyer, depicting a culture that is divorced from consequences and suffers the consequences of the divorce, voices his theme too abstractly. He locates but does not quite deliver the "lost" of his contemporary lost generation.
For a while, though, everything is exuberantly found. The author evolves a wonderfully aimless routine of late-century lotus-eating for his characters, none of whom have any particular reason for being in Paris stronger than the need to be away from some particular other place. The aimlessness makes the pace rather desultory; for a while, interest lies mainly in the author's clever writing and generational and social detail. "Together they gave off a double helping of solitude," he observes of two young men who, knowing nobody else at a party, talk to each other.
The encounters of Luke with Nicole and Alex with Sahra provide the book's most infectious energy. Mr. Dyer writes spendid courtship riffs of two different kinds. Luke meets Nicole casually as she strolls past a lunchtime soccer game he is playing. On their first date they cross and re-cross the nighttime Seine, spinning a comically disjointed series of conversational fantasies while quietly checking each other out. Whimsy provides cover as the erotic charge builds and (never mind how, but a stray dog is responsible) discharges.
Unlike Luke and Nicole, who fall into bed that same evening and are instantly inseparable, Alex and Sahra conduct a canny series of advances and retreats. Alex has the original notion of bringing his friends along the first time they go out. In the bouncy and zigzag evening that ensues, the future couple are able to observe and maneuver free of the metered confidences and probings of a one-on-one date. The detours are severe as well as comic; when the two finally come together after no little suspense, there is a sense less of spectacular passion than quieter necessity.
For a year or so the foursome makes playful use of France and the quite bearable lightness of late-century, pre-Kosovo Europe. Also of their own youth, erotic and intellectual fizz, and the lightening of a single couple's emotional burdens when there are two couples to shift them. Mr. Dyer is a genial revels-master of meals, games (they vie to recite by heart every film, cinema and showtime listed in Pariscope), trips to the country and great swirling loops of talk. He is also a virtuoso with graphic sex and its shortfalls. Not that there is not authentic feeling, but that the feeling is somehow unlived and unearned.
"Paris Trance" is a fictional neutron bomb: places, things, pastimes, even emotions remain standing; it is the people who are gone. The point of Mr. Dyer's book and the problem with it are the same: both lodge in that "Trance." For his post-modern European young, and perhaps for a wider Western culture, ugly reality has been tamed and dissipated to the point where it has lost governance of the perceptions. The playground world is not a world.
In his attempt to suggest this, the adept Mr. Dyer loses hold in a number of ways. For one thing, he separates Luke, as advocate of pure sensation, from the other three, who recede into various kinds of reality. The author is trying to assert this reality, but it seems uncongenial; as a result we get little sense of it other than being told about it.
The telling device is faulty. One of the four is narrator as well as character, and the author makes an irritating mystery of who it is, though we easily guess. More seriously there is an unsustainable grandiloquence as this narrator awkwardly drops cautionary notes into his account of the revels, alternates them with bursts of glorifying Luke, and finally recounts the ruin he has come to. Beautiful and damned, in other words: the culture as well as the individual.
Only -- and it is a very big "only" -- we haven't seen Luke as especially more beautiful than the others; and when the damning comes it is trivial. This miniaturized Werther, his romantic illusion shattered, accomplishes his fate with no more than the equivalent of a popgun. An intended generational message, but intentions aren't fiction and in "Paris Trance" they go awkwardly with the accomplished social comedy that is.

HEADLINE: Raphael Recanati, Philanthropist, Dies at 75

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Raphael Recanati, an Israeli-American shipping and banking figure better known in New York for his philanthropic largesse -- particularly as a mainstay of Beth Israel Medical Center -- died last Friday in the medical center. He was 75 and lived on the Upperast Side and in Herzliyah, Israel.
The cause was congestive heart failure, Beth Israel said. 
 Mr. Recanati was a pillar of Israel's private economy, with interests in the high-tech, shipping, commerce and banking fields. He was a key figure in attracting foreign investment to its high-tech industries.
He fostered the growth of Israel from its very beginning by using his knowledge of shipping to supply it with munitions, food or whatever else foreign shippers would not deliver at the time. At his death he was chairman of the IDB Group, an offspring of the Israel Discount Bank, which his family founded in 1935.
In this country, his main business engine was the Overseas Shipholding Group of New York, owner-operators of a fleet of oceangoing bulk vessels. He was its founding chairman and, at his death, chairman of its finance and development committee.
He contributed to educational, cultural and especially medical institutions both in Israel and the United States. In New York, the main recipient of his largesse was Beth Israel, whose educational and research missions he bolstered in many ways.
The medical center saw his hand in the advances it could make in such fields of specialized medicine as cardiology, liver research, neurology, pulmonary medicine, dermatology, orthopedic surgery, pediatrics and infectious diseases. He supported its Heart Institute, the Recanati Cardiology Research Fund and the Recanati/Horowitz Cardiology Diagnostic Reseach Fund.
He helped other institutions as well. Mount Sinai School of Medicine has a Recanati/Miller Transplantation Institute. Harvard University Medical School gained an endowed chair with a Recanati Professorship in Immunology.
He was honored as a Guardian of Yeshiva University, which now has Recanati Israel Student Exchange Fellowships and a Recanati course in Cabala at Yeshiva and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Seminary. Those counting on his regular support also included the UJA-Federation Annual Campaigns, the Beilinson Medical Center in Israel, and the Recanati School of Business at Tel Aviv University. He was a trustee of the Weizman Institute of Science, Tel Aviv University, and the American support groups of Tel Aviv and Ben Gurion Universities.
Raphael Recanati's family was from Salonika, Greece, where he was born. They went to Palestine in 1935. After finishing high school, Raphael Recanati joined the Palmach, a Jewish unit fighting for the creation of Israel.
He learned about shipping on a secret mission to Egypt's Jewish community, and when Israel declared its independence in 1948 he founded the Israel-America Shipping Line. The company was active also in New York and evolved into the present Overseas Shipholding Group.
Mr. Recanati also formed an American branch of the family bank, Israel Discount Bank of New York, which he built into the most profitable Israeli overseas bank. He was a co-founder in 1970 of the investment arm of IDB Group and, through subsidiaries, established Discount Investment Corporation and PEC Israel Economic Corporation New York.
His business savvy spawned hundreds of enterprises in Israel. It also produced a scandal over allegations of securities fraud and manipulation of bank stock prices. A Jerusalem court sentenced Mr. Recanati to eight months in prison in the mid-1980's, but the case was thrown out on appeal.
Mr. Recanati is survived by his wife of 53 years, Dina Hettena Recanati; two sons, Oudi, of Israel, the chairman of IDB Holdings, and Michael, of Manhattan; and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dow Jones inLink With Germans as Rivalry Grows in Europe

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 1

 BODY:
Hoping to fend off The Financial Times of London in Continental Europe, Dow Jones & Company announced an alliance today with Germany's biggest daily business newspaper.
Under the deal, Dow Jones agreed to exchange a stake in The Wall Street Journal Europe for a stake in Handelsblatt, owned by Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck of Germany. 
 The two newspapers plan to use each other's reporting, with each allowing the other to translate and publish its material on the same day.
The new alliance is the latest turn in a heated rivalry to dominate Europe's business press.
The Financial Times, owned by Pearson P.L.C., has teamed up with the German magazine publisher Gruner & Jahr to introduce a new German-language version of its salmon-colored daily.
Employing about 100 reporters and editors in Germany, the newspaper is expected to start later this year and compete directly with Handelsblatt.
Dieter von Holtzbrinck, chairman of Holtzbrinck in Dusseldorf, said his partnership with The Journal was not a defensive reaction to The Financial Times.
"It looks like a reaction, but it is really a coincidence," he said at a news conference here today.
Karen Elliott House, president of Dow Jones International, said the alliance would strengthen both papers.
"The point here is not to homogenize these two publications," she said. "We want to use our relative strengths to enhance each other."
Established in 1983, The Wall Street Journal Europe says its circulation is about 70,000, with about 57,000 outside Britain. The Financial Times claims a circulation of about 367,000, about 113,000 in Continental Europe.
In Europe's increasingly integrated economy, the competition to dominate its business media has become increasingly important and heated.
The newest stage of the rivalry poses an intriguing test for two opposing language strategies in Europe's polyglot market.
Partly because English is the most common denominator for many Europeans, both The Financial Times and The Wall Street Journal Europe come closer than any other daily newspapers to being Europe-wide publications.
But the German-speaking region of Europe is substantial -- more than 80 million people in Germany plus those in Austria and much of Switzerland.
Dow Jones refuses to provide financial details about The Wall Street Journal Europe, though the company says it has been profitable for several years.
Holtzbrinck, owned by the Holtzbrinck family, is one of Germany's biggest publishing and media groups. Besides Handelsblatt, it owns book publishers including Henry Holt, Farrar Straus & Giroux in the United States, and scientific and technical journals and the influential German weekly Die Zeit.
Under the agreement, Holtzbrinck will acquire 49 percent of The Wall Street Journal Europe, while Dow Jones will acquire 22 percent of Handelsblatt. In addition, Holtzbrinck is acquiring part of Dow Jones's minority stakes in a Czech publishing venture and the German financial news agency VWD.

HEADLINE: Production Rose in May, Survey Says

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
The rebound in United States manufacturing accelerated in May and more factories reported paying higher prices for materials, a National Association of Purchasing Management survey showed today.
Separately, the Conference Board reported today that its index of leading economic indicators fell one-tenth of 1 percent in April, its first monthly decline in almost a year. And the Commerce Department said that the country's construction spending unexpectedly fell 2.4 percent in April, the first decline in six months. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index rose to 55.2 last month, its highest level since October 1997, from 52.8 in April. Index readings above 50 mean that most manufacturers surveyed reported improved business.
"The manufacturing sector is enjoying a resurgence after a very difficult period driven by the financial crisis in Asia," said Norbert Ore, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at the Chesapeake Corporation, a paper and packaging concern in Richmond.
The association's index of prices paid rose to 52.2 in May from 49.9 in April, indicating that more companies reported price increases during the month. The price index, which is also at its highest level since October 1997, probably reflected an increase in world petroleum prices earlier this year.
The numbers suggest that the economy may be growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. "It looks like the manufacturing sector is up and running, and the Fed cannot be overjoyed with that," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisers Inc. in Holland, Pa.
The production index, a gauge of current output, rose to 59.2 in May from 57.6 in April. The new orders index, a measure of current demand, rose to 58.9 in May from 54.8 in April.
"Manufacturing was so badly beaten up last year that it will be a very long time before there is any danger of overheating," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets Inc. in New York. "The problem is, from the market's perspective, that weak manufacturing will no longer offset strength elsewhere in the economy. Consumer spending has got to slow to keep the Fed at bay."
Analysts were mostly dismissive of the two other economic reports released today. Fewer building permits and a drop in consumer expectations led the decline in the leading economic indicators. While they fell in percentage terms, the levels for both remain very high, said James Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Securities in New York. "Consumer confidence is the last thing we're worried about right now," Mr. Glassman said.
Construction spending fell 2.4 percent in April to a $697.4 billion annual rate, as work on everything from homes to hotels to highways declined. The decline was the first since October and the largest since a 1.1 percent drop in June 1997. It also followed a 1.3 percent gain in March.
"After a run of four successive strong reports, construction spending was due for a correction, and this is it," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Data SuggestingInflation Risk Help to Push Treasuries Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices slumped yesterday, pushing yields to their highest in more than a year, after a report pointing to manufacturing strength stoked concerns the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates.
The report "really upset people," by suggesting growth and faster inflation, said Graham Allen, who oversees $50 billion of fixed-income investments at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles. With the jobs report looming on Friday and figures on May consumer prices expected later in the month, "the market's got some fairly rocky times ahead," he said. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 1 7/32, to 90 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.94 percent, from 5.82 percent on Friday. Earlier, yields briefly touched 5.95 percent, the highest since May 15, 1998.
Yields on two-year notes, among securities most responsive to changes in Fed policy, rose to 5.54 percent from 5.40 percent, the highest in almost a year.
Bond prices tumbled after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of manufacturing activity rose to 55.2 in May -- the highest level since October 1997. The group's index of prices paid also rose in the month, indicating more companies reported price increases during the month.
The report was "a negative for the market," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets.
Traders sold bonds after the report because it provided more signs of strength in the economy, which has expanded for eight straight years. With the Fed having signaled last month that it was prepared to raise rates to keep inflation from picking up, investors say any indications of strength would help build the case for a rate increase.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Gold Price Plunges, a Company Thrives

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 1

 BODY:
The price of gold has fallen to levels unseen in more than 20 years. But that does not seem to faze Peter Munk, chairman of the Barrick Gold Corporation, one of the world's biggest and most profitable mining companies.
"I'm not a gold bug," Mr. Munk said. "I didn't form Barrick because I love gold. To me it was a fabulous business opportunity." Even in the current market, he said, the company produces gold for less than half the price it gets, and "to me, that's like paradise." 
 Mr. Munk's appraisal of the gold business has not shifted, even though the price has fallen to roughly $268 an ounce late today from more than $400 three years ago. The most recent reason for the decline is the announcement by Britain last month that it would sell half its gold reserves, aggravating oversupply fears.
Certainly, higher prices would make Barrick even more profitable. But it is now "the most profitable gold company in the world," Mr. Munk said. So his concerns are not those of the world's gold traders and speculators.
Mr. Munk, 71, has been involved in other businesses -- stereo manufacturing, hotels in the South Seas, oil and gas -- with mixed results. But he has done exceptionally well with Barrick, which he helped establish in 1983. Today it mines gold in Ontario and Quebec provinces as well as in Nevada, Peru and Chile.
Last year, the company earned a record $301 million on revenue of $1.3 billion, even though the average spot price for an ounce of gold was $294 in 1998, down from $332 in 1997.
Barrick fared well for three reasons. It mined 5 percent more gold, lowered its operating costs by 12 percent, to $160 an ounce, and sold its output for an average price of $400 an ounce by hedging -- selling gold it had not yet produced.
Not one ounce of gold Barrick has mined has ever been sold for the market price. Working with investment bankers, it sells contracts for future delivery and invests the proceeds from those transactions in high-quality securities. After commissions are paid, Barrick records the gains from its investments as part of the selling price for gold.
So while the price of bullion has been falling hard, Barrick stock has held up quite well. Today, Barrick shares traded in New York fell 31.25 cents, to $16.9375, well within their 52-week range of $12.875 to $23.625.
Several precious-metals analysts expect Barrick's profit to keep rising because the company is less reliant on high-cost mines and is expanding low-cost operations. In a recent report, HSBC Securities in Toronto said it expected Barrick's profit to rise to $334 million, even though its average selling price for an ounce of gold is projected to fall roughly 4 percent, to $385.
During a recent and rare interview in Toronto, Mr. Munk described Britain's proposed sale over two years of 415 metric tons of gold, or 913,000 pounds, as a relatively small quantity that had provoked a knee-jerk reaction. "There is nothing that this market can come up with in terms of bad news that has not been totally digested by the main holders," he said.
Unlike longtime gold bugs who fret about the vulnerability that has settled around gold, making it no different from other commodities, Mr. Munk said he thought the price of bullion had been amazingly strong. Had he been asked 10 years ago what sales from reserves by governments would do to the price, "I would have said it would have been between $40 and $50" an ounce.
But this degree of price resilience in the face of bad news, he maintained, "really proves that gold has a fundamental balance of value as a commodity that is supported by healthy demand that is created by the world's population getting wealthier."
Nonetheless, there are reasons why the commodity price of gold is languishing. Other experts point out that gold no longer plays a key role in world financial markets or as a hedge in investment portfolios. Moreover, some of the biggest owners of gold are selling. Central banks in six countries -- Canada, Australia, Belgium, the Netherlands, Argentina and the Czech Republic -- have already sold bullion from their reserves. Joining Britain will be Switzerland, selling more than 1,000 tons. The International Monetary Fund may also become a seller.
The new European Central Bank has determined that its member countries will commit gold for 15 percent of the reserves backing the euro currency. But according to the Gold Survey for 1999, published by Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. of London, three countries have considerably more gold -- Germany, with 32 percent of its reserves in bullion, France with 40 percent and Italy with 45 percent.
The possibility that chunks of these holdings, totaling 10,000 metric tons, will spill into a market with total annual demand just over 4,000 tons worries speculators. The United States has more than 8,000 metric tons, according to the Gold Survey.
Other forces at work in the financial markets are hurting gold.
One has been the lending of gold by central bankers to hedge funds, which have sold into the market with the hope of repaying the banks later with cheaper bars. Interest on this lending is a source of revenue for the central banks. Another has been distress selling within battered Asian economies, which led to a large increase in what is known in the industry as scrap supplies. Last year, scrap rose 70 percent, to almost 1,000 tons, Gold Fields said.
Mr. Munk expressed belief that the gold market would absorb the central bank sales without much disruption as long as the bankers make their intentions clear.
"Once you have transparency, the market is large enough," he said. "The gold market is as liquid as for any currency."
Absorbing central bank sales may take time. But the annual demand for gold has been slightly above 4,000 metric tons for the last few years, while new supplies from mines have totaled about 2,500 metric tons. Low prices have taken some high-cost mines out of production.
Mr. Munk acknowledged that few rich people now hoard gold bars to protect themselves against economic uncertainty -- they prefer United States Government bonds. But, he said, the impact has been offset by new wealth that economic growth is creating not just in North America and Europe but also in such countries as India, China and Turkey.
"The explosion of the consumer pool, the trillions of dollars of wealth created by the stock market -- all that just increases a constantly growing fundamental demand," he said. "And it has nothing to do with people who 15 years ago bought gold because they believed in the doomsday of the financial world, like my grandfather did."

HEADLINE: Princeton Puzzle: Where Have Jewish Students Gone?

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
As a high school student 50 years ago, Stanley Katz thought Princeton University was paradise, a place inhabited by pipe-smoking scholars with patches on their elbows and mustaches. "I said, 'Katz, that's you.' "
But as he learned more about Princeton, it dawned on him "that this was the last place in the Ivy League -- except maybe Dartmouth -- that was for me," he said. "It became clear to me that if not anti-Semitic, it wasn't congenial to Jews." He went to Harvard. 
 Today Mr. Katz is a Princeton professor and president-elect of its Center for Jewish Life, and the university is a far more welcoming place. The president, the provost and the dean of the college are Jewish. So are many of the faculty members. Professor Katz's center is a lively place, with a large kosher kitchen and a stream of events, from casino nights and swing dances to Talmud classes and Friday night services.
So how can it be, Mr. Katz and other Jews on campus are asking, that Princeton's Jewish enrollment has fallen by nearly half since the early 1980's -- to about 10 percent, or about 450 undergraduates, from a high of 18 percent? Why do other Ivy League campuses -- Harvard, Yale, Columbia, Penn -- manage to keep Jewish populations of at least a quarter and in some cases more than a third? (The figures, drawn from surveys by the University of California at Los Angeles that ask first-year college students their religious preferences, are considered rough estimates.)
The decline in Jewish enrollment at Princeton is not new: the surveys suggest that it reached the present level in the early 90's. And the figures closely track a nationwide pattern; the percentage of college students who identify themselves as Jews has declined steadily over the last two decades.
But in April, a series of front-page articles in The Daily Princetonian, the student newspaper, called attention to the decline and touched off a campuswide debate.
It is a touchy subject, and not just because Princeton thought it had long since put to rest its ancient reputation for anti-Semitism. Many Jews and non-Jews on campus point out that even at 10 percent, Princeton's Jewish enrollment far exceeds the Jewish makeup of the general population, which is roughly two percent. (Minority enrollment -- black, Hispanic and Asian-American students -- is now 27 percent, not markedly different from the general population.)
And some Jewish students and professors say they fear the discussion could make matters worse, by discouraging Jewish high school students from applying to Princeton. "This series of articles likely hurt the likelihood of Princeton gaining more Jewish students," a sophomore, Rebecca Opdyke, wrote in a letter to the student newspaper.
Other Jewish students protested that the articles did not capture the rich lives they lead at Princeton, not only in terms of religion, but also socially and educationally.
"Maybe Princeton is labeled as a school Jews don't go to, but that's not true," said Todd S. Rich, a junior economics major from East Brunswick who is president of the Center for Jewish Life. "We're thriving."
The center has even set up a task force to consider what it might do "to counter this negative image," said Princeton's rabbi, James S. Diamond. "The reality is that the quality of Jewish life here is probably as good as anywhere in the country," he said.
At Princeton, the history of anti-Semitism is tangled with the college's exclusive private eating clubs, whose anti-Semitism was visible as recently as 1958, when they denied bids to nearly two dozen students, many of them Jewish. Today, not only are Jews welcomed at the clubs -- at roughly half now, members simply sign up for the club of their choice -- but some Jewish students even cite the clubs as one of Princeton's attractions.
The comfortable intertwining was visible one recent Friday evening when some students attended Shabbat services in tuxedos and ball gowns; they were going directly from the Jewish center to the eating clubs, which celebrate the last day of classes with black-tie dinners.
The changes in the clubs are not the only sign of Princeton's openness to Jews. William G. Bowen, Princeton's president from 1972 to 1988, signaled his interest in drawing more Jewish students in several ways. He visited Jewish day schools. He invited the chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary to deliver the annual year-end baccalaureate address. He created a kosher dining hall on campus. And he initiated plans for the Center for Jewish Life.
"I felt it was very important that Princeton be much more inclusive in all of dimensions than it had been, and I and others made an effort to make the place be more welcoming to Jews and others," Mr. Bowen said.
"I didn't think about it in terms of numbers," he added. "I thought about it as a group of students who were outstanding and who weren't coming to the university in the numbers they should have, based on what they had to offer. Or if they came, they weren't getting involved in the life of the university."
Some faculty members say that after Mr. Bowen's departure, there was a relaxation of efforts to reach out to high school students -- including Jews -- who might otherwise see Princeton as an upper-crust enclave where they would not fit in. "The point about perceptions and images is that you have to work hard to maintain them," a history professor said. "In the 70's and 80's they were beginning to change."
Nobody is advocating affirmative action for Jews. Fred A. Hargadon, Princeton's dean of admissions, says his office does not consider religion at all and does not view the religious composition of other colleges as a useful measure.
"No two colleges do it the same way," he said, "and we don't all admit the same 1,000 kids."
He says his office visits Jewish schools like any other high school. This month, for example, he visited the Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway High School in Cedarhurst on Long Island, a meeting that drew nearly 600 students and parents. Princeton took one of the academy's three applicants this year and put another on its waiting list.
Daniel Vitow, the high school's principal, said the five-hour visit was evidence of Princeton's interest in his students.
"For a senior admissions person to do this sent a very clear message that he's very favorably disposed to our kids," Dr. Vitow said.
But Albert Goetz, a college adviser at another Jewish day school, the Ramaz School on Manhattan's East Side, says Princeton seems less interested in his top students than 10 or 15 years ago.
"Princeton is a Garden of Eden for our kids," he said. "It's close to New York. It's beautiful. And you can be Jewish there. We just can't get access."
Some of Princeton's Jewish faculty members say the discussion about Jewish students has put Harold Shapiro, the university's president, in a difficult position because he feels that as a Jew he cannot recruit Jewish students as actively as Mr. Bowen did.
Mr. Shapiro said he saw no bias against Jewish students in Princeton's admissions procedures. But he added, "If there's something we're doing that consciously or unconsciously discriminates against any religion, then we should stop it, but no one has presented me with any evidence."
He goes further, expressing dismay that anyone should think about students based on their religion. "As you know, I'm Jewish, and not only am I Jewish, but I'm very active in the Jewish community," he said. "I know how dangerous it is to be categorized this way."
One answer to those concerned about the number of Jewish students may be an expansion of the student body. A faculty and administration committee that studied Princeton's admissions process last year concluded that the college was turning away many desirable applicants because of its size. (Princeton takes about 1,150 freshmen, compared to about 1,600 at Harvard and 1,350 at Yale.)
The committee recommended that the college expand its entering class by 125 to 150 students. President Shapiro and Dean Hargadon both back such expansion and the trustees are studying the proposal.
In the meantime, the Center for Jewish Life task force is considering ways to encourage more Jewish applicants and to convince those who are admitted to come. The main strategy so far is to try to showcase Princeton's Jewish life for high school students and their families.
As Mr. Rich, the student president of the Center for Jewish Life, puts it, "We want to take concrete steps to show how very happy we are."

HEADLINE: A New Approach to North Korea

 BODY:
North Korea can improve relations with the United States by responding positively to the offer William Perry, the former Defense Secretary, delivered last week. Mr. Perry carried a letter from President Clinton offering to phase out American economic sanctions and begin steps toward diplomatic recognition of North Korea. But Washington will do so only if Pyongyang commits itself to give up its nuclear weapons ambitions and long-range missile programs. 
 Mr. Perry got a warm welcome, although he did not get to meet with the North's leader, Kim Jong Il. Pyongyang should be given reasonable time to reply to the Clinton proposal, but would be most unwise to reject it.
Washington's new offer goes well beyond the 1994 agreement that froze North Korea's nuclear weapons program in exchange for help in constructing Western-style power reactors. The North continues to comply with that agreement, as shown again last week when American inspectors found no evidence of building at a site Washington once feared was being prepared for new nuclear installations.
But provocative North Korean actions in other areas, like last year's surprise test of a long-range missile, and repeated requests for large sums of money in exchange for further arms control progress, have left Washington wary of making further incremental deals with the North.
North Korea, for its part, feels that it was led to expect some progress toward ending sanctions and moving toward recognition in 1994 and that Washington has not yet followed through on these issues. The Administration can return to these questions now because of a recent change in South Korean policies toward the North. Kim Dae Jung, who became South Korea's President last year, favors a conciliatory policy toward Pyongyang, including an end to American sanctions. He hopes that expanding economic and diplomatic ties will encourage gradual change in the North and decrease the chances of a new war on the Korean Peninsula.
Washington is right to coordinate America's policies with Seoul's by also offering better ties. But there can be little progress unless the North abandons its nuclear and missile ambitions.

HEADLINE: After Three-Month Recess, Microsoft TrialResumes

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
After a three-month recess and unsuccessful efforts to reach a settlement, the rebuttal phase of the Microsoft antitrust trial opened today with a concerted attack on the previous testimony of the company's chief economic witness.
In the attack, Franklin M. Fisher, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is testifying on behalf of the Government for the second time, called the economic analysis of Richard L. Schmalensee, his former student and a fellow economist at M.I.T., "peculiar," "ridiculous," "credulous" and naive. 
 Mr. Fisher is the first of six witnesses, three for each side, who are to take the stand in this, the final stage of testimony that is intended to allow the Government and the Microsoft Corporation to rebut charges made during the earlier stage of the trial. Mr. Schmalensee, a dean at M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, will return to the stand later this month.
Under pressure from Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, lawyers for both sides have agreed to complete all of the rebuttal testimony by July 4. Government officials say that in this time, they hope to fill some holes in their case -- while doing nothing to damage the commanding advantage they believe they already hold, based on Micrsoft's lackluster performance in court during the earlier portion of the trial.
Microsoft intends to challenge the credibility of the other side's case, a strategy that proved effective for David Boies, the Government's lead trial lawyer, in his earlier questioning of Microsoft witnesses. But by its choice of witnesses and topics of emphasis, Microsoft also appears to be trying to mitigate damages, to soften the possible remedies, should it be found to have violated antitrust laws.
Both Mr. Fisher and Mr. Schmalensee testified at length earlier in the trial on the question of whether Microsoft holds a legal monopoly in personal-computer operating systems -- a critical question that will determine what kind of remedies can be applied if the Government prevails.
In his testimony early this year, Mr. Schmalensee tried to make the case that Microsoft was not a monopoly, largely by suggesting that the few, marginal competitors Microsoft now faces, or others, could conceivably become serious challengers in the future.
Mr. Fisher tried yesterday to puncture that argument, saying, "Just because there are unknown future threats does not mean Microsoft doesn't have a monopoly today."
Mr. Boies led Mr. Fisher through a carefully choreographed series of questions during the direct examination -- a new practice for this trial. Earlier, witnesses submitted their direct testimony in writing.
Mr. Fisher called several of Mr. Schmalensee's analyses "reasonably confused," adding at one point, in a discussion of market dominance, "I don't think Dean Schmalensee understood this issue."
Later in the day, Mr. Boies led Mr. Fisher through a critical dissection of several charts and graphics that Mr. Schmalensee had offered as evidence. Mr. Fisher argued that in several of them, his colleague had made incorrect assumptions and offered improper numbers, leading to erroneous conclusions.
For example, Mr. Schmalensee had tried to make the case that Microsoft was charging too little for Windows -- something a monopolist was unlikely to do. He had then offered a complex economic formula for a realistic price.
But this afternoon, Mr. Fisher said, "he made a big mistake."
Mr. Schmalensee's formula put the average price of a personal computer at $2,000 or $2,500, when, in fact, the average price is now about $950, Mr. Fisher said.
The witness also criticized Mr. Schmalensee's analysis of the market share for Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser, which showed Netscape as a strong competitor. By Mr. Fisher's analysis, Internet Explorer now has about 62 percent of the corporate market compared with 38 percent for Netscape, a unit of America Online.
But in the end, Mr. Fisher said, it did not really matter whether Microsoft had 40 percent of the browswer market, or 60 percent or 80 percent.
A central tenet of the Government's case is that Microsoft fought to crush Netscape because Microsoft feared that Netscape's browser could one day be used as an alternative to the Windows operating system. If that happened, Microsoft would lose its crucial advantage, the fact that software developers write programs for Windows first.
"The goal was not necessarily to drive Netscape to zero," Mr. Fisher said. It was, he said, to make sure that Netscape did not maintain a market share that would ever allow sofware developers to write for Netscape alone. So by that measure, Mr. Fisher said, "Microsoft has already won."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- The ReturnOf Mighty Mice;
After 18 Months in the Cellar, Small-Capitalization Stocks Inch Up on Their Big Cousins

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Small-cap stocks are on a tear, but can they make up all the lost ground of the last few years?
Spurred by the strengthening economy, frenetic takeover activity and hints of higher inflation that would make it easier for smaller concerns to raise prices, small-company stock indexes have jumped 10 percent since April after lagging behind the larger companies that fill the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by the widest margins in a generation. Small stocks even held up well the last three weeks, as the broad market dropped about 5 percent. 
 Many market strategists expect small-cap companies -- with market values up to $1 billion to $2 billion -- to continue to outperform the larger-company stocks that have fueled the stock market boom. Despite their strong returns so far in the second quarter, smaller-company stocks remain near their cheapest valuations in memory, compared with other stocks. Not only could that give them an extra boost if the stock market goes up, but, perhaps as demonstrated this month, provide a cushion compared with bigger-company stocks if the market falters.
"I think this could be the real thing for a while," said Jeremy J. Siegel, professor of finance at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. "I am impressed with the relative strength they've been showing."
But even small-cap fans are not sure these stocks will ever approach the valuations they achieved in the past, when they occasionally traded at more than twice the price-to-earnings ratios of bigger stocks.
There are a number of reasons.
First, while small stocks once were the only place many investors put money for higher-risk investments, now emerging markets, Internet stocks, options, and other riskier bets draw much of that money. Second, larger companies will benefit more from continued economic globalization. And third, some say, the generally inflationary era of the last few decades is not likely to repeat itself.
T. Rowe Price's New Horizons fund has been a longtime barometer for small-cap valuations. Until this year, the fund's price-to-earnings ratio fluctuated between one and two times the P/E of the S.& P. 500. But it fell to 0.78 at the end of March, the lowest level in 38 years, though with the recent outperformance of small stocks, the ratio has risen somewhat.
Investors should get used to seeing smaller-company stocks trade at lower relative valuations mostly because the rising prices of goods and services that has paced small-stock performance since the end of World War II will not be a big factor again, predicts James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, the investment-management arm of Wells Fargo.
"We're going to a new relative valuation range," he said. "All of these historical relationships are going by the wayside. Small-cap investors at least have to give some thought to that."
Mr. Siegel agrees. "I'm still not of the belief that they're going to outperform big stocks" over the long-term, he said. "The globalization of the world economy is still going to be a major theme in the next decade, and big-cap stocks are going to benefit most from that scenario."
Not that any of that will hurt small-cap stocks anytime soon, given how much they have trailed the rest of the market. The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks had its worst year ever against the S.& P. in 1998, lagging behind by 30.8 percent. And the last two times the New Horizons fund's P/E relative to the S.& P. dipped below one -- it hit 0.95 in March 1977 and September 1990 -- small stocks subsequently outperformed for several years.
Further, predicts Mary Lisanti, a longtime small-cap fund manager, smaller-company stocks' earnings growth will eventually overtake that of larger companies, causing their current valuation discounts to narrow. "There's no question they're cheap; everybody knows that," said Ms. Lisanti, chief investment officer for equities at Northstar Investment Management in Stamford, Conn.
"It's probably the best of times" to be a small-cap investor, she added. "The risk is still relatively low, the fundamentals are starting to improve, and no one is paying attention. You have a window of opportunity here for a couple of months before everybody gets excited."
Corporate insiders have noticed. "We're seeing a higher level of buying in small-cap stocks" by executives of these companies, said Bob Gabele, director of insider research at First Call/Thomson Financial. "Insiders play for value, and they're saying there's a lot of value in these small-cap companies."
But the most compelling evidence in support of a small-cap renaissance may be what amounts to a wave of corporate arbitrage that is washing over small stocks. Larger companies have been acquiring small-cap companies this year at a furious pace.
Merrill Lynch predicts the number of small-cap mergers and acquisitions this year involving companies with market values of under $2 billion will be the highest in a decade. Most notable is the surge in leveraged-buyout activity, in which an investor group acquires a company mostly with debt and uses its cash flow or asset sales to repay the money. In fact, Merrill Lynch estimates there will be as many small-cap leveraged buyouts in 1999 as in the previous four years.
Why so many deals? In large part because bigger companies have been able to offer good-size premiums to persuade small company managements and shareholders to sell. At the same time, the bigger players still are able to use the acquisitions to bolster their per-share earnings immediately by paying for them with their own more richly valued stock.
There is even some irony here: Stocks are trading at lofty levels not seen since the heyday of the Nifty 50, the large growth stocks that led the market's charge in the early 1970's, as many investors have abandoned the notion of Benjamin Graham and David L. Dodd that stocks should be bought at prices that reflect their underlying value. But by rapidly buying these small companies on the cheap -- and using their own more expensive stock to pay for it -- larger companies are taking advantage of the sort of unusual price discrepancies that students of the famous investing scholars love.
The current activity amounts to "a Graham-and-Dodd behavior that we haven't seen in the market" in some time, said Satya Pradhuman, the director of small-cap research at Merrill Lynch.
Preston Athey, manager of the T. Rowe Price Small-Cap Value fund, said 18 out of about 210 companies in his fund had been taken over the last seven months.
Never before has takeover activity been so high among small companies, he said. "This is new and different," Mr. Athey added. "The disparity in valuations has become so large that the economics of doing a deal are just overwhelming."
For mutual-fund investors, small-cap funds with strong three-year returns through April 30 include Robertson Stephens Emerging Growth A, with a 29.6 percent three-year annualized return; Berger New Generation, 23.4 percent; Oppenheimer Enterprise A, B and C shares, 23.2 percent, 22.3 percent and 22.3 percent, respectively; Value Line Special Situations, 22.5 percent; Dreyfus Emerging Leaders, 21.9 percent, and Baron Growth, 19.3 percent.
The funds are open to new investors, have at least $100 million in net assets and require no more than a $5,000 initial purchase. All data are from Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company in Chicago.
One reason often cited for the difficulty small stocks may have in the future is their lack of liquidity -- the ability to buy or sell large blocks of stocks easily without affecting the price through your own transaction. That could keep many large institutional investors away. But that very effect has contributed to small stocks' recent rally, says Jean-Marie Eveillard, the Societe General fund manager.
Since big stocks had been beating small stocks by such wide margins until recently, pension funds, foundations and other large money managers have had to buy huge blocks of smaller stocks to bring their portfolio weightings back in line with their targets, Mr. Eveillard said.
"After four years of big stocks doing so much better, you probably have entire portfolios that are almost 100 percent in big-growth stocks," he said.
"It's not easy for them to rebalance," he added, because liquidity is with the big-growth companies. So when big portfolio managers do go into the market to buy smaller companies, shareholders in those stocks get a significant pop.
Mr. Eveillard predicts the valuation gap will continue to narrow, though he is less certain how that will happen.
"There are two ways the gap in valuations can close," he said. "One is for small stocks to catch up; another way is for big stocks to catch down. So far it has been more a matter of small stocks catching up, but who knows?"

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: From Lawsuits to Tea Bags, Challenges to Commuter Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 1

 BODY:
Looking to eliminate the New York City commuter tax, elected officials from New Jersey and Connecticut unleashed an assortment of lawsuits, legislation and tea bags today in an effort to demonstrate that the tax discriminates against out-of-state commuters.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman traveled to a busy Hoboken train station during the evening rush hour to announce that, as expected, the state had filed a class-action lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court challenging a new law that exempts only suburban New Yorkers from the tax. 
 The suit, filed by New Jersey's Acting Attorney General, Paul Zoubek, charges that it is a violation of the United States Constitution for New York to continue levying the 0.45 percent wage tax on the 240,000 New Jersey commuters and thousands of workers who live in Connecticut, Pennsylvania and other states.
In Washington, two New Jersey Congressmen, Bob Franks and Rodney Frelinghuysen, introduced legislation that would ban any state from taxing out-of-state commuters at a higher rate than its own residents.
And in Jersey City, six elected officials gathered outside a PATH commuter train station and held the most peculiar protest, emptying a few small bags of orange pekoe tea into the Hudson River in symbolic re-enactment of the Boston Tea Party tax protest of 1773.
That city's Mayor, Brett Schundler, who organized the protest, said that he planned to file a class-action lawsuit in Federal court and would use a nonprofit citizen advocacy group, Empower the People, to pay for newspaper ads urging commuters to join the court battle.
"This law creates a protectionist barrier, a tariff, against out-of-state residents," Mr. Schundler said. "And just as the colonists dumped tea into Boston Harbor to protest taxation without representation, we did it today to show we won't stand for this kind of unfair treatment."
Commuters and elected officials in New Jersey and Connecticut have been vigorously opposing the tax since Republicans in the New York Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki first suggested exempting suburban New Yorkers from the tax last month. The change in the tax code, which was intended to help a Republican State Senate candidate in Rockland County, will cost New York City at least $210 million a year in lost revenue from suburban New York State commuters.
New Jersey commuters account for another $110 million, according to Governor Whitman, and commuters from Connecticut and elsewhere pay another $40 million in city taxes.
Also today, Connecticut's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, filed a lawsuit against the tax. Mr. Blumenthal told The Associated Press that "Our action today will clean up New York's constitutional mess."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was outraged that his Republican counterparts in Albany enacted the law over his objections, said today that he had been expecting the lawsuits.
The Mayor has also vowed to fight the law in court, although he wants to see only the exemption repealed, and all commuters liable for the tax.
"This is really an example of shooting yourself in the foot, of the worst kind," Mr. Giuliani said today, criticizing Governor Pataki and other political leaders in Albany. "In an effort to have everybody position themselves with a particular Senate race in Rockland, and everybody playing gotcha in Albany, what they did was get themselves. And you look back on it as maybe an example of what's wrong with our politics in the latter part of our 20th century."
The lawsuits announced today are part of a growing number of legal challenges to the law. Two private lawyers filed a lawsuit last week in New York State Supreme Court, and Pennsylvania officials say that they, too, will challenge the tax.
But Governor Pataki, who says the tax exemption will help stimulate New York's economy, believes the courts will uphold it, said his spokesman, Michael McKeon.
"We are confident that the law will be upheld," Mr. McKeon said. "But even if the plaintiffs are successful, New Yorkers will still get a $210 million tax cut."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk
