HEADLINE: POISON ISLAND: a special report;
At Bleak Asian Site, Killer Germs Survive

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: VOZROZHDENIYE ISLAND, Uzbekistan

 BODY:
In the spring of 1988, germ scientists 850 miles east of Moscow were ordered to undertake their most critical mission.
The scientists, working in great haste and total secrecy in Sverdlovsk, first transferred hundreds of tons of anthrax bacteria -- enough to destroy the world's people many times over -- into giant stainless steel canisters. 
 Then they poured in bleach to decontaminate the deadly pink powder, packed the canisters onto a train two dozen cars long and sent the cargo almost a thousand miles across Russia and Kazakhstan to this remote island in the heart of the Aral Sea, American and Central Asian officials say.
Here Russian soldiers dug huge pits and poured the sludge into the ground, burying the germs and, Moscow hoped, a grave political threat.
While Mikhail S. Gorbachev was pressing glasnost and perestroika and strengthening ties with the West, intelligence evidence was mounting in Washington that the Soviet Union, contrary to its treaty pledges, was producing tons of deadly germs that the world had banned.
The stockpile had to be destroyed in case the United States and Britain demanded an inspection.
Vozrozhdeniye Island was a natural choice. Until the military finally left here for good in 1992, Renaissance Island, as it translates from the Russian, had been the Soviet Union's major open-air biological testing site. Today the island, which the former Soviet republics of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan share, is the world's largest anthrax burial ground.
For the United States, it is an intelligence gold mine. At the invitation of Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, American military scientists and intelligence experts have been secretly traveling here for the last four years to survey the island and take samples of the buried bacteria.
What they have found is stunning, the experts say. Tests of soil samples from 6 of 11 burial pits show that although the anthrax was soaked in bleach at least twice -- once in the 66-gallon containers and again after it was dumped and buried for decades under three to five feet of sand -- some spores are still alive and potentially deadly.
Tests performed by American military laboratories have also shown that the anthrax vaccine being given to 2.4 million American military personnel is effective against the Russian strain of this deadly scourge, -- at least the strain found here.
While this has reassured the Clinton Administration, the discovery of live spores of buried anthrax has alarmed Kazakhstan and especially worries Uzbekistan, which has been exploring for oil on the two-thirds of the island it controls.
Because the Aral Sea is shrinking -- a result of wrongheaded Soviet irrigation policies -- this deserted, isolated island has grown from 77 square miles to 770 and will soon be connected to the mainland.
As a result, Uzbek and Kazakh experts fear, the buried anthrax spores could escape their sandy tomb, stirred up by carriers like gophers and other rodents, lizards and birds, and brought to Uzbek and Kazakh territory.
The disease is spread from animals to people by direct contact; it is treatable with antibiotics if detected immediately. In weapons, it is disbursed as an aerosol to be inhaled.
Central Asian and American officials fear that as access to the island becomes easier, the buried anthrax could be dug up by terrorists and used to make more of it.
In addition, officials said, exposure could threaten a local population whose health is already abysmal. International medical experts are just starting to assess which of the residents' many chronic ailments are attributable to poverty and environmental degradation, and which might be linked to the region's biological and chemical legacy.
 
The Island Breeding of Germs, Breeding of Fears
 Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, which have both officially renounced weapons of mass destruction, have independently asked the United States for help in assessing and cleaning up this terrible biological legacy of Soviet rule.
Uzbekistan also permitted this correspondent to visit Renaissance Island earlier this year -- the first visit by a journalist -- and to interview officials and scientists concerned about the hazards.
The trip, coupled with interviews with about two dozen scientists, Government officials and military experts in Central Asia, Russia and the United States, has shed light on one of the most closely guarded biological secrets of the cold war.
Although President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia issued an edict in 1992 closing the site and vowing that the laboratory would be dismantled and decontaminated within three years, the cash-strapped Moscow Government never followed through. And Russia has never acknowledged responsibility for the anthrax cemetery here.
Military scientists at the United States Army Medical Research and Material Command and other laboratories where the samples are being studied refused comment on the island and the tests. But other officials said the labs are still deciphering the Russian anthrax's molecular structure and trying to determine why spores collected from some of the pits did not die.
"We have always known that anthrax is hard to kill," said one military expert, who would discuss the issue only if he were not identified. "But this strain has proven especially durable, and this wasn't even the most powerful strain the Soviets made."
Signs of life diminish as the Soviet-era MI-8 helicopter speeds toward this island on a 90-minute flight from Nukus, the nearest Uzbek military base. As the chopper approaches the island, fishermen in their wooden boats disappear and what was once a living sea becomes marshland. Scraggly trees give way to patches of sagebrush until, finally, there is nothing left to see save salt-covered, cement-colored sand that the Aral Sea once covered, now as dry and cracked as an ancient face. Nothing seems to live here.
Given its remote location and inhospitable climate, the island was long a favored Russian spot for secretive arrangements. A study soon to be published by the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California concludes that the island and Aralsk, a former port city now about 60 miles inland in Kazakhstan, were first used by the K.G.B.'s predecessor as exile camps for kulaks, the private farmers whom Stalin repressed.
In 1936, wrote Gulbarshyn Bozheyeva, the study's principle author, Vozrozhdeniye and Aralsk, which administered the island, were placed under the Ministry of Defense, which in 1954 built a biological-weapons test site on the island, calling it Aralsk-7.
"The lack of vegetation," she wrote, "hot and dry climate and sandy soil reaching 60 degrees Centigrade in summer" -- 140 degrees Fahrenheit -- were perfect for germ testing in that they would "reduce the spread and survival of pathogenic organisms."
American officials said that although satellites recorded some unusual activity on the island in 1988, the United States did not learn that the Soviets had buried anthrax from Sverdlosk here until 1992, when Kanatjan Alibekov, or Ken Alibek as he is now known, a high-ranking germ-weapons official, defected.
Mr. Alibek had been the director of the giant Soviet anthrax production plant at Stepnogorsk, in Kazakhstan. Between 1988 and his defection, he was the deputy director of Biopreparat, a secret network of about 40 supposedly peaceful sites, including Stepnogorsk, that provided civilian cover for work on biological weapons.
In his book, "Biohazard" (Random House, 1999), Mr. Alibek does not disclose either that anthrax was buried on the island or what he told American officials during interviews after he defected. But he does report that such germs as tularemia, Q-fever, brucellosis, glanders and plague were tested on Vozrozhdeniye beginning in the 1970's by Ministry of Defense labs and later by Biopreparat.
In 1986 and 1987, he added in a recent interview, a strain of plague that was resistant to standard antibiotics was tested. In 1987, the book states, Dr. Alibek's scientists tested the powerful anthrax that he had developed at Stepnogorsk.
The Monterey study and Dr. Alibek say the Soviet military labs also tested typhus, botulinum toxin, Venezuelan equine encephalitis, smallpox and microbial strains with characteristics useful in warfare, like high virulence and resistance to ultraviolet rays or heat.
Today, evidence of the grim research abounds. As one approaches the vast laboratory complex and test range, a visitor sees the telephone poles a kilometer apart on which detectors to measure germ agents were mounted and to which animals were tied during open-air testing.
The abandoned laboratory and high-containment unit that once handled the deadliest of agents have been stripped of equipment, pipes and even their floor and wall tiles -- shiny, light-green mosaics decorated with a fish motif. What the Soviets left behind, scavengers -- apparently impervious to fears of contamination -- have stripped away for sale at bazaars in Nukus and faraway Tashkent, intelligence experts say.
The enclosed breeding areas that once housed thousands of animals killed in the tests -- rabbits, guinea pigs, white mice and hamsters, and larger animals like horses, sheep, donkeys, monkeys and baboons -- are now empty, windows smashed or missing, roofs collapsed.
Hundreds of small cages are stacked in a dilapidated storage room; in another stands a human-sized cage, apparently for what scientists call "nonhuman primates." Hundreds of primates died hideous deaths, sometimes in a single experiment, say Russian and American scientists.
The stench is familiar to veterans of the gruesome world of germ warfare -- a mixture of bleach, dust, animal dung and death.
On the northern part of the site, less than a mile from the laboratory, are the three-story barracks, homes, kindergarten and cafeteria used by the Russians scientists and their families -- about a thousand people in all.
Today, the children's playground with its swings and a jungle gym are an eerie reminder of those who once called this forbidding place home. Russian scientists who worked here said most of the children were not vaccinated against the agents that were tested just a few miles downwind.
"We didn't test unless the wind was blowing south, away from the living quarters," said Gennadi L. Lepyoshkin, a former Soviet colonel who was Stepnogorsk's director after Dr. Alibek and was vaccinated against many of the lethal pathogens he tested.
In a recent interview at Stepnogorsk, Dr. Lipyoshkin, who is now director of Kazakhstan's National Center for Biotechnology and a co-author of the Monterey study, spoke almost nostalgically of his weeks here in the mid-1980's, testing Stepnogorsk's "products."
"The island was smaller and beautiful then, and the lab much closer to the sea," Dr. Lepyoshkin said, displaying the water colors he painted and landscapes he sketched when he was not working with deadly microbes, playing volleyball, drinking vodka or engaging in other island pastimes.
 
The Residue
Seeking U.S. Aid To Clean Up Site
In interviews in Tashkent, Uzbek officials said it was only after their country became independent in 1992 that they understood the implications of their biological legacy.
"We were shocked when we first learned the real picture," said Isan M. Mustafoev, the Deputy Foreign Minister.
Alarmed by the health and environmental impacts of unconventional weapons, President Islom Karimov renounced them.
In 1995, after Russia refused to tell Uzbekistan what chemical or biological sites had been built on Uzbek territory or what had been tested or buried here, Uzbekistan asked the United States for help, Mr. Mustafoev said. On May 25 the United States and Uzbekistan signed an accord that provides up to $6 million in aid to dismantle and decontaminate a former Soviet chemical-weapons testing site near the Aral Sea.
Kazakhstan quietly permitted Pentagon officials to visit Vozrozhdeniye in 1995. Two years later Uzbekistan also invited more American experts to take samples of the buried anthrax, Mr. Mustafoev said.
Because the Uzbek Ministry of Defense rather than Foreign Affairs was responsible for the American mission, Mr. Mustafoev said, his ministry was not told precisely what the tests showed about the samples that American teams collected, most recently in October. The last mission's goal, American officials said, was to determine why the some anthrax had survived.
In their forays, the Americans wore white overalls like space suits and gas masks with respirators. All team members were vaccinated. "It was like a moon landing," one official said, "only scarier."
Scientists said much can be learned from the material.
William C. Patrick 3d, who made germ weapons for the United States before President Nixon outlawed them nearly three decades ago, said the samples would enable scientists to determine not only the strength of the Soviet strain or strains, but also whether the anthrax had been genetically engineered or enhanced in other ways for virulence or other qualities considered desirable for its use in weapons.
Neither Dr. Patrick nor any officials directly involved in the missions would discuss what the samples had shown. But several experts confirmed that the tests indicated that the anthrax vaccine now being given American soldiers was effective. Molecular testing on the strains was continuing, they added.
Mr. Mustafoev said the national oil company, which is now exploring for oil on Uzbekistan's part of the island, is not drilling close to the buried anthrax. "No amount of oil is worth risking human lives," he said.
Though Uzbekistan is deeply concerned about the potential danger, decontaminating the island, given its size and the amount of anthrax, would be prohibitively expensive, Mr. Mustafoev and American officials agreed.
But Kazakhstan has asked American help in assessing contamination levels, which the Administration is encouraging Uzbek and Kazakh officials to work on jointly with American experts. And all three countries have been pressing Russia to provide more information about what happened here.
Milton Leitenberg, a professor and expert on Russia's unconventional weapons, said that in 1987 Moscow listed Aralsk -- but not the island -- among its germ-related sites, a listing required by the 1972 convention that banning germ warfare.
In its 1992 declaration, Russia finally listed the island, but as a site where only defensive testing for vaccines and materials had been performed. "The Russians," Professor Leitenberg concludes, "have never come clean about these programs."
 
The Neighbors
The Poor and Sick Could Get Even Sicker
The people who live near the island know all too well how little Russia cared for their safety and welfare. No region of Uzbekistan has been harder hit by the Soviet Union's economic policies or its relentless pursuit of unconventional weapons than Karakalpakstan, a semi-autonomous Uzbek republic of almost 5 million people with their own distinct traditions, language and culture.
In Karakalpakstan, the home of the Aral Sea, the once thriving fishing industry has been devastated, the arable land ruined by overuse of fertilizers and pesticides and the ground water polluted.
Yusup S. Kamalov, an Uzbek scientist who heads the Union for the Defense of the Aral Sea, an independent environmental group, called the situation "next to hopeless."
The sea, once the world's fourth largest lake, now ranks 10th, he said. Its surface water has shrunk by half, its volume reduced by 75 percent. "The sea is dying," he said.
Ian Small, the country manager of Doctors Without Borders, the volunteer physicians' group, says Karakalpaks are among the most "chronically sick people in the former Soviet Union." Ninety eight percent of pregnant women are anemic. Infant mortality rates are comparable to those of sub-Saharan Africa. Two-thirds of the population suffer from some chronic illness, often tuberculosis, whose incidence is the highest in the former Soviet Union.
"We've seen an alarming increase in kidney disease and various cancers," he said. "But because there has been no census since 1989 and health statistics are either nonexistent or unreliable, it's impossible to know whether what we are seeing is the result of the region's general poverty and environmental degradation or the past chemical and biological testing."
While local and Uzbek officials try to provide decent health care, he said, they and his small group, the only international relief group in the region, are overwhelmed. The doctors' group is beginning to conduct a health survey that may shed some light not just on the incidence of diseases but also on their causes.
Most germ-weapon scientists familiar with Vozrozhdeniye say there is little immediate danger to the local population as long as the anthrax remains undisturbed. But with the continued shrinking of the sea, the island is becoming more readily accessible. In some of the pits, anthrax sludge is beginning to leach up through the sand, one recent visitor said.
Although Uzbek officials have kept Renaissance Island closed, local residents will inevitably come in contact with the still deadly bacteria once it is linked to the mainland. "We're now totally in the dark," Mr. Small said. "It's scary not to know what we're dealing with."

HEADLINE: New Diet Drug Sells Well, But It Didn'tSet a Record

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
After one month on the market, the diet drug Xenical, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, will not go down as the most successful new pharmaceutical in history, but analysts remain confident that it will become a best seller.
Xenical, which the Food and Drug Administration approved in late April, accounted for 96,485 prescriptions during its first four weeks on the market. By contrast, Viagra, Pfizer's impotency pill, and Celebrex, Monsanto's arthritis drug, had prescriptions in their first months of 367,857 and 150,113, respectively, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant. The introductions of Viagra and Celebrex were two of the most successful in pharmaceutical history. 
 Even though Xenical did not topple Viagra, analysts say its first weeks of sales have been stellar, allowing it to build momentum as more doctors become comfortable with it.
After Xenical was introduced, it received much fanfare as a fad drug. Analysts now expect sales to grow as Hoffmann-La Roche combats the fad image by telling doctors about the drug's therapeutic advantages.
"It's important that momentum for Xenical not peak too early," said Viren Mehta, a partner at Mehta Partners, a biopharmaceutical research firm. "You want to have an educated group of physicians about the drug. Hoffmann-La Roche has studies under way that point out the science of the drug."
From its first week on the market, Xenical has inspired controversy. A new kind of drug, it blocks the body's absorption of dietary fat. Despite its new mechanism, Xenical brought recollections of fen-phen, a weight-loss drug cocktail that was removed from the market in 1997 over concerns that it caused heart valve damage.
Adding to that worry, critics noted that many patients who used Xenical lost modest amounts of weight -- typically 5 percent to 10 percent of their body weight -- and risked some messy side effects, including fecal incontinence, if they did not reduce their fat intake.
Xenical's case was further hurt by an immediate Internet market, similar to the universal cyberspace availability of Viagra and Propecia, Merck's hair loss pill. To overcome this shady beginning, Hoffmann-La Roche has not offered Xenical samples to doctors.
While some doctors remain critical of Xenical -- dismissing it because of the modest weight loss it produces -- others are becoming avid fans. Hoffmann-La Roche has 2,000 sales representatives peddling the drug, and their message is apparently taking hold in some hospitals.
"If you look at Xenical in treating obesity, it is important to note that it does something that other diet drugs don't do," said Dr. Louis Aronne, director of the Comprehensive Weight Control Program at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. "You can use it to treat obese people and not worry about it causing cardiovascular side effects. A lot of obese patients have cardiovascular risks."
To promote Xenical's benefits further, Hoffmann-La Roche expects to begin advertising it directly to consumers sometime in the third quarter of 1999. The ads are expected to loft sales of Xenical, which most analysts expect to hit $750 million to $1 billion at their peak.
"The sales will be erratic," said Neil Sweig, an analyst with Southeast Research Partners. "But that's the market. People who take this type of drug are never satisfied. They want the easy way out to lose weight. In this market, there is not any loyalty here."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE PRIZE;
Issue of Who Controls Kosovo's Rich Mines

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
A number of unofficial partition plans have been drawn up for Kosovo, all raising the question of who would control an important northern mining region.
The bombing has made up-to-date production figures difficult to come by. Experts say the resources include large deposits of coal, along with some nickel, lead, zinc and other minerals. The industries are important contributors to Yugoslavia's $21 billion economy, and Belgrade would presumably be loathe to surrender them in any plan to divide the province. 
 One thought is that President Slobodan Milosevic could portray partition as a victory over NATO if Serbia retained control over important churches and historic monasteries in Kosovo, as well as the mines, which are around Mitrovica. But some experts said they believed that after months of bombing, economic issues were no longer paramount to Mr. Milosevic.
"In his own eyes, Mr. Milosevic sees himself as protector of Serbian nationhood," said Aurel Braun, a professor of international relations at the University of Toronto who has written two books on Eastern Europe. "He is a man who basically has ignored the economy, which was in a very bad condition before this conflict started. So this is hardly a leadership that will make any decision based on economic rationality."
Professor Braun said he believed that Mr. Milosevic could see retaining control of the region as a way to reward supporters after the conflict ends, reinforcing his grip on power. "He is corrupt and he does want his cronies to make money," the professor said. "But he is primarily a political animal, and his power derives from being a man who flies the Serbian flag. In this scheme of things, economic factors are pretty low down on the scale."
In 1995, the last year for which figures are generally available, all of Yugoslavia produced 41 million metric tons of coal, as well as significant quantities of pig iron, crude steel and copper. How much of that came from Kosovo, the poorest part of Serbia, is unknown.

HEADLINE: In Mexico, Children, and Promises, Unkept

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: AGUA PRIETA, Mexico, May 31

 BODY:
When Martina Toscano Quiroz gave three of her seven children up for adoption, her main goal, she said, was to give them a chance for a better life.
She is a single mother who earns less than $40 a week as a cleaning woman in this dusty town on the Arizona-Mexico border. Her home is a fly-infested shack with dirt floors and walls patched together from scraps of wood. 
 But, she acknowledged, her decisions were not entirely noble. The lawyer who took her children to live with middle-class families in New York made promises so enormous, she said, that it was as if he had offered her the stars.
"He told me he would build me two rooms with new tin for the roof and strong brick walls," she said. "And he told me he would build me a bathroom with a toilet and a faucet."
Ms. Toscano, 30, never got her new house. She said the lawyer, Mario Manuel Reyes Burgueno, took her daughters -- ages 8, 4 and 2 -- and then told her he could only give her a few hundred pesos for food.
Last week, Mr. Reyes and two women on Long Island were charged with running a cross-border baby-smuggling ring that sold Ms. Toscano's children and at least 14 others to couples in New York for as much as $22,000 each. The two women, Arlene Lieberman and Arlene Reingold, have declined to comment, while lawyers and friends of Mr. Reyes have suggested that he was trying to help poor women and their children.
In the wake of the arrests, some of the adoptive parents say they were the unwitting victims of a scheme that lured them into expensive and illegal agreements and that took advantage of their desperation to have children.
But in this isolated patch of the United States' border with Mexico, worlds away from the comfortable homes of Long Island, the view of these adoption agreements is even more complicated and tragic. Social workers here say they counsel dozens of mothers like Ms. Toscano, who are in such dire economic and social distress that they broker their children for money or shelter.
Several lawyers around the area, social workers said, have made offers to buy children from poor mothers. But, the social workers said, the lawyers usually renege on their part of the deals once the children have been delivered to families in the United States.
"I have had attorneys come here and offer me $100 for every child I give to them for adoptions," said Eunicia Soto, who runs an independent orphanage called Rancho Feliz at the eastern edge of Agua Prieta. "I tell them my children are not tomatoes for sale, and that I never want to see them on my property again."
But such defiance can only go so far, and Government officials say that there is so much smuggling of drugs and humans across this border -- a wide-open space divided, for the most part, by barbed-wire fencing -- that they cannot stop the trade. Smuggling has long been a pillar of the economy and culture of Agua Prieta, with a population of 130,000, and Douglas, its much-smaller sister city in Arizona. Ten years ago, border patrol agents discovered a high-tech tunnel, 30 feet beneath the desert floor, that had electric lighting, concrete reinforcement and hydraulic lifts and had been used to transport tons of cocaine into the United States.
And in recent years, as the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has intensified its patrols in El Paso to the east and San Diego to the west, a stream of illegal immigrants from Mexico has been funneled through Douglas into the United States. Officials said that as many as 1,000 illegal immigrants are apprehended around Douglas each day, more than at any other I.N.S. station along the 1,900-mile border between the two countries.
"This is a real illegal universe," said Keoki Skinner, a former journalist who runs juice bars on both sides of the border. "There's so much illegal activity that goes on here that a lot of people seemed numb to it. But the idea that babies are part of the illegal traffic has really shocked a lot of people."
"It's like, things have gotten really bad if women are offering to sell their babies," he said.
For Martina Toscano, life was beyond bad. Short and pudgy and with a worn, tan face that makes her look much older than her age, Ms. Toscano said she moved to Agua Prieta 15 years ago from a small village some 100 miles away. There was no work in her village, she said, so she and her brother moved to the border to work in the factories known as maquiladoras, which are owned by companies in the United States. Within two months of moving here, she said, she was pregnant with her first child.
"I wanted a husband and a family," she said. "I met a man who offered to marry me and take care of me, so I gave myself to him."
But after the baby was born, the child's father abandoned Ms. Toscano, and her mother moved to town to help her take care of the child. But two years later, came another man with promises, and another baby was born. Then another man and another.
After her sixth child was born, Ms. Toscano said, she met a woman who offered to help place some of the children for adoption in the United States. Ms. Toscano said she refused. But on the next day, a tall, broad man knocked on her door.
It was the first time she had met Mario Reyes, she said. His words, she said, hit her like stones.
"He told me, 'Look at how you live,' " she recalled. "He told me that my children could have better lives in the United States. He promised that he would find them nice families who would love them and send them to school."
She said she yelled at Mr. Reyes, telling him that he had no right to judge the way she lived; that she did the best she could to provide for her children and that they were comfortable in their lopsided shack.
"Then he told me that if I gave him my children, he would help me to live better," she said. "He told me he would build me two rooms."
Mr. Reyes took two of Ms. Toscano's children: 8-year-old Flor Azucena and 4-year-old Zoitza. He promised that the two girls would be placed together in the same home, she said, and that their adoptive parents would send photographs and updates on how the girls were adjusting.
But the girls were separated almost immediately, she said. Flor Azucena went to the home of John and Rosalie Liberto in Miller Place, on Long Island. Zoitza's whereabouts remain unknown.
A year later, she said, Mr. Reyes sent Ms. Toscano's 2-year-old daughter, Gabriela, to live with the Libertos.
Mrs. Liberto said in an interview that she and her husband paid Mr. Reyes, Ms. Lieberman and Ms. Reingold more than $50,000, in what they thought were adoption fees, for Gabriela and Flor Azucena, whom they called Nicole.
"With that money I could have built a mansion and 10 bathrooms," Ms. Toscano scowled. "But I am still here, living in filth."
A year ago, Flor Azucena's American parents agreed to send her back to Agua Prieta because she missed her mother so badly.
Mrs. Liberto cried when she was asked why she agreed to let Flor Azucena go. The decision, she said, arose from memories of growing up poor and being sent every year to a summer camp in Pennsylvania. It was the most beautiful place she had ever seen, Mrs. Liberto said. But after a few days, she recalled, she was crying and pleading to go home. "A family bond is something you cannot break," she said.
"I knew I had to send her to her mother," she said of Flor Azucena. "After she left, you would have thought there was a death in the family. It was one of the only times I ever saw my husband cry."
Flor Azucena, sitting on the dank double bed she shares with two of her siblings in Agua Prieta, described her Long Island parents as kind and loving. But, she said, "I wanted to be with my mother."
Showing a visitor pictures, she recalled her time in the United States.
"That is my bedroom," she said, pointing to a photograph of her sitting on a bed with a fluffy, flowered comforter.
"That is me at my aunt's baby shower," she said, looking at a picture of herself wearing a silvery velvet dress, with a shiny headband in her hair.
"That's my best friend," she said, showing a photo of herself standing in a tight embrace with a freckle-faced red-headed girl.
"That's my mom and dad," she said, stopping the show for a moment to gaze at a picture of Mr. and Mrs. Liberto.
Soon to turn 11, Flor Azucena looks almost nothing like the soft, confident girl in the photos. Her complexion is uneven, her hair tangled and as she speaks, she stares down.
She does not go to school here, she says, because of fights she has had with other children. So while her mother is at work, she spends her days watching programs on an old television set and playing on the field of dust outside her house with her three siblings: 12-year-old Aurelia, who also does not go to school, 4-year-old Edgar and 1-year-old Ameirani. A 15-year-old brother lives with Ms. Toscano's mother elsewhere in the city.
The family's plight is not uncommon, said Ms. Soto, of Rancho Feliz. She organizes child-care workshops for single women in town who do not earn enough money to support their children. Some of the women, she said, turn to prostitution.
In the most desperate cases, she said, mothers give up their children for money or other things. One of her clients, she said, had given away her baby so that she could get electricity installed in her home.
"These kinds of things are not common, but they do happen," Ms. Soto said. "When I work with these mothers, my main message to them is that they do not have to give their children away in order to survive. They can make it, if they try. And I tell them that I will help them."
That message kept Guadalupe Serrano's family together. Ms. Serrano, 34, a mother of four, said she was a recovering drug addict who used to support her habit with prostitution. Two years ago, she said, she was approached by a lawyer who offered her $10,000 for her toddler. Ms. Serrano refused to name the lawyer, but she said it was not Mr. Reyes.
"He told me that she would have a good life and that people in the United States wanted children so much that they are willing to pay a lot of money," Ms. Serrano recalled.
Today, Ms. Serrano works at Rancho Feliz and raises her children in a cottage there. Speaking about her daughter, Olivia, who is now 4, she said, "I would have given her away." But Ms. Soto would not let her: "She made me feel ashamed for thinking about it," she said.
Ms. Toscano, however, has no regrets about sending her children to the United States and is happy that Gabriela is in a beautiful home where she is loved. Although she would like to know what happened to Zoitza, she regularly gets pictures from the Libertos of Gabriela.
"The life they have there is better than what they could have here," she said. Flor Azucena, staring at the ground, nodded in agreement.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Merrill Lynch to Offer On-Line Stock Trading
Merrill Lynch plans to add a low-cost service for people who want to trade on the Internet. Instead of its average charge of $80 to $100 for a trade, the brokerage firm will let customers trade on line for $29.95, matching the fee charged by Charles Schwab & Company. But customers will not have access to research or guidance from a broker.
In addition, customers of Merrill Lynch can pay an annual fee of at least $1,500 for unlimited trading and advice, either on line or through a broker. Page A1. 

Liberty Media Buys Associated
Liberty Media Group, the television programming company controlled by John C. Malone, expanded into the wireless communications business by agreeing to acquire Associated Group of Pittsburgh in a complicated stock deal that involves AT&T. Associated is the largest investor in Teligent, which provides telephone and data communications services to companies using advanced wireless technology. C8.
 
F.T.C. Ends Cisco Investigation
The Federal Trade Commission said that it was ending its nine-month investigation into partnership discussions that Cisco Systems, the maker of data communications gear, held in recent years with two rivals. That means that Cisco will escape the sort of regulatory and legal pressure that the Government has brought to bear on Intel and Microsoft. C8.
 
Analysts Still Confident in Xenical
After a month on the market, the diet drug Xenical, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, will not go down as the most successful pharmaceutical introduction in history, but analysts are confident that it will be a best seller. C2.
 
Stocks Mostly Fall, but Dow Rallies
Stocks sold off early in the session on concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates later this month. The Dow Jones industrial average later recovered, closing up 36.52 points, to 10,596.26, but the Nasdaq composite index declined 58.49 points, or 2.37 percent, to 2,470.52. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.58 points, to 1,294.26. C12.
 
 
Bond prices slumped, pushing yields to their highest level in more than a year. The yield of the benchmark 30-year bond rose to 5.94 percent, from 5.82 percent on Friday. C12.
 
Manufacturing Rose in May
The rebound in United States manufacturing accelerated in May and more factories reported paying higher prices for materials, a National Association of Purchasing Management survey showed. Separately, the Conference Board reported that its index of leading economic indicators fell one-tenth of 1 percent in April, its first monthly decline in almost a year. And the Commerce Department said that the country's construction spending unexpectedly fell 2.4 percent in April, the first decline in six months. C8.
 
Microsoft Antitrust Trial Reopens
After a three-month recess and inconclusive efforts to settle the Microsoft antitrust case, the trial's rebuttal phase opened with a concerted attack on the previous testimony of Microsoft's chief economic witness. C2.
 
Dow Jones in Link With Germans
In the latest turn in a heated rivalry to dominate Europe's business press, Dow Jones & Company announced an alliance with the German newspaper Handelsblatt and agreed to exchange a stake in The Wall Street Journal Europe for a stake in Handelsblatt. C4.
 
America Online in Two Music Deals
America Online said that it would buy two Internet music companies, Spinner Networks and Nullsoft, for $400 million in stock. The acquisitions underscore the growing popularity of listening to music over the Internet. C9.

HEADLINE: Trade Status With China: Risky Vote Tomorrow

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
For the seventh time since he took office, President Clinton will ask Congress, on Thursday, to renew China's trading privileges with the United States. That has always been a dicey proposition, though one that Mr. Clinton -- with aggressive lobbying help from companies with interests in China -- has always won.
But this year the battle over what are now called "normal trade relations" promises to be more confused, more emotional and far trickier than any time since the military crackdown in Tiananmen Square, 10 years ago. Just a few months ago, Mr. Clinton and the Chinese had hoped to be asking Congress for far more, for permanent trade privileges, as part of a deal that would usher China into the World Trade Organization. 
 Mr. Clinton's aides say that on Thursday the President will hold open the possibility that the bigger and more permanent deal will soon be struck, presumably after the furor dies down here over accusations of Chinese spying and in Beijing over bombing the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. But some of Mr. Clinton's advisers said privately they feared that the chances of having a trade deal signed with the Chinese and through an angry Congress were increasingly remote.
"What we are watching," an adviser said last week, "is a seven-year initiative with China crumble in our hands."
Once the White House called that initiative the development of a "strategic partnership" with China, a phrase stricken from all official references to that country. So has the term "commercial diplomacy," once used to describe how increased economic engagement with China would strengthen ties in other arenas.
Now the White House, and business leaders, are arguing the opposite, why national security issues should be divorced from trade.
The White House's seeming ambivalence about how to tackle the vote, which usually becomes a Congressional referendum on the state of Chinese-American relations, is mirrored by the Republicans' ambivalence. Roughly half the Republican Presidential hopefuls, including Gary Bauer, Patrick Buchanan and Steve Forbes, argue that the spy case underscores why the United States should suspend negotiations with China over entering the W.T.O.
The other half, including George W. Bush and John McCain, have carefully separated the issues, with Mr. McCain, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, arguing: "We should make judgments on the basis of our trade interests. The scandal is not that they spied on us, but that we let them."
For many executives the debate on responding to the spying accusations echoes the debate that played out in the first two years of the Administration, over tying China's human rights record to its trade privileges. Mr. Clinton himself started out that way and reversed course, separating human rights issues from arguments over the annual renewal.
The chairman of Intel Corporation, Andrew Grove, said he saw the relationship in terms of parallel universes. "There is the political and geopolitical universe, where nations have problems and collaborations," Mr. Grove said. "There is the trade universe, and then there is a universe of technology issues. And what we have to deal with -- whether we want to tie those three together, so that if hits a brick wall they all stop making progress."
Mr. Grove's concern, one that he and other technology executives plan to voice here next week, is that Congress will link the trade vote to new restrictions on technology transfers.
"It's entirely possible that higher-end Pentium III's will not be salable in China," Mr. Grove said, referring to top-of-the-line Intel microprocessors. "Imagine that, a personal computer you will be able to buy for $1,200 at CompUSA by the end of the year could not be shipped to China."
Mr. Grove and other technology executives argue that such restrictions would not deny technology to China, but that they would rather force China to develop its own processes. "And then you have to ask are we better off in any of those universes -- the political one or the trade one or the technological one -- if we force them to build up their technological base on their own?"
In Congress, though, such subtleties have not been debated. After Tiananmen, Congress imposed trade and technology restrictions, many of which have since been lifted. There may be the same reaction this time.
But some experts on Capitol Hill say they believe that when passions cool, there will once again be momentum for a trade deal that opens China's markets.
"In the end," said Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is pushing for permanent trade privileges, "people will come to realize that all the concessions in this trade agreement are on China's side."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Reshaping Retail Space And Making It Pay Off

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
In late 1995, the owners of Paramount Plaza, a 2.4-million-square-foot office building at 1633 Broadway, were looking for ways to reinvent about 100,000 square feet of multilevel retail space. Now, more than three years later, the renovated space between 50th and 51st Streets has three new tenants -- the Mars 2112 restaurant, Cosi Sandwiches and the Equinox Fitness Club -- in 65,000 square feet.
The way in which the deals were made, and the time it took to make them, illustrate how real estate transactions can often turn on obvious issues, like money, and on less apparent ones, like a landlord's taste -- in tenants, and in bread. 
 "I had been making proposals to the building for a small former bank space on the corner, and the landlord wasn't responding," said Faith Hope Consolo, a broker with the Garrick-Aug Worldwide retail brokerage company who was hired by the owners as a consultant. "Then suddenly, they called me and said they wanted to come visit. I thought they wanted to make a deal."
The "they," the owner of the building, is the Paramount Group, the investment arm of the Otto family of Germany, who own Spiegel, the mail-order company. The building, put up in 1971, has tenants like the Gershwin and Circle in the Square theaters, the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization and the Showtime cable network.
A small retail deal was not what Paramount had in mind. Ms. Consolo had been a consultant to the State Economic Development Corporation in devising its retail plans for Times Square, and Paramount wanted her to do the same for 1633 Broadway.
"They said they wanted to redevelop the space, and possibly re-lease about 65,000 to 100,000 square feet of it," Ms. Consolo said. "At the time, 35,000 square feet was vacant and there was the possibility of more vacancies. Times Square was starting to come together, with Disney and the New Amsterdam Theater, and they wanted to take advantage of the changes."
She and a Garrick-Aug colleague, Joseph A. Aquino, spent six months studying street traffic, the kinds of stores that the neighborhood could use and the kinds of stores that the building's tenants wanted.
"There was an incredible amount of traffic," Ms. Consolo said. "The 8,000 people who worked in the building. Others who worked in the neighborhood. Tourists from all the hotels nearby. There's a subway stop in the building -- the 50th Street stop on the No. 1 and 9 lines. We found that the 50th and Broadway corner had 80 percent of the traffic counts at 57th and Seventh and 42d and Seventh."
The 1996 study, Mr. Aquino said, found that an average of 24,000 pedestrians passed the northwest corner of 50th and Broadway on a weekday between 7 A.M. and 5 P.M.
The building's tenants and neighborhood visitors from the three-state area "all said they wanted affordable food," Ms. Consolo said. "Everybody in the building wanted a good gym. There was already a gym called Living Well Lady there, but the tenants said they wanted a real fitness center."
The study found that redoing the space, which is on several levels, would be of prime importance. "A lot of the space, on the building's concourse and subconcourse, was hidden," Ms. Consolo said. "There was no visibility from the street." So, she said, "several million dollars" were spent on new signs and awnings, new storefronts and a new lighting plan.
"The building looks dramatically different," she said. "We opened up the visibility into the lower level, reworked the staircase to make for easier access and egress and made everything user-friendly from the street."
Ms. Consolo, who after completing the study was named exclusive leasing agent for the space, said that there was a lot of interest but that some of it was unwanted.
"We had interest from Filene's Basement, Loehmann's, T. J. Maxx," she said. "A lot of discounters wanted the space, but the owners didn't want apparel. We had offers from Staples and Office Depot, but the landlord didn't want them, didn't like their signage. Paramount felt that a tenant like that would be too dominant a presence for an office building. Everything took a long time because each offer had to go back to Germany for consideration. And Paramount is very cautious."
Duane Reade, which has had a store in the building for years, remained. The first new deal was made in April 1998, for a theme restaurant, Mars 2112, which opened last fall.
"Before Mars 2112 we had a lot of interest from the Rainforest Cafe, and Paramount liked them," Ms. Consolo said. "But Rainforest Cafe decided it would be too expensive to build the space. The Mars 2112 offer came right after that."
Mars 2112 cost $15 million to build, occupies 35,000 square feet on the building's main concourse and tries to create the experience of dining on Mars in the year 2112. It was built by Paschal M. Phelan, a European businessman, and is reached by way of the building's sunken plaza. A flying saucer 22 feet in diameter sits outside the 400-seat restaurant's glass front doors. Inside, customers take a bumpy five-minute "shuttle" to Mars -- and then traverse walkways suspended over simulated pools of bubbling lava.
Next came Cosi Sandwiches, which signed a lease last fall for 5,000 square feet on the ground level and opened over the winter. "We had Au Bon Pain and everybody in the food business looking at the space, but Paramount decided it didn't want a very large chain," Ms. Consolo said. "In the end, Paramount chose Cosi because they liked their bread."
The final deal, for 25,000 square feet, was signed last month. The fitness club leased 26,000 square feet on the concourse and subconcourse levels and is to open in February.
Average annual retail rents in the neighborhood are about $100 a square foot for ground space and $40 to $50 a square foot for concourse and lower levels.
"In the end, the tenants got what they said they wanted," Ms. Consolo said. "And so did the landlord." Including the bread.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: LIGHTING;
Clipping Together A Zeppelin

BYLINE: By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
There's a persistent mystery to the way flat patterns fold up into full ones. That, along with economy of design, lends fascination to a new family of hanging lamps from Artecnica, designers and manufacturers in Culver City, Calif. These spherical and zeppelin lamps, which sell for $30 to $45, take shape from polycarbonate panels that assemble quickly with clips. Like certain high-tech buildings, they make a fetish of the cleverness with which their parts join. The result has the quality of a puzzle. Information: (310) 559-3555.
 PHIL PATTON

HEADLINE: In Spanish and Portuguese, Web Growth Spurt

BYLINE: By JAMES RYAN 

 BODY:
IN January, Anna Spinello, a clothing designer in Buenos Aires, set up a Web site to help boost sales of her spring line. By clicking on a little flag, a viewer can see the site in English, Spanish or Portuguese.
"Considering we haven't publicized it, we've had an amazing response," said her son Francesco Spinello, 42, who manages the small, family-run business (www.annaspinello.com) that sells to boutiques in Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Brazil. "We've made a lot of contacts that should pay off with the next collection." 
 The Spinellos are part of a wave of Latin Americans who have recently discovered the Web. Lagging perhaps two years behind the United States, Japan and Western Europe in its development, the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking Internet market is one of the fastest-growing in the world and has emerged as the latest battleground for viewers among such Internet titans as America Online and Yahoo.
"This is the year the scales are tipping," said Heather Killen, the vice president of Yahoo International, who oversaw the start-up of a Spanish version of the Yahoo portal (espanol.yahoo.com) in June 1998. "The shape of the Internet is no longer a comet with the U.S. as the head and this thin trail behind."
Latin American governments, aware of the need to promote local Internet access and business so that more precious dollars do not flow overseas, are also beginning to look at ways to encourage more people to get on line.
The governments of Argentina and Chile, for example, have mandated that privately held phone companies charge half price for local Internet access phone calls. Recent privatization of the state-run phone company in Brazil, which is the only Portuguese-speaking country in Latin America, is expected to lead to reduced phone charges and better infrastructure and service in that country, the most populous in the region, accounting for roughly half the Internet users.
"If they don't allow citizens on line, they realize their country is going to be at a significant disadvantage in the future," said Annika Alford, chief Latin American Internet analyst for IDC, a market research company in Framingham, Mass.
Among the Internet's contributions to Latin America will be allowing the Spinellos and other merchants to expand their reach across borders.
"The Internet is an extraordinary medium to improve communication and exchange among different cultures and languages," Mr. Spinello said. "In Brazil, for example, we have few clients now but there is great potential for growth."
Internet companies in the United States, faced with slowing growth at home, are looking for expansion through service in languages other than English. This year, for the first time, there will be more people gaining access to the Web from outside the United States than from within, many of them preferring to do so in their native tongue.
The Spanish-speaking population in the United States also holds growth potential for Internet companies. Luis Hernandez, an 18-year-old bilingual senior at Hollywood High School in Los Angeles, uses the Internet to search for information about his favorite Latin bands and to chat with childhood friends living in Mexico as well as other Spanish speakers using one of America Online's Hispanic chat rooms. The Spanish language "is easier for me to write in -- I'm faster," he said, adding: "It's our culture. We understand ourselves."
As they rush to sign up Spanish-language consumers, Internet giants in this country face stiff competition from both Latin American media companies and existing Spanish-language portals -- the industry term for a site that is both a primary destination and a gateway to the Internet at large -- based in the United States. Of these portals, Starmedia Network (starmedia .com), which saw its stock nearly double on the first day of trading in its initial public offering last week, has grabbed much of the attention for its Spanish-Portuguese site.
But other ventures are vying for the same users, and the last few weeks have seen a flurry of announcements of new sites in the Spanish-language Internet sector. Among the competitors are Que Pasa (quepasa .com), a Spanish-English site, and Yupi (yupi.com), which recently acquired Ciudad Futura, a Spanish-language on-line entertainment site (www.ciudadfutura.com), and says it is the front-runner with more than 5.7 million users and 80 million page views per month from both the Yupi and Ciudad Futura sites. Starmedia lays claim to 60 million page views per month and 2.4 million users.
Bloomberg recently announced that it would soon open a bilingual personal finance site for Hispanics in the United States (www.negociosbloomberg.com).
Just how many Hispanic Internet users there are is the subject of some debate. The number of users of the Internet at large -- or of a specific site -- is hard to measure, in part because of differences in the methods of measurement in the fast-changing world of electronic media. While operators of Web sites typically keep detailed logs of user traffic, there is no generally accepted industry auditing process for those data. And outside companies that try to compile Web usage data, a la television's Nielsen ratings, must extrapolate from audience samples that are widely thought to undercount Internet use from work and ignore or undercount Internet use from overseas.
Companies like Starmedia, lumping together Hispanics in this country, Portuguese-speaking Brazil, the countries of Spanish-speaking Latin America, Spain and Portugal, come up with a figure of about 20 million users worldwide, two-thirds of them in Latin America. IDC, which takes a slightly more conservative approach, based on its figures showing that there is an installed PC base in Latin America of nearly 16 million computers and an Internet penetration rate of 20 percent, estimates that by the end of 1999 there will be 7 million Latin Americans on line. At an annual growth rate of 32 percent over the next five years, IDC predicts that number will grow to 19 million on line by the year 2003.
Hispanics in the United States are another large and growing market for Spanish-language sites. Data from Nielsen Net Ratings, which monitors Web traffic, indicate that about 5 million of the 30 million Hispanics in the United States are on line. A study by Forrester Research, however, put the figure closer to 10 million.
A focus group study by Yahoo indicated that 70 percent of American Hispanics preferred to get at least some of their content in Spanish. That would suggest that there might be as many as seven million Hispanics in this country surfing Spanish-language sites. Yupi, with headquarters in Miami Beach and offices in seven Latin American countries, estimates that 20 percent of its traffic comes from American users.
While Hispanics in this country may be an important sector of the Spanish-language audience, the big growth in the user base is expected to come from Latin America, particularly Brazil, with a population of 160 million.
Pedro Rosa, 33, a writer and translator in Rio de Janeiro, said he downloaded software and regularly communicated via E-mail with other writers in the United States and elsewhere. He also conducts much of his research on line, sometimes using the Brazilian search engine Cade (cade.com.br), sometimes an English or French one.
"It gives me access to a lot of dictionaries and translating tools," said Mr. Rosa, who has also taken screen-writing courses over the Web through a company called Online Learning, based in Los Angeles.
Already the Web is breaking down national barriers. On Starmedia's bulletin boards and classified pages, for example, people from many Latin American countries post notices side by side or banter in chat rooms. Some speak of the Internet as having achieved a "virtual regionalization."
Winning over locals like Mr. Rosa may prove a challenge for United States companies moving into an increasingly crowded market. Already there are in the neighborhood of 450 Internet service providers in Brazil, 240 in Mexico and 170 in Argentina, according to numbers from America Online's Latin American unit, as well as long-established major destinations, many of them sponsored by Latin American media giants like TV Globo (globo.com.br) and Grupo Folha (uol.com.br) in Brazil and Grupo Clarin (clarin.com.ar) in Argentina.
A common strategy is to find local partners who can help pave the way in a market where personal relationships are key to business success.
"You can't sit in a city on another continent and say, 'Right, I'm going to launch something in Chile,' " said Phil Ingram, marketing manager of Orientation.com, which is based in New York and is creating a network of country portals. "You have to have local contacts who can build bridges."
Orientation.com plans to carve a niche for itself by focusing on some of the smaller, overlooked countries -- Colombia, Costa Rica, Chile -- with a network appealing to business travelers, offering a currency converter, weather forecasts and trade show information in English and Spanish.
America Online has formed a 50-50 partnership with the Cisneros Group, a major entertainment and telecommunications force in Latin America that is based in Venezuela. And last month, the two partners hired Charles Herington as president and chief executive of AOL Latin America, which will first tackle the Brazilian market and later Argentina. Mr. Herington previously helped Taco Bell and Pizza Hut spread their franchises in South America.
Marketing Internet services, however, will prove more complicated than selling fast food. Sites must be locally tailored. Jack Davies, president of AOL International, promised that Brazilians will not find themselves force-fed a service planned for North Americans, but will instead find a product reconceived for their needs.
"It's going to be very bright, very alive, very colorful, more so than corresponding AOL.com's because of the festive nature of Brazil," Mr. Davies said.
Though features like chat, E-mail and up-to-the-second news have proved enormously popular in Latin America, as they have elsewhere in the world, electronic commerce, including sales of books, CD's, computer equipment and clothing, may catch on more slowly because of cultural and logistical differences. Brazil, for example, does not have the United States' extensive tradition in mail-order catalog buying on which to build an electronic commerce market.
"We Brazilians like to see the thing, touch it, like to be sure we're going to have something," said Mr. Rosa, who once ordered books from Amazon.com but had to wait seven weeks for them to arrive and vows never to buy on line again.
Further slowing the expansion of the Internet user base in Latin America has been the regional economic crisis. The number of Internet users in the region more than doubled from 1997 to 1998; the 1999 growth appears to be only half as fast, IDC said.
Mr. Herington at AOL, among others, said that the Internet itself might provide the solution by improving communication and distribution channels.
Adding to the obstacles for Latin American Web surfers are underdeveloped telephone systems, the relatively high cost of Internet access and the fact that many phone companies in Latin America charge by the minute for local calls. Mr. Rosa, who estimates he spends an average of 60 hours a month on line, pays the equivalent of $20 a month to his Internet service provider for unlimited access, but local toll charges add another $40 to his monthly phone bill.
"How many people can afford this?" Mr. Rosa said of his fellow Brazilians. "Most people don't have enough money to afford a computer. The base isn't going to expand unless we do all sorts of socioeconomic development."

HEADLINE: Spotlight On an Outpost Of Black Talent;
A New Jersey Theater Steps Onto the Big Stage

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
For Ricardo Khan, the road to a Tony Award began with a matinee performance of "Hello, Dolly!" in 1967. Mr. Khan, then a gawky 16-year-old theater buff, still remembers the awe he felt as the curtain went up in the St. James Theater to reveal Cab Calloway and Pearl Bailey in roles that had been radically recast by the producer, David Merrick.
"I wasn't inspired because it was on Broadway," Mr. Khan said, "but because it was an all-black cast. It was a cast," he said with a pause, "that looked like me." 
 A decade later, using a $225,000 Federal jobs grant, Mr. Khan established the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, N.J., and began making theater by, for and about black Americans. It is a mission that, Mr. Khan admits, has had its share of financial pitfalls and has had him spending more than a few afternoons sweeping floors, tiling bathrooms and "wondering why I got into this."
But any doubts were swept away this past season.
On April 26, the company celebrated its Broadway debut when "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues," a joint production with two other nonprofit theaters, was picked up by a consortium of commercial producers and reopened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.
A week later Crossroads learned that it had won one of theater's highest honors: the Tony for outstanding regional theater. On top of that, "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" received four Tony nominations, including one for best musical.
The Crossroads story is one of individual and institutional persistence. Inspired by the black theater scene of the 1960's, the company survived cutbacks in Federal financing by forging relationships with New Jersey businesses and New Brunswick officials who used the arts as a cornerstone for urban renewal. Still, its success has been bittersweet: the theater's growth and prominence on a national stage coincides with a period of crisis for many other black theaters, a point brought home during the highly publicized debate in 1997 between the playwright August Wilson and the artistic director Robert Brustein on issues of race and cultural power.
The success of Crossroads does not mean that black theater is in the full bloom of health, though there are promising signs. Crossroads is the first company devoted to works by black Americans to win the Tony for regional theater since the award's creation in 1976. And it is one of only two black theater companies that belong to the League of Resident Theaters, an association of 70 leading nonprofit theaters; the Freedom Theater in Philadelphia, joined the league this year.
Nationwide, there are about 50 full-time black theater companies, said Woodie King Jr., who founded the New York-based New Federal Theater, one of the country's oldest black troupes. He said that major black companies include the New Federal, the Freedom Theater, the National Black Theater in Harlem, the St. Louis Black Repertory, the ETA Creative Arts Foundation in Chicago, Jomandi in Atlanta, the Ensemble Theater Company in Houston, and the Penumbra Theater in Minneapolis. But as Mr. King points out, today's ranks bear little resemblance to those that emerged in the wake of the civil rights movement.
"In the late 1960's," he said, "there were 45 black theaters in New York alone."
That was the vibrant scene Mr. Khan leaped into when he founded Crossroads. "The Negro Ensemble Company was strong, the New Federal was strong, the National Black Theater was strong," Mr. Khan said. "These were role models."
 
Legal Aspirations, Theatrical Passions
The son of a Trinidadian doctor and an American nurse, Mr. Khan attended Rutgers University in New Brunswick, studying law but falling in love with theater. After graduating, Mr. Khan and Lee Richardson, a classmate, set up a 60-seat theater in an abandoned warehouse on an access road at the city's edge.
They used seed money from an unlikely source, the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, a Federal jobs program. Not that there wasn't ample labor involved. At first, Mr. Khan acted, directed and cleaned the floors, a regimen that finally dulled his passion for being onstage.
"I decided the acting could be done a lot better by someone not thinking about whether the bathroom was leaking or why there weren't people in the seats," he said.
Instead Mr. Khan became an astute player as a director and producer, raising money and connecting with local government leaders, talents that served his company well when Federal funds dried up in the 1980's. Mr. Richardson left the company in 1987.
While many black theaters, including the acclaimed Negro Ensemble, failed or lost steam, Crossroads grew into an institution with a budget of more than $3 million. It has reduced its debt to $600,000 from $1.7 million in 1995.
The company resides in a handsome 320-seat theater in the heart of New Brunswick built in 1991 for $4 million by a partnership of local government and private benefactors. About 65 percent of the company's audience is African-American, Mr. Khan said, a substantial increase since the theater's early days. The artistic roster is also integrated; for example, works by the playwrights Romulus Linney, who is white, and Migdalia Cruz, who is Puerto Rican, were presented in the theater's new play series in March.
Volunteers prepare food and greet audience members nightly. Kente cloth and African artifacts decorate the walls and music fills the lobby. High-profile fans include Bill Cosby and Gen. Colin L. Powell.
"Being outside a major media center has been to their benefit because they haven't had to fight for attention," Mr. King said. "And being in a city where Johnson & Johnson is based doesn't hurt either."
Crossroads gets support from Johnson & Johnson and other pharmaceutical companies in New Jersey. The Schering-Plough Corporation in Madison, sponsored the theater's annual new play festival this year. Other major corporate supporters include the AT&T Foundation and Absolut Vodka.
Since the mid-1980's, the theater has grown artistically, too, attracting young talents like George C. Wolfe, who developed "The Colored Museum" at Crossroads in 1986. Three years later, Mr. Wolfe returned to work on "Spunk."
"I'm sure I required a lot as an artist," Mr. Wolfe said, "and they provided it."
Productions in recent years have included new plays by Mr. Wilson ("Jitney") and Ruby Dee ("The Disappearance").
The company's breakthrough production came in 1989, when it presented the world premiere of "Sheila's Day," performed by a collaboration of South African and American actresses. The play, about the parallel journeys of a black South African woman and a black woman in the American South, traveled to Washington, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and South Africa.
"Sheila's Day" piqued the interest of many theater professionals, said Chris Jones, chairman of the regional theater committee for the Tony Awards. "That's when people began noticing and talking about Crossroads," he said.
His committee was also impressed by the company's "specificity of mission," he said, as well as its programs, like internships that enroll students from traditionally black colleges.
While the overt political meaning of "Sheila's Day" earned the theater some acclaim, it was nothing compared with the publicity generated by a fervent debate over its general role in black theater.
It began in 1996 during a national theater conference in Princeton, N.J., where Mr. Wilson pointed out in a keynote address that Crossroads was then the only black theater company in the League of Resident Theaters. This, Mr. Wilson said, reflected a lack of support for professional African-American theaters, and he argued that what African-American artists needed most was not roles in plays produced by predominantly white theater companies, but theater companies and stages of their own.
"The things Wilson said are things people wanted to say for so long," Mr. Khan said. "And people roared with enthusiasm because he said it. They might not agree with all of it, but at least he said it."
But some believed that Mr. Wilson's message smacked of separatism. The most prominent critic was Mr. Brustein of the American Repertory Theater in Boston. The debate culminated in a sold-out discussion between the men at Town Hall in Manhattan, an event that many felt clarified little.
Looking back, Mr. Khan is typically sanguine: "It was wild, it was glorious. But it's not like we'd been thrust into the middle of something. We were already in it. It's just someone pointed a light on it."
 
A Welcoming Stage For Black Talent
For black theater artists, Crossroads' status as a national player was established long before the Brustein-Wilson debate.
Ron Taylor, the creator of "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues," said that without Crossroads, the show could have easily died two years ago. After three years of sporadic touring of high schools, small town auditoriums and regional theaters, "Blues" had lost its main financial backer, the Denver Theater Center.
"I got on the telephone and started calling," Mr. Taylor said. One of the people he called was Mr. Khan, whom he had never met, but knew by reputation.
"Rick said, 'I love this show,' " Mr. Taylor recalled, adding that Mr. Khan hadn't actually seen it yet. "He said, 'If you can get it to the East Coast, I think we can get it to New York.' "
Working with the artistic directors of the Alabama Shakespeare Festival and the San Diego Repertory Company, Mr. Khan helped arrange a tour, with a three-week run at the New Victory Theater in Manhattan in March. The New Victory sold out.
One important factor leading to the Broadway run was Mr. Khan's long friendship with Eric Krebs, a commercial producer who lives near Crossroads and has been a longtime supporter. Mr. Krebs assembled a group of other investors to move the show from the New Victory to the Beaumont, where sales have been promising.
Still, Mr. Khan said he had no intention or time to rest on his laurels. He has a three-year plan to eliminate the theater's debt, a mission he hopes the regional theater Tony will help. Mr. Khan would also like to build an endowment for the theater.
Artistically, too, Crossroads is looking to expand. Nurturing new theater about African-American life continues to be the goal; what that means, however, is changing.
"Our existence is not defined anymore by what it is to be black in America, but to be black in the world," Mr. Khan said. "You spend a lot of time on black and white and it starts to restrict you. Black people are redefining who we are. Theater can do that too."

HEADLINE: Home Sales Unexpectedly Rose in April

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes unexpectedly rose in April to the second-highest level ever, driving prices to a record high and giving Federal Reserve policy makers another reason to consider raising interest rates, Government figures showed today.
Sales surged 9.2 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 978,000 units, the Commerce Department reported. That topped analysts' forecasts for a 1.5 percent decline and came after an eight-tenths of a percent decrease in March. 
 Rising mortgage rates contributed to the April increase, builders and economists said.
Average rates for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose to 7.23 percent last week, up from about 6.8 percent at the start of the year and a three-decade low of 6.49 percent last October.
The median price of new homes rose 3 percent in April, to a record $159,500 from $154,800 in March, Commerce Department figures showed. That is 7.8 percent higher than a year earlier.
Rising prices do not necessarily mean buyers are being priced out of the market. With a 7.23 percent mortgage on a $159,500 home, a buyer would pay $1,086 a month in principal and interest costs, compared with a $1,007 payment at 6.49 percent.
The rise in home sales "will be one more piece of the puzzle that says to the Fed it's appropriate" to raise interest rates, said Diane Swonk, deputy chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago. "The strong home sales keep generating additional spending, and this just puts that much more in the pipeline."
Just last week, Mr. Greenspan indicated policy makers were watching the housing boom's effect on the rest of the economy. "The home sales market is a critical factor of what's going on in retail sales," he said in a speech to the National Retail Federation.
April's sales level was second only to November's record pace of 958,000 homes. So far this year, home sales have averaged an annual rate of 921,000. If sustained, that would exceed last year's record 886,000 homes sold.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Slip but Rebound; Nasdaq Up, Other Gauges Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks slumped in early trading yesterday but rebounded somewhat after bargain hunters stepped in to scoop up shares of Internet and other high-technology issues. By the close, the Nasdaq composite index had reversed course and posted a solid gain, but the other main gauges were flat.
Once again, concern about higher interest rates dominated trading, analysts said. A report showing that sales of new homes surged unexpectedly in April was the latest in a series of reports suggesting that the economy continues to grow at an unsustainably fast pace and that the Fed will most likely raise rates. 
 "Interest rate fears are the big problem," said Kenneth Ducey, director of trading at BT Brokerage, a unit of Bankers Trust. "People are very nervous" that the Fed or the fixed-income market may tighten credit. A key report on the nation's employment situation is set to be released tomorrow.
However, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said nothing bearing on rates in a lunchtime appearance in Boston, and the markets seemed to take that as a cue to rally.
One exception was brokerage stocks, which continued to reel from Merrill Lynch's announcement of a new on-line trading service. Merrill finished down 4 9/16, to 70 11/16, after two analysts cut earnings estimates for next year. Nasdaq, which is dominated by computer and other high-technology issues, finished with a gain of 20.38 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 2,432.41. At its low, just after noon, the loss was more than 47 points.
The Dow Jones industrial average, meanwhile, ended 18.37 points lower, or two-tenths of a percent, to 10,577.89, after being down nearly 132 points before the comeback. Eighteen of its 30 components lost ground while 12, mostly cyclical issues, rose.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.55 point, to 1,294.81, but advancing stocks barely surpassed declining ones, 243 to 241, with 16 unchanged.
Despite the recent wide swings, the Chicago Board Options Exchange's volatility index has been remarkably subdued, according to Lawrence D. Cavanagh, an options strategist at Value Line. With a decline of 1.69 points yesterday, the index stands at 26.23, far below this year's high approaching 35 in mid-January. "Option premiums have not jumped the way they usually do" when the investment tide turns, Mr. Cavanagh said. "A lot of people are not terribly worried."
Stocks fell in six of the preceding eight sessions, pulling the Dow 4.6 percent below its record 11,107.19 on May 13.
"What the market continues to do is unwind the real economic fear of last year, which motivated investors to own the safest vehicles in each asset class," Greg Smith, chief investment strategist at Prudential Securities, told clients yesterday. For stocks, this was the large-capitalization growth stocks, which are unlikely to "return to the growth rates they had previously shown."
Still, inflation fears should ease and June should prove "pretty good for both stocks and bonds," Mr. Smith predicted. Some of yesterday's biggest gyrations were in Ameritrade, the on-line broker, which closed with a gain of 5 7/8, to 85 5/8, after trading as low as 73 and as high as 91 5/8. On April 14, the shares were worth more than twice as much, peaking at 188 3/8. Charles Schwab, the nation's biggest on-line broker, slumped as low as 91 1/4 yesterday before finishing at 96 1/8, down 3 3/8.
After trading as low as 151 1/2, Ebay rallied to close up 2 5/16, to 168 13/16, while Amazon.com recovered from a low of 97 1/8 and finished up 6 5/16, to 112 1/8.
J. P. Morgan lost 2 5/8, to 130 7/8, the biggest drag on the Dow, while I.B.M. had the most positive impact, rising 1 3/4, to 113 3/4.
American Home Products, which tumbled on Tuesday after announcing an earnings shortfall, recovered 1 13/16, to 53 13/16.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Flat
 By Reuters
 Another wave of strong economic data jolted Treasuries yesterday, although the losses were contained by the notion the market has cheapened enough to entice buyers.
Early in the day, Treasury yields rose to their highest levels in at least a year after the Commerce Department reported a 9.2 percent rise in new single-family home sales in April to a 978,000-unit annual rate. That topped the 890,000 rate the market had expected.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 90 22/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.92 percent, from 5.94 percent on Tuesday.
