HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Fierce Bidding War for a Five-Star Refuge in Bangkok

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 2

 BODY:
Have a drink in the tranquil lobby of the Regent Hotel here, beneath palm fronds and the hand-painted silk ceiling, and you would scarcely guess that this five-star refuge is the object of one of the most lively and improbable bidding wars in Asia.
The combatants are Goldman, Sachs & Company and an American-born Thai citizen, William E. Heinecke. Goldman owns 34 percent of the Regent and wants to buy control of the hotel. Mr. Heinecke's company, Royal Garden Resort, owns about a one-quarter stake and is determined to fend off the investment bank. 
 The battle, which began after Goldman bought its holding in the Regent two months ago, reaches a crucial stage on Thursday, when both sides are required to submit final tender offers for the 356-room hotel. Neither will disclose its next move, but Mr. Heinecke maintains that cash alone will not guarantee victory.
"There is a lot more than just money involved," he said in his office here, cluttered with model airplanes and photographs of him at the wheel of a 1966 Ferrari racing car. "This property has a bit of emotion attached to it."
In truth, the outcome of the bidding war is less significant than the fact that it is taking place at all. Bangkok is glutted with half-empty hotels. And while it has been nearly two years since the devaluation of the Thai currency set off the Asian crisis, most investors still give this country a wide berth.
"This is the first takeover battle in Thailand since the crash," said Anil Thadani, chairman of Schroder Capital Partners, a private investment firm in Singapore that owns a stake in Royal Garden Resort. "Hopefully, it marks the reawakening of investor interest in Thailand."
The battle for the Regent also demonstrates that some assets in Thailand remain valuable, even amid the economic wreckage. Although the Regent's bookings and profits swooned in 1997, rooms began filling up again last year as Goldman and other foreign investment houses sent battalions of bankers to help Thailand sort out its debt-ridden banks and companies.
Goldman, which through its real estate funds owns stakes in the Essex House in New York and the Ritz-Carlton in Laguna Niguel, Calif., first became interested in the Regent last year, when a troubled Thai investor put a 24 percent stake up for sale. That deal was snatched by Mr. Heinecke.
Goldman returned the favor in April, when Mr. Heinecke thought he had completed a deal to buy an additional 33 percent from a Japanese investor. Instead, Goldman walked away with that stake and promptly made a tender offer for the rest of the Regent's parent, the Rajadamri Hotel Company.
"You don't get an opportunity, anywhere in the world really, to buy a five-star existing property because people tend to hold them for dear life," said Henry Cornell, who supervises Goldman, Sachs's equity investments in Asia.
Mr. Cornell said Goldman's bid is superior because it is offering to buy the entire hotel at a value of $45 million. Mr. Heinecke is only willing to buy 10 percent, just enough to keep Goldman from gaining effective control.
But Mr. Heinecke has been a wily opponent. The 49-year-old entrepreneur was born in the United States, but spent the last 36 years in Thailand. He has become a tycoon here with interests from hotels and restaurants to toiletries and golf accessories. In 1991, he became a Thai citizen.
Now, Mr. Heinecke is turning his local standing into a weapon. He is casting the battle as one between a scrappy local outfit and a giant foreign interloper. The argument resonates in a country where fears of foreign colonization have risen as much of corporate Thailand has tumbled into insolvency.
"There are people who feel that some foreigners have tried to take advantage of Thailand when it was down," Mr. Heinecke said.
Pravit Rojanaphruk, an editor and columnist at The Nation, an English-language newspaper here, said: "Of course, there are fears of foreigners overrunning Thai society. But whether it is bad for Thailand is debatable. The Thais who owned the assets before didn't do such a great job."
Mr. Cornell is careful not to criticize the Regent's managers, who he insists he would retain. But he noted that the company could do more. He said Goldman would use the Regent as a base to build or buy other hotels. For starters, he envisions a new Regent on the resort island of Phuket, in Thailand's south.
"This is a spectacular company with great assets," he said. "You need someone to imbue it with strategic purpose."
Mr. Heinecke said the Regent's shareholders do not want Goldman to turn the hotel into a vehicle for speculative ventures. Among the minority shareholders are the Thai Farmers Bank, the Crown Property Bureau, the business arm of Thailand's royal family, and the King himself.
So far, Mr. Heinecke seems to be holding his own. Barely 2 percent of the shares have been tendered to Goldman. Unless it offers more money or a stronger sales pitch, it is unlikely to gain control.
Mr. Cornell does not seem ready to give up, but he complains that a simple real estate deal has become a political football. "We're not the big, bad foreign bogyman," he said. "It's not like we're going to pick the hotel up, put it on a boat, and move it to New York City."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
Stop Bombing, China and Russia Insist

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 2

 BODY:
China and Russia repeated their demand today that NATO air strikes be halted before political talks to resolve the crisis in Yugoslavia begin.
Russia's Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, spent the day meeting with China's top leaders, discussing their shared opposition to the NATO bombing campaign and their mutual desire to foster a "strategic partnership" aimed at offsetting the global dominance of the United States. 
 A joint communique issued this afternoon by Mr. Ivanov and China's Foreign Minister, Tang Jiaxuan, said, "NATO's immediate halting of military operations is a precondition of a political settlement of the Kosovo issue."
Mr. Ivanov told reporters that plans were being laid for a state visit to China by President Boris N. Yeltsin later this year, following up President Jiang Zemin's visit to Russia and an ailing Mr. Yeltsin last year.
Mr. Ivanov said that increased political, economic and military cooperation between Russia and China "will contribute to stability and the interests of the international community" by helping to create a more "multipolar world."
While Russia has advanced military hardware to sell China, the scope for economic cooperation appears to be limited.
Total trade between the countries last year was only $5.5 billion, a small fraction of China's trade with Japan and the United States.

HEADLINE: Teamsters Reach an Accord With Haulers of New Cars

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Averting a strike that would have disrupted the Big Three auto makers, the teamsters' union and trucking companies that haul new cars to dealers reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday in negotiations that were the first big test for James P. Hoffa, the union's new president.
Mr. Hoffa trumpeted the four-year contract as a major triumph for 12,800 car-haul workers, increasing their pay and pensions and providing health insurance to those who retire before the age of 65. In addition, the agreement for the first time provides coverage of prescription drugs, supplementing Medicare, for retirees 65 and over. 
 "This contract serves notice the teamsters are back," Mr. Hoffa said in a news conference yesterday morning at a hotel in Arlington, Va., where at 1 A.M. the two sides had reached agreement. "This contract sets a new standard for working people across the nation."
Mr. Hoffa's backers hope that the accord, struck 25 hours after the expiration of the old contract, is only one of many that will yield impressive wage and benefit gains like those his father, James R. Hoffa, achieved when he headed the International Brotherhood of Teamsters four decades ago.
But the new contract provided enough of a nod to management, including the lack of a raise in the first year, that the president's critics within the union were able to argue that it was in no way a home run.
Like a politician trying to put the best gloss on developments, Mr. Hoffa boasted that the union had persuaded the car haulers to surrender on two of their major demands: a lower starting pay for new car-haul workers and increased use of part-timers.
Throughout the negotiations, industry officials had argued that they needed to reduce labor costs and gain more flexibility to keep railroads and nonunion companies from increasing their share of the car-haul market. But Ian Hunter, the chief negotiator for National Automobile Transporters Labor Division, which represents 17 car-hauling companies, acknowledged that he had made numerous concessions to prevent a walkout. "We were very eager to avoid a strike," Mr. Hunter said. "And we have succeeded in one of our acknowledged obligations, to improve the financial status of our employees."
Several industry analysts said a number of factors had given Mr. Hoffa the upper hand at the bargaining table. With Detroit churning out cars at record levels, even a short strike could have greatly disrupted dealer sales, especially those of hot-selling cars. Further, the nation's low unemployment rate would have made it harder for car-hauling companies to find replacements for striking workers. And the Wall Street boom has made it easier for the industry and its benefits fund to afford more generous pensions and health coverage.
"He obviously has won some important things in this agreement," Harley Shaiken, a professor of industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley, said of Mr. Hoffa. "He went into it with important leverage. The auto makers didn't want a strike, and they leaned on their transporters."
The current average pay of the car-haul employees -- drivers and the garage workers who maintain the trucks -- is about $20 an hour. Under the agreement, which faces a ratification vote over the next few weeks, they are to receive a $1,500 lump-sum payment, rather than a raise, in the first year and then 50-cent-an-hour wage increases in years 2, 3 and 4.
Further, those with 25 years' experience will be able to retire at 55 with a $2,500 monthly pension; under the old contract, they could not receive a $2,500 pension until 57.
Mr. Hunter, the industry's chief negotiator, said the contract would increase labor costs 3 percent to 4 percent each year.
Terry Hewer, who as a business agent with Local 299 in Detroit represents 850 car-haul workers, said: "From what we've seen, it's an excellent contract. The negotiating committee did a good job meeting one of our biggest concerns, which was better pension benefits."
Mr. Hoffa declared that he had forced the industry to drop plans to use Mexican truckers to transport new cars to the United States from Mexican factories. But Mr. Hunter maintained that management had not put forward such a proposal. "We never asked to use Mexican drivers," he said, "not once."
Ken Paff, a longtime Hoffa critic who is national coordinator of Teamsters for a Democratic Union, said the contract provided for too many concessions. In particular, he cited a provision eliminating much of the overtime pay that car-haul workers now receive by working on weekends: in the Midwest and the South, the new agreement will allow companies to hire new mechanics and pay them straight time when they work on weekends, rather than time and a half or double time.
"Hoffa's brought back concessions to the teamsters," Mr. Paff said.
Detroit's Big Three welcomed the agreement. A strike of much duration at all could have cost the auto makers hundreds of millions of dollars in lost sales.
"We're very happy about it," said James Holden, DaimlerChrysler's executive vice president for sales and marketing. "You'd hate to have anything like a transportation interruption interrupt this market."
David Healy, an automobile analyst with Burnham Securities, said, "Generally car plants don't have enough space to store more than a couple days' output, so a strike would have clearly involved some plant shutdowns and some layoffs and would have whacked profits."

HEADLINE: A Boom Built on Big Wheels;
Sales of Light Trucks Drive the Auto Industry's Expansion

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

 BODY:
Craig J. Thomas stands near the end of DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s assembly line in Fenton, Mo., and waits for a spindly orange robot to lower a pickup bed to meet the rest of a Dodge Ram truck. Then, 37 times an hour, 300 times a day, he bolts the bed to the truck and waits for the next pickup to reach him.
In mid-May, he got a break from the rhythm of the robots to celebrate with other workers: the company said it would spend $435 million to expand the Ram factory. 
 "In this industry, the first thing they teach us is it is feast or famine," said Mr. Thomas, 25, who has been feasting on overtime for two years. "A truck always sells."
The auto industry is feasting, too. Flush with profits from five fat years and scrambling to keep up with red-hot demand for pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, auto makers are on an expansion binge.
In just the last month, DaimlerChrysler, General Motors, American Honda Motor and Ford Motor have announced plans for outlays of a stunning $1.54 billion to upgrade factories or build new ones. Today, G.M. is expected to say it will spend another $1 billion to build a nine-story headquarters for its car engineers in Warren, Mich.
"There's a whole lot of new capacity," said Christopher J. Benko, managing director of the Autofacts Group, a unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers. "There are probably more plants coming."
And maybe trouble, too. In effect, the industry is gambling that the economy will just keep growing. If it is wrong -- if the economy stumbles and America's love affair with new cars and trucks cools -- the industry could be stuck with huge excess capacity, leading almost inevitably to price wars, skidding profits and labor unrest.
A recession seems a remote possibility right now, with auto sales hitting a record 6.9 million in the first five months of this year, up from a robust 6.4 million for the corresponding period last year. Still, some analysts say a slump in demand is not a question of if, but when.
"When the market starts to tail off, then you'll start to hear about some of the more negative aspects and the plant closings," said Michael E. Robinet, director of forecast services at CSM Worldwide, an auto research firm in Northville, Mich. "There will be some consolidation that will have to occur."
While auto makers don't know when the economy will head south, they do know that their rivals are breathing down their necks right now. And so they are focusing on giving customers what they want.
What they want are trucks. In 1990, cars accounted for slightly more than 67 percent of new-vehicle sales, while light trucks -- which include sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups -- made up the rest. Last year, the two categories were almost neck and neck; cars made up 52.4 percent of sales and light trucks 47.6 percent.
Foreign auto makers, which have historically specialized in cars, are now counting heavily on America's truck fever, partly in response to the success of Mercedes-Benz's M-class sport utility vehicle.
Honda, best known for its dependable sedans, plans to invest $400 million to build a factory near tiny Lincoln, Ala., capable of producing 120,000 sport utility vehicles or minivans annually beginning in 2002.
"It will enable us to offer a full range of vehicles in the U.S., from small cars to light trucks," said Koichi Amemiya, American Honda's president and chief executive. "This demand has stretched our production to the limits."
In addition, Honda has said it plans to invest $30 million to increase engine-production capacity at its factory in Anna, Ohio, and another $30 million to add the capacity to build sport utility vehicles to its factory in Alliston, Ontario.
The Toyota Motor Corporation, meanwhile, is spending $500 million to expand its new $700 million Tundra pickup factory in Princeton, Ind., to enable it to build large sport utility vehicles there starting next year.
This fall, BMW will start building its X5 "sports activity vehicle" at the Spartanburg, S.C., factory where its Z3 roadsters are now built. BMW spent $600 million to expand the factory, and plans to hire 1,000 more workers to build the X5.
Ford and G.M. are hustling to meet demand, too -- or rather, in G.M.'s case, to create it. G.M. has seen its United States market share of passenger vehicles decline from 35.7 percent in 1990 to less than 30 percent last year; in a bid to reverse that slide, the company said last month that it would pay $450 million to build an assembly plant in Lansing, Mich., and $250 million for a plant producing transmissions for commercial trucks in White Marsh, Md.
Those projects come in addition to a $500 million commitment the company made last year to replace its V8-engine factory in Flint, Mich., with a V6-engine factory. Indeed, G.M. spent $21 billion to upgrade facilities in the United States between 1994 and 1998, and plans to invest $28 billion more between now and 2004.
Why the expansion drive at G.M. if sales are flagging? The company is desperate to build more popular trucks and fewer slow-selling cars. Executives are quietly planning to close inefficient factories and replace most of them with modern plants that can produce the same number of cars and trucks using half or a third as many workers.
To placate its unions, G.M.has pledged to reduce its work force through retirements, not layoffs. And it has tried to locate new plants near old ones so current employees can take the new jobs.
"In total, we will not increase our overall capacity," said Ronald L. Zarrella, president of G.M. North America. "While the Lansing plant is a car plant, the general direction of those footprint decisions will be to shift more of our mix from cars to trucks, crossover vehicles and other truck derivatives."
Alone among the big auto makers, Ford has avoided building new factories. Instead, it has managed to squeeze more production from existing plants, notably by increasing their ability to switch from one model to another. Just last week, for example, Ford said it would assemble a new luxury pickup truck, the Lincoln Blackwood, at the factory in Claycomo, Mo., where it makes its F-series pickups.
These expansion announcements come as G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler prepare for negotiations this month for a new three-year labor contract, and the United Automobile Workers is certain to demand the renewal of clauses that protect employees against layoffs.
But the U.A.W. has failed to organize workers at foreign-owned plants, and the discrepancy creates an uneven playing field. It means lower labor costs for Japanese and European auto makers in good times and bad. While U.A.W. workers are guaranteed 95 percent of their pay even if they are laid off, companies with nonunion workers would not face those high costs if they needed to shut factories down in slow times.
Right now, the U.A.W. is fighting the teamsters' union for the right to organize workers at Honda's Ohio factories. Hoping to exploit Daimler-Benz's acquisition of Chrysler last year, it is also campaigning to add Mercedes-Benz's American workers to its roster, as well as those at Freightliner, a DaimlerChrysler unit that builds heavy trucks.
In top-level sessions in Germany during DaimlerChrysler's annual shareholder meeting last month,the union accused the company of anti-labor activities and pressed it to remain neutral as the union continues its drive to represent the Alabama workers.
But even as the U.A.W. seeks to expand its influence, labor experts warn that it must cast aside its old militancy for the sake of job security for the next generation of workers.
"There is a real challenge here for labor," said David L. Gregory, a law professor at St. John's University in Queens. "To be competitive in an international economy, the unions are going to have to cooperate with management."
DaimlerChrysler's expansion of its Jeep factory in Toledo, Ohio, is a good example of the pressures the union faces. After Chrysler said it might close the aging factory and build a replacement elsewhere, workers -- and the city -- engaged in an extensive "keep Jeep" campaign.
In the end, the company decided to spend $600 million refurbishing the old factory and another $600 million to build a new one next door. But together, the two modern factories will employ just 4,900 workers, down from 5,600 in the existing factory, because they will be more efficient.
Ohio taxpayers will pay a big piece of the tab: The company won concessions from the city and state worth $232 million, or about $47,000 for each job retained. This combination has drawn fire from Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, as an egregious example of "corporate welfare" because the company won concessions in exchange for downsizing. Mr. Nader also questioned whether residents whose homes are to be demolished to make room for the factory were fairly compensated.
DaimlerChrysler makes no apologies. "The city has worked with the neighbors and I think everybody is happy now," said Gary L. Henson, senior vice president for manufacturing at DaimlerChrysler. "We're going to continue to reduce our costs as we modernize."
Because the company's trucks have proved so popular, its Chrysler unit has added 15,000 workers during the 1990's. At its Dodge Ram Quad Cab factory in Fenton, DaimlerChrysler will receive $10 million to $20 million in aid from the State of Missouri for worker training, but no tax breaks in exchange for its expansion.
DaimlerChrysler's investment has cheered the workers in Fenton. "We've been through a plant closing, the old-timers have, and we know what that means," said Randy Glover, president of U.A.W. Local 136. "Thank God people can't get enough of this Dodge truck."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The new welfare rules may be tested in the next recession.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
PROPONENTS of the 1996 welfare law are finding plenty of reasons to feel smug these days. Republican leaders held a news conference last week to proclaim a triumph after releasing a study by the General Accounting Office that showed plunging welfare rolls, soaring employment rates among former recipients and no burst of homelessness, as many of the law's opponents had predicted.
So should opponents, including several high-ranking Administration officials who resigned when President Clinton signed the Republican-sponsored bill, acknowledge they were wrong? 
 "No," says Wendell Primus, one of those officials who resigned in protest and who now works for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group in Washington. It might seem churlish to slough off all the good news, but Mr. Primus has a point. The test of the '96 act comes when the next recession hits and there will be no Federal security blanket for the first time in 60 years. In an interview this week, Mr. Primus echoed testimony he gave to Congress last week. "Many former recipients are surviving on less income today than when they were on welfare. And the number that will need to return to the rolls in the next few months or years in an effort to make up for their lost income by combining work and welfare could prove staggeringly high."
First, the good news. Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group, testified last week that the welfare law, rather than the robust economy, was a key reason "for this unprecedented decline -- now reaching 44 percent since March 1994" in caseloads. He estimates that there are almost seven million fewer people on welfare. He cites an analysis by the Federal budget office that reductions in welfare benefits were offset by "two or threefold gains in income due to work." Besides, he says, perhaps 30 percent of poor single-mother families live with nonfamily members from whom they can derive support.
The General Accounting Office adds to the cheery evaluation. Its review of studies from seven states finds employment rates of people who left welfare rolls ranging from 61 percent to 87 percent. Those are stunningly high numbers, well beyond predictions when the law was passed. By contrast, the employment rates among current welfare recipients hover around 30 percent.
Sarah Brauner and Pamela Loprest at the Urban Institute reviewed 11 studies of people who have recently left welfare and turned up another encouraging result: More than half of the employed people who left welfare worked 30 or more hours a week, nearly full time. A few of the studies found that a majority of recent welfare recipients report life is better for those who leave the rolls.
Mr. Primus presents a darker view. Incomes of single-mother families did rise before the 1996 act passed. But between 1995 and 1997, the income of the poorest 20 percent of single-mother families fell by almost 8 percent despite a fast-growing economy, a substantial increase in Federal tax credits for poor working parents and the fact that time limits on welfare benefits had not kicked in. The fall in welfare benefits overwhelmed the rise in earnings. And Mr. Primus rebuts Mr. Besharov's suggestion that the income of nonfamily members could fill in the gap. "Maybe 3 percent of the million households who lost money coped by sharing income," he said.
"I find an income loss for roughly a million families of $860 per family, which represents a decline of 15 percent," he added. "That's big."
Mr. Primus also points out that welfare rolls fell after 1995 five times more than did the number of people living in poverty. He says that Mr. Besharov exaggerates the importance of income gains reported by the Government for all female-headed families because many of those families were not poor. In one study, only 35 percent of those who left welfare earned as much as $12,000 a year, and even that level falls short of the poverty level for a family of three by about $1,000. A Wisconsin study showed that between a third and a half of those who left welfare for good had income above the poverty level.
The Urban Institute study concludes that most people who leave welfare "report having incomes that are lower than or similar to their combined earnings and benefits before exit." Its review also shows that only about half to two-thirds of people who leave welfare receive Medicaid benefits and only about half receive food stamps even though the welfare law did not withdraw these benefits. Participation rates for those who leave welfare are much lower than among those who continue on welfare. About a third of the families who leave report problems paying for food and utilities.
Mr. Primus focuses on another threatening statistic. In Maryland, about 20 percent of welfare recipients returned to the rolls after 3 months. In Wisconsin, about 30 percent returned after 15 months. "The issue of families needing to return to welfare will become more important as increasing numbers of recipients reach their time limit on aid and returning to the rolls will no longer be an option for them," he said.
The data behind any evaluation of the welfare-to-work programs are skimpy. Few states have conducted reliable surveys. "We could draw no conclusion about the status of most families that have left welfare," the General Accounting Office says. But Mr. Primus and others provide enough cautionary tidbits to make the case that "considerable caution ought to be exercised before pronouncing welfare reform an unqualified success."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As the Euro Falls, Some in Europe Fault German Growth and Leadership

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 2

 BODY:
During his campaign a year or so ago to reassure anxious Germans about adopting a new European currency, then-Chancellor Helmut Kohl insisted at almost every opportunity that the euro would be "as strong as the Deutsche mark."
But now, five months after the euro's well-publicized debut, the original fear has proved almost exactly wrong. It is not the euro that is dragging down Germany, but German issues that are dragging down the euro. 
 Having dropped nearly 12 percent against the dollar since its introduction on Jan. 4, the European single currency reached a new low here today of $1.0327, settling later in New York at 1.0355, and is inching ever closer to the economically insignificant but politically mortifying level of 1-to-1.
The euro's plunge has ignited a round of finger-pointing between European political leaders and European central bankers, who met today and refused to intervene on behalf of the currency.
But it has also put the spotlight on Germany, which accounts for one third of the 11-nation euro zone's total output, and on its Social Democratic Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder.
Otmar Issing, the European Central Bank's chief economist and a former top official at the German central bank, said this week that Germany was in danger of becoming "the sick man of Europe."
Economic growth is running well below 2 percent, slower than any other euro zone country but Italy. Its exports are languishing, investment capital is heading overseas and unemployment remains stuck above 10 percent.
And at the center of all that is a continued paralysis over reducing Germany's high tax rates and making its rigid work rules more flexible.
"It is not the Portuguese, the Spanish, the Irish or the French that are pulling down the value of the common currency," wrote Oliver Schumacher on the front page of today's issue of Die Zeit, the influential German weekly. "No, it is above all the Germans."
The political implications are profound. Mr. Schroder, who is playing host at a meeting of European heads of government on Thursday in Cologne, had hoped to produce a common declaration on plans to fight unemployment.
But he was unable to reach agreement with France, and the meeting will in any case be overshadowed by the euro's decline and by deliberations over the war in Yugoslavia.
He and many other economists have harshly criticized Mr. Schroder's unwillingness to push for deep economic changes -- much deeper cuts in social spending, corporate tax rates and regulation.
Thanks in part to the Yugoslav war, which has given Mr. Schroder the image of a refreshingly tough leader on foreign policy, the Chancellor's popularity has climbed in recent polls.
But the economic problems have ignited a new wave of criticism about what his detractors call a rudderless leadership.
To be sure, the euro has other problems. Investors were rattled last week when European finance ministers agreed to let Italy run a slightly higher budget deficit than it had originally promised. The war for Kosovo underpins such pessimism.
But most economists agree that German stagnation is the biggest problem. More than anything else, they say, the euro's decline stems from a glaring contrast between slow growth in Europe and the continuing surge of the United States economy.
And that disparity stems primarily from Germany as well as Italy, which together account for about half of the euro zone's economic activity.
France's output is growing at an annual rate of more than 2 percent. Many smaller European countries -- Finland, the Netherlands, Spain, Portugal and Ireland -- are growing well above 3 percent annually, overcoming problems caused by the Asian financial crisis and its aftermath.
"The United States, with its high degree of flexibility, has managed to get through the problems fairly well and so did some of the smaller countries" in Europe, said Thomas Mayer, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs here. "But Germany has not."
German Government officials dismissed such criticism today, arguing that the euro's decline was not a problem in itself and that German growth would accelerate.
"I am confident of a pickup in the second half of the year," Economics Minister Werner Muller, said in an Italian newspaper interview.
A weak euro does give Europe a lift because exports become cheaper and therefore more competitive in the American and other foreign markets. But the euro's decline also undermines its credibility and puts the European Central Bank in an increasingly difficult position.
Precisely because European growth has slowed so sharply, the central bank cut its base-line interest rate to 2.5 percent from 3 percent early in April. If the bank now tried to defend the currency by raising rates, it would very likely slow European economies further. Bank officials also argue that attempts to intervene in world money markets would almost certainly be futile.
Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, appeared tired and impatient with reporters' questions about the euro's decline after a board meeting here today.
"These very short-term volatile movements in exchange rates -- I'm inclined to play them down," Mr. Duisenberg said. But other board members, notably the outgoing president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, have in the last few days said that they are unhappy about the euro's fall.
Mr. Duisenberg tried to dampen expectations about intervening in world markets, but he left himself room for maneuvering.
"I will comment on intervention when it is necessary to do so," he said, adding that "the issue of intervention was discussed only to the extent that we spoke about what I should say when a question comes on the issue of intervention."
The key question, though, comes back to Germany and Mr. Schroder. Gerhard Grebe, an economist here with Bank Julius Baer, said investors were closely watching what his new Finance Minister, Hans Eichel, would propose in its next round of tax reforms, due on June 30.
"The new Government created a lot of uncertainty that damaged the relationship with the corporate sector," Mr. Grebe said. "If Eichel comes up with really substantive cuts in corporate rates and real relief, then everybody will realize there is a change in public policy."
But so far, Mr. Schroder has shown little willingness to challenge the orthodox socialist wing of his Social Democratic Party on some major policy issues. Indeed, he has ignited a new round of protests from industry groups by pushing through laws that remove the tax-free status of people in low-paying part-time jobs.
"There has been a complete failure to act on structural reforms," said Stephen Bell, an economist at Deutsche Bank Securities. "Indeed, they've been marching in the other direction."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Files Lawsuit Challenging Tax Repeal

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sued the state yesterday in an attempt to reverse the commuter tax repeal, saying that state lawmakers should have asked the city's permission before abolishing the tax last month.
The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, charges that the state cannot eliminate taxes that feed the city treasury without a request, known as a home-rule message, from the Mayor and the City Council. It also charges that the State Legislature violated its own rules by rushing the repeal through, and that it failed to amend the city's administrative code to reflect the repeal. 
 "We are going into this lawsuit in a very optimistic fashion," said Michael D. Hess, the city's Corporation Counsel, who joined Mr. Giuliani in an afternoon news conference at City Hall. "We want to retain that money for the good uses that the city will put it to."
The city's lawsuit came a day after elected officials in New Jersey and Connecticut filed their own legal challenges to the commuter tax repeal, which applies only to residents of New York State. Those suits charged that the Legislature acted unconstitutionally by abolishing the tax for New Yorkers but not for commuters from other states.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said in response to the lawsuit, "We are confident that this $210 million tax cut will be upheld and provide another important boost to the economy." And State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Nassau County Republican who sponsored the repeal, said the suit was "simply without merit."
Mr. Skelos said the state did not need the city's approval to pass the repeal because city residents do not pay the commuter tax. He also said that "the power of taxation is vested with the State Legislature," and that "the power to create the tax carries with it the inherent power to repeal that tax."
Mr. Giuliani has been railing against the repeal for weeks, saying that commuters should help pay for city services and complaining that the unexpected loss of revenue would force him to scale back tax cuts for city residents. The repeal will cost the city at least $210 million a year, and if New Jersey and Connecticut succeed in their lawsuits, the loss will increase to $360 million a year.
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, joined Mr. Giuliani in filing the suit, as did Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller; Mark Green, the Public Advocate, and Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President.
The Mayor and the Speaker have complained that the commuter tax repeal has hindered their progress in negotiating a new budget, which the Council is legally required to adopt by June 5. Both sides have said the sudden loss of revenue would force them to jettison many of their own tax cut proposals, including reductions in several business and sales taxes.
With the deadline for adopting a budget looming, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone are still arguing over how much to spend on stadium and school construction, which taxes to reduce and whether to restore cuts to libraries, museums and community programs, people familiar with the negotiations said yesterday. The Mayor's budget plan includes $166 million in cuts to those institutions and programs, but the Council wants to restore those cuts and provide even more money.
The Mayor and the Speaker made little progress toward an agreement in a meeting yesterday afternoon, one official said. But aides to both men said they still believed an agreement could be reached by early next week. Meanwhile, both leaders are trying to focus public attention on the loss of the commuter tax revenue, and how it will affect the city's $35 billion budget.
"We are very disappointed that the leadership in Albany decided to play the game of politics without inviting the people they were playing against to participate," Mr. Vallone said yesterday. "This lawsuit is the last hope that we have of saving the city of New York from a $400 million rip-off every single year."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Clinton, in Air Force Address, Warnes Milosevic to 'Cut His Losses' and Accept NATO's Terms

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 2

 BODY:
President Clinton today urged Slobodan Milosevic to "cut his losses" by bending to allied demands for ending the NATO attacks on Yugoslavia.
The alternative, Mr. Clinton warned the Yugoslav President, is the military and economic devastation of Serbia. 
 In an address to the 944 graduates of the Air Force Academy in Falcon Stadium here, Mr. Clinton asserted again that the NATO air campaign is grinding down the Serbian army and vowed that it would prevail if the allies and their people do not grow weary of the costly operation, now in its 10th week.
"Day by day, night by night, our air campaign is succeeding," Mr. Clinton told the newly commissioned second lieutenants in their new blue-and-white uniforms. "There is a clear choice before the Serbian leader: He can cut his losses now and accept the basic requirements of a just peace, or he can continue to face military failure and economic ruin on his people. In the end, the outcome will be the same."
Mr. Clinton also formally announced a NATO plan to dispatch about 50,000 troops to the Balkans to escort more than 800,000 refugees back to their homes in Kosovo after the conflict ends. The United States will contribute 7,000 troops, Mr. Clinton said.
Administration officials said it had not been determined precisely what forces the United States would contribute, but they said the contingent would include armed troops trained for combat as well as engineering units to clear mines, build roads and provide shelter.
With the snow-frosted summit of Pike's Peak as a backdrop, the President responded to critics in the United States and Europe who say the removal of human-rights observers from Kosovo and the beginning of the air attacks in March touched off Mr. Milosevic's expulsions of non-Serbs from Kosovo, the province in southern Serbia.
The President said the assaults on the Kosovars were planned for months before the allied air strikes began. He said that Mr. Milosevic had driven thousands of Kosovars of Muslim descent from their homes last fall, and that Serbian troops had massacred civilians in Rajac in January.
"Ethnic cleansing in Kosovo was not a response to bombing," Mr. Clinton said. "It is the 10-year method of Mr. Milosevic's madness. Had we done nothing, the tragedy would have been permanent, accepted and in effect condoned by the world community.
"He could not be prevented, therefore, from driving the Kosovars from their land. But he can be prevented from keeping them out of their land. His 10-year cleansing campaign will end once and for all."
By tradition, the President addresses the graduates at one of the four military academies each year, on a rotating basis. Mr. Clinton also spoke here in 1995.
In 1997 Mr. Clinton used his address at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., to emphasize the benefits of the expansion of NATO to include Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. He said NATO's growth would insure a more stable and peaceful Europe and noted that many ethnic and border conflicts in eastern and southern Europe had been resolved since the end of the cold war.
"That in turn," Mr. Clinton told the new Army officers then, "makes it less likely that you will ever be called to fight in another war across the Atlantic."
Two years later, at today's Air Force Academy commencement, Mr. Clinton announced the planned deployment of the 7,000 Americans to the Balkans. He also saluted two academy graduates who are flying missions in the region.
"I am very proud of them and very proud of you for following in their tradition," Mr. Clinton told today's graduates.
Mr. Clinton repeated pledges of reconstruction aid for Albania, Macedonia and other nations that have borne the tide of refugees from Kosovo.
He said the United States and its European allies have moral and strategic interests in bringing peace and prosperity to the poorest corner of Europe. He even promised help to rebuild Serbia after the war "if, but only if, it practices democracy, respects human rights and has leaders who uphold the basic standards of human conduct."
He did not condition that aid on the overthrow or departure of President Milosevic. But Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary, said, "It's hard to see a role for someone like Milosevic in a democratic Serbia."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Federal Jury Deadlocked In Genentech Patent Case
A Federal jury deadlocked in a lawsuit contending that Genentech had infringed a University of California patent in developing its first big product, human growth hormone.
The deadlock represented a narrow escape for Genentech because the panel vote was 8 to 1 in favor of the university, according to the jury's foreman. The university said it would ask for a new trial. Page C10. 

Germany Scrutinized as Euro Slides
Having dropped more than 10 percent against the dollar since its introduction at the beginning of the year, the euro hit a new low, dragged down in large part by Germany's languishing economy. The plunge has ignited a round of finger-pointing between European political leaders and European central bankers, but it has especially put the spotlight on Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro-zone's total economic output, and its new left-of-center chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder. C6.
 
Bank Reviews Deal With Robertson
The Bank of Scotland is reviewing its joint telephone and Internet banking venture with Pat Robertson, the conservative American television evangelist, after criticism from depositors. Responding to Scottish disapproval of him, Mr. Robertson once called Scotland a "dark place." C4.
 
Auto Sales Increased 5.3% in May
Auto executives were exuberant about May car and truck sales, which rose 5.3 percent and continued to propel the industry toward its best year ever despite weak monthly results from General Motors. For the first five months of 1999, buyers have snapped up 6.9 million cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks. C20.
 
Stocks Drop Early, Then Rebound
Stocks slumped in early trading but rebounded after bargain hunters scooped up shares of Internet and other high-technology issues. The Nasdaq composite index gained 20.38 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 2,432.41. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 18.37 points lower, or two-tenths of a percent, at 10,577.89. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.55 point, to 1,294.81. C8.
 
A Contract for Car Haulers
The teamsters' union and companies that haul new cars to dealers have reached a tentative agreement, averting a strike that would have disrupted the Big Three auto makers. A18.
 
Sales and Prices of New Homes Rise
Sales of new homes unexpectedly surged 9.2 percent in April to the second-highest level ever, driving prices to a record high. Sales rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 978,000 units, exceeding forecasts for a 1.5 percent decline. The median price of new homes rose 3 percent in April, to a record $159,500 from $154,800 in March. That is 7.8 percent higher than a year earlier. C9.
 
Verdict Still Out on Welfare Law

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Increased by 5.3% in May

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 2

 BODY:
Auto executives were exuberant today as May's car and truck sales propelled the industry toward its best year ever.
Despite weak results from the General Motors Corporation, the industry's sales rose 5.3 percent in May compared with results in the period a year earlier, when sales were also stellar. Last month's seasonally adjusted annual sales rate of 17.3 million was surpassed only by a rate of 17.8 million set in December 1986. Anything more than an annual rate of 15 million rate is considered strong. 
 For the first five months of 1999, buyers have snapped up 6.9 million cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks, well ahead of the 6.4 million they bought in the first five months of 1986 -- the industry's best sales year.
"May was a blockbuster sales month for Ford and the industry -- stronger than we expected," said Robert Rewey, the Ford Motor Company's group vice president for marketing, sales and service. "A record year is within reach."
Ford sales rose 8.1 percent, to 379,153 vehicles. Light-truck sales climbed 5.8 percent, while car sales rose 11.5 percent. The results exclude Volvo, which Ford bought earlier this year.
"Consumers are responding to strong economic fundamentals -- growth in jobs and income, low inflation and interest rates, as well as innovative products," Mr. Rewey said. "We believe those fundamentals will keep U.S. auto sales healthy for the rest of 1999."
Chrysler, the American unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G., had its best month ever. "We're thrilled with the performance for the month," said James P. Holden, executive vice president for sales and marketing at DaimlerChrysler. "It's been a great five months." He predicted the industry would exceed the record of 16.1 million vehicles sold in 1986.
DaimlerChrysler's sales rose 5.9 percent, to 264,732, with car sales up 1.5 percent and sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks up 7.7 percent. The company's Mercedes-Benz unit saw its sales rise 6.8 percent, to 16,732.
The industry's sales gains came despite a 4.4 percent sales decline last month at G.M., compared with its sales in May 1998.
"The market this month once again was really hot," said Roy S. Roberts, vice president and group executive for North America vehicle sales, service and marketing at G.M., which sells more cars and trucks in the United States than any other company. So far this year, G.M.'s sales are running 1.3 percent higher than they were in the first five months of last year.
G.M.'s car sales dropped 6.7 percent, while its sales of sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks fell 1.9 percent. Most of the declines came from Chevrolet, G.M.'s largest division, where sales fell 11.4 percent. Sales of full-size sport utility vehicles like the Suburban, the Chevy Tahoe and GMC Yukon were so weak that G.M. executives are considering whether to offer rebates on them to bolster sales.
The Toyota Motor Corporation said its sales rose 4.7 percent, to 142,625, in May compared with results in the period a year earlier, and an executive there said the industry's sales pace seemed to have climbed to a new level. "There seems to be a developing consensus that this is a new plateau, not merely a surge," said Yale Gieszl, executive vice president at Toyota Motor Sales.
The Honda Motor Company's sales rose 6 percent, to 98,158, last month, with sales of pickup trucks, minivans and sport utility vehicles jumping 42.6 percent because the Odyssey minivan is proving so popular. Car sales inched up four-tenths of 1 percent.
Five years of strong sales, which seem to be only getting stronger, have prompted Honda and many other auto makers to announce plans to build new factories or expand existing factories.
Particularly because sales have been so strong this year, auto makers were relieved to learn today that the teamsters' union and the vehicle-transport companies that deliver new cars to showrooms had averted a strike by agreeing to a new four-year contract. Page A18.
"With the threat of a car-transporter strike behind us, we are looking forward to a strong summer selling season," said Dick Colliver, executive vice president of American Honda.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Scalping Law Trims Wallets Of Knick Fans

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IF you wanted to see the Knicks play the Pacers in Indianapolis Tuesday night, you could have bought a seat for $65 from a ticket broker. But if you'd like to see them play this weekend in Madison Square Garden, expect to pay at least $250.
One possible explanation for this price difference is that New York is a much bigger city with more affluent fans competing for seats. But you find a similar gap even when you compare New York with Los Angeles, another metropolis with lots of wealthy fans. 
 During the first two rounds of the basketball playoffs, when the Lakers were still in contention, brokers were selling tickets to games in Los Angeles for $50. The cheapest seats available in New York during those earlier rounds cost three to four times as much.
Why so much more? Perhaps the main reason is that so many politicians are determined to protect us. Unlike California and Indiana and most other states, New York outlaws ticket scalping, and Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has just issued an inch-thick report demanding even stiffer penalties for scalpers.
New York's law, which was renewed this week by the Legislature, makes it illegal to resell a ticket for more than 10 percent above the face value. Ticket brokers have evaded the law by operating in New Jersey and Connecticut, but they still run the risk of prosecution if they make a deal with anyone in New York. These restrictions on the legal flow of tickets have fostered black market practices and prices.
By contrast, people in Los Angeles and Indianapolis can resell tickets for whatever they want, so the holders of season tickets to Laker and Pacer games can readily profit by selling their playoff seats to brokers. And although the brokers are legally free to charge astronomical prices, there are so many tickets on the open market that they cost less than in New York.
"The more you allow tickets to be openly traded, the more you'll see prices come down," said Stephen Happel, a professor of economics at Arizona State University at Tempe. He has seen this process firsthand in Phoenix, where he helped persuade the authorities to establish areas outside sports arenas at which licensed brokers, street scalpers and fans can sell tickets on game day at any price they want.
"New York is such an anomaly," Dr. Happel said. "Right there under the shadow of Wall Street, you're trying to turn people into criminals for buying and selling pieces of paper that are essentially no different from call options. But you can't defeat the laws of demand and supply. The more restrictions you put on selling tickets, the more you'll drive up prices, and the more you'll encourage hard-core criminals to get in the business."
The criminal results of the current law are amply documented in the report issued last week by the Attorney General. His investigators took more than four years studying brokers and box office employees to discover what was already known by economists and citizens of the old Soviet Union: when you fix the price for something below its market value, people will pay bribes to get their hands on it.
THE report says the widespread corruption should be combated by classifying box office bribery and ticket scalping as felonies. (They are now misdemeanors.) But why not eliminate the crime wave by eliminating the crime? In an interview, the Attorney General was asked why a ticket broker shouldn't be as free to set prices as, say, a real estate developer like Mr. Spitzer's father.
"You could make a theoretically powerful argument in favor of lifting price controls on tickets," Mr. Spitzer said. "But a legislative decision was made to impose the controls, and that has created an attendant problem of commercial bribery. All we're trying to do is eliminate the bribery that has become endemic in the ticket industry."
Mr. Spitzer did have some words of encouragement for New Yorkers who would like the same freedom to buy tickets as people in other states. He suggested that box offices at arenas and Broadway theaters could start selling market-priced tickets on the Internet.
"Perhaps they could eliminate the middleman," Mr. Spitzer said, "and auction off tickets on Ebay directly to consumers."
The idea is intriguing, but it's hard to imagine the local box offices doing anything so creative very soon. For now, the cheapest way to see the playoffs is to drive to Indianapolis.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Deplores the Condition of New York Public Schools

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Signaling a likely theme for her potential Senate campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday deplored the condition of New York City's public schools, asserting that they had been undermined by political infighting and underfinancing by City Hall.
In two speeches on the subject, the First Lady never mentioned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican who has also expressed interest in running for the Senate next year. But her remarks -- at a spirited outdoor graduation at City College in Harlem and at a $500-a-plate Democratic fund-raising luncheon at Tavern on the Green -- clearly invoked the public battling between Mr. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and suggested that it was ruinous for the school system. Mrs. Clinton left little doubt that if she runs, she would attempt to make Mr. Giuliani's stewardship over the city's schools a central issue. 
 "We can never lift up our public schools -- or the students they serve -- by tearing them down," Mrs. Clinton said as students rose out of their seats in applause. "We can never insure the economic future of this city or state or our nation by undermining the public education system that is at the very foundation of the American dream."
Mrs. Clinton, who has been trying in recent weeks to use her recent travels to New York as a way of establishing some connection to the state where she has never lived, cited what she said was the motto for Public School 1 in Manhattan: "All children can learn -- no exceptions, no excuses."
"We can do this if we will stop pointing fingers and instead use our hands to roll up our sleeves and get to work together," she said.
Mr. Giuliani's aides have been expecting this line of attack, and some Democrats believe that the Mayor's recent criticism of Dr. Crew, whose appointment he had strongly supported, was a calculated effort to distance himself from problems in the schools. And Mr. Giuliani lingered at the lectern at City Hall when the topic came up yesterday, brushing away Mrs. Clinton's criticism as he sought to turn the discussion back to what his aides want to be the central subject of the campaign: her residency.
Asked if he viewed the speech as an attack on his education policies, Mr. Giuliani responded: "Well, I'm glad she found her way there. Next question."
When a reporter pressed him on the subject, he said: "I think that it's nice to see that she's finding her way around New York. Maybe I'll travel to Arkansas."
The crosstown exchange offered an early glimpse of the intensity that might accompany a contest between the two. The election to succeed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who is retiring, is not until November 2000. But the rows of television cameras recording Mrs. Clinton's speech suggested the fierce interest that the hint of such a race has stirred, even though neither Mr. Giuliani nor Mrs. Clinton has announced that they are actually running.
Mrs. Clinton's remarks appeared sharper in tone that most of her recent speeches in New York, which have tended to offer broader discussions about the problems facing the nation. Her commencement speech contained passages that sounded very much like a political stump speech, complete with the kind of sharp, pungent sentences that are likely to find themselves onto the evening news.
The speech came one day after she spent 90 minutes meeting with Hank Morris, the Democratic consultant who helped run the successful campaign of Senator Charles E. Schumer last year. Mrs. Clinton's criticisms of the public school system yesterday were evocative of Mr. Schumer's attacks on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato last year.
"No one wins, especially our children, if our schools are plagued by poor test scores and performance, by low expectations and social promotions," Mrs. Clinton declared, not mentioning that Mr. Giuliani is, in fact, a strong opponent of social promotion, the practice of allowing even failing students to go on to the next grade. "No one wins, especially our children, if politics takes up much needed seats in the classrooms."
Mrs. Clinton said she would support more money for early education and teacher training, as well as spending to improve run-down schools and to reduce class size.
She received a huge ovation as she entered the courtyard where City College was holding commencement exercises for 3,034 students. Spectators who caught sight of her, dressed in a black and lavender robe, shouted, "Yo, Hillary!" and "You go, girl!"
Mrs. Clinton turned and smiled.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
MOSCOW AND WEST MAKING HEADWAY ON A KOSOVO PLAN

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 2

 BODY:
Russia and the West narrowed their differences today over the measures required to end the war in Kosovo, limiting the room for President Slobodan Milosevic to maneuver and increasing the pressure on him to reach a settlement.
"We have found a common approach," said Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Russian envoy to the Balkans, after a marathon negotiating session in Bonn with American and European officials that went on through much of Tuesday night and ended only this afternoon. 
 A senior Administration official said "common approach" was a bit of an overstatement. Nevertheless, the official added, the unity of purpose was sufficient to justify a visit to Belgrade late today by Mr. Chernomyrdin and the Finnish President, Martti Ahtisaari, who is representing the European Union.
The envoys presented a draft accord to President Milosevic, who said he would continue talks with them early Thursday.
European diplomats said Russia had agreed for the first time that all Yugoslav forces -- army, police and paramilitary -- should withdraw from Kosovo and that the withdrawal be substantially under way before any pause in NATO bombing. Perhaps a few hundred soldiers could return, but only after the deployment of a 50,000-strong international resettlement force, which would include 7,000 Americans.
But the West and Russia remain apart on the composition and the command structure of the force: Russia is holding out for United Nations control; the West insists on NATO command.
Michael Steiner, the top diplomatic adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, said diplomacy would now follow two main tracks: an attempt to secure Mr. Milosevic's agreement to the terms hammered out between the West and Russia, and an effort to pass a United Nations Security Council resolution that reflects the agreement.
The plan that was being presented to Mr. Milosevic "preserved and elaborated" NATO's demands in their entirety, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin said.
But it remained far from clear that Mr. Milosevic would agree to the newest terms, which appear closer to NATO demands than to the vague statement by the Group of Seven industrial nations and Russia on May 6, which Yugoslavia has formally accepted. That gap will be the subject of President Ahtisaari's discussions in Belgrade.
The Bonn talks between Russia and the West were unexpectedly difficult and marked by brinkmanship: Russia threatened to withdraw, and the departure of Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Ahtisaari was twice delayed at the last moment.
European diplomats said Mr. Chernomyrdin argued long and hard for a pause in the 71-day-old bombing as a gesture of good will, but was finally swayed by arguments that such a break would not make Mr. Milosevic more pliant or more ready to negotiate in good faith.
In the end, Russia agreed that the Yugoslav leader must start a substantial and verifiable withdrawal before a halt in the bombardment.
The plan specifies that Mr. Milosevic has to withdraw all his forces from Kosovo, Mr. Rubin said. "We made reasonable progress, particularly on the scope and the timing of the Serbian withdrawal," one United States official said. "The Russians have understood that for us, 'all' means 'all.' "
The plan also specifies how many days Mr. Milosevic has to show that he is complying with a "rapid and precise" timetable of withdrawal for his 40,000 troops for the allies to stop the air strikes, a senior Administration official said. The official declined to specify the number of days.
Once the Serbian withdrawal has begun in a "verifiable and demonstrable way," NATO would be willing to stop the bombing but reserved the right to resume, the official said.
Mr. Chernomyrdin summarized the talks by saying, "I think at the moment there is a realistic chance that the war will end."
Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, who has been shuttling between Washington, Moscow, Helsinki, Bonn and Brussels, said, "Increasingly the international community is speaking with one voice."
In effect, Russia and the West have shifted their area of agreement from broad principles that were vague on crucial issues to the outline of a concrete program to which Mr. Milosevic must now respond.
The principles, adopted on May 6, did not stipulate that all Yugoslav forces must withdraw, and alluded only to the deployment of "effective international civil and security presences" in Kosovo, rather than the NATO-led force on which the Clinton Administration has insisted.
It was on the question of the makeup of this force that differences with Russia proved most difficult to overcome, American officials said. "The Russians are still pushing for a United Nations-controlled operation, but after Bosnia we learned the lessons of watered-down command structures," one said.
In Bosnia between 1992 and 1995, a "dual key" system under which both NATO commanders and senior United Nations officials had to approve any military action proved unwieldy, ineffective and sometimes disastrous.
Before leaving for Belgrade, Mr. Chernomyrdin said that under a compromise reached in Bonn: "NATO will command NATO forces, Russia the Russian forces. Relations between the two contingents will be governed by separate agreements."
But Mr. Steiner, the German diplomat, said this statement should not be taken at face value. "Obviously, each politician has his constituency that has to be satisfied," he said.
Joschka Fischer, the German Foreign Minister, said, "We have some good news, but I do not want to overrate it. We have to remain skeptical until the last moment."
In fact, European and American officials said, a command structure similar to the one now governing relations between Russian and Western forces in Bosnia is being considered. This system involves a NATO chain of command, but it gives the Russian contingent there considerable latitude.
Officials said a Russian proposal that it take charge of a zone in the northern part of Kosovo while NATO countries control the southern part of the province had been rejected because it might appear to lay the basis for partition.
Mr. Steiner said it was now crucial to involve the United Nations.
"If what we have now is the basis for a solution, then we must get it legalized in the Security Council as quickly as possible," he said. "That in turn will give us the political leverage we need."
If a Security Council resolution could be passed calling for a complete Serbian withdrawal and the deployment of a large international force with a central NATO presence, as well as the return of all ethnic Albanian refugees, then the pressure on Mr. Milosevic would clearly increase further.
Western officials said that with such a resolution, a full and formal agreement from Belgrade might not be necessary. "All we would need is the absence of a rejection from Mr. Milosevic, and the withdrawal of his troops from Kosovo," one said.
But it remains unclear whether China, whose relations with the United States were soured when NATO bombers hit its Belgrade embassy last month, would agree to such a resolution and whether wording could be found that would circumvent any remaining Russian objections about the nature of the international force that would enter Kosovo.
Russia and the West have come a long way since the first days of the NATO bombing, when anger in Moscow was at fever pitch and rumors were circulating that Russian missiles had been redirected at European targets.
However the diplomacy now progresses, immense difficulties remain. Not the least is how to convince the divided Albanian leadership and the guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army that any accord with Mr. Milosevic is even remotely credible. The Serbs must also be convinced that there is a credible way to disarm the rebel army.
In addition, the West would apparently be committing itself to a vast deployment of forces and huge investment of resources in a state headed by a man -- President Milosevic -- who was indicted last week by the international criminal tribunal in The Hague on charges of war crimes.
President Ahtisaari is expected to report on the results of his talks with Mr. Milosevic at a summit meeting of European leaders in Cologne on Thursday and Friday.
President Jacques Chirac of France said today of the rapprochement between Russia and the West that it "undoubtedly opens the door to a significant chance for a political settlement."
"In this situation," he added, "I cannot really see how the Serbian authorities could refuse the solution demanded of them by the whole international community."

HEADLINE: Pakistan Frees Journalist It Held for Sedition

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 2

 BODY:
The Pakistani Government dropped sedition charges today against a journalist who has been highly critical of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and it released him after almost a month of detention and interrogation.
In recent weeks, the United States, the European Union, human rights groups and the World Bank had all strongly protested the Government's detention of the journalist, Najam Sethi, as the most outrageous example of its attempt to repress the country's press. Mr. Sethi is editor of The Friday Times, an English-language weekly in Lahore. 
 Pakistani officials had said they suspected Mr. Sethi of working for an Indian intelligence agency after he gave a speech in New Delhi on April 30 that painted a bleak picture of Pakistan's political and economic condition. Pakistan's chief envoy to India had described the speech as "contemptible treachery."
But Mr. Sethi said today after his release that he believed he was detained, not because of the speech, but because the Prime Minister was angered by Mr. Sethi's editorials, as well as Mr. Sethi's decision to give an interview to the BBC, which was investigating corruption charges against Mr. Sharif and his family.
Days before his arrest, Mr. Sethi said, a senior official close to Mr. Sharif telephoned him and accused him of conspiring with the BBC to overthrow the Government.
On May 8, the Punjab state police dragged Mr. Sethi from his bedroom in the middle of the night, beat him, blindfolded him and turned him over to the army intelligence service.
"They interrogated me about everything I've done for the last 30 years," Mr. Sethi said. "But they did not mistreat me. And at the end of the day, I believe that they informed the Prime Minister that no charges of treason could be leveled against me."
Three days ago, he said, the Government moved him from the custody of the army's intelligence service to police detention. And rather than pressing charges against him in military courts, a sedition case was filed against him in a special anti-terrorism court, charging Mr. Sethi with opposing the creation of the state of Pakistan and anti-national activities.
But today, the Government withdrew those charges during a Supreme Court hearing on a bail application for Mr. Sethi.

HEADLINE: China Opens Another Door To an Isolated North Korea

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Thursday, June 3

 BODY:
North Korea's No. 2 political leader arrived in Beijing today for the first high-level meeting between the two Communist allies in eight years, talks that will be closely watched by the United States and China's Asian neighbors.
The official, Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the Supreme People's Assembly, brought a large entourage of political, trade and military officials and may also visit Shanghai and Hangzhou. 
 Months in the planning, the talks are intended to demonstrate that the alliance between North Korea and China remains strong. They come just as the United States has made its own offers of cooperation in an effort to moderate North Korea's military and economic policies.
During the Korean War, in the early 1950's, China sent troops to help North Korea beat back the advancing Americans, and China has remained determined ever since to preserve the Communist Government there as a buffer on the Korean peninsula.
But the alliance has been a tortured one. Even though Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader at the time, visited Beijing in 1991, the relationship was deeply strained the next year when China bowed to practical reality and recognized North Korea's archenemy, South Korea, with its dynamic economy.
More recently, China has been concerned by North Korea's disastrous economic policies, which have forced China to provide large amounts of aid and could cause a social collapse, and by the North's missile tests, which have undermined China's regional security goals.
"North Korea is a troublesome ally," said Bates Gill, a military expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "But the Chinese see propping up the regime is their only real option."
In the talks this week, North Korea is expected to ask for renewed commitments of the food, energy and other aid that has helped the Government of Kim Jong Il (the son of Kim Il Sung) survive a famine and severe slowdown of its industries. The country's rigidly controlled, closed economy has never recovered from the demise of the Soviet Union and the subsidies and barter arrangements that Moscow provided.
China, in turn, is expected to press its secretive ally to moderate its behavior in areas that have threatened China's own strategic interests, appealing to North Korea not to repeat its tests of a new long-range missile. The surprise launching over Japan last fall set off alarm bells throughout East Asia and strengthened Japan's support for developing antimissile defenses with the United States -- a development seen by China as a threat.
China is also expected to urge North Korea not to develop nuclear weapons, according to a Western diplomat, who said China wants to avoid any increase of tension on the Korean peninsula.
China has long maintained scientific and technical exchanges with North Korea, but many Western experts say there is no evidence that advanced weapon technology have been handed over directly in recent years. North Korean sales of missiles to countries like Iran have been a major concern of the United States, and the extent of Chinese influence over such sales is disputed.
Chinese officials say they will urge North Korea to begin opening up its economy so it can resume development and reduce its desperate need for outside aid. But China is unlikely to pose any ultimatums that could lead to a serious break in relations or endanger the Communist Government, diplomats say.
China publicly endorses cooperation between the two Koreas and the "four party" international talks -- including Japan and the United States -- on a long-term peace settlement. At the same time, China wants to avoid a total collapse in North Korea, or other scenarios in which South Korea essentially absorbs the North: that would bring an American ally, and possibly American troops, right to China's border.
"China doesn't want U.S. forces north of the 38th parallel," said Douglas Paal, an Asia expert in Washington who served on the National Security Council during the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
Last week a former United States Secretary of Defense, William J. Perry, visited North Korea, offering economic and diplomatic benefits if the country would agree to abandon its missile and nuclear-weapons programs. There has been no official reply.
The two Koreas have also discussed resuming talks on the reunification of families and economic aid, officials in South Korea say.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Publicis Acquires Stake in Burrell

BYLINE: By Patricia Winters Lauro 

 BODY:
In another effort by a mainstream agency company to expand in the growing realm of advertising to minorities, Publicis S.A. in Paris said yesterday that it had acquired a 49 percent interest in Burrell Communications Group in Chicago, which specializes in campaigns aimed at black consumers. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. 
 Burrell, described as the largest agency of its kind in America, has 133 employees working on accounts with billings estimated at $166 million for advertisers like Coca-Cola, McDonald's, Procter & Gamble and Sears. The alliance with Publicis, the world's No. 13 agency company, with estimated billings of $6.3 billion, will enable Burrell to work with Publicis agencies such as Publicis & Hal Riney and Publicis Technology. Burrell will continue to be led by Thomas J. Burrell, chairman and chief executive.
"The future of advertising in the United States will be determined in part by its ability to reach the nation's economically powerful and culturally influential minority communities," said Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive of Publicis.
Mr. Burrell said that "the additional resources of Publicis" would enable Burrell to help "our clients on a global scale."
The deal is the first such investment by Publicis; other big agency companies that have become active in the field include Omnicom Group, True North Communications and Young & Rubicam Inc.

HEADLINE: Elderly Vote for Morality

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Shift by Older Voters to G.O.P. Is Democrats' Challenge in 2000" (front page, May 31): You report that older Americans are in better financial shape than they were 30 years ago. 
 The reason is Social Security. Without it, about half of the elderly would be poor. Two-thirds rely on Social Security for half or more of their income. Many older Americans who consider themselves middle class would be poverty stricken without Social Security. Enactment of schemes to privatize the program would push many back into poverty by offering a gambling trip to Las Vegas instead of a secure, inflation-adjusted lifetime income.
 
HELEN L. GINSBURG
Flushing, Queens, May 31, 1999

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
ANCELL, NATHAN S.

 BODY:
ANCELL-Nathan S. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are saddened by the loss of Nathan S. Ancell, a beloved leader and cherished friend who was deeply committed to the Jewish people. A compassionate humanitarian, he earned enormous admiration for his extraordinary generosity and wisdom. Through his leadership and support of UJA-Federation, he helped alleviate human suffering and enhance Jewish educational and cultural programs. An honorary officer of UJA-Federation, he formerly served as a member and honorary co-chair of our Board of Directors. He was also an honorary board chair of the Mid-Westchester YM-YWHA and a past associate board chair of the Associated YM-YWHA's of Greater New York, both beneficiary agencies of UJA-Federation. We extend our sincerest condolences to his daughters, Susan Darley and Penny Randall, and his grandchildren, Leigh, David, Edin, Jackie, Lea, and Piper. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.
ANCELL-Nathan S. The Brandeis University community mourns the death of a cherished friend. A member of our Board of Trustees for twenty-five years, Mr. Ancell truly left his mark on Brandeis. In recognition of his outstanding leadership, the University awarded him an honorary doctorate in 1990 and the Distinguished Community Service Award in 1988. His innovative mind and entrepreneurial spirit will be sorely missed. Together with his late wife, Enid, and his late sister and brother-inlaw, Florence and Theodore Baumritter, Mr. Ancell supported numerous Brandeis programs. A chair in physics, buttressed by a fellowship in physics, stands as a testament to the family's generosity and commitment to Brandeis. We extend our deepest sympathies to his daughters, Susan Darley and Penny Randall; to his six grandchildren; and to his entire family. Jehuda Reinharz, President Steve Grossman, Chairman Board of Trustees
