HEADLINE: Woman and Boy Die in East Orange Fire

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A woman and a 4-year-old boy trapped in a top-floor apartment in a burning building in East Orange, N.J., died yesterday minutes after being rescued, officials said.
A young girl and three firefighters were also injured, and 63 families were left homeless by the ferocious blaze, which destroyed the roof and top two floors in the south half of the Citadel, a broad prewar building along the once-grand main street of a city that has been struggling for decades. 
 The fire in the five-story, yellow-brick Citadel, at 176 South Harrison Street, started on the top floor just before 5 P.M. and was quickly accelerated by afternoon breezes, said Darryl Jeffries, the city's public information officer.
Within minutes the fire had burst through the building's roof, sending flames shooting into the air, and soon the fourth floor was also engulfed, Mr. Jeffries said. As firefighters scrambled to set up their equipment, a woman appeared at a top-floor window holding a child, residents said, and banged on the glass.
As water from the ground, from hoses on ladders and from firefighters on the roof of the intact half of the building cascaded all around them, firefighters ran a ladder up to the top-floor apartment, broke the windows and pulled the woman and three children, aged 4 years, 3 years and 18 months, out of the building, Mr. Jeffries said.
The 4-year-old child, James Ingram, died of smoke inhalation at University Hospital in Newark. The woman, who was 53, died of smoke inhalation at East Orange General Hospital.
A young girl was in stable condition at Orange Memorial Hospital, while a 51-year-old firefighter from Cranford was recovering at University Hospital from a head injury. Two East Orange firefighters were treated at East Orange General Hospital for smoke inhalation.
The cause of the blaze, which was declared under control at 7:30 P.M., is still under investigation. Mr. Jeffries said he believed that the building was in compliance with all fire codes, including sprinkler requirements. He said a firewall had helped confine the damage to the south half of the two-flanked building.
Of the 63 displaced families, 43 had no place to stay and were spending the night at a shelter the Red Cross set up in a middle-school cafeteria, said Walter Gramm, the chief executive of the Metropolitan New Jersey chapter of the American Red Cross. He said the families would be allowed to stay for up to a week, after which the Red Cross would try to get them more permanent quarters. He said it appeared that parts of the building would not be ready for habitation for some time.
The fire in East Orange, a suburb of Newark with about 73,000 inhabitants, comes as the city was in the midst of efforts to rehabilitate Harrison Street, a street that was once a boulevard of millionaires but that has been in decline since the 1960's.
"These apartments had butlers and maids, doormen," Mr. Jeffries said. "It was quite ritzy for its time. It's not quite that now," he said, describing today's Harrison Street as "economically and ethnically diverse" but adding that "the character of the buildings is still there."
Referring to the fire, he said, "I think the city is resilient enough to rebound."

HEADLINE: Robert Sobel, 68, a Historian of Business, Dies

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Robert Sobel, a prolific historian of American business life whose topics ranged from the economic philosophy of President Calvin Coolidge to the influence of the junk-bond financier Michael Milken, died on Wednesday at his home in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 68.
The cause of death was brain cancer, said a spokeswoman for Hofstra University, where Professor Sobel taught for 43 years. 
 Professor Sobel's first book, "The Origins of Intervention," was published in 1961, when he was a 30-year-old history instructor at Hofstra, in Hempstead, N.Y. His latest, completed as he underwent unsuccessful cancer treatments, is a study of business blunders called "When Giants Stumble," just released by Prentice-Hall Press.
Besides teaching, Professor Sobel was the author, co-author or editor of more than 50 books and hundreds of articles and corporate profiles.
Most of his books were written for a general audience, but he never bristled when some scholarly writers dismissed him as a "popularizer," said his colleague and friend George David Smith, a professor of economic history at New York University. "Quite the contrary -- he saw that as his mission in life."
Still, that did not stop Professor Sobel from taking a gentle revenge on his ivory-tower critics in 1973, with publication of "For Want of a Nail," his mock textbook recounting the history of North America had General Burgoyne won the Revolutionary War battle at Saratoga. His spoof included pompous footnotes about petty disputes among imaginary scholars and a wholly invented bibliography of ludicrously boring and arcane references -- as well as an appendix featuring a list of the "leaders of the United States of Mexico," starting with its first president, Andrew Jackson.
But his dominant passion was Wall Street, a metaphysical neighborhood that had fascinated him since childhood. "It is as though you are walking through a historical theme park, with this engaging man at your side pointing out the sights," said Andrew Tobias, the author and investment guide, in a review in The New York Times of "The Last Bull Market: Wall Street in the 1960's" (W. W. Norton, 1978).
Professor Sobel wrote two studies of the New York Stock Exchange and two books on the American Stock Exchange. Friends said he considered "The Life and Times of Dillon Read" (Dutton, 1991) to be his finest book, but he produced other notable profiles of Wall Street characters, including "Dangerous Dreamers: The Financial Innovators from Charles Merrill to Michael Milken" (John Wiley & Sons, 1993).
To that he added a history of financial panics, a history of speculative bubbles and an account of the frenzied market of the 1920's.
Richard Sylla, an economic historian at New York University, acknowledged that Mr. Sobel's "pot-boiler style" sometimes drew criticism in academic circles. "But specialized scholars could learn a lot from him -- and you are talking to one who did," Professor Sylla added.
While in graduate school, friends say, Mr. Sobel found that he loved to write. "He was a compulsive writer," Professor Smith said. "He was miserable when he was not writing."
Indeed, in an academic realm where publishing is often considered the grim alternative to perishing, Mr. Sobel's published works were only one tributary of the broad river of words he produced. Unlike most academic writers, he was happy to ghost-write business books bearing other people's names. And he collaborated on a host of biographical projects that never reached a public audience, including the privately published memoirs of Joseph Cullman, the legendary leader of Philip Morris, and an authorized biography of Louis E. Wolfson, an early pioneer in corporate takeovers who ran afoul of Federal securities regulators.
Professor Sobel was clearly less enthralled by the corporate world, but that only slightly affected his output. His corporate histories included studies of RCA, ITT, the Penn Central Railroad, the automotive industry, the tobacco industry, the Trammell Crow construction empire and two books on I.B.M.
Rounding out his bookcase were economic assessments of Herbert Hoover and Calvin Coolidge and studies of the American Revolution, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution.
Robert Sobel was born and raised in the Bronx, the son of a commercial draftsman who drew promotional posters for the Loews chain of movie theaters. He was educated at James Monroe High School and the City College of New York, and earned his master's degree in history at New York University in 1952 before enlisting in the armed forces during the Korean War.
He later told family members that he had hoped to be a military intelligence officer but was turned down because of unfounded suspicions that he was related to Morton Sobell, another City College graduate who was a figure in the spy case involving Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Instead, he served as an administrative clerk in the Army.
He returned to New York University after his discharge in 1955. He worked as a history instructor there and, starting in 1956, at Hofstra while working on his doctorate at N.Y.U. After his degree was conferred in 1957, he joined the faculty at Hofstra, where he remained for four decades.
In 1990, he was awarded the university's Lawrence Stetson Distinguished Professorship in business history, which he held until his retirement in May 1998. A memorial service will be held for Professor Sobel in September at the Hofstra campus, where flags have been lowered to half-staff in his honor.
For all the years he spent in the classroom, friends say that teaching history did not satisfy him as much as writing history -- or, indeed, writing anything.
Besides producing books, articles, book reviews, and scripts for television and audiotapes, he was a weekly columnist for Newsday from 1972 to 1988. At the time of his death he was a contributing editor to Barron's magazine. He also worked as a consultant for the Winthrop Group in Cambridge, Mass. His family says that two completed book manuscripts are scheduled for publication posthumously.
Professor Sobel is survived by his wife, Carole Ritter Sobel of Long Beach; his mother, Blanche Sobel of Riverdale; a brother, Alan Sobel of Brooklyn; two children, Barbara Sobel of Queens and David Sobel of Alexandria, La., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Gauges Mixed in Anticipation of Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Stock prices meandered to a mixed finish yesterday as traders and investors awaited today's release of the Government's monthly report on the job market, which will provide the first broad look at the economy's performance in May.
An overly robust reading, analysts think, will make it more likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates -- a development already anticipated in the futures markets -- at its two-day policy meeting later this month. 
 "People were just trying to jockey for position before tomorrow's big report," said Donald M. Selkin, chief market strategist at Joseph Gunnar & Company. "The key thing to watch is the average hourly earnings."
Word of a possible peace agreement in Yugoslavia made little impression yesterday because weeks of bombing were regarded as having played little role in the spring retreat from record highs. European markets, however, were thought likely to benefit from an end to hostilities.
Once again the Nasdaq composite index made the widest swing, but in contrast to its performance on Wednesday, it weakened in the afternoon and finished with a loss of 29.09 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,403.32, just above its low of the day. Internet stocks were among the chief casualties, with conditions so soft that at least two initial public offerings were postponed.
The Dow Jones industrial average, on the other hand, surged in the final 15 minutes of trading and ended with a gain of 85.80 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 10,663.69. American Express, the biggest contributor to the advance of the blue-chip index, gained 3 3/16 , to 121 5/8.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, meanwhile, scarcely budged, ending with a gain of 4.73 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 1,299.54, as 267 of its components rose and 212 declined.
Strong reports of May sales lifted retail stocks, with Dollar General up 3 1/16 , to 30, Wal-Mart Stores up 1 1/8, to 45 1/2, and Best Buy, whose president forecast better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, up 6 1/8, to 54.
Drug stocks, which have been out of favor recently, posted good gains despite a report that President Clinton is close to a decision involving Medicare overhaul that would allow the elderly to pay less for prescription drugs. Pfizer climbed 2 1/4, to 108 1/2, while Merck, Eli Lilly and Warner-Lambert each gained more than a point.
Shares of oil-service companies were mostly higher, with Schlumberger, which was added to the recommended list at Goldman, Sachs, rising 7/16 , to 60 7/16 , after trading as high as 62 3/16 .
Brokerage stocks continued to reel from Merrill Lynch's decision to offer low-cost on-line trading. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette slumped 2 1/4, to 57 1/8, and Knight/Trimark fell 2 5/8, to 50 5/8, but Paine Webber, which replaced Bankers Trust in the S.& P. 500 after the close, advanced 15/16 , to 42 3/4.
Zany Brainy, a retailer of toys, games and books, made its market debut with the sale of 6.1 million shares at 10. The stock traded as high as 13 1/8 before closing at 11 7/16 .
Internet stocks resumed their slide. Yahoo fell 7 1/8, to 135 3/8; At Home slumped 9 3/16 , to 105 1/4; Star Media dropped 8 11/16 , to 40 1/4; Ebay slid 7 1/2, to 161 5/16 ; Priceline.com fell 82 5/32 , to 84 1/8, and Amazon.com declined 7 1/16 , to 105 1/16 .
Volume was a moderate 733.3 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, up from Wednesday's 730.5 million, with advancing issues surpassing declining ones by 1,624 to 1,325. There were 48 new highs over the last 12 months and 45 new lows.

Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
Bond yields hovered near one-year highs yesterday as traders worried that a Government jobs report today will increase the chances that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 14/32 , to 90 8/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.95 percent, from 5.92 percent on Wednesday.
Some traders are convinced the employment report, a key barometer of the economy's strength, will persuade the Fed to raise rates.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS;
An Intellectual Guerrilla: Thabo Mbeki

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, June 3

 BODY:
As Winnie Madikizela-Mandela shouted recently to a cheering crowd in a black township: "I'm sick and tired of white-controlled media who say they don't know Thabo Mbeki. Who cares?"
President Nelson Mandela's ex-wife, whose speeches usually have vaguely threatening undertones, was unsubtly pointing out that when Mr. Mbeki takes over as President on June 16, he will govern with a huge mandate whether whites or anyone else know him or not. 
 Not that this means they need be afraid. South Africa's second post-apartheid President is someone who has no military background, is an able administrator and repeatedly pledges himself to democracy and to fighting corruption even in his own party.
His Government, Mr. Mbeki said in his victory speech today, will "approach the exercise of power without any arrogance, with humility."
If Nelson Mandela is the George Washington of this new democracy, the kind of giant among men who turns down offers to be king, then Mr. Mbeki is its John Adams. Like Adams, he is small, sharply intelligent, visionary, reflective, sometimes tart-tongued, and an adept back-room fighter.
He is also, on any occasion, the man most likely to turn up too formally dressed.
Playing on their difference in raiment, the dapper Mr. Mbeki, 56, has mused publicly on his resentment of people who constantly ask whether he can fill Mr. Mandela's shoes.
"Why should I wear those big, ugly things?" he said. "Or," he added with a shudder, "those shirts" -- meaning the bold "Madiba shirts" that Mr. Mandela adopted after a trip to Indonesia.
Mr. Mbeki intends to fit his own smaller but more meticulously polished shoes.
Born on June 18, 1942, Thabo Mbeki (pronounced TAH-boh mm-BEG-ee) grew up in poverty in Mbewuleni village in the Idutywa area of the Transkei -- the historic land of the Xhosa.
Though he grew up on the side of the valley with the rural peasantry who wore blankets and painted their faces with red clay, Mr. Mbeki was the son of radical party intellectuals who ran a small store and taught school to survive.
He was in the liberation struggle virtually from the age of 10, when he and a cousin sold Coke bottles to raise money to pay their African National Congress membership fees. The struggle eventually cost him a son, a brother and, two biographers say, any real relationship with his father, who was one of its heroes.
The father, Govan Mbeki, spent much of his life in jail and sent his children away to relatives very young so they couldn't come to depend on parents who expected to be arrested. The elder Mr. Mbeki, whose wife still lives in Idutywa, now lives in a bungalow on the grounds of his son's official mansion, but "seems sad, lonely and regretful," with "little familial warmth either in the relationship or even in Thabo's achievements," according to a new biography, "The Life and Times of Thabo Mbeki" (Adrian Hadland and Jovial Rantao, Zebra Press, April 1999).
Mr. Mbeki dislikes revealing himself. His precampaign book "Africa, the Time Has Come" is just a collection of speeches, with a dry 22-page biographical sketch.
But even the speeches reveal a great deal. His 1964 statement to a United Nations committee in London, delivered when he was a 21-year-old student asking it to somehow prevent the Pretoria Government from hanging his father, is an ennobling portrait of the elder Mr. Mbeki, touching in its combination of humility and righteousness.
His 1978 speech "The Historical Injustice" shows a piercing intellectualism as he subjects the history of South Africa to Marxist analysis, skewering the British imperialists and the Boer pioneers for corrupting even the capitalism and Calvinism they preached, regressing into feudalism, a racist version of Lutheranism and simple murder and theft because it was easier and more profitable than adopting the liberalizing trends of Europe.
And for sheer poetic power, his "I Am an African" speech, celebrating the new Constitution in 1996, surpasses even the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, which it somewhat resembles -- although Dr. King was a more riveting speaker.
He is becoming better known because biographers are probing his past; the fact that he fathered a child at 16 who disappeared 17 years later, probably at the hands of the police, has humanized him a bit. So have photos of him as a young man leaning affectionately against friends or smiling at his 1974 London wedding to Zanele Dlamini, who was studying social work and now heads a bank for rural women.
Mr. Mbeki is now seen as a politician, but he is really a lifelong intellectual guerrilla, rather than an armed one. At Lovedale Institution, a South African boarding school, he excelled at Latin, mathematics and science, but was expelled in his senior year for leading a student strike. A white teacher who recognized his erudition arranged for a scholarship to the University of Sussex in England; but he began school late because he had been arrested by the Rhodesian Government while trying to slip out to Britain without a passport.
After getting a degree in economics and backing causes from nuclear disarmament to getting the United States out of Vietnam, he was sent by Oliver Tambo, the London-based president of the African National Congress, to set up offices in Zambia, Botswana, Swaziland and Mozambique, making the white South African Government feel surrounded.
He became one of the public faces of the dissident group, meeting reporters and accompanying Mr. Tambo on diplomatic trips to Moscow, Washington and other capitals. In the 1980's, when white executives and prominent Afrikaners defied their Government to meet the African National Congress in exile, Mr. Mbeki was always there.
In 1990, after the A.N.C. was legalized, he returned home for the first time in 28 years.
While the spotlight briefly lingered on Cyril Ramaphosa, a union leader who negotiated the new Constitution, Mr. Mbeki returned to his role as heir apparent with his election as African National Congress chairman in 1993.
The fear of him, particularly asserted among whites, is that he prefers back-room victories to open debate and puts "Africanism" above equality.
Those fears got new fuel this week when Business Day, a financial paper, reported that he had intervened to stop Judge Edwin Cameron, one of the country's best legal minds, from being named to the highest court.
Quoting "judges and lawyers close to the process," the paper said he persuaded Mr. Mandela to choose an "able and solid" black candidate because there are only three nonwhites on the 11-seat Constitutional Court.
Mr. Mbeki's legal adviser denied that he did more than consult, but that was regarded with skepticism; his office never admits being behind the sidelining of political rivals.
But in a recent interview with the newspaper The Sowetan, Mr. Mbeki made no bones about his "Africanist" perspective.
"If you are talking about poverty alleviation and eradication, then necessarily you will focus on people who are poorest," he said. "If that is what is mean by Africanist, you cannot avoid it."

HEADLINE: Exiled Leaders of Tiananmen Gather to Mull Errors and Accomplishments

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3

 BODY:
For the first time since soldiers drove them at gunpoint from Beijing's Tiananmen Square 10 years ago, the top leaders of China's democracy movement gathered at Harvard University today, like alumni converging for a reunion on the leafy New England campus.
The gathering of the men and women the Chinese Communists had denounced as instigators of a "counter-revolutionary rebellion" was itself significant, the leaders said, since some of them spent years in prison and others have squabbled among themselves over what went wrong and what they can do from exile to change China's Government. 
 The former leaders, most of whom were university students at the time, offered no new plan for political reform in China, but they acknowledged mistakes they had made with unusual candor and insisted that the movement they began has already changed China for the better.
"Tiananmen did not fail," said Li Lu, who was a physics student at Nanjing University and a leader of the Tiananmen demonstrators before the Communist leadership called in the troops on the night of June 3-4, 1989.
"The Communists killed the messenger but had to take part of the message," said Mr. Li, who is now managing partner of Himalaya Capital Partners, a hedge fund in New York. "The democracy movement marked the end of the idea that one party dictatorship can bring good to China, and so now the Communists are tolerating things like village elections that they would never have accepted before."
Among those who attended the conference were Wang Dan, who organized the student discussion groups at Beijing University in the months before the spring 1989 protests; Wang Juntao, who ran an independent think tank in Beijing that backed the students; and Wu'er Kaixi, a student at Beijing Normal University who gained prominence by daring to challenge Prime Minister Li Peng during a nationally televised meeting. Both Wang Dan and Wang Juntao were arrested after the crackdown and sent to prison. Mr. Wu'er escaped and now works as a radio talk-show host in Taiwan.
They were joined by Wei Jingsheng, perhaps China's best-known dissident and the author of the most daring wall posters calling for democracy during the short-lived Democracy Wall movement in 1979. For his temerity, Mr. Wei spent 18 years in prison.
Today, Mr. Wu'er said, "I'm optimistic, even in exile." The Communists think they have made a "deal" with the Chinese people, giving them economic development instead of political freedom, he said.
"What the Chinese Government doesn't understand," he said, "is that the people become greedy when they start to make money, and when the Government thinks it is satisfying them by giving them economic freedom, the people will inevitably want more freedom to protect their ability to make money, until this leads to democracy."
Merle Goldman, a professor of Chinese history at Boston University and an expert on Chinese dissidents, said the participants at the conference now have "a much better understanding of what democracy means and what it takes to bring about political change. The tragedy is, they can't use this knowledge now from abroad."
"This is a group that is remarkably talented and intelligent and cares about China," she said, pointing to the success of most of the leaders since they were exiled. In addition to Mr. Li, who has degrees from Columbia's law and business schools, she said, Wang Dan is a graduate student in history at Harvard, Wang Juntao is studying for his Ph.D. in political science at Columbia, and Chai Ling, the best-known female student leader, runs her own Internet company in Cambridge, having earned a degree from the Harvard Business School.
Paradoxically, Mr. Wu'er pointed out, many of these highly intelligent activists got their inspiration from Mao Zedong, when he launched the Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's. "We spent our first 10 years in the Cultural Revolution, and we came to believe that if all the people in the world united, we could create utopia," Mr. Wu'er said. "It was very idealistic and appealing."
The experience also led these young Chinese to question authority, as Mao preached that the youthful Red Guards should track down and attack corrupt party officials, Mr. Wu'er said. Then, when Mao died in 1976 and Deng Xiaoping replaced him as China's paramount leader, Mr. Wu'er continued, he "left us confused" by denouncing the Cultural Revolution and preaching that to "get rich is glorious." This created a "vacuum in ideology" that prompted some students to begin studying democracy on their own.
But there was also criticism today of the students' tactics. Chen Jun, a former Red Guard turned welder who published a magazine during the Democracy Wall movement in 1979, said the student protesters had a "dream without a plan or leadership" and led a "romantic-tragic movement."
The students in 1989, Mr. Chen said, were too elitist and mired in China's imperial tradition of petitioning the Government for change rather than striking out on their own, and too afraid of the Government's reaction if they allied themselves with dissatisfied factory workers who could have brought them greater numbers and power.
Mr. Li said the group, now formally organized as the Tiananmen Generation Association, plans to meet again next year, in Taiwan, to observe the presidential election there.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Canada Agree on a Plan to Restrict Catches of Endangered Salmon

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, June 3

 BODY:
Seeking to end a long-festering international dispute that has imperiled salmon stocks and once provoked an angry blockade of Alaska-bound ferries by Canadian fishermen, the United States and Canada announced a comprehensive plan today to set quotas on salmon catches along thousands of miles of the Pacific Ocean coast and establish a conservation fund to help protect the fish.
After failing to agree on such limits after the last salmon treaty expired seven years ago, the two countries have engaged in often heated disagreements over who was responsible for dwindling runs of the region's signature fish. The salmon are, of course, oblivious to international boundaries, spawning in the rivers of one nation and migrating to the seas of the other, and forging any kind of binational pact to protect them had proved a remarkably contentious proposition. 
 Both sides sought to impose various limits, angering the other. At one point, Canada seized several American fishing boats, and British Columbia once threatened to block the United States Navy from access to a submarine test station in Canada. And in the summer of 1997, embittered Canadian fishermen who blamed Alaskans for taking too many fish formed a 180-boat flotilla around an Alaskan ferry for three days near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.
But now, with both nations having taken serious steps in recent years to declare their salmon species threatened, and with the leaders of both countries agreeing that a new pact was needed, negotiators said today that they had negotiated an agreement, one that will cut catches of some particular salmon runs by up to 40 percent. Among the negotiators, who spoke at briefings here and in Vancouver, was Lloyd Cutler, a former White House counsel, appointed by President Clinton to head the American bargaining team.
In some cases, the fund will be used to buy up fishing licenses, essentially paying fishermen not to fish. But more broadly, through a complex patchwork of guidelines covering dozens of different rivers and salmon populations over the next dozen years, the pact will for the first time set yearly harvest levels based on scientific measurements of the salmon stocks. This "abundance-based" system will replace pre-set limits that both countries had tried to impose in the past.
The new agreement covers coastal areas and rivers in Oregon, Washington, British Columbia and Alaska. Some elements will need legislative approval in both countries, including authorization of the conservation funds, but there are few signs that that process will be contentious.
By itself, the agreement will not necessarily revive the nine different salmon runs declared threatened or endangered earlier this year under this country's Endangered Species Act. But it will be a major element of an overall plan to restore the salmon populations, which in many cases are at only a fraction of their peak populations earlier this century.
A hundred years ago, a visiting biologist from the Smithsonian Institution, Richard Rathbun, found the fish to be so prevalent in the Northwest that he wrote, "The quantities of salmon which frequent these waters is beyond calculation, and seems to be so great as to challenge human ingenuity to affect it in any way."
But development, logging, irrigation for farming, dam-building, overfishing and countless other human activities have combined since then to hammer the salmon population.
Gov. Gary Locke of Washington, a Democrat, hailed today's announcement as a landmark in which both countries had agreed to switch from a "first-come" fishing policy to a "fish-first conservation approach."
Much of the salmon eaten in this country is raised in domestic pens, and the availability and price of that fish is unlikely to be affected by today's agreement. But those who fancy the higher-priced wild fish could well find that its price rises, especially in years in which low measurements require significant cutbacks in the harvest.
As one example in the network of new rules, the ceiling on catches of chinook salmon from southeast Alaska, now set at about 263,000 yearly, would be lowered to about 150,000 in years of what is defined as "normal abundance," said Jeff Curtis, Western conservation director for Trout Unlimited, a group that has been lobbying strongly for a new treaty to protect salmon runs.
But that number could fall to as low as about 60,000 or could be set even higher than current limits.
"The whole issue is incredibly complex," Mr. Curtis said. "But what we have here is a pretty reasonable and innovative compromise."
Other steps will clearly be needed to revive the salmon, and the listing under the endangered-species act has prompted local governments in the growing Seattle-Tacoma and Portland areas to outline possible measures, from raising water rates and curbing fertilizer and pesticide use to curbing new development.
And another debate looms over once-unthinkable proposals to remove some dams in the West, which interfere with the salmon's ability to return to their spawning grounds.
The roughly $150 million in the conservation fund, most of it paid by the United States, will be used to buy licenses and to undertake restoration efforts in rivers whose spawning areas have been damaged.
In a bid to give a political lift to Vice President Al Gore, the White House had him issue an official statement about the treaty, which is likely to help Mr. Gore's Presidential campaign in the Northwest.
"Our agreement today with the Government of Canada on Pacific salmon is welcome news for the environment and for the economy in both our countries," Mr. Gore said. "Salmon are part of the very fabric of the Pacific Northwest, and President Clinton and I are absolutely committed to insuring that they not only survive but thrive once again."
In Ottawa, Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy praised the agreement in an announcement to Parliament.
"It does demonstrate that when two sides work together for a mutual benefit, in this case the conservation of the fishing stock, you can come up with a good deal," Mr. Axworthy said.
If the treaty is successful, the numbers of wild chinook and coho salmon returning each year to rivers in Oregon, Washington and Idaho could grow by the thousands because Canada would have taken steps to limit fishing hundreds of miles to the north. Similarly, cuts in the American fishing harvests, here and in Alaska, could restore thousands of fish to the great spawning areas of Canada's West Coast, including the Fraser River, one of the principal rivers for sockeye salmon.
Those sockeye spawn in the river, and the young salmon make their way out to the Pacific, later returning through Alaska, British Columbia and the San Juan Islands of Washington to their native grounds to spawn and begin the cycle again.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
New Space for Middle-Income Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Weeks before Queensway -- a 122-unit middle-income rental building in Woodside, Queens -- was completed last month, it was fully leased, reflecting the demand for housing for people with annual incomes of $35,000 to $80,000.
The studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments, with 425 to 900 square feet of space, were rented in 10 days in April for $750 to $1,425 a month. They are on the upper six floors of the eight-story building at 58-12 Queens Boulevard, between 58th and 59th Streets. 
 The first floor houses a 25,000-square-foot Staples office supply store, and the second floor has 20,000 square feet of medical office space. There is also parking for 235 cars, for residents and patrons of the businesses.
The $17.6 million project is the latest, and among the largest, completed so far under the city's New Housing Opportunities Program, which is meant to spur the development of middle-income apartments.
The program, which issued its first round of financing 12 months ago, provides developers with construction and permanent financing as well as a public subsidy in the form of a second mortgage of up to $3 million at an interest rate of 1 percent, or up to $30,000 per unit. In exchange, developers must build or renovate rental buildings or limited-equity cooperatives for middle-income residents. The tenant's annual income may not exceed seven or eight times, depending on family size, the monthly rents for the apartments, or 250 percent of the median New York City income, or $133,500, whichever is less. Allowable monthly rents range from $600 for the smallest studios to $1,750 for the largest three-bedroom apartments. The Queensway studios rent for $750 a month because they are not among the smallest in developments financed under the program.
Developers with new construction projects are also eligible for a 25-year tax abatement from the city. Those who are renovating structures can get an abatement of up to 20 years. Both abatements diminish over time until the buildings are assessed the prevailing property taxes.
In the program's first round, $113 million was provided to 15 projects with a total of 1,061 residences; 4 of the projects are complete and the remainder will be completed over the next 3 to 12 months. Under the second round, announced in March, $150 million to $175 million in financing is expected to be given over the next year to produce 1,200 to 1,500 more units, according to city figures.
Queensway received a $17.6 million construction loan, which the city's Housing Development Corporation, using proceeds from the sale of taxable bonds, will convert into an $11.8 million permanent loan. The corporation, using its own reserves, will provide a $2.2 million second loan. The Dime Savings Bank of New York guaranteed the construction loan and is to provide a $5.7 million permanent mortgage for the project's commercial component.
The financing made the developer, CDI Queens Blvd. L.L.C. of Great Neck, N.Y., "feel comfortable enough to move forward" with the project, said Charles J. Belanich, a partner. He and his two partners, his brother John Belanich and Ivan Starcic, invested $5 million in the project.
Charles Belanich said that when the partners took on the project three years ago, they intended to build only the commercial space. "The market in Queens was not there then to do the housing," he said.
The partners bought the site, once occupied by a gas station, a warehouse and a few residences, in 1996 from Astoria Federal Savings Bank. The bank had foreclosed on the property a few years earlier when the original developer ran into financial difficulties.
In 1997, the partners secured Staples as a retail tenant. Late that year, Mr. Belanich said, the partners started work on the commercial space and invested $500,000 to construct a foundation that would accommodate the additional six stories of housing at a later date. That date came sooner than expected, thanks to the city financing, he added.
About 200 applications were received for the 122 apartments. "As many applicants were rejected for making too much money as for making too little," Mr. Belanich said.
Tenants will begin moving in this month. Matthew Goldstein, 28, a ticket brokerage employee and aspiring actor, is leaving a shared apartment on the Upper East Side for a studio at Queensway.
"I wanted my own place, and with a tight budget I knew I had to go out of Manhattan to afford an apartment," Mr. Goldstein said, noting that he will be paying $50 more a month for his studio than he pays for his share of the rent in Manhattan. "I never thought I would find a place so quickly. I'm thrilled."
Russell A. Harding, president of the Housing Development Corporation, said that because land and construction costs have risen, subsidies for projects financed under the program's second round have been increased to up to $30,000 per unit from $20,000 per unit. Developers are eligible to receive up to 50 cents more for every $1 in land costs that exceed the typical $20,000 per unit.
And to encourage family-size apartments, the corporation will provide up to $25,000 per unit to developers with projects in which at least half of the apartments have two or more bedrooms, and up to $30,000 per unit if 75 percent of the units have two or more bedrooms. Developers can also receive up to $25,000 per unit if rents are 15 percent to 30 percent lower than the levels acceptable under the program, and up to $30,000 per unit if rents are more than 30 percent lower.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BELGRADE;
Weary and Wary, the Serbs Are Bitter

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 3

 BODY:
It was hard to find anyone in Belgrade today who expressed support for President Slobodan Milosevic, but with the news of a peace deal, the recriminations came unusually swiftly.
Ivica Tasic, 33, a bookseller on the main shopping street, asked the most common question: "Who will ask him why so many people had to die and all of us have had to go through this? He will never have to answer." 
 And Katarina Ivanovic, 32, asked, "Why did all those people die?"
Residents of Belgrade expressed relief at the news of a deal that could end the war, but their relief was tinged with bitterness that they had been put through 10 weeks of bombing for little apparent gain.
Most politicians welcomed Belgrade's acceptance of NATO's terms as a chance for peace and prosperity, but people on the street did not seem so sure. Few said they would be celebrating. Many were uncertain, even skeptical that this really meant an end to the war. Some warned that NATO had more in store for them.
"It's all a trick," said one flamboyantly dressed student with ragged dreadlocks. "They will send nuclear bombs next."
Jelena, an economist who has found herself unemployed since the beginning of the war, said: "People will not be celebrating. They are relieved but weary. This is a wise decision, but it should have been accepted at the beginning."
Visnja, a retired teacher, said, "It is great, because it means a stop to the killing of people and to the ruin of our country." She acknowledged that the agreement seemed like a defeat for Serbia, but added, "We do not have any other choice."
Mr. Milosevic had to agree because he faced "a destroyed country and destroyed people," said Visnja's friend Mila, an architect. Both women chatted freely in an outdoor cafe, but they did not want their full names in a foreign newspaper.
"I think that he was even thinking of going on to fight a ground war," Mila said of Mr. Milosevic, "but there are some intelligent people around who warned that we should on no account embark on a ground war."
For such "intelligent people," the women said, the loss of electricity and water was the last straw. Added to that, Mila had four missiles land just 300 yards from her home on Monday. "I did not realize the bombing would be so drastic, that civilians would be killed," she said. "I thought it would just be in Kosovo."
Many Serbs expressed anger at their Government for the long bombing campaign. "That was a mistake of our Government," said Damir, 22, a waiter in a hotel restaurant. "A lot of people died for nothing."
His friend Nenat, 23, chimed in, "We did not want foreign troops on our land, but now so many people have died, it's not worth it anymore."
Some tried to put a good face on things. "Well, everything is O.K. if you have your head on your shoulders," said Sloba, a worker drinking beer with a friend selling popcorn. "Things will get better."
Others took some solace in branding NATO a loser, too.
"At least Kosovo is clean of a lot of Albanians and not all of them will come back," said Nenat, a supporter of the extreme nationalist Serbian Radical Party.
As Mila put it: "You could not say NATO is the winner when they had such a large force and they had to bomb for nearly three months." Her friend Visnja added, "NATO is the moral loser -- such a large force attacking such a small country."
Many Serbs remain suspicious of NATO's intentions, saying they expect that the alliance would not be satisfied with occupying Kosovo and would later move to take over the whole of Serbia in their pursuit of Mr. Milosevic.
Few think that Serbia will be free of war for long: some foresee civil war, and some think NATO will be behind it. Nenat said that "with 50,000 troops" in Kosovo to resettle refugees, the alliance "could start a war in 15 minutes,"
Virtually everyone predicts that Serbian civilians will flee Kosovo as their troops and police forces leave, swamping Serbia with a new wave of refugees. They also predict an exodus from Serbia as people try to go abroad. "What is there for us here?" Nenat asked.

HEADLINE: Rivlin, No. 2 Official to Greenspan, Quits at Fed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Alice M. Rivlin resigned today as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, leaving the No. 2 job empty at the central bank as it confronts a tough call on whether to raise interest rates.
Ms. Rivlin, 68, said she was stepping down to do research at the Brookings Institution and to devote more time to her role as head of the District of Columbia's Financial Assistance Authority, which is trying to clean up Washington's finances. 
 Colleagues said there was no hidden agenda in her decision, which came a little less than four weeks before the Fed is to next vote on whether the persistent strength of economic growth requires an increase in interest rates to forestall the possibility of resurgent inflation.
Although her resignation will not take effect until July 16, the Fed said she would not take part in the monetary policy meeting June 29 and 30.
While unexpected, Ms. Rivlin's resignation is unlikely to have a crucial effect on the debate within the Fed on the degree of danger that inflation poses to the nation's long economic expansion.
She has been perhaps the most outspoken proponent at the central bank of the view that the economy is more capable of noninflationary growth than in the past, and more sympathetic than most of her fellow policy makers to the idea that driving the unemployment rate lower under those circumstances is worth the risk of a slight uptick in prices.
But her views were well within the economic mainstream, and never once during her three-year tenure did she vote against the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, whose influence inside and outside the institution vastly overshadowed her own. Indeed, Ms. Rivlin was the fourth deputy since Mr. Greenspan took office almost 12 years ago.
"Greenspan has the bulk of the power, given both his position as chairman and his successful stewardship of the Fed up until now," said William Dudley, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "This doesn't really change things very much."
Ms. Rivlin accepted the Fed post somewhat reluctantly in 1996 at President Clinton's behest, and although she was sometimes mentioned as a possible successor to Mr. Greenspan, she never lost the reputation of being more interested in fiscal policy -- her area of expertise -- than in monetary policy. And Mr. Greenspan showed every sign of wanting to stay on in the job even after his third term ends next June.
Ms. Rivlin declined interview requests today.
Her departure leaves Mr. Clinton with two slots to fill on the Fed's seven-member board of governors. The White House is close to completing background checks on its choice for the seat left open last year by the resignation of Susan M. Phillips -- Carol Parry, an executive vice president of Chase Manhattan.
Administration officials said they had been aware of Ms. Rivlin's intention to leave for several weeks, and that the search for a successor was "well under way." They gave no hint of who was under consideration.
Ms. Rivlin announced her resignation after the close of the stock market. The news had little effect on other financial markets.
In her resignation letter to Mr. Clinton, Ms. Rivlin said, "The Fed is a strong bulwark of U.S. economic policy, and I believe we have contributed to keeping the American economy growing and reducing strains in the international financial system.".
In a statement, Mr. Greenspan said, "Her wisdom influenced all our deliberations."
Mr. Clinton, for whom she served as White House budget director and before that deputy director, said in a statement that she had been "a steady and strong voice for fiscal discipline."
Fed watchers have scrutinized the central bank particularly closely the last several weeks, after its decision on May 18 to tilt policy toward an increase in interest rates. The first substantial clue could come on Friday, when the Labor Department releases May unemployment data.
In many ways, the Fed's discussions in coming weeks will crystallize a debate that has dominated policy making for the last several years. To a substantial degree, that debate has revolved around issues central to Ms. Rivlin's view of the economy. She has made the case that not just factors like higher productivity are tamping down inflation, but that low unemployment -- seen in traditional economic models as a trigger for inflation -- might itself be spurring higher productivity by forcing companies to hold down wage costs through improved efficiency.
"Economists have had in their head the idea that tight labor markets would lead to inflation and low productivity," she said in an interview in April with The Financial Times. "It may be that under the present circumstances of fierce global competition, the effect of tight labor markets is exactly the opposite."
Ms. Rivlin has also been forthright in her belief that a low unemployment rate -- especially during a period in which Federal, state and local governments are pushing many welfare recipients into the work force for the first time -- is a benefit that should not be given away through blind adherence to old rules about the relationship between inflation, growth and unemployment.
"The models have been predicting higher inflation based on tight labor markets," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at Wells Fargo & Company in Minneapolis. "Alice Rivlin tended to rely less on models and more on her own judgment."
Ms. Rivlin's long service as an economist and public official included the post of director of the Congressional Budget Office, which she founded, from 1975 to 1983.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Roche to Pay $4.2 Billion For the Rest of Genentech
Roche Holding, the European drug maker, said that it would exercise its right to buy the 33 percent of Genentech it does not already own for $82.50 a share, or $4.2 billion. Roche will then issue new shares equivalent to as much as 19 percent of Genentech, the pioneering biotechnology company, so the company can continue to be publicly traded. 
 Analysts said the transaction was good for Roche, which should realize a gain when it sells shares, and good for Genentech, which retains its quasi-independent status. But it is not so good for stockholders because shares have been as high as $90 over the last year. They fell $4.50, to $82, on the news. Page C2.
 
Retail Sales Increased 5.6% in May
Sales in retail stores open at least a year rose 5.6 percent in May as consumers continued to show great confidence in the economy by snatching up everything from wardrobes in summer white to pool furniture. C2.
 
Stocks Mixed Ahead of Jobs Report
Stock prices were mixed as traders and investors awaited today's release of the Government's monthly report on the job market for May. The Nasdaq composite index finished with a loss of 29.09 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,403.32. The Dow Jones industrial average surged in the final 15 minutes of trading and ended with a gain of 85.80 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 10,663.69. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended with a gain of 4.73 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 1,299.54. C7.
 
Microsoft Scrutinizes Testimony
A lawyer for Microsoft questioned the credibility of James Barksdale, the chief executive of Netscape, in the rebuttal phase of the software giant's antitrust trial. The apparent inconsistencies between Mr. Barksdale's testimony last fall and statements out of court caught the attention of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson -- so much so that the judge urged a Government lawyer to take account of them in court. C5.
 
New Publisher at Los Angeles Times
Kathryn Downing was named publisher of The Los Angeles Times, taking over from Mark Willes, who remains chairman and chief executive of the paper's parent, Times Mirror. Ms. Downing, the paper's president for the last 14 months, was hand-picked by Mr. Willes as his successor. C6.
 
Sanctions Sought in Beef Dispute
A trans-Atlantic fight over hormone-treated beef intensified when United States and Canadian officials asked the World Trade Organization to approve $253 million in retaliatory trade sanctions and the European Union countered by demanding arbitration that it hopes will lower the overall amount. C4.
 
Factory Orders Rose 0.5% in April
Factory orders rose half a percent in April, excluding demand at aircraft makers, the fifth increase in the last six months, Commerce Department figures showed. Overall orders fell 1.2 percent during the month after declining six-tenths of a percent in March. In a separate report, initial jobless claims rose 4,000, to 305,000, last week. C2.
 
China Tightens Control of Currency
The Chinese authorities announced that they were tightening control over international transfers of the yuan, the nation's currency. The news rekindled fear about a devaluation, but the People's Bank of China denied any such plans. C4.
 
New Global Banking Rules Proposed
The top global banking regulator introduced proposals that would strengthen protections against bad loans and subject the risk-assessment operations of big international banks to greater supervision. C4.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE NETTLES;
Kosovo Problems Just Beginning

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Even if the agreement reached today with Slobodan Milosevic ends the bombing of Yugoslavia, staggering problems lie ahead, first among them the repatriation of nearly a million Kosovars to the land of ashes and graves that was their home.
If they do return, experts on the region said, the Kosovars will probably rally behind the guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army, making the rebels even less likely to disarm or abandon their dreams of independence, which NATO opposes. 
 "There are three things to watch as this unfolds," said Michael Mandelbaum, a professor of foreign policy at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. "First, the war isn't over until the bombing stops. Second, it's not a success until the refugees return. And third, it will not hold until the K.L.A. is disarmed."
Beyond that, the United States and its allies must still find a way of dealing with President Milosevic, now indicted for war crimes but still the man in charge in Belgrade.
Then the allies have to repair relations with the Russians and Chinese, which have been sorely strained by the Kosovo conflict.
Beyond that stretches the enormously costly challenge of rebuilding the devastated economies of Kosovo, the rest of Serbia and their neighbors. Only if that succeeds can the United States and NATO begin to think of ending the stewardship they have now assumed, whether by design or miscalculation, in the perennially troublesome Balkans.
"What remains unresolved far exceeds what has been resolved," said Richard N. Haass, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution.
The gloomy and cautious talk stood in contrast to the hopes raised by Belgrade's apparent agreement to conditions for an end to the 10-week bombardment negotiated by Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland and Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott of the United States. As described by the negotiators, these conditions include the verifiable withdrawal of all Serbian troops from Kosovo, the deployment of a NATO-led peace force and the return of refugees.
To the experts, however, the very fact that Mr. Milosevic had agreed to a deal touched off alarms. Many voiced suspicions either that he would test allied resolve further, as President Saddam Hussein has done repeatedly in Iraq, or that he would undermine the peace in other ways.
David Rieff, a senior fellow at the World Policy Institute who has written extensively on the region, said: "If Milosevic is able to call some kind of victory, this is a pause, rather than the end. I hope I'm wrong, God knows. But my sense of this is that strife is mother's milk to Milosevic. He hasn't changed. He's no different from the man responsible for the Bosnian war and the mass expulsion of most Kosovars and the murder, we'll probably discover, of many, many thousands."
Assuming that the deal works, a Pentagon official said, NATO forces must work swiftly to assess the situation in Kosovo and to determine when and how the refugees can start returning home. One problem, the official said, is to prevent a chaotic flood of refugees. The official said the first priority would be to care for the untold thousands of Kosovars driven from their homes but still wandering about in the province.
Some experts, however, thought it might prove difficult to persuade many refugees to return home.
"All I hear from people who follow refugees is that many will choose not to go home," said Walter R. Mead, senior fellow for United States foreign policy at the Council on Foreign Relations. "It's too late to put in a crop, their homes are devastated and burned down, the roads are all in a mess, there's nothing to go back to except a winter of starvation."
Mr. Haass added: "NATO cannot coerce them to return. It has to be safe. They have to have shelter, a livelihood."
If NATO does succeed in bringing home the refugees, the peacekeeping forces will be confronted with the problem of disarming a strengthened rebel army and quelling demands for independence. Today's agreement reportedly reaffirms that the guerrillas should be disarmed and that Kosovo should remain, at least formally, a province of Serbia.
The overarching problem, said Susan Woodward, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, "is that all the people we want to help us make a stable Kosovo have been destroyed by the effects of the bombings. They're either in third countries, or so traumatized that they can't be reorganized, or they've been killed."
"The people who are going to control the next stage of the process are the K.L.A.," she said.
The long-term challenge before NATO will be to find ways of disentangling itself from the Balkans. That, the experts agreed, will require restoring a viable economy to the entire region, including Serbia.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
Kosovo Peace Accord: 10 Steps to a Verifiable End of Violence

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Following is the text of the international proposal to end the Kosovo conflict that was accepted today by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. The text was provided by the State Department.
 Agreement should be reached on the following principles to move toward a resolution of the Kosovo crisis: 

1. Immediate and verifiable end of violence and repression in Kosovo.
 
2. Verifiable withdrawal from Kosovo of all military, police and paramilitary forces according to a rapid timetable.
 
3. Deployment in Kosovo under U.N. auspices of effective international civil and security presences, acting as may be decided under Chapter VII of the Charter, capable of guaranteeing the achievement of common objectives.
 
4. The international security presence with substantial NATO participation must be deployed under unified command and control and authorized to establish a safe environment of all people in Kosovo and to facilitate the safe return to their homes of all displaced persons and refugees.
 
5. Establishment of an interim administration of Kosovo as a part of the international civil presence under which the people of Kosovo can enjoy substantial autonomy within the F.R.Y. Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to be decided by the Security Council of the United Nations. Interim administration to provide transitional administration while establishing and overseeing the development of provisional democratic self-governing institutions to insure conditions for a peaceful and normal life for all inhabitants in Kosovo.
 
6. After withdrawal, an agreed number of Yugoslav and Serbian personnel will be permitted to return to perform the following functions:
*Liaison with international civil mission and international security presence.
*Marking/clearing minefields.
*Maintaining a presence at Serb patrimonial sites.
*Maintaining a presence at key border crossings.
 
7. Safe and free return of all refugees and displaced persons under the supervision of the U.N.H.C.R. and unimpeded access to Kosovo by humanitarian aid organizations.
 
8. A political process towards the establishment of an interim political framework agreement providing for a substantial self-government for Kosovo, taking full account of the Rambouillet accords and the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the other countries of the region, and the demilitarization of the U.C.K. Kosovo Liberation Army . Negotiations between the parties for the settlement should not delay or disrupt the establishment of democratic self-governing institutions.
 
9. Comprehensive approach to the economic development and stabilization of the crisis region. This will include the implementation of a Stability Pact for South-Eastern Europe with broad international participation in order to further promotion of democracy, economic prosperity, stability and regional cooperation.
 
10. Suspension of military activity will require acceptance of the principles set forth above in addition to agreement to other, previously identified, required elements, which are specified in the footnote below. A military-technical agreement will then be rapidly concluded that would, among other things, specify additional modalities including the roles and function of Yugoslav/Serb personnel in Kosovo:
 
Withdrawal
*Procedures for withdrawals, including the phased, detailed schedule and delineation of a buffer area in Serbia beyond which forces will be withdrawn.
 
Returning Personnel
*Equipment associated with returning personnel.
*Terms of reference for their functional responsibilities.
*Timetable for their return.
*Delineation of their geographical areas of operation.
*Rules governing their relationship to international security presence and international civil mission.
 
FOOTNOTE
Other Required Elements
*Rapid and precise timetable for withdrawals, meaning e.g., seven days to complete withdrawal; air defense weapons withdrawn outside a 25 kilometer mutual safety zone within 48 hours.
*Return of personnel for the four functions specified above will be under the supervision of the international security presence, and will be limited to a small agreed number (hundreds, not thousands).
*Suspension of military activity will occur after the beginning of verifiable withdrawals.
*The discussion and achieving of a military-technical agreement shall not extend the previously determined time for completion of withdrawals.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "SIDE BY SIDE -- Two Peace Plans: How They Differ"
Some of the key differences between the current peace plan and the one refused by the Serbs in France in talks in February and March.
 
TROOP WITHDRAWAL
NEW PLAN: A "quick" and "verifiable" withdrawal of all Serbian troops and police.
RAMBOUILLET: More gradual Serbian withdrawal.
 
PEACEKEEPERS
NEW PLAN: Peacekeepers are deployed under U.N. auspices with "an essential NATO participation."
RAMBOUILLET: 28,000 NATO peacekeepers commanded by NATO.
 
RETURNING SERBIAN PERSONNEL
NEW PLAN: The return of some Serbian military personnel, after their initial withdrawal, limits their number to "hundreds, not thousands."
RAMBOUILLET: Thousands of Serbian soldiers and military police could have remained in Kosovo for up to a year.
 
POLITICAL FUTURE
NEW PLAN: Guarantees "substantial autonomy" but appears much more ambiguous than Rambouillet. An interim administration will be selected by the U.N. Security Council.
RAMBOUILLET: Outlined a detailed political architecture, police and court system for postwar Kosovo. After three years a referendum would have led to independence.

HEADLINE: Justice Dept. Is Said to Be Close to a Decision on Indicting a Chinese Company

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
In a diplomatically sensitive case, the Justice Department is nearing a decision on whether to indict one of China's most powerful state-owned corporations, law-enforcement officials and lawyers say.
Some career prosecutors in the department have recommended the indictment of the corporation, Catic, an aerospace giant, on charges of buying American machining equipment for civilian use in 1994 and diverting some of it to a military plant, the officials and lawyers said. 
 The equipment was sold to the Chinese by McDonnell Douglas, now part of The Boeing Company, which has also been under criminal investigation for possible violations of American export laws.
But the current chill in relations between Beijing and Washington and Congressional scrutiny of the case has complicated the decision. Law-enforcement officials said they were unaware of any previous case in which the United States had indicted a Chinese government entity on the scale of Catic, the China National Aero-Technology Import Export Corporation.
Catic agreed with the Justice Department last month to extend the deadline for filing charges, the officials and lawyers said. It was five years ago that McDonnell Douglas applied for a Commerce Department license to sell the machining equipment to Catic, which buys and sells civilian aerospace technology.
Since the extension, the parties have been in a "continuing dialogue," and Catic has discussed the possibility of paying a civil penalty to resolve the case, one lawyer said.
Barbara Van Gelder, Catic's lawyer in Washington, said today that "we are exploring a settlement with the Justice Department and the Commerce Department."
The Commerce Department can impose civil penalties for violations of export control laws and could bar Catic and its affiliates from future export licenses if the company was criminally convicted of export control violations.
Larry McCracken, a spokesman for Boeing, which bought McDonnell Douglas in 1997, said, "We're cooperating but we don't want to get into the details at this point."
A Justice Department spokesman had no comment on the investigation.
Catic has ample incentive to resolve the case without risking its fate with an American jury at a time of strained Chinese-American relations.
The sale of machining equipment was part of a billion-dollar jetliner deal in 1994 in which McDonnell Douglas was to build aircraft in China. At the time, the aircraft deal was promoted by President Clinton and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown as a centerpiece of the Administration's commercial diplomacy, the policy of using economic engagement to broaden ties with Beijing and promote exports.
But within a few months of the announcement of the deal, McDonnell Douglas discovered that some of the equipment it sold to China had been sent 800 miles from Beijing to a military facility in Nanchang that makes missiles and fighter aircraft. And though the 1994 deal announced by President Clinton called for the building of 20 planes, a Boeing spokesman said today that China would build only 1 or 2 planes with the company.
A conviction of Catic could further strain relations between the countries and curb other American exports to China, officials said.
Moreover, the Administration's policy of promoting exports to China now faces serious challenge in Congress. Last week a select Congressional committee's report on transfers of sensitive American technology to China concluded that American export control policies had tilted too much toward commerce at the expense of national security.
The committee, headed by Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, said the machining equipment deal was a case study in how China "will attempt diversions when it suits its interests."
The committee's unanimous report also found that Catic had played a central role in China's drive to acquire technology with civilian and military uses and that on several occasions Catic had "misrepresented the proposed uses of military useful U.S. technology." The Clinton Administration prevented the committee from disclosing further details.
In addition, Justice Department officials blocked the committee from disclosing 1994 cables that showed how Administration officials delayed seeking timely assurances from Catic on how it planned to use the machining equipment so as not to disrupt Mr. Brown's announcement in China of the McDonnell Douglas aircraft deal, officials familiar with the report said.
The Commerce Department received an assurance from Catic after Mr. Brown left China but it left unanswered the question of exactly where the machining equipment would be located, according to excerpts from a Sept. 13, 1994, cable included in the Cox committee report.
On Sept. 14 the department approved the export of the machining equipment -- some of it more than a decade old, including machine tools to shape and bend large aircraft parts -- for use in Beijing as part of the McDonnell Douglas project to build aircraft in China.
The license included some last-minute additions to allay concerns raised by the Pentagon. In August, the Defense Intelligence Agency warned that the Chinese did not really need the equipment for the civilian aircraft deal but that "an advanced machine tool facility presents a unique opportunity for Chinese military aerospace facilities to access advanced equipment which otherwise might be denied," the Cox report said.
Commerce Department officials said the licensing conditions that were added led to a discovery by McDonnell Douglas in 1995 that some of the equipment had wound up at the Nanchang military complex. The equipment was eventually moved to a civilian location in China.
The Commerce Department began an investigation seven months after the discovery of the diversion. The discovery and recovery illustrate, Commerce officials say, that their enforcement system works.
The case was also referred to the Customs Service and the Justice Department. In 1996, a Federal grand jury began examining whether Catic and McDonnell Douglas had complied with export control laws.
By last September, prosecutors in the office of the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia had completed a lengthy memorandum recommending charges against both Catic and McDonnell Douglas, according to law-enforcement officials.
But then the lead prosecutor in the case left the Government. Over the next several months other prosecutors reviewed the case and asked the Customs Service to continue its investigation, officials said.
During the subsequent review, some lawyers basically concurred with the original memorandum while others raised questions, including some reservations about the strength of the case against McDonnell Douglas, which is said to rely more on circumstantial evidence, officials and lawyers said.
It is not known whether the Justice Department has given final approval to seek any indictments from the grand jury.

HEADLINE: Casino Visions, And Fears;
Man's Plan to Donate Land To Indians Riles Hamlet

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: SAMSONVILLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
For years, longtime residents and weekenders from Manhattan treasured this woodsy hamlet as the closest thing to rustic paradise, a place where the streams made more noise than the residents, where slender country roads rolled past old stone walls, where the number of general stores (1) dwarfed the number of traffic lights (0). One could sigh, and sigh again, when contemplating the crisp air, the clear-day vistas of Connecticut and, perhaps most precious of all, the leisurely and utterly predictable cadence of life.
But that was before the rumors about an American Indian casino turned life upside down, triggering fears that this pastoral incarnation of "Ah, Wilderness" would suddenly turn into "Paradise Lost." 
 It all began late last year, when word got out that a wealthy landowner here, Harry C. Fotopoulos, planned to donate about one-sixth of his more than 300 acres to the Oglala Sioux of South Dakota. The goal, Mr. Fotopoulos said, was to create a historic theme park and campground, complemented by a motel and some restaurants, that would help the impoverished tribe.
"I'm 70 years old," said Mr. Fotopoulos, who during a recent interview at his cabin here tucked a gun and hunting knife into his belt. "Whatever time I have left, whatever good I can do for some people, that'll be my legacy. This can turn out to be such a beautiful, beautiful thing for the Indians."
The trouble is no one here believes him. After all, the Sioux live about 1,500 miles away and have never had a historic connection to New York State, much less the Catskills or this Ulster County hamlet, which is part of the town of Olive. So instead, many residents say they are convinced that Mr. Fotopoulos, a Manhattan real estate developer, really wants to pave the way for a casino.
"It's insane; never ever has there been anything done to this pristine land," said Harriet Black, who, with her husband, Bob, splits her time between their sign business in Manhattan and their weekend house on Haver Road, next to Mr. Fotopoulos's property. "This is a crime in the deepest sense. It's not man-made crime; it's God and nature crime."
In truth, the chances for a casino are remote, Federal officials say. Even establishing a sovereign Indian nation on Mr. Fotopoulos's property would not be easy. But the fact that Mr. Fotopoulos has widened roads on his property, submitted a subdivision plan and declared that he is this close to clinching the transfer has persuaded many residents that some kind of radical change -- casino, theme park, commercial enterprise, whatever -- is imminent.
As a result, the story has evolved into much more than just the biggest development skirmish in this part of the Catskills since -- well, since never. The fight has been so unexpected, so out of character, that for the first time, residents are now feeling vulnerable, and somewhat powerless, about an idyllic world that they never dreamed would change.
Mr. Fotopoulos, in turn, says he has been surprised, and disappointed, by the reaction.
"How dare anybody not want to help the Indians?" said Mr. Fotopoulos, who bought his property about 40 years ago. "This is an absolute disgrace that people are trying to force me to do with my land what they want to do with the land. Now, I don't want a casino up there. But if they stop me, then I may transfer the whole 300 acres. And I'll say, 'Now let's put a casino.' "
Until recently, Mr. Fotopoulos, who has dabbled in politics in Manhattan and was once branded (unfairly, he says) by The New York Post as one of the city's worst landlords, had never evinced any interest in American Indian affairs.
But last year, a group called the Five Feathers Heritage Group that Mr. Fotopoulos said was affiliated with the Oglala Sioux approached him about donating some land. How and why they picked Mr. Fotopoulos is not clear. But when he learned about the Sioux -- who have an unemployment rate higher than 80 percent -- he said that, yes, he would donate a 54-acre parcel.
With the transaction now almost final, work on a five-acre parking lot could begin this summer, Mr. Fotopoulos said. Eventually, he hopes to invite some Oglala Sioux to live on the land, start a bottled water business, stage mock battles, dig a new lake, build a fort with vending booths. Among other ventures.
At first, Mr. Fotopoulos said he wanted to reap about 45 percent of the profits. But now, he says he wants only the ability to manage the project and, perhaps, a small plaque to commemorate his efforts.
"There is no money for me," he said. "It's money for the Indians."
Whatever Mr. Fotopoulos's intentions, a casino is probably unlikely because of stringent Federal criteria, said Rex Hackler, director of communications for the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs.
To open a casino on one's own reservation is one thing, but to open one off site -- in another state, halfway around the country -- is unheard of, and hard to fathom. Of the 100 or so applications for off-site casinos since 1988, only two have been approved, and both were adjacent to existing reservations and had tremendous community support, Mr. Hackler said.
"I'd say that this one is as close to impossible as you can get," he said.
Even so, there is plenty of fear and loathing to go around here over whatever the final product will be, because of concerns over traffic and the environment in a watershed area abutting the Ashokan Reservoir.
The subject has inspired so much concern that longtime residents and weekenders from the city have shoved aside traditional tensions over development, forming a rare united front to oppose the project.
They have planted signs that say, "No Camp -- No Theme Park -- No Casino." A citizens' group, Preservation of Olive New York, published its first newsletter in early May. Some residents even rented an airplane last winter to fly over Mr. Fotopoulos's property to take photographs of what they suspected was illegal logging activity. (But the pictures were not very good, said Vincent Barringer, the Olive Town Justice.)
"I think it's unglued a lot of us," said Ellen Iwanowski, who runs the Dream House Bed and Breakfast, just down the road from Mr. Fotopoulos's cabin. "If he goes and gives this piece of property to this Indian nation, and they're a sovereign nation, Harry has nothing to say and neither does anyone else. We're all afraid, I tell you."
Some American Indians also feel ambivalent about Mr. Fotopoulos's plans. Like other wealthy landowners, Mr. Fotopoulos may be more concerned about writing off his taxes ($9,000 a year) than promoting Indian culture, said Victorio Roland Vargas Mousaa, former program planner for American Indian Community House in Manhattan.
"I'm not sure if he's sincere," said Mr. Mousaa, who has visited Mr. Fotopoulos's property. "I've seen it so many times before: people using Native Americans to get out of their tax problems."
Mr. Fotopoulos is working with Arthur Zimiga, a Sioux businessman and retired college administrator, and Michael Sierra, another established member of the Sioux. But the two are not acting on behalf of the tribe, said Chief Harold Dean Salway, president of the Oglala Sioux Tribe.
"They've never approached me on this subject matter, and that's why I've been advised that there could be some questions about misrepresentation," Mr. Salway said.
Mr. Zimiga, one of the founders of a new bottled-water company called Lakota Waters, did not return several telephone calls seeking comment. Mr. Sierra also could not be reached for comment.
At the same time, though, Mr. Salway said the tribe would welcome any gift of land, and any chance for a casino. "The potential could be profound," he said. "It could help bring us out of poverty."
As it stands, there is little indication that the passions will abate soon. At a recent Olive Town Planning Board meeting on the 54-acre subdivision, a crowd of more than 100 people, many glowering, packed a meeting that normally attracts a handful. As Bob Tumasian, one of Mr. Fotopoulos's representatives, and Bob Cross Jr., his surveyor, unfurled some sketches, dozens of people hovered over the table, like generals studying war maps.
Then, as board members expressed frustration about Mr. Fotopoulos's endgame, Mr. Tumasian tried to turn the tables on the skeptics. "There will not be any Indians running around with tomahawks," he said. "There will be a theme park. What seems to be the problem with giving a piece of property to the Native Americans? Is it prejudice?"
A chorus of angry noes crackled. This is a place, after all, where people, some of them hardened protesters with etched memories of the 1960's, have never felt a need to prove their progressive credentials, especially with Woodstock just 30 minutes away.
But the meeting got testy, at times. There were exchanges between Mr. Tumasian and the Planning Board, and blunt comments from the audience demanding that the participants speak up. And while board members promised to scrutinize Mr. Fotopoulos's plan, not everyone felt optimistic about the future.
"It's really hard to imagine," said Douglas Costanzo, a carpenter who fled New York City 20 years ago for what he assumed would be the quiet life, "how you move to a place that you think is far away from the rest of the world, and someone wants to change it into the rest of the world."
