HEADLINE: Gambling Panel to Call for Array of Limits

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3

 BODY:
After two years spent studying the social and economic effects of the gambling industry's vast growth, a Federal commission completed its work here today and prepared to deliver a list of more than 70 recommendations to President Clinton, Congress, governors and Indian leaders.
Among the proposals are a moratorium on gambling expansion, a ban on college-sports betting and a prohibition against all wagering on the Internet. 
 The nine members of the Federal panel, the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, had to overcome stark differences among themselves in order to give unanimous approval to a sweeping report on the state lotteries, casino gaming, racing and other forms of legal wagering that last year generated revenue of more than $50 billion.
The commissioners found that for all the economic benefits, the boom in wagering had also brought an array of negative consequences, most significantly a rise in problem gambling. But they agreed that the gaming industry would remain a fixture on the American landscape, at least as far as they could see to the horizon.
"It is clear that the American people want legalized gambling and it has already sunk deep economic and other roots in many communities," says their report, which they are to deliver on June 18. "Its form and extent may change -- it may even disappear -- but for the present, it's a reality."
Congress's creation of the commission in 1996 initially caused fear in the casino industry that Federal regulations and new taxes would result. But the report calls for no such measures to be imposed on the major commercial casino operators.
Among the recommendations, however, are a call for states to impose a pause in gambling expansion, as a way of encouraging local governments to review closely the effects of gaming businesses on their communities; a prohibition on all forms of Internet gambling, because of the Net's little-regulated reach; a curtailing of state lottery advertising and new lottery games; closer regulation of the casinos operated on Indian reservations, and a vast array of ways to finance research and treatment of problem gambling.
The commission also recommended "tight restrictions" on political contributions from casino companies, whose ability to prosper is closely tied to licensing and regulatory decisions by state officials; a ban on college-sports wagering, legal now only in Nevada; a ban as well on the unregulated gambling boats that sponsor "cruises to nowhere," and the removal of automated cash machines from casino floors.
None of those restrictions will be realized, of course, unless they are adopted by legislators, and many of the tougher proposals are expected to face fierce political opposition.
"In the real world, two or three recommendations and a couple of observations will get through and in the end be viewed as what this commission contributed," said one member, Richard C. Leone, president of the Century Foundation, a public-policy research institute.
But the commission's most ardent gambling opponent, James C. Dobson, president of the conservative Focus on the Family, said he intended to use his organization's web of radio broadcasts and mailing lists to force lawmakers to respond to the recommendations. "We will work at getting the word out," Mr. Dobson said. "I really don't think this report is going to gather dust."
The commission spent two years and $5 million traveling the country, to tour the back rooms of casinos, see the thousands of workers streaming into and out of the gambling halls on Mississippi's Gulf Coast and the Las Vegas Strip, and hear testimony from hundreds of people on everything from the dangers of compulsive gambling to the economic benefits that legalized betting had brought to Indian reservations.
Yet the commissioners often found it difficult to reach consensus on an industry that may yield billions but also draws strong moral objections from many.
The panel's chairwoman was Kay Cole James, a conservative Republican who is a dean at Regent University, a Virginia institution that was founded by Pat Robertson and bills itself as "America's premier Christian graduate school." Her views were frequently at odds with those of members like J. Terrence Lanni, chief executive of the Las Vegas casino giant MGM Grand.
Over time, though, agreement was struck on a number of issues. Mr. Lanni, for example, surprisingly parted company with other gambling proponents on Wednesday to vote in favor of restricting casino contributions to state and local political campaigns. "This won't sit well with people in my industry," he said. "But I think it's important that we maintain the appearance as well as the substance of integrity."
Despite such accords, critics complained that the commission's effectiveness had ultimately been undermined by unyielding positions among some members. As a result, the critics said, the report is filled with recommendations that are not likely to have much effect.
"They're coming out with lightweight recommendations, no question," said Arnie Wexler, a counselor on compulsive gambling who testified before the commission.
And Tom C. Rodgers, a lobbyist for the Indian gambling industry, called the commission "a lost opportunity." Echoing a view held by others, Mr. Rodgers said the panel could have been more effective had fewer members come to the task with a predisposition on gambling.
"You see this with every commission like this," he said. "People try to form a compromise, but they can't for political reasons."
People on both sides of the gambling debate, meanwhile, were declaring victory. "It's clear that the commissioners came away understanding that there are vast benefits associated with some forms of gambling," said Alan Feldman, a spokesman for the Las Vegas casino company Mirage Resorts. "This whole process represented our opportunity to show government and the public just how legitimately operated our businesses are."
Mr. Feldman conceded, however, that the commission's report would show that "there are areas we need to work on."
Tom Grey, who heads the National Coalition Against Gambling Expansion, said he believed that the report would give his movement much-needed ammunition.
"By getting the commissioners to come out and say that the product -- gambling -- is flawed, gives us fuel to attack," Mr. Grey said. The existence of the commission has "made the industry recognize that they have a problem" with compulsive gambling, he added. "Now gambling will be in the public consciousness along with alcohol, tobacco and drugs."
Still, Mr. Grey concurred with others who said that while the commissioners had studied most of the social and economic issues associated with gambling, they had proved unwilling to recommend anything that might severely affect the earnings of the powerful casino companies.
These critics also said that some of the seemingly tough recommendations either faced uphill political battles or would have little effect in the end. The proposed ban on Internet gambling, for example, is seen as nearly impossible to enforce fully. And two weeks ago, just minutes after the commission addressed a wave of college-sports gambling scandals by voting to recommend that sports books in Las Vegas be prohibited from taking bets on college games, casino officials quickly pointed out that such a proposal was highly unlikely to ever pass the Nevada Legislature.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Fruit of Miscalculation

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 3

 BODY:
From the start, this has been a war of miscalculation.
NATO, led by the Clinton Administration, assumed that a relatively short period of bombing would be enough to cause President Slobodan Milosevic to capitulate over Kosovo. 
 Drawing the wrong lessons from Bosnia, Western officials underestimated the historical and cultural importance of Kosovo to the Serbs.
And the allies badly undervalued the province's political importance to Mr. Milosevic, who rose to power on the promise to protect the Serbs of Kosovo against the Albanian majority.
But today, as he accepted a deal not much better than he was offered before the bombing began 10 weeks ago, Mr. Milosevic seemed to have miscalculated as badly.
The Serbian leader, for his part, expected the NATO alliance to split, particularly as the number of civilian casualties grew. He is unlikely to have thought Bill Clinton would ignore those casualties and even intensify the bombing.
While the alliance's southern tier became frazzled as refugees flowed into Albania and Macedonia and then into Western Europe, the human tide neither destroyed Serbia's impoverished neighbors nor sundered the alliance.
Mr. Milosevic was right in his calculations that NATO did not want to risk a ground invasion of Serbia, whose citizens, no matter how some may revile Mr. Milosevic, seemed willing to die for their country.
While only a ground invasion could sweep him from power, he ultimately came to believe that NATO could continue its comparatively cost-free bombing campaign for many more months, striking civilian targets as well as military ones and utterly devastating Serbia.
With his own losses mounting -- at least 1,200 civilians have died in NATO accidents and NATO estimated today that at least 5,000 Yugoslav soldiers and policemen have died -- Mr. Milosevic clearly decided that now was the moment to end an unequal war and preserve his own power.
He is evidently calculating again. At least for now, he is surviving NATO's war against his country with his power intact.
In a weak political field, he still looks like a titan, and for many in Serbia -- especially the working classes, the old and the poor -- he is likely to retain his aura of mastery. His party is already claiming to have inspired this little nation to a noble resistance against the combined forces of 19 of the world's most advanced nations.
"This is a little nation that resisted for two months against the greatest might that has ever existed in history, and there was no demoralization, no panic, no mass desertions," said Aleksa Djilas, a historian, exaggerating only a little.
"This has shown that Western public opinion has proved less humane than we believed: It was willing to tolerate far higher casualties in the country being attacked than we had assumed, and it was prepared to tolerate far fewer casualities on its own side than we had assumed."
Serbia's weak democratic opposition parties, largely muzzled during the war by censorship, have been eager to say that Mr. Milosevic's problems will really begin after peace is established, once the patriotic fever has passed and people awake to the economic ruin around them.
There is some truth to that, even Mr. Milosevic's supporters agree, as the country faces a hot summer and a cold winter with demolished electrical power stations and heating plants.
The bombs have done enormous damage to the economy, which was already battered by eight years of international sanctions. Billions of dollars of factories and equipment have been smashed, and nearly every important highway or railway bridge has been damaged or destroyed, along with the country's only two oil refineries.
And as long as Mr. Milosevic and his top aides, many of them recently indicted for war crimes, remain in power, it remains to be seen whether Serbia will get any serious reconstruction aid or investment from Western countries or the European Union.
If anything, the West may tighten economic sanctions, increasing the sense of isolation of its relatively cosmopolitan citizens.
Western aid itself -- or the promise of it -- is already being used as a sort of incentive to Serbs to depose Mr. Milosevic, by electoral means or otherwise.
And it is possible that the Yugoslav Army and the police, having withstood NATO's extensive bombing in Kosovo without cracking, will find that Mr. Milosevic has made peace at too cheap a price, discarding their own sacrifice and that of their dead comrades.
Already Vuk Obradovic, a former general who leads a small opposition party, has called for Mr. Milosevic's resignation and asked: "What was the price of this war? And what did it accomplish?"
Those questions have now been echoed by the former Mayor of Belgrade, Nebojsa Covic, who broke with Mr. Milosevic in 1996.
While military casualties have been a state secret, Yugoslav generals have said recently that they were relatively low, estimating that 1,800 people have been killed or wounded badly enough to leave their posts.
But NATO officials, in a response today, estimated that perhaps 5,000 Yugoslav military and police troops have been killed and more than 10,000 wounded -- the first time the allies have provided such figures.
Whatever the number, the report by NATO seems to be another effort to increase the political pressure on Mr. Milosevic from an angry citizenry that may feel betrayed by the deal on Kosovo after so many dead. The Serbs themselves like to speak of their small families, compared to large Albanian ones, and the loss of enough conscript sons could set off spontaneous demonstrations, like the ones recently repressed in Krusevac, Aleksandrovac and Cacak.
While Yugoslav officials tried to minimize the importance of those demonstrations, they also vowed to crush them, and this sort of war weariness in the southern Serbian heartland, where Mr. Milosevic has always found his strength, is likely to have been another important factor in his decision to end the war.
For all Mr. Milosevic's new vulnerabilities, he remains lucky in his fractured, disputatious opposition.
The ultranationalist leader of the Radical Party, Serbia's deputy prime minister, Vojislav Seselj, vowed today to quit the Government if NATO troops enter Kosovo. He will no doubt try to challenge Mr. Milosevic in elections, but most Serbs are not going to find the prospect of even more tension with the world community a politically attractive platform. Once out of power, Mr. Seselj will also find the draconian press laws he favored put to use against him.
And the democrats are too busy either knifing each other or competing for Mr. Milosevic's favors in coalition governments to do him significant harm.
Zoran Djindjic, the prominent leader of the Democratic Party, has probably destroyed his political career in Serbia by fleeing to its sister republic, Montenegro, while others remained in Belgrade under the bombs.
Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement and a former leader of the democratic opposition, still commands the largest political following there. He was prominent in pushing for an early peace settlement, and he has his own television station because his party controls the Belgrade municipality.
But Mr. Draskovic is considered flighty, and as he praised the peace accord today, he also made it clear that he would be more than willing to rejoin Mr. Milosevic's Government, especially if Mr. Seselj quits. If so, he could be a useful interlocutor with the West for the indicted President Milosevic.

HEADLINE: Procter & Gamble to Trim Jobs and Close Plants

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company is expected to announce next week that it will cut thousands of jobs worldwide, close several underperforming plants and take a huge charge to become more competitive and improve profits, according to analysts and institutional investors who have met with management.
The reorganization will give investors the first detailed look at where Durk I. Jager, the new chief executive at P.&G., is steering the company, which makes Tide detergent, Pampers diapers and Crest toothpaste among other things. 
 The cuts, most of which are expected to take place outside the United States, are intended to streamline P.& G.'s top-heavy management structure and allow the company to compete better in fast-changing and highly competitive global markets.
P.& G. is expected to divide its businesses into seven units, which will be run as global entities instead of as parts of regional divisions. The units will focus on specific product segments, including hair care, laundry and feminine hygiene, and are expected to speed up the company's lethargic product development cycle.
The changes, part of what P.& G. is calling Organization 2005, are part of a plan to focus on research and development instead of geographical expansion. The strategy represents a new direction for the company under Mr. Jager, who took over in January after 29 years with P.&G.
"I think this is a bit of a change in mind-set," said Mark Godfrey, senior analyst with Investco Funds Group in Denver, which holds 1.6 million P.& G. shares. "Before they stuck to a pretty conservative game plan. Durk has come in and shaken things up a little bit."
The reorganization is expected to be announced on Wednesday when executives meet with investors and analysts in New York. The company declined yesterday to comment on any planned job cuts or shift in its business structure.
Investors and analysts said that in addition to the job cuts and plant closings, they expected the company, which has 110,000 employees worldwide, to announce charges of $2 billion to $3 billion related to the reorganization. It would be the first significant revamping since 1993, when the company dismissed thousands of workers, closed dozens of plants and also took huge charges.
Analysts said management would have to justify another round of hefty charges. But the overall reorganization, if well executed, should make the company more competitive and ultimately increase profitability, they said.
"The very strong hint we've been getting from P.& G. is that they will end up being more nimble and getting product to market faster," said Constance Maneaty, an analyst with Bear, Stearns.
P.& G., though still a dominant force in consumer products, has long been accused of having a cumbersome management structure, a slow product development pipeline and a far too conservative global growth plan. Such weaknesses have enabled rivals like Unilever to grow more aggressively globally and smaller competitors like the Clorox Company to respond faster to new product trends. In one high-profile misstep, P.&G. was too slow to come out with new versions of Crest, long the undisputed leader in toothpaste. As a result, Colgate-Palmolive's new brand, Total, now outshines Crest.
Recently, however, P.& G. has begun to show more spunk. It has worked to push more forcefully into international markets. And last year, it introduced Febreeze, a product that removes odors from fabric and has quickly become a juggernaut. What is more, P.& G. is rolling out two products that while not revolutionary, analysts said, represent innovation that has at times been lacking at the company. They are Dryel, a dry-cleaning kit for home use, and Swiffer, an electrostatic mop with with disposable cloth.
Driven by the potential of such new products as well as innovation with its more traditional products, like new features on diapers and new formulas for laundry detergent, P.& G. has said that it expects to lift earnings 12 percent to 14 percent even without a reorganization. Now, "I'd expect that range to ratchet up," said Sally Dessloch, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEW ARMY;
EUROPEAN UNION VOWS TO BECOME MILITARY POWER

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 3

 BODY:
The leaders of 15 European countries decided today to make the European Union a military power for the first time in its 42-year history, with command headquarters, staffs and forces of its own for peacekeeping and peacemaking missions in future crises like those in Kosovo or Bosnia.
Long an economic giant, the European Union today has a common currency, the euro, in 11 countries. But when it comes to foreign and defense policy, Europe does not even have a telephone number, as Henry A. Kissinger sarcastically observed 25 years ago when he was Secretary of State. 
 All that will change by the end of next year, the 15 leaders vowed today.
By late 2000, according to the plan announced at the European Union summit meeting here, a single foreign and security policy czar will speak for Europe and carry out the military will of European leaders. The move will enable many of the members of NATO, as well as several European nations that are not in the alliance, to mount their own campaigns without America's might.
The European leaders declared: "The union must have the capacity for autonomous action, backed up by credible military forces, the means to decide to use them, and a readiness to do so, in order to respond to international crises without prejudice to actions by NATO."
They echoed language first used by President Jacques Chirac of France and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain six months ago after two crises in the Balkans showed how far Europe still had to go to be taken seriously as a military power, even on its own continent. Neither in Bosnia nor in Kosovo were European countries, whose total armed forces exceed those of the United States in size, able to project military power convincingly enough to halt the violence.
Today, all 15 leaders agreed to absorb the functions of the 10-nation Western European Union, a long-dormant European defense alliance founded a year before NATO in 1948. They said the Western European Union's 60,000-troop force, Eurocorps, would be put at the disposal of the new, more assertive Europe that is taking shape under the European Union. "In that event," they said, "the W.E.U. as an organization would have completed its purpose."
With Germany's 1990 unification acting as a spur to its neighbors to closer unity, the Treaty of European Union, negotiated at the end of 1991, committed the Europeans to a common currency and a common foreign and security policy and defense policy, building on the common market they created in 1957.
They reaffirmed those aspirations in another treaty signed in 1997, and succeeded in launching the euro at the start of this year.
But the common foreign and security policy sputtered along through successive crises in the Balkans in which the Europeans showed little unity or common purpose until the Americans sent in armed forces to help them in Bosnia in 1995.
Now Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, Mr. Chirac, Mr. Blair and the others are determined that Europe should be taken more seriously on the world stage. Part of what is driving them, their advisers say, is concern that the United States, with only 100,000 troops in Europe now compared with three times that many at the end of the cold war, will not indefinitely be willing to pull the fat out of the fire for Europeans who have long since been rich enough to provide for their own defenses.
American diplomats have welcomed Europe's newfound willingness to do more for itself. But they remain skeptical about whether they will actually be willing to spend the billions of dollars it would take to build the stronger European defense pillar that American defense secretaries for decades have been saying they wanted.
Today's declaration by European Union leaders makes clear that they still have a lot of work ahead of them to create the kind of military decision making and planning ability that NATO has had for many years.
Mr. Chirac suggested that the Western European Union's general staff and military committee, both based in a small headquarters in the center of Brussels some distance from NATO's, should be transferred to the European Union and presided over by its new foreign and security policy coordinator.
That could be Javier Solana of Spain, now Secretary General of NATO, whose candidacy for the job was on the leaders' agenda here tonight.
If Mr. Solana is selected, one senior American official said, "We would be very happy."
Gunter Verheugen, a German Government official who has also been suggested for that job, said of the plan to strengthen European defense, "It is not a replacement for the Atlantic partnership, but a significant and necessary complement to it."
The leaders themselves also noted, "The alliance remains the foundation of the collective defense of its member states."
All 10 members of the W.E.U. -- Britain, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Germany, and Greece -- already belong to both NATO and the European Union. Denmark does, too, but has only observer status in the smaller European defense organization, as do four other European Union members, Austria, Ireland, Finland and Sweden, which are neutral or nonaligned and do not belong to NATO.
These countries would be able to join future European Union peacekeeping or military operations, but only if they wanted to, the leaders agreed today, saying they would also welcome participation by other European countries.
NATO leaders agreed at their summit meeting in Washington in April on detailed arrangements to lend military headquarters organizations, multinational staffs, and tanks, helicopters and other equipment to the Europeans if they decided to undertake operations the United States prefers to avoid.
But these arrangements exist only on paper so far. In reality, when the NATO allies decided to use air power to try to force Yugoslavia to accept a settlement in Kosovo, only the United States had the hundreds of airplanes to throw into the battle and intelligence satellites and weaponry to mount a campaign with minimal risk to pilots.

HEADLINE: Stalemate on State Budget Eases as Assembly Yields

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 3

 BODY:
Prospects for approving a state budget moved today from abject stalemate to the realm of serious negotiation as Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver agreed to cut his house's spending proposals by $1 billion or more, the first significant movement by any side in three months.
The shift means that the overall budget figure proposed by the Democratic-controlled Assembly is near that of the Republican-majority Senate, though both still want to spend significantly more than Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican. The two houses are close enough that they could soon convene a conference committee to decide how the available money should be spent. 
Mr. Pataki welcomed the Assembly's movement, but he said today that the state remained far from settling a budget.
Democrats have felt under siege over this budget, now 64 days overdue. For months, Mr. Pataki has loudly assailed their proposal as unrealistic and irresponsible, while refusing to get involved in budget negotiations, an unusual stance that was intended to distance him from the looming fiasco of another very late budget.
He made it clear that he felt no pressure to jump-start negotiations and did not mind keeping the government running with a string of emergency spending bills, a stopgap that Democrats disliked because it limits spending to last year's levels.
A new law that requires withholding legislators' paychecks when a state budget is not completed by the deadline of March 31 has begun to exert great personal pressure on some lawmakers, and social service agencies, school districts and hospitals that rely on state money have begun to clamor for some degree of certainty about what they will receive as they prepare their own budgets. Meanwhile, Democrats have hunted without success for a way to avoid a repeat of last year, when Mr. Pataki vetoed well over $1 billion in spending approved by the Legislature, most of it appropriated for Democrats' pet projects.
In January, Mr. Pataki, who said he was determined to limit the increase in the state's budget to last year's inflation rate, proposed a $72.7 billion plan. He sought significant cuts in several programs dear to the Legislature, and particularly Democrats, like Medicaid and aid for public colleges and their students. And he proposed reversing the state's two-year-old commitment to financing prekindergarten classes for 4-year-olds, and the lowering of class sizes in kindergarten through third grade.
In March, the Assembly adopted a plan that was, by the Democrats' estimates, $2 billion higher than the Governor's. Republicans insisted it was actually $4 billion more. The Senate adopted a plan $1.1 billion higher than the Governor's.
Today, Mr. Silver said he had agreed to cut his overall spending plan to $1.1 billion to $1.5 billion over the Governor's plan, suddenly putting the Assembly on the same general terrain as the Senate and nearly eliminating the main obstacle to a conference committee. By the Democrats' estimate, they had reduced their demands by about $1 billion; the Republicans said Mr. Silver had come down by $2 billion or more.
At a news conference, Mr. Silver, clearly angry at the Governor and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, blamed them for reducing allocations for programs he said were needed, and delaying the budget. Mr. Silver, normally a reticent, colorless public speaker, gave an agitated account of the year's budget process, at one point giving a four-minute response to a simple question.
In explaining how the Democrats' retrenchment began with a conversation he had with the Governor late Wednesday, the Speaker charged that Mr. Pataki's exploration of a possible Presidential run, an idea that he abandoned last week, had consumed the Governor's time and attention, leaving no time for state issues.
"Now that his Presidential campaign has come to a halt," Mr. Silver said, "and he's been here, I chose to speak to him and explain to him his characterization of the Assembly budget has always been wrong, but that I was prepared to meet him more than halfway."
Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno agreed that once the conference committee convenes, a detailed budget can be hashed out in 10 to 14 days, raising the prospect -- all but unimaginable at the start of the week -- that a budget could be passed by the scheduled end of this year's legislative session, on June 16.
But Mr. Pataki tried to douse any high expectations that might be raised by the Democrats' new stance, saying, "We are still very, very far apart."
"I am not encouraged by the fact that we are still more than $1 billion apart in the month of June," he said. "It's just we're no longer $4 billion. It's like, how bad is it? Not quite as bad as it used to be. But it's still not something where I think we can look with a great sense of optimism."
The Governor also reiterated his warning that he viewed even the Senate Republicans' number as too high, and that he would veto items in a budget that large.
The Assembly Democrats want either a tacit commitment from the Governor not to use his veto aggressively, or a deal with the Senate Republicans to try to override any vetoes.

HEADLINE: Feeling Rich? Don't Get Smug Yet

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (Op-Ed, June 1) correctly argues that the consumer-led boom in the American economy "may not produce happiness, but it does create jobs." But American growth, impressive as it is, is showing signs of weakness. 
 Two warnings have surfaced: the rise in inflation in April, which may be temporary, and the trade deficit's recent jump to $19.4 billion, as more manufacturing jobs were lost and exports fell.
Spending, and trade, must keep the door open for foreign goods. But another trade war is heating up, and this battle over beef comes on the heels of the banana wars and a steel skirmish. Putting up trade barriers will limit the ability of Americans to buy that extra cellular phone, something to keep in mind as we head for more trade battles and an election year.
 
PAMELA S. FALK
Flushing, Queens, June 1, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of law at Queens College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Feeling Rich? Don't Get Smug Yet

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (Op-Ed, June 1) points out some of the pros and cons of increased spending but fails to mention the environmental costs. Larger cars, larger houses and larger closets with more clothes mean increased resource extraction, processing and conversion. Even if the depletion of natural resources were not problematic, the act of depletion can wreak havoc on the environment. Gold mining, for example, can leave toxic wastelands. The manufacture and the disposal of many goods create contaminants. So as consumption rises, so do the rates of cancer and a host of other health problems.
 
MARGRETHE WINSLOW
Oakland, Calif., June 1, 1999

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
MILOSEVIC YIELDS ON NATO'S KEY TERMS; 50,000 ALLIED TROOPS TO POLICE KOSOVO

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 3

 BODY:
On the 72d day of NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, President Slobodan Milosevic accepted an international peace plan today to end the Kosovo conflict and allow nearly one million ethnic Albanian refugees to return to what is left of their homes.
After forcing most of those refugees to flee from Kosovo and enduring thousands of Serbian military and civilian deaths, Mr. Milosevic and the Serbian Parliament agreed rapidly to all key NATO demands after envoys from Russia and other European nations brought what they made clear was the best offer he was going to get from NATO. 
 In a swift retreat that may spell political trouble for him down the road, Mr. Milosevic agreed to withdraw all Yugoslav military and police forces from Kosovo within seven days and allow 50,000 foreign troops under a United Nations flag -- many of them from NATO and under NATO command -- to police the province.
That withdrawal could begin as early as Sunday, said Goran Matic, a minister in the Yugoslav Government, once military leaders of both sides agreed on the details. What is important for Belgrade is that the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army not be allowed to fill the vacuum and flood into Kosovo, he said, and that NATO keep its commitment to "demilitarize" the rebels.
While NATO has emphasized the need for a strong force to prevent the Yugoslav President from reneging on his commitments, Belgrade officials and some Western diplomats here believe that its real difficulties will come from the Kosovo Liberation Army, which has received NATO support and is unlikely to give up its ambitions for independence.
Initial public reactions in the West, which appeared to be taken by surprise by the sudden prospect of victory, were cautious, and it was not immediately clear when or through what means the conflict will be brought to a conclusion. Western spokesmen said the Serbs must begin a "credible and verifiable withdrawal" from Kosovo before the bombs would stop, but NATO's bombing campaign slackened noticeably today.
The peace proposals accepted today were negotiated between NATO and Russia, which was acting for Belgrade. Once the Russian envoy, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, agreed on the basics of the deal with the American Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott, Mr. Milosevic -- who was indicted for war crimes last week -- clearly felt that he had no choice but to accept them or endure further destruction.
Under the proposals, fewer than 1,000 uniformed Serbs will be allowed to re-enter Kosovo, to guard key border posts and Serbian holy sites, as a symbol of Serbian and Yugoslav sovereignty over the southern province. But there will be little substance left to Belgrade's assertion of sovereignty. Kosovo will get "substantial autonomy" within Yugoslavia but for all intents and purposes, will have little to do with the Serbian or Yugoslav state.
An interim international authority will supervise the running of Kosovo and the establishment of new democratic institutions and elections, the return of all refugees and the rebuilding of the province. In the meantime, there will be new negotiations between Serbian and ethnic Albanian leaders to work out a long-term political settlement.
But in what Belgrade pointed to as a victory, the proposals accepted today do not propose a new examination of Kosovo's sovereignty after three years or any referendum on that topic, as did the draft proposals accepted by the Albanian side only in Rambouillet, France, in March. It was the Serbian refusal to accept those accords that led to the opening of the NATO air war on March 24, the sharp acceleration in the Serbian effort to push the Albanians out of Kosovo and the tidal wave of refugees into surrounding countries.
Yugoslav officials also said their resistance had forced NATO to find a solution within the United Nations and with the participation of the Russians. And they emphasized the firm international guarantees of Serbia's sovereignty over Kosovo, unlike the temporary sovereignty proposed at Rambouillet.
But there was also important nationalist criticism of Mr. Milosevic and this deal. The Radical Party and its leader, Deputy Prime Minister Vojislav Seselj of Serbia, voted against the proposals in Parliament, and Mr. Seselj vowed to quit the Government the day NATO troops enter Kosovo.
A former President of Yugoslavia, the nationalist historian Dobrica Cosic, called the vote "an extorted decision" and the proposals "a post-modernist packaging for the occupation of Kosovo." In an interview, Mr. Cosic, whose views on Kosovo carry much weight here, called Parliament's acceptance "a matter of survival, and not a matter of freedom and rights."
But there was no immediate political threat to Mr. Milosevic. The weak democratic opposition parties supported the move, and Vuk Draskovic, who was fired as Yugoslav Deputy Prime Minister during the war, praised the vote and said he would be willing to rejoin the Government, especially if Mr. Seselj quit.
Some confusion remains over who will lead the international force and over its exact makeup. The Russians are still insisting that their forces going to Kosovo will not be under NATO command, and have not yet agreed to send troops. The agreement accepted today by Mr. Milosevic says the forces will be under the auspices of the United Nations, but European and American officials say the troops will in fact be commanded by NATO.
Nor was it immediately clear when a military-to-military text would be negotiated, or when the agreement would be codified into a United Nations Security Council resolution.
But the deal may finally bring some peace, if not reconciliation, to Kosovo. A year ago, the province contained some 2.2 million people, about 90 percent of them ethnic Albanian.
Today, Kosovo is eerily depopulated, with nearly one million Albanians now living abroad as refugees and several hundred thousand more displaced from their homes. As many as 5,000 ethnic Albanians, NATO has charged, have been killed by the Serbs. Thousands of Serbian women and children have also fled the province, and it is likely that many Serbs will not want to remain in a Kosovo once their army and police have withdrawn.
With many thousands of ethnic Albanian shops and homes burned and looted, and basic services like road transport, electricity and water supplies destroyed or heavily damaged by the air war, the job of reconstructing Kosovo will also be enormous.
And it is likely that foreign troops and aid workers will occupy the province for many years to come, at a cost of billions of dollars.
After talks this morning between Mr. Milosevic and the diplomatic team of Mr. Chernomyrdin and President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland, who represented the European Union and articulated NATO's views, the state news agency Tanjug said simply, "Yugoslavia accepts the document for peace brought by the highest representatives of the European Union and Russia."
The statement continued, "The three sides unanimously agreed that commitment to peace was of vital importance, not only for Yugoslavia, but for the whole region and all of Europe."
Earlier this morning, the Serbian Parliament accepted the proposals on which party leaders had been briefed by Mr. Milosevic the night before. The Parliament voted 136 for and 74 against. Presumably, the 74 against included most of Mr. Seselj's 80 deputies.
Afterward, Mr. Seselj was blunt. "For sure, we will not stay in the Serbian Government from the moment that troops from aggressor countries, particularly the U.S.A., enter Kosovo," he said. And he warned that NATO troops "will not feel safe in Kosovo."
But Mr. Draskovic was ebullient, calling the vote "a great day for the Serbian nation and all the citizens of Yugoslavia." He said, "The Serbian Parliament today declared peace, and the beginning of peace must be the beginning of a new policy of radical economic and democratic reform."
Serbian state television tonight did not mention Mr. Seselj's opposition or quote him at all, but it did give Mr. Draskovic time to praise Mr. Milosevic.
There was no statement from Mr. Milosevic himself. But the television anchorman recited a long statement from Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party praising the Serbian nation and the international guarantees of Yugoslavia's "integrity and sovereignty."
"This decision brings us the cessation of the criminal bombing, of the killing of the people, and it brings us peace," the statement said. "The role of the United Nations is being affirmed in accordance with the U.N. Charter. Through the unity of the people and through the heroism of our army and our police, we have defended the country from a vastly superior enemy who committed aggression against our country with the goal of annulling our integrity and sovereignty."
There was also a statement from the Yugoslav United Left party of Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic.
"We are proud of the heroic resistance of our people," it said, adding that "in these circumstances we feel we can accept conditions" laid down by the world. "We are looking for the end of the bombing, and the great renewal," it said.

LENGTH: 1105 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/ Safety;
More Trucks on Road: Should Rules Change?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DRIVERS of cars may have the impression that there are more big trucks competing with them for space on the highway, and recent Government statistics confirm that their perception is correct. And although road fatalities are down over all, those involving heavy trucks are fairly level, at more than 5,000 a year.
A booming economy combined with a shift to just-in-time deliveries has meant a boom for the truck business. The chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, James E. Hall, pointed out in recent testimony that the industry is producing about 220,000 heavy trucks annually, up from 130,000 a decade ago. The Transportation Secretary, Rodney E. Slater, said that the number of miles traveled by trucks had increased 25 percent in the last four years, and the American Trucking Associations said last month that mileage could rise 15 percent this year alone. 
 Trucks are getting safer, but not fast enough to keep pace with their increased use. Large trucks were involved in fatal crashes at a rate of 2.5 for each 100 million miles traveled in 1997, the most recent year for which full statistics are available. That is down by more than half from 20 years earlier, when the rate was 5.4 for each 100 million miles. (In comparison, the rate for cars in that period fell to 1.9 from 3.5.)
But truck miles traveled more than doubled in that period, to 191 billion miles from 95 billion miles, so the absolute number of fatalities did not change much. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, part of the Transportation Department, said late last month that fatalities totaled 5,398 in 1997, of whom nearly all were in a car, van, pickup or other light vehicle, not in the heavy truck. The preliminary number for 1998 is 5,302. (The figures do not measure whether the accident was the truck's fault.)
Mr. Slater, speaking a day before a Congressional hearing that included testimony critical of his department's oversight, was announcing a goal of reducing truck fatalities by 50 percent over 10 years. He had good reason to try to beat Congress to the punch: A variety of critics, including his own department's inspector general, trace safety shortcomings to his department's inspectors, who these critics say seemed better suited to watching the large, staid, regulated trucking companies of the past than to to keeping an eye on the highly competitive, fast-moving swarms of small operators that dominate the roads now.
The industry is in such flux that the regulators have trouble keeping track of it. Nearly 500,000 trucking companies are registered with the department, but regulators say they think that up to 30 percent have merged or gone out of business.
A study released last week by Norman Y. Mineta, who was chairman of the House Transportation Committee when he represented a California district, said that companies less than three years old had higher crash rates and more safety problems. Tens of thousands of companies are less than three years old. The Transportation Department had asked Mr. Mineta to do the study.
Inspectors spent many hours trying to educate companies on safety procedures and Transportation Department regulations, said Kenneth Mead, the inspector general. "Partnership, collaboration and education went too far," he said, with the department often agreeing to forgo the collection of fines or other enforcement measures in exchange for promises to do better. But he said a significant minority of companies "had no interest in being educated."
One change announced by Mr. Slater is a limit on negotiated settlements and "wrist slaps," and an emphasis on bigger fines.
 Not everyone agrees that harsh penalties should replace education and warnings. The American Trucking Associations, reacting to a slight decline in deaths in 1998 from the year before, said this showed the success of "government partnership in safety education and outreach programs."
 The Government, though, is moving to get tougher. Mr. Slater said another goal was to double the number of "compliance reviews," or in-depth examinations of trucking companies, done by each investigator.
The department is also trying to streamline the legal framework for ordering bad carriers to shut down. Federal law used to require that the department show a company was an "imminent hazard" before it could bar the company, but Mr. Mead said the department never had a working definition of imminent hazard. A law that took effect this spring changes the standard to "unfit," and the department is trying to establish a regulation that defines the term.
Joan Claybrook, a former administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration who is now president of Public Citizen, a nonprofit advocacy group, said the problem was that the Transportation Department lacked the research and data base to make good decisions, as well as "a capacity to plan or meet deadlines for issuance of safety standards." Many safety advocates outside the department want truck regulation moved to the traffic safety administration from its current home in the Office of Motor Carriers, which they say shares the perspective of the trucking industry.
Mr. Slater has resisted the change and pointed to an improving level of safety which, he said, can be made better yet. Safety experts say that the biggest improvement in the last few years has been requiring a commercial driver's license under a national system. That prevents truckers from carrying licenses issued by several states and accumulating violations on each.
But Kenneth Wykle, the Federal Highway Administrator, said regulators had yet to use violations accrued on personal licenses, like speeding or drunken driving, as a basis for revoking a commercial license. Truckers involved in fatal accidents are often discovered to have such violations, he said.
The biggest unsolved question is hours-of-service regulations. That, said Mr. Mead, is "tied directly to fatigue." There are limits on how many hours a trucker can drive and how many he can be on duty, including loading time, but they are widely flouted, partly because drivers are paid by the mile.
"We're dealing with firms that create an environment or a culture where drivers are expected to drive to exhaustion," he said.
Experts say that the problem varies by the size of the company. Big companies with deep pockets may fear liability suits and follow the rules more closely; small ones often don't. But the industry is heavy with small companies. Mr. Mead said that 317,000 companies have six or fewer tractors; only 2,800 have more than 100 tractors.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 29; Column 2; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2472 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
Colonial Myth And Reality

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Thomas Jefferson was taking questions from the audience, all reverential, about the Louisiana Purchase, his interest in wine making and the men who shaped his mind. (Sir Isaac Newton, Sir Francis Bacon and John Locke, he replied.) Skittish about breaking the weird decorousness of the event at Colonial Williamsburg, which was a supposed conversation with the retired third President, I nonetheless raised my hand and asked if Jefferson had changed his opinion about the newspapers of his day after they printed the "scurrilous rumors" about Sally Hemings, the slave with whom he is thought by many modern historians, on the basis of DNA evidence, to have fathered a child.
"Is that still continuing?" replied the smiling Jefferson, the actor Bill Barker, as the audience laughed. Playing to type and historical accuracy, Jefferson then said, "I never made answer on it publicly, and I will not do so today." 
 He added, in a soft Virginia drawl, that he was happier since giving up newspapers in his retirement -- during Jefferson's Presidency, the papers went big with the Hemings scandal -- but then said, paraphrasing Jefferson's most famous defense of freedom of the press, that he would rather have "a nation with newspapers and no government than a nation with government and no newspapers."
The audience broke into enthusiastic applause, as if a President himself had spoken.
For three days this spring, my husband and I and our two children, ages 9 and 5, wandered around Colonial Williamsburg, the Virginia "living history" museum built by John D. Rockefeller Jr., which I had anticipated as another Disneyland. Instead, I found it genuinely historically interesting, if sometimes hokey, with a new emphasis on the slaves who made up more than half the town's population in the 18th century.
Like the study of American history itself, the 18th-century capital of the Virginia colony has changed in its 65 years of restoration from a sanitized celebration of the white planter elite -- even in 1981 the historian Mike Wallace wrote that "it embodies a vision of total social order" -- to a more real, and not always politically correct, evocation of the nastier past. A 1994 re-enactment of a slave auction, for example, caused outrage among some blacks.
 
Untold Stories
This year's theme at Williamsburg, "Enslaving Virginia," offers the most extensive programming yet on the town residents whose stories were largely unknown to tourists until the 1970's, when a new generation of Williamsburg historians began insisting on their inclusion. Since 1998, Williamsburg has organized its programs around four rotating "Days in History." And if you are there on the day that is supposed to be Nov. 17, 1775, when Lord Dunmore, the colony's governor, offered freedom to any slave who sided with the British crown, it is possible to spend almost all of your time, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., in history walks, talks and re-enactments focused on slavery.
In between, you can stumble into conversations with some of Williamsburg's 100 or so "character interpreters," actors who engaged us in interactive, impromptu and slightly embarrassing theater often meant to teach the unsavory reality of the past.
"Terrible news about town today, you have probably heard," one actor playing a Colonial Williamsburg resident announced when we approached him and a cluster of patriots on Duke of Gloucester Street, the main street.
"Negroes with arms -- can you believe it?" another asked.
"A wise move, to free the servants and slaves of your enemy," the first said, referring to Lord Dunmore.
Stepping in, which seemed to be what I was supposed to do, I asked how people who spoke of freedom could own slaves.
"God himself has put them here to be slaves," a third actor said.
And then, making sure we got the point, the first said, "You cannot free such valuable property."
But earlier we had been to the Courthouse for the re-enactment of several trials and an unpleasant moment when Williamsburg's desire to be honest about its history with blacks collided with 1999 sensitivities. An audience of tourists filled the spectators' benches as actors playing a bailiff, an obnoxious defendant and a judge argued over a case.
At one point the judge asked for three volunteers from the courtroom to inspect some land in dispute. The tourists all volunteered eagerly, amused to be playing 18th-century colonists. The bailiff selected three, two of them young black men.
But the judge rejected the two, because they were black. "Free Negroes can't serve!" barked the defendant, underscoring the point, as the two 20th-century blacks sat down, looking embarrassed. When I asked Williamsburg about the incident after I got back, Stephen Elliott, the vice president for education, winced, saying that the scene had been cut from the trial last year and that it shouldn't have happened.
 
Choices for Visitors
We arrived in town, a seven-hour drive from New York City, halfway through another of Williamsburg's "days in history," May 15, 1776, when the colonists declared their independence. We were unaware of this until we were efficiently educated by a Williamsburg Inn concierge, who presented us with the Visitor's Companion, a newspaper for tourists, which listed a daunting buffet of all Colonial Williamsburg events for the week. Looking at it was like trying to decide what courses to take in college, but our concierge quickly circled what she thought was best for us and the children.
We weren't staying at the inn proper, the behemoth white-columned institution of choice for visiting heads of state (Williamsburg was the site of an economic summit conference for the world's industrial powers in 1983) but at its lower-priced and modern Providence Hall Wing, which is recommended for families. There, the rooms are bigger and decorated with the usual wing chairs, but not with antiques. We had a balcony that looked over a duck pond, and were just a short walk from the inn, where we ate breakfast.
The next morning we walked the five minutes to the historic district for an orientation tour, led by a guide, Jerry Hedgepeth, who pointed out attractions like the Wyeth House, where Jefferson went to law school, and advised us that "if you haven't been here before, don't try to kill yourself."
He also gave a brief history lesson: In 1699 the Virginia capital moved from Jamestown to Williamsburg, a planned city built around a town common, Market Square, and anchored by the Capitol building at one end and the College of William and Mary at the other. Although Virginia's capital moved to Richmond in 1780, Williamsburg was still intact in 1926, when Rockefeller began the restoration that would eventually cost $68 million. Today there are more than 500 restored or reconstructed buildings and 90 acres of gardens and greens.
One of the first things I noticed was that Williamsburg, though bucolic, was not pristine; paint was peeling off many of the white clapboard houses, some of the grass was scruffy and sandy dirt covered the main streets. And yet earlier criticism of the town by historians focused on its absurd perfectness. When I got back home, I called Cary Carson, Williamsburg's vice president for research, who told me that Williamsburg has in fact worked recently to make the town less precious.
"We used to paint all of the buildings at the same time," he said. "But nobody now and nobody then painted their property from end to end." He added that sand is now brought in to cover up the 20th-century blacktop of Duke of Gloucester Street and that some of the lawn-mowing is done by grazing sheep.
After the tour, we went to some of the trades shops, popular with the children, like that of the printer and the wig maker, who told us that the hairpieces favored by 18th-century gentlemen were "beastly uncomfortable, but they were fashion."
In the afternoon I went on "Enslaving Virginia," a one-hour history walk with a guide, Harvey Bakari, who ran through a quick general history of slavery, then described how slaves did the invisible work, lost to history, that made Williamsburg possible. He concluded that "the system of slavery would cause the colony to live with a contradiction, the contradiction of liberty and bondage."
The only problem, and it was hardly Mr. Bakari's fault, was that there were few remnants on the walk to illustrate his points; the slaves lived in Williamsburg's outbuildings behind the big houses and left behind no furniture and almost no belongings. Although slaves may well have spent as much time as anyone else laboring behind the scenes in the town's grand buildings, their identities were invisible in the Governor's Palace or the Courthouse.
We ate most of our meals in Williamsburg's not-cheap restaurants, where the waitresses wore period garb and the Colonial-style food was mediocre, although no doubt better than what people really ate in the 18th century. The best was Christiana Campbell's Tavern, a reconstruction of the original, where George Washington dined.
I had scallop and oyster pot pie and was startled when an actress playing Mrs. Campbell materialized in front of us, asking how we liked our dinner. The real Mrs. Campbell was described not very pleasantly by an 18th-century traveler as "a little old Woman, about four feet high; & equally thick, a little turn up Pug nose, a mouth screw'd up to one side." The actress was younger and taller, but her odd little dinner performance proved how fluid, and alive, history is.
Today the contradictions of Jefferson on slavery are as riveting as they were in his time. Just as we imagined the real Christiana Campbell in her tavern, we could imagine the real Jefferson arguing in the House of Burgesses, a part of the reconstructed Capitol that nonetheless was compelling to see. History by definition is an act of the imagination, especially for children. Williamsburg helps it take flight.
 
Stepping Back Into the 1700's (With Some Modern Comforts)
Here is information about visiting Colonial Williamsburg:
 
Colonial Williamsburg
ADDRESS: Colonial Williamsburg, Box 1776, Williamsburg, Va., 23187-1776, (800) 447-8679 or (757) 220-7645. Web sites are www.history.org and www. colonialwilliamsburg.org.
ADMISSION: A Patriot's Pass ($35; $20 for children 6 to 12) provides admission and parking for a year, including entry to all exhibition buildings, like the Capitol, the Courthouse and the Governor's Palace; discounts on concerts and plays, and entry to 18th-century homes open to the public, including the Peyton Randolph House and the George Wythe House. The Colonist's Pass ($31; $18 for children) is good for two consecutive days and includes all basic admission privileges along with the Governor's Palace. It does not include parking, which costs $6. The one-day basic admission ($27; $16 for children) includes the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Center, the DeWitt Wallace Gallery and all exhibition buildings in the historic area except the Governor's Palace. It does not include parking. All packages include an orientation walk and are free for children under 6. And all allow visitors to wander into any of the Colonial trade sites. Other packages are available at the Visitor Center and at ticket offices around the historic center.
HOURS: 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily at most sites.
SPECIAL PROGRAMS: The theme at Williamsburg this year is "Enslaving Virginia," focusing on slavery and how historical events affected the people who lived in Williamsburg, especially the slaves, who made up 52 percent of the population. "Am I Not a Man and a Brother: Abolition and Anti-Slavery in the Early Chesapeake" is an exhibition on how the abolition and anti-slavery movements found expression in the decorative arts and in the printed word; through Jan. 2, in the DeWitt Wallace Gallery. Four rotating "Days in History" programs focus on events on a particular day in the 18th century. Programs today and Tuesday use Nov. 17, 1775, "The Sword Is Drawn: Lord Dunmore's Proclamation," with the focus on armed conflict. Tomorrow and Wednesday are May 15, 1776, "Virginia Declares Independence." Sunday is May 8, 1769, "Rule, Britannia," when most Virginians believed that problems could be worked out between the colonies and England. Monday and Thursday are April 29, 1775, "The Gathering Storm," when antagonism between the British and the colonies has reached a boiling point.
 
Where to Stay
WILLIAMSBURG INN, PROVIDENCE HALL, COLONIAL HOUSES, WILLIAMSBURG LODGE, WILLIAMSBURG WOODLANDS and GOVERNOR'S INN are owned by Colonial Williamsburg. Summer rates range from $133 to $330. Information: (800) 447-8679 or (757) 229-1000.
COURTYARD BY MARRIOTT, 470 McLaws Circle, Williamsburg, (757) 221-0700. A double room in June is $129 on weekdays, $149 on weekends.
MOTEL 6, 3030 Richmond Road, Williamsburg, (757) 565-3433. A double room in June is $52 on weekdays, $56 on weekends.
Where to Eat
KING'S ARMS, CHOWNING'S, SHIELDS and CHRISTIANA CAMPBELL'S TAVERN are on the premises of Colonial Williamsburg. For reservations: (800) 447-8679 or (757) 229-2141. Dinner entrees from $17 to $26.
THE TRELLIS, Merchant's Square, Williamsburg, (757) 229-8610. Upscale California casual. Dinner entrees from $18 to $25.
 
How to Get There
PLANE: Williamsburg is 150 miles south of Washington, midway between Richmond and Norfolk off Interstate 64. The Newport News-Williamsburg International Airport is 20 minutes from Williamsburg and is served by United Express, (800) 241-6522, and US Airways, (800) 428-4322. Round-trip flights between La Guardia or Newark and Newport News, changing at Dulles Airport in Washington, range from $226 (a 14-day advance reservation and a Saturday stay over) to $616 (last-minute ticket). US Airways and its US Airways Express offer nonstop flights between La Guardia and Norfolk International Airport, 50 miles southeast of Williamsburg, for $226 round trip.
TRAIN: Amtrak service to Williamsburg is available twice daily. The trip from New York to Williamsburg is eight and a half hours; round-trip fares begin at $144. Information: (800) 872-7245.
CAR: Colonial Williamsburg is a 45-minute drive from either Richmond or Norfolk on I-64 (exit 238). After exiting, look for green and white signs to the Visitor Center. After purchasing an admission pass, you may take the shuttle bus or walk to the historic area. Rental cars are available from the major chains at the airport or through Colonial Rent-a-Car, which has an office at the train station, (757) 220-3399.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders, Minus Planes, Rise 5th Time in Six Months

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
Orders placed with manufacturers other than airplane makers rose in April, suggesting that a record peacetime expansion may be picking up speed.
Factory orders rose five-tenths of a percent during April, when often- volatile demand at the Boeing Company and other aircraft makers is excluded, making it the fifth increase in the last six months, Commerce Department statistics showed today. Overall orders fell 1.2 percent during the month after declining six-tenths of a percent in March. 
 The report could give Federal Reserve policy makers fresh reasons to raise interest rates. Still, some analysts said such a move might not be warranted. While "there's nothing to suggest the economy is cooling off," reports do not suggest the economy is growing fast enough to ignite inflation, said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
In a separate report, initial jobless claims rose 4,000, to 305,000, last week, the Labor Department said. This year, claims have averaged 305,000 a week, lower than 1998's average of 316,000, suggesting that companies continue to hire workers.
The employment picture is helping lift demand for everything from new clothing to toys to electronics.
"I don't see any sign of slowing down in consumer spending -- there are still robust numbers across the board," said Steve Paspal, senior analyst at Sovereign Asset Management, a unit of John Hancock Funds.
Nonmanufacturers, such as banks, farms and retailers, said in May that business continued to grow, although at a slower pace than April, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly index released today. The index declined to 60 from 64 in April, largely because of declines in growth in new orders. An index above 50 indicates more businesses reported improved conditions than reported declining ones.
The report on nonmanufacturers comes two days after the association reported a continuing recovery in manufacturing in May. Its factory index rose in May to its highest level since October 1997 and held above 50 for a fourth consecutive month after eight months of below-50 readings.
Edward Gramlich, a Fed governor, said today that the factory index "raises concerns" as policy makers ponder whether to raise interest rates at their next meeting, which will be on June 29-30.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
$253 MillionSanctions Sought in Beef Fight With Europe

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 3

 BODY:
A trans-Atlantic fight over hormone-treated beef intensified today when United States and Canadian officials asked the World Trade Organization to approve $253 million in retaliatory trade sanctions and the European Union countered by demanding arbitration that it hopes will lower the overall amount.
Like a recent dispute over bananas, the quarrel over beef reflects American anger over the failure of the 15-nation European Union to abide by decisions of the trade organization, which makes the rules of international commerce. The trade arbiter has said that the European preference for bananas grown in former colonies is illegal. 
 Faced with the European Union's refusal to revise its banana-import policy, the Clinton Administration imposed $191.4 million in tariffs on European products. It is seeking a further $202 million in 100 percent tariffs on a new range of European goods because the European Union has refused to lift its ban on beef produced in the United States, as it was supposed to do by May 13 under a previous trade organization ruling.
The Canadians asked for $51 million in sanctions because their beef is also blocked from the enormous European market.
The trade organization first found the beef ban illegal in 1997 on the ground that food safety concerns cannot be used to restrict trade without a specific finding of a health risk.
As in the bananas case, European Union officials invoked the right to a review by a trade organization arbitration panel and are expected to argue that the United States beef trade is worth only half the claimed yearly losses.
The European Trade Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said today that the trade bloc would seek a significant reduction, arguing that the United States figure of $202 million was "grossly excessive." He said, "They haven't suffered that amount of damage."
In declining to meet the May deadline, the European Union issued preliminary findings from a new scientific study that said that one growth-promoting hormone could cause cancer. Ian Wilkinson, deputy head of the European Union's mission to the trade organization in Geneva, said 17 studies are expected to be done by the end of the year.
Meantime, the dispute goes to a three-member arbitration panel that under the trade organization's rules must decide by July 12 on the amount of trade sanctions. Only then will the trade organization permit the United States and Canada to impose them.
However, signaling a new area of dispute, the Europeans seek a final list of products that will be penalized before sanctions are imposed, a request Washington opposes.
An initial list, which included pork, Roquefort cheese, truffles and mineral water, was published on March 25 in the Federal Register. But Rita Hayes, the United States envoy to the trade organization, said today that "the final list of sanctions will not be drawn up until we have W.T.O. authorization" -- after arbitration is completed.
She said that although the United States cattle industry had reported $500 million in lost business annually, Washington asked for a lower amount because "we felt this was a figure that would represent the amount of damages we are looking for."
Efforts by the two sides to arrive at a compromise failed when European Union officials would not commit to lifting the ban eventually. Then, after the May 3 release of preliminary findings that supported the United States position, the consumer affairs director for the European Commission declared that it would never lift the beef barrier. "There has never been a comparable statement from anyone in the E.U. contradicting this statement," Ms. Hayes said today.
The United States has offered to label its beef exports as produced in this country, but that suggestion has foundered in part because the whole area of altered or adulterated foods is highly sensitive. One consequence of the "mad cow" disease outbreak in Britain three years ago was that beef consumption in Europe plummeted. More recently, a scandal over Belgian poultry and other products that could be laced with the highly toxic chemical dioxin has reinforced fears about the food trade.
Both sides in the beef dispute have agreed to have scientists look at the evidence in the European Union study that was released last month. But United States officials say they have produced no new data or findings that the six hormones at issue can cause cancer. "There are no health risks from U.S. beef," Ms. Hayes said, citing conclusions by World Health Organization experts last February that three of the hormones, which occur naturally in animals, do not pose health risks.
In the United States, 63 percent of all cattle and 90 percent of feed cattle are fitted with hormone implants, which are placed under the skin behind the animals' ears, to hasten growth.

U.S. Acts on Dioxin Scare
 WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reuters) -- The United States will block imports of poultry and pork from the European Union to make sure that the products are not tainted with the cancer-causing chemical dioxin, an official with the Department of Agriculture said today.
Earlier, European leaders decided to destroy chicken and egg-based foods originating in Belgium in Europe's worst food safety scare since the "mad cow" disease outbreak in Britain.
The European Commission has already announced emergency Europe-wide restrictions on the affected Belgian chicken and egg products, including fresh pasta, mayonnaise and cakes, and may now impose even tougher curbs on pork after learning that pig breeders, in addition to poultry farmers, may have used animal feed tainted with dioxin.

HEADLINE: A Buoyant May at Retailers As Shopping Spree Goes On

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
United States retailers posted robust sales in May as consumers continued to show great confidence in the economy by snatching up everything from wardrobes in summer white to pool furniture.
Sales in retail stores open at least a year, a key industry measurement, rose 5.6 percent in May compared with results in the month a year earlier, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. The figure was not a perfect comparison, however, because some merchants did not include sales from the Memorial Day weekend, traditionally a big spending weekend, which came a week later than last year. 
 The strong increase adds to an already brisk year for merchants. In the first four months of 1999, sales in stores open at least a year rose 6.7 percent compared with figures in the period a year earlier. That was one of the biggest jumps in years, according to the Goldman Sachs survey.
Analysts see few signs that the consumption binge will abate. "The depth and breadth of this economic expansion has been unbelievable, and we continue to think the consumer is in good shape," said Jeff Feiner, managing director at Lehman Brothers. "The really good news is that despite better-than-expected numbers, retailers have budgeted very conservatively for the more important second half of the year." Mr. Feiner has increased earnings estimates for several large retailers.
Discount chains continued to be at the center of the sales boom. Wal-Mart Stores posted an increase of 7.7 percent, and Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, was up 7.4 percent. Specialty apparel stores -- buoyed by hot weather, which caused customers to snatch up capri pants and brightly hued tank tops -- also sustained strong increases. Ann Taylor was up 10.1 percent, and American Eagle Outfitters was up 18.7 percent.
Even previously struggling brands showed solid gains. The Limited Inc., which posted a 10 percent growth in sales, had star performances from all its units, including Lane Bryant, which was up 12 percent, and Express, up 6 percent.
A notable exception in speciality apparel came from the normally invincible Gap Inc. Though sales were up a solid 8 percent, almost all the growth came from the rocket-charged performances of the Banana Republic division, which gained 17 percent, and Old Navy, 19 percent. The Gap Stores and Gap Kids posted declines of 1 percent to 4 percent. Analysts had been predicting that the Gap stores would rise 1 percent to 4 percent.
"We are not going to deliver a home run every time, especially since we were up against very strong numbers from last year," said Warren Hashagen, chief financial officer at Gap. Still, he added that "we have had a little bit of weakness in the merchandising assortment, but we are getting new merchandise in this week."
Department stores, which have consistently lagged behind the discounters in recent years, nevertheless had a strong showing. Federated Department Stores, whose units include Bloomingdale's and Macy's, had an increase of 4.1 percent, and Saks, the former Profitt's, said sales increased 3 percent.
Even the moderate-price merchants, the J. C. Penney Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company, which have struggled in recent years as they have lost customers to hipper outlets like Target and Old Navy, posted respectable gains. Sales were up 2.2 percent at Penney and 1.9 percent at Sears.
