HEADLINE: Support Shrinks for China's Trade Status

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 3

 BODY:
President Clinton briefly acknowledged the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square killings today and argued, with logic that is meeting increasing skepticism on Capitol Hill, that only by pushing ahead on expanding trade with Beijing can the United States remain "a force for social change in China."
Though members of Congress were not formally in Washington to receive Mr. Clinton's annual notification that he was renewing "normal trade relations" with China, they said they expected Mr. Clinton would once again prevail. Though Congress has often threatened to revoke China's trade status, it has never actually done so, even in the months after Tiananmen. 
 Nonetheless, by the count of some legislators, the majority in support of renewal is shrinking, on both the left and the right. Since reports of Chinese spying at national nuclear laboratories emerged, conservatives who once paid scant attention to human rights issues in China have formed an alliance of convenience with those who have long advocated linking China's trade status with its behavior in other arenas.
It is an alliance that clearly leaves some uncomfortable. Today, Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat and a harsh critic of Mr. Clinton's policy, argued anew that Congress should deny China the trade benefits -- mostly lower taxes on Chinese goods shipped to the United States -- because Mr. Clinton's "engagement" policy "has not succeeded in making trade fairer, people freer or the world safer." But she also went after some of the newest critics of engagement: Republicans who were seizing on the spy scandal.
"This year, with a highly charged partisan atmosphere," she said, "the Republican leadership now wants to have it both ways. They want to exploit politically the failures of the Clinton China policy, while appeasing the business community" by renewing China's trade status.
In fact, many members of Congress appear of two minds. The Democratic minority leader, Representative Richard Gephardt, has consistently voted against renewal of the trade rights and in a telephone interview today he said he would oppose it again this year -- and expected "somewhat more support."
But he also backs the Administration's efforts to strike a deal with China that would get it into the World Trade Organization. Part of that bargain would require Congress to drop the annual debate and grant China a permanent version of what was once called "most favored nation" status. (The pro-trade contingent in Congress argued that the old phrase was misleading, since the privileges are given to all but a few rogue states.)
"There's a difference," Mr. Gephardt said. "If China's accession to the W.T.O. is done right, it can be a real force for change because it would provide a real structure of rules and a way we could enforce them."
But he has been pressing the White House to include some commitments from China on human rights, something missing from the current talks on China's membership.
On the one hand, several members of Congress say they want to preserve the right to vote each year on China's trade status because it gives them an opportunity to vent their emotions on one of the most emotionally charged issues in American foreign policy. On the other hand, they are under greater pressure from business constituents, farmers and investors to take the deal that China has offered, which calls for vast openings in China's market over the next five years.
"We obviously have a difficult situation this year," said Representative David Drier, a California Republican who has often led the fight to renew trading rights. "There's a great temptation to mix this issue with the findings of the Cox Commission on spying, with campaign contribution issues and with anger at China's response to the accidental bombing of their embassy in Belgrade. But to me it still doesn't make sense to withdraw the one positive thing we have going with the Chinese."
The Administration makes a similar case, arguing that even if China has gone backward on human rights issues (by the State Department's annual assessment) and security relations are tainted by the spying report, Washington should not waver from its trade policies.
But the White House's argument in favor of engagement is running into increasing opposition precisely because the predicted results have hardly materialized.
When President Clinton switched sides on this debate in 1994 and decided to separate the annual trade accord from China's human rights record, he argued that deeper economic engagement would inevitably open up the country to a more progressive view of rights. He made that case again today in a written statement, saying trade would spread "the tools, the contacts and ideas that promote freedom."
To some degree that is clearly the case: E-mail has changed the way Chinese communicate with the outside world, and American companies in China have pressed for clearer laws and insisted on enforcement of international copyright rules and other conventions. But China still imprisons dissidents and suppresses challenges to the Communist Party.
As a result, there is growing pressure on the White House to include at least some vague commitments on human rights in any agreement to get China into the World Trade Organization. "Members will need some cover to retreat from their past positions," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch/Asia.
But given its current mood, and the anti-American demonstrations on the streets last month, China seems unlikely to let noneconomic commitments into its W.T.O. accord.
Republicans are badly split. Today the House Budget Committee chairman, John Kasich, an Ohio Republican, said that at a time of espionage charges, renewing China's trade status "sends the wrong message at the wrong time."
But that was in sharp contrast to Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, who warned last week that this year's renewal "could be in some jeopardy" if continued revelations about China "poison the environment." He has argued for a more tempered approach, one that recognizes that "we should not hold all of our other interests hostage" to China's behavior.

HEADLINE: Robert Sobel, 68, a Historian of Business, Dies

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Robert Sobel, a prolific historian of American business life whose topics ranged from the economic philosophy of President Calvin Coolidge to the influence of the junk-bond financier Michael Milken, died on Wednesday at his home in Long Beach, N.Y. He was 68.
The cause of death was brain cancer, said a spokeswoman for Hofstra University, where Professor Sobel taught for 43 years. 
 Professor Sobel's first book, "The Origins of Intervention," was published in 1961, when he was a 30-year-old history instructor at Hofstra, in Hempstead, N.Y. His latest, completed as he underwent unsuccessful cancer treatments, is a study of business blunders called "When Giants Stumble," just released by Prentice-Hall Press.
Besides teaching, Professor Sobel was the author, co-author or editor of more than 50 books and hundreds of articles and corporate profiles.
Most of his books were written for a general audience, but he never bristled when some scholarly writers dismissed him as a "popularizer," said his colleague and friend George David Smith, a professor of economic history at New York University. "Quite the contrary -- he saw that as his mission in life."
Still, that did not stop Professor Sobel from taking a gentle revenge on his ivory-tower critics in 1973, with publication of "For Want of a Nail," his mock textbook recounting the history of North America had General Burgoyne won the Revolutionary War battle at Saratoga. His spoof included pompous footnotes about petty disputes among imaginary scholars and a wholly invented bibliography of ludicrously boring and arcane references -- as well as an appendix featuring a list of the "leaders of the United States of Mexico," starting with its first president, Andrew Jackson.
But his dominant passion was Wall Street, a metaphysical neighborhood that had fascinated him since childhood. "It is as though you are walking through a historical theme park, with this engaging man at your side pointing out the sights," said Andrew Tobias, the author and investment guide, in a review in The New York Times of "The Last Bull Market: Wall Street in the 1960's" (W. W. Norton, 1978).
Professor Sobel wrote two studies of the New York Stock Exchange and two books on the American Stock Exchange. Friends said he considered "The Life and Times of Dillon Read" (Dutton, 1991) to be his finest book, but he produced other notable profiles of Wall Street characters, including "Dangerous Dreamers: The Financial Innovators from Charles Merrill to Michael Milken" (John Wiley & Sons, 1993).
To that he added a history of financial panics, a history of speculative bubbles and an account of the frenzied market of the 1920's.
Richard Sylla, an economic historian at New York University, acknowledged that Mr. Sobel's "pot-boiler style" sometimes drew criticism in academic circles. "But specialized scholars could learn a lot from him -- and you are talking to one who did," Professor Sylla added.
While in graduate school, friends say, Mr. Sobel found that he loved to write. "He was a compulsive writer," Professor Smith said. "He was miserable when he was not writing."
Indeed, in an academic realm where publishing is often considered the grim alternative to perishing, Mr. Sobel's published works were only one tributary of the broad river of words he produced. Unlike most academic writers, he was happy to ghost-write business books bearing other people's names. And he collaborated on a host of biographical projects that never reached a public audience, including the privately published memoirs of Joseph Cullman, the legendary leader of Philip Morris, and an authorized biography of Louis E. Wolfson, an early pioneer in corporate takeovers who ran afoul of Federal securities regulators.
Professor Sobel was clearly less enthralled by the corporate world, but that only slightly affected his output. His corporate histories included studies of RCA, ITT, the Penn Central Railroad, the automotive industry, the tobacco industry, the Trammell Crow construction empire and two books on I.B.M.
Rounding out his bookcase were economic assessments of Herbert Hoover and Calvin Coolidge and studies of the American Revolution, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution.
Robert Sobel was born and raised in the Bronx, the son of a commercial draftsman who drew promotional posters for the Loews chain of movie theaters. He was educated at James Monroe High School and the City College of New York, and earned his master's degree in history at New York University in 1952 before enlisting in the armed forces during the Korean War.
He later told family members that he had hoped to be a military intelligence officer but was turned down because of unfounded suspicions that he was related to Morton Sobell, another City College graduate who was a figure in the spy case involving Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Instead, he served as an administrative clerk in the Army.
He returned to New York University after his discharge in 1955. He worked as a history instructor there and, starting in 1956, at Hofstra while working on his doctorate at N.Y.U. After his degree was conferred in 1957, he joined the faculty at Hofstra, where he remained for four decades.
In 1990, he was awarded the university's Lawrence Stetson Distinguished Professorship in business history, which he held until his retirement in May 1998. A memorial service will be held for Professor Sobel in September at the Hofstra campus, where flags have been lowered to half-staff in his honor.
For all the years he spent in the classroom, friends say that teaching history did not satisfy him as much as writing history -- or, indeed, writing anything.
Besides producing books, articles, book reviews, and scripts for television and audiotapes, he was a weekly columnist for Newsday from 1972 to 1988. At the time of his death he was a contributing editor to Barron's magazine. He also worked as a consultant for the Winthrop Group in Cambridge, Mass. His family says that two completed book manuscripts are scheduled for publication posthumously.
Professor Sobel is survived by his wife, Carole Ritter Sobel of Long Beach; his mother, Blanche Sobel of Riverdale; a brother, Alan Sobel of Brooklyn; two children, Barbara Sobel of Queens and David Sobel of Alexandria, La., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS;
An Intellectual Guerrilla: Thabo Mbeki

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, June 3

 BODY:
As Winnie Madikizela-Mandela shouted recently to a cheering crowd in a black township: "I'm sick and tired of white-controlled media who say they don't know Thabo Mbeki. Who cares?"
President Nelson Mandela's ex-wife, whose speeches usually have vaguely threatening undertones, was unsubtly pointing out that when Mr. Mbeki takes over as President on June 16, he will govern with a huge mandate whether whites or anyone else know him or not. 
 Not that this means they need be afraid. South Africa's second post-apartheid President is someone who has no military background, is an able administrator and repeatedly pledges himself to democracy and to fighting corruption even in his own party.
His Government, Mr. Mbeki said in his victory speech today, will "approach the exercise of power without any arrogance, with humility."
If Nelson Mandela is the George Washington of this new democracy, the kind of giant among men who turns down offers to be king, then Mr. Mbeki is its John Adams. Like Adams, he is small, sharply intelligent, visionary, reflective, sometimes tart-tongued, and an adept back-room fighter.
He is also, on any occasion, the man most likely to turn up too formally dressed.
Playing on their difference in raiment, the dapper Mr. Mbeki, 56, has mused publicly on his resentment of people who constantly ask whether he can fill Mr. Mandela's shoes.
"Why should I wear those big, ugly things?" he said. "Or," he added with a shudder, "those shirts" -- meaning the bold "Madiba shirts" that Mr. Mandela adopted after a trip to Indonesia.
Mr. Mbeki intends to fit his own smaller but more meticulously polished shoes.
Born on June 18, 1942, Thabo Mbeki (pronounced TAH-boh mm-BEG-ee) grew up in poverty in Mbewuleni village in the Idutywa area of the Transkei -- the historic land of the Xhosa.
Though he grew up on the side of the valley with the rural peasantry who wore blankets and painted their faces with red clay, Mr. Mbeki was the son of radical party intellectuals who ran a small store and taught school to survive.
He was in the liberation struggle virtually from the age of 10, when he and a cousin sold Coke bottles to raise money to pay their African National Congress membership fees. The struggle eventually cost him a son, a brother and, two biographers say, any real relationship with his father, who was one of its heroes.
The father, Govan Mbeki, spent much of his life in jail and sent his children away to relatives very young so they couldn't come to depend on parents who expected to be arrested. The elder Mr. Mbeki, whose wife still lives in Idutywa, now lives in a bungalow on the grounds of his son's official mansion, but "seems sad, lonely and regretful," with "little familial warmth either in the relationship or even in Thabo's achievements," according to a new biography, "The Life and Times of Thabo Mbeki" (Adrian Hadland and Jovial Rantao, Zebra Press, April 1999).
Mr. Mbeki dislikes revealing himself. His precampaign book "Africa, the Time Has Come" is just a collection of speeches, with a dry 22-page biographical sketch.
But even the speeches reveal a great deal. His 1964 statement to a United Nations committee in London, delivered when he was a 21-year-old student asking it to somehow prevent the Pretoria Government from hanging his father, is an ennobling portrait of the elder Mr. Mbeki, touching in its combination of humility and righteousness.
His 1978 speech "The Historical Injustice" shows a piercing intellectualism as he subjects the history of South Africa to Marxist analysis, skewering the British imperialists and the Boer pioneers for corrupting even the capitalism and Calvinism they preached, regressing into feudalism, a racist version of Lutheranism and simple murder and theft because it was easier and more profitable than adopting the liberalizing trends of Europe.
And for sheer poetic power, his "I Am an African" speech, celebrating the new Constitution in 1996, surpasses even the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, which it somewhat resembles -- although Dr. King was a more riveting speaker.
He is becoming better known because biographers are probing his past; the fact that he fathered a child at 16 who disappeared 17 years later, probably at the hands of the police, has humanized him a bit. So have photos of him as a young man leaning affectionately against friends or smiling at his 1974 London wedding to Zanele Dlamini, who was studying social work and now heads a bank for rural women.
Mr. Mbeki is now seen as a politician, but he is really a lifelong intellectual guerrilla, rather than an armed one. At Lovedale Institution, a South African boarding school, he excelled at Latin, mathematics and science, but was expelled in his senior year for leading a student strike. A white teacher who recognized his erudition arranged for a scholarship to the University of Sussex in England; but he began school late because he had been arrested by the Rhodesian Government while trying to slip out to Britain without a passport.
After getting a degree in economics and backing causes from nuclear disarmament to getting the United States out of Vietnam, he was sent by Oliver Tambo, the London-based president of the African National Congress, to set up offices in Zambia, Botswana, Swaziland and Mozambique, making the white South African Government feel surrounded.
He became one of the public faces of the dissident group, meeting reporters and accompanying Mr. Tambo on diplomatic trips to Moscow, Washington and other capitals. In the 1980's, when white executives and prominent Afrikaners defied their Government to meet the African National Congress in exile, Mr. Mbeki was always there.
In 1990, after the A.N.C. was legalized, he returned home for the first time in 28 years.
While the spotlight briefly lingered on Cyril Ramaphosa, a union leader who negotiated the new Constitution, Mr. Mbeki returned to his role as heir apparent with his election as African National Congress chairman in 1993.
The fear of him, particularly asserted among whites, is that he prefers back-room victories to open debate and puts "Africanism" above equality.
Those fears got new fuel this week when Business Day, a financial paper, reported that he had intervened to stop Judge Edwin Cameron, one of the country's best legal minds, from being named to the highest court.
Quoting "judges and lawyers close to the process," the paper said he persuaded Mr. Mandela to choose an "able and solid" black candidate because there are only three nonwhites on the 11-seat Constitutional Court.
Mr. Mbeki's legal adviser denied that he did more than consult, but that was regarded with skepticism; his office never admits being behind the sidelining of political rivals.
But in a recent interview with the newspaper The Sowetan, Mr. Mbeki made no bones about his "Africanist" perspective.
"If you are talking about poverty alleviation and eradication, then necessarily you will focus on people who are poorest," he said. "If that is what is mean by Africanist, you cannot avoid it."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
2 Asia Airlines See Progress In Labor and Money Crises

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 4

 BODY:
The skies may soon become smoother for two Asian airlines buffeted by labor disputes and financial problems.
Philippine Airlines said today that it had raised $200 million in fresh capital to resuscitate its debt-ridden operations. And Cathay Pacific Airways is preparing for talks with its pilots to resolve a dispute that has grounded between a third and half of its daily flights since May 28. 
 In both cases, analysts cautioned that the good news should be tempered by caution.
Although Cathay Pacific made a significant concession when it agreed on Thursday to reopen negotiations with its pilots, it is not clear that more talking can close the wide gap between the carrier and its pilots over salaries.
Cathay's senior pilots called in sick in record numbers today to protest a deadline that the airline had given them to accept a new pay package. That forced the carrier, which is based in Hong Kong, to cancel 59 of its 117 scheduled flights. Cathay made up some of the flights with 26 chartered planes.
"It's a very positive step that they're talking," said Peter Negline, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in Hong Kong. "But both parties have gone over this ground at length. I don't have reason to believe that either side has moved its stance enough to reach an immediate resolution."
Cathay has threatened that if the senior pilots do not accept its salary offer by June 11, it will lay them off. The airline had earlier said that it would not reopen talks unless the pilots made concessions, but now it has agreed to meet with their union, the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association, here on Saturday.
In the case of Philippine Airlines, the carrier met a deadline of today to raise $200 million or face liquidation. The trouble is, most of the money is being contributed by the company's largest shareholder, Lucio C. Tan, and investors close to him. Mr. Tan himself has put up $100 million.
It is not clear that the creditors of Philippine Airlines, who have been increasingly hostile toward Mr. Tan, will support his bid to stay in control of the carrier. Mr. Tan, a big player in tobacco and beer, is one of the richest men in the Philippines. He has relied on his close ties to President Joseph P. Estrada of the Philippines to keep the airline operating, despite its $2.2 billion in debts.
"Tan clearly has an understanding with Estrada," said Jim Eckes, a consultant at Indoswiss Aviation Ltd. in Hong Kong. "But does he have an understanding with the creditors? I don't see the creditors, who haven't been paid for a year, being in a position to accept him in top management."
Among the largest creditors of Philippine Airlines is the Export-Import Bank of the United States, which announced plans in May to seize four planes. The bank had earlier endorsed a plan to rehabilitate the airline -- after Mr. Tan ceded day-to-day management to a team of executives from Cathay Pacific.
But Mr. Tan took back the chief executive title in late April, consigning the team from Cathay to a marginal role.
Cathay Pacific and Philippine Airlines have more differences than similarities. Cathay's investors include Swire Pacific, a leading Hong Kong business empire, as well as the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, China's big state-run investment banking concern, and is regarded as one of Asia's best-run airlines. Philippine Airlines, which was once owned by the Philippine Government, is a virtual catalogue of airline maladies -- with unprofitable routes, a costly and oversized fleet and a bloated work force.
Yet both carriers have suffered during the Asian crisis, which has sapped tourism and business travel throughout the region. Cathay recorded its first loss in 35 years in 1998, $542 million (Hong Kong), or $69.9 million (United States). Philippine Airlines has lost more than $330 million the last four years.
Mr. Negline estimated that Cathay could lose $38 million because of the canceled flights. But given its underlying strengths, he and other analysts are sanguine about its prospects. Salaries of Cathay's top pilots are among the highest in the industry. And Hong Kong's laws favor employers over employees.
"Cathay will start firing people at some point," Mr. Eckes said. "I just don't think the pilots can afford to go on strike."
Officials in Hong Kong are praying for an quick end to the dispute. The territory's tourism industry was just starting to perk up after a long drought. By disrupting the travel plans of 40,000 passengers and counting, Cathay's dispute could end up hampering Hong Kong's recovery from the recession.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Deutsche Bank Seals Bankers Trust Deal

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Deutsche Bank A.G., sealing its position as the world's largest bank, completed its acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation yesterday and effectively put an end to the Bankers Trust brand name.
Deutsche said it planned to stop using or gradually phase out that name in almost all businesses except private banking. Deutsche will temporarily maintain the name of the Bankers Trust investment banking unit, BT Alex. Brown, as Alex. Brown for some of the merged company's investment banking activities in the United States. 
 A round of layoffs also began at Bankers Trust yesterday, with the announcement of large job cuts in the bank's fixed-income business. Though some were concerned that a disproportionate share of the layoffs would fall on Bankers Trust employees in this country, Deutsche said that its previously announced plan to lay off 5,500 people from both companies over a three-year period remained unchanged.
A Deutsche spokeswoman said those layoffs, which represent nearly 6 percent of the combined company's work force, would reflect the strengths and weaknesses of Deutsche's and Bankers Trust's various units and were agreed upon by management teams from both companies.
With $817 billion in assets, Deutsche is a legendary powerhouse in European banking but has had less success making inroads into the highly competitive and highly entrepreneurial world of investment banking. In addition, Deutsche has been regarded by many analysts as somewhat lumbering in a world in which financial services are rapidly changing.
Deutsche's chief executive, Rolf E. Breuer, said in an interview that he believed the $9 billion takeover of Bankers Trust would give Deutsche a "shot in the arm" and make it a more competitive player in European mergers and acquisitions -- a market that is expected to heat up in the next few years as the European economy and European companies consolidate.
Although Dr. Breuer said he was "interested in advising on megadeals" in the United States, he also said he had no intention of competing head on with the firms that already have a lock on that business -- Goldman, Sachs, for example, and Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Dr. Breuer reiterated the bank's intention to centralize control of the investment banking operation in Frankfurt, the Deutsche home base. But he said he did not believe that a culture clash would emerge as Deutsche digested Bankers Trust.
He said that Americans would be running the investment banking business and that compensation within that unit would reflect the lush salaries that typify the investment banking industry.
"We have to pay market rates," Dr. Breuer said. "Otherwise people will leave."
Though any merger often involves thorny challenges in getting former competitors to cooperate, Dr. Breuer said Deutsche planned to move swiftly to integrate the operations of both banks.
He said the bank was still negotiating a settlement regarding questions about its handling of bank accounts owned by victims of the Holocaust. He said Deutsche would participate in a restitution fund that should be in place by Sept. 1, but he declined to estimate how large the fund would be.
Dr. Breuer also said Deutsche did not expect any further legal or financial problems stemming from Bankers Trust's recent guilty plea to Federal charges that it had misappropriated unclaimed customer funds. He said United States regulators had immunized Deutsche from any further claims as part of its takeover of Bankers Trust.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Authorities Suspend Operations at a Major Japanese Insurer

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 4

 BODY:
Financial authorities suspended operations today at the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company, only the second major insurer in Japan to go out of business since World War II.
Toho's troubles underscore the problems facing the wobbly insurance industry, and today's collapse may be just the beginning. And because Toho has a tie-up with the GE Capital Corporation of the United States, the suspension will be watched closely by the foreign financial community as a test of whether foreign concerns can withstand possible spillover effects from weak or ailing Japanese partners. 
 Many of Japan's insurers have been staggering under the weight of billions of dollars in property losses and bad debts. Like the nation's big banks, Japan's life insurance companies went on buying sprees during the economic go-go years at the end of the last decade, and they are now stinging from losses as property prices have in some cases plunged 90 percent from their peak values.
"The life insurance industry in Japan has problems which could be equally as serious as those in the banking industry," said Andrew Smithers, president of Smithers & Company, a financial consultancy based in London.
Mr. Smithers said Toho was probably the most vulnerable of the insurers, but that there were a couple of other insurers that were also bleeding. Partly because Toho's demise had been anticipated, financial experts say that there is unlikely to be any backlash effect on other financial institutions.
Financial authorities have just started a major inspection of the nation's insurance companies, and analysts anticipate a shake-out in the industry. Government inspections of the banking industry led to the nationalization of two large institutions last fall.
The Government has established a new protection fund for insurance policyholders, but analysts say the fund has very little money and that it is possible that the Bank of Japan may have to extend loans to the fund to cover payments to policyholders.
In April 1997, the Nissan Mutual Life Insurance Company collapsed, leaving many policyholders nearly empty-handed.
About a year ago, GE Capital, a unit of General Electric, negotiated its way into Japan's closed and clubby insurance industry by striking a deal with Toho and setting up a joint venture, GE Edison Life Insurance. Analysts praised the deal because the new venture would start afresh with only Toho's new business, while the old, more risky policies remained with Toho Mutual. GE thus seemed to isolate itself from possible fallout from a collapse of Toho.
But the suspension order by the Financial Supervisory Agency appears to affect at least a small part of GE Edison's operations. It is not clear whether negative publicity over the collapse of Toho may also have any impact in the minds of policyholders on the reputation of GE Edison. GE Edison issued a statement today saying that its operations would be "secure and unaffected" by Toho's suspension.
Toho officials told a news conference this evening that its accountants refused to attach their blessing to the financial statements for the year ending March 31. Accountants in Japan have a reputation for being generally lenient in their audits, and their refusal suggests that Toho was in severe financial distress.
Toho officials said that its auditors figured that the company had to dispose of 230 billion yen, or about $2 billion, in bad assets arising from potential losses on securities, foreign exchange deals and bad loans. If the company had done so, then it would have had a capital deficit of about 200 billion yen, or about $1.7 billion.
Japanese life insurers, like Toho, have been squeezed by plummeting interest rates in Japan. For years, Government rules had forced them to pay out high, fixed returns on insurance policies. But with interest rates falling to nearly zero, the money that life insurance companies received from policyholders was invested in stocks and bonds offering increasingly lower returns so that they often ended up paying more out to policyholders than they received from their investments, which are their major source of income.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Undercut in Effort To Depict Rival as Thriving

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Trying to defang the Government's antitrust charges against it, the Microsoft Corporation introduced a host of evidence this week to show that the Netscape browser was still healthy and thriving, despite Microsoft's all-out assault on the browser market.
But in a single stroke this afternoon, a Government lawyer undercut Microsoft's strategy by producing a Microsoft E-mail written in January suggesting that the company had cynically and selectively produced data to support this point of view. 
 In the E-mail, Greg Shaw, a Microsoft public relations executive, asked others at the company: "What data can we find right away, showing that the Netscape browser is still healthy? The Government is introducing a bunch of data showing Netscape headed down big time and Microsoft way up."
The Netscape Communications Corporation's browser held a commanding lead until Microsoft entered the market with a browser, Internet Explorer, that was tied to the Windows operating system and set out on a campaign to dissuade other companies to work with Netscape. The Government's antitrust case is built on the contention that Microsoft used its dominance in operating systems to bolster its share of the browser market illegally.
"It would help if you could send me some reports showing their market share healthy and holding," Mr. Shaw added.
Later that morning, Robert Bennett, group product manager for Windows, wrote back, saying, "All the analyses have pretty much come to the same conclusion, which is that Netscape is declining and Internet Explorer is gaining."
A half-hour later, Yusef Mehdi, director of Windows marketing, weighed in, saying that he had found one survey showing "us very close on Internet Explorer share" and another that "has Netscape even or even higher."
"This is for the trial," Mr. Mehdi added, "so let's provide the more negative analysts."
As David Boies, the lead Government lawyer, read that aloud, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is trying the case without a jury, chuckled and shook his head, while Microsoft's lawyers looked grim.
And when Mr. Boies asked the witness, Franklin Fisher, an economist from Massachusetts Institute of Technology, what he thought this said about his analysis of Microsoft's take on the browser war, Mr. Fisher said only: "This document speaks for itself rather louder than most."
In questioning the witness again a short time later, a Microsoft lawyer, Michael Lacovara, heatedly asserted that all the Microsoft executives involved in the E-mail exchange were "marketing and public relations personnel" and that the exchange was "a discussion of trial public relations," not of legal issues. In fact, at one point, Mr. Shaw wrote that the request for market data "is for press purposes."
But it was not the first time Microsoft had been shown to gin up surveys or statistics that would indicate support for the company's view.
In January, Mr. Boies offered as evidence an E-mail message in which William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, wrote, "It would help me immensely to have a survey showing that 90 percent of developers believe that putting the browser into the operating system makes sense." Later, he added, "Ideally we would have a survey before I appear at the Senate on March 3d."
In subsequent E-mail messages, Microsoft employees laid out how they would phrase the survey questions to be sure they elicited the responses Mr. Gates wanted.
Earlier today, Mr. Boies also seemed to take some of the sting out of Microsoft's attack Thursday evening on a previous Government witness, James Barksdale, who was chairman of Netscape. In court last October, Mr. Barksdale asserted that because of what he described as Microsoft's predatory conduct, Netscape could no longer get computer makers to provide the Netscape browser with their products.
"That's over half the distribution channel, and we're basically out of it," he said. But an internal document prepared for America Online at the same time, as part of that company's research for its purchase of Netscape, showed that just over one-fifth of the nation's computer manufacturers were shipping Netscape at the time.
As a result, Mr. Lacovara asserted that Mr. Barksdale's credibility had been thrown into question, and Judge Jackson expressed interest in that.
Today, Mr. Boies pointed to several passages in Mr. Barksdale's direct written testimony in which he listed all the companies that were shipping Netscape on at least some of their computers and explained precisely what the arrangements allowed. All this detailed information, Mr. Boies and Mr. Fisher both said, showed that Mr. Barksdale was not trying to overstate the depth of Netscape's problem. Judge Jackson did not remark on this development.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Falls Again, But Job Growth Is Moderating

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
America's unemployment rate dropped to 4.2 percent in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday. That matches the 29-year low first reached in March and is just the latest sign that the nation's labor market remains remarkably robust.
But there was also a strong hint in yesterday's report that the jobs boom may be moderating. While employers actually added 841,000 workers to their payrolls in May, the increase was rather paltry given it is usually the peak time of year for seasonal hiring. After the Labor Department took account of the usual spring hiring surge, the seasonally adjusted gain in payroll employment turned out to be virtually nil -- a net gain of a mere 11,000 jobs. 
 By contrast, the increase for April was a whopping 343,000 when adjusted for seasonal factors.
"There are some signs of slowing," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, "but at the same time the labor market is very tight and there's some upward pressure on wages."
As seen through the corrective lens of seasonal adjustment, the weakness in May hiring was widespread. Manufacturers, who have been buffeted by the economic slowdown in the rest of the world, trimmed 45,000 workers from their payrolls, bringing the total reduction since March 1998 to nearly half a million. Construction payrolls, which had been climbing, on average, by 28,000 workers a month, fell by 40,000. And services -- the main engine of job growth -- added far fewer workers than usual, just offsetting the losses elsewhere.
Stepping back a bit, it turns out that the economy has added an average of 196,000 jobs a month on a seasonally adjusted basis in the first five months of 1999, significantly fewer than the average of 243,000 a month in the second half of 1998. What is more, total hours worked are growing more slowly, at an annual rate of less than 1 percent in the second quarter versus 2 percent in the first.
May's mixture of strength and weakness gave investors no clear idea of whether the Federal Reserve, whose monetary policy committee meets at the end of the month, is likely to raise interest rates or not.
"This is very much a 'wait and see what happens next' report," said Katherine Abraham, the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It's too soon to draw any conclusions about this being a turning point."
David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, agreed. "It leaves the Fed where they were," he said, "looking for a sign that inflation is dangerous enough to be worth stomping on or just a phantom menace."
In the last several weeks, one strong report after another on everything from car sales to house purchases to factory output has fanned fears that the Federal Reserve is about to raise rates. Last month, the Fed's monetary policy-making committee, citing an "already tight labor market" and strong domestic spending, voted to adopt a "bias" toward raising rates -- though it did not actually raise them.
The central bank has been on the alert for signs that the good times are pushing wages up faster. Hourly pay did jump a bit, rising 5 cents, to $13.19 in May.
But pay increases have been exhibiting a seesaw pattern over the last few months, up one month, fairly flat the next, rather than a clear acceleration. The increase from a year ago is 3.6 percent, the same as last month. Last year, wages rose 4.4 percent. "You still see a deceleration," Mr. Rippe said.
Investors, who typically pay more attention to payrolls than to the unemployment rate, reacted to the report with a collective sigh of relief. Bond prices inched lower, while several stock indexes rallied.
American workers, of course, have been celebrating the current state of the job market at shopping malls, car dealers' lots and new housing subdivisions. It is easy to see why. Last month, the unemployment rate for college graduates dipped to 1.9 percent. Over the last year, while the number of college graduates in the work force rose by 1.7 million, the number of managerial, professional and technical jobs rose by an even larger number.
Even the youngest, least-educated, least-experienced workers are doing nicely. Unemployment among teenagers dropped to 12.6 percent in May from nearly 15 percent at the beginning of the year. And the unemployment rates among black and Hispanic workers remain at historic lows.
"This is still a very strong economy," said Mr. Wyss of Standard & Poor's. "The problem is much more that people can't find workers than that people can't find jobs."
The pattern of job growth may be shifting a bit along with the pace. Hiring by service firms, whose appetite for more workers has seemed to have no bounds, turned sluggish in May for the first time since 1996. Hotels and landscaping services hired fewer workers than earlier in the year, but even industries less prone to seasonal ups and downs -- financial services and management consulting, for example -- pulled back. Employment in health care services leveled off after months of rapid growth. Retailers, which added sales clerks at a rapid pace during the last year, hardly hired any in May. Exceptions included car dealers and furniture stores, a reflection of the hot market for cars and houses. Business services -- mainly computer services and data processing -- continued to pull in workers.
Despite the boom in all kinds of construction, which has been adding an average of 28,000 jobs a month since last fall, payrolls actually shrank in May. The decline mostly reflects what the Labor Department referred to as "erratic" weather, which has caused this year's seasonal hiring to begin earlier than usual. But higher interest rates, falling housing starts and a shrinking backlog of new commercial construction contracts suggest that hiring may stay weak in months to come.
Industries that have been shedding jobs continued to do so. Despite the recent rebound in oil prices, mining outfits cut 7,000 jobs, mostly in oil and gas extraction. Declines in factory employment were widespread, encompassing heavy machinery, aircraft, clothing and textiles.
There are signs that this may change, said Robert Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. Workers who are on the assembly lines are busier than ever. The average factory workweek, nearly 42 hours, and the average overtime, 4.6 hours, are high by historical standards. Together with fatter order books, higher production and shrinking inventories, this suggests that manufacturers may soon be running help wanted ads.
The May jobs report reflects an annual benchmark revision in the Labor Department's payroll survey. As usual, the department found that more jobs had been created than originally estimated.
But Ms. Abraham said this year's upward revision of 44,000 jobs was smaller than usual.

HEADLINE: Europe's New Military Aspirations

 BODY:
The air war over Yugoslavia, though successful, brought renewed attention to one of NATO's oldest problems. While 19 countries belong to the alliance and take part in its political decision-making, most of the military power comes from just one of these countries, the United States, as does much of the political leadership. More than two-thirds of the NATO planes used against Kosovo and Serbia were American. This week the European Union, which includes most of NATO's European members, adopted a plan aimed at partially redressing the balance. That is a welcome development. But European governments will have to overcome many obstacles if the plan is to have any practical effect.
The idea is to give Europe the ability to carry out peacekeeping and small-scale combat operations on its own, while continuing its reliance on American participation in bigger conflicts. That ability is already improving, at least for peacekeeping. Four years ago in Bosnia, the United States had to provide one-third of the 60,000 peacekeepers. It will be supplying only 14 percent of the 50,000 soldiers planned for Kosovo. 
 The European Union plan, which would unfold over the next 18 months, commits member countries to transform their military forces so that they can be used more effectively in crisis and peacekeeping situations. It also designates a full-time coordinator of European foreign and defense policy, a job given yesterday to Javier Solana, the current Secretary General of NATO. Merely naming a coordinator will not bring coherence to the disparate foreign policies of the European Union's 15 sovereign countries. But Mr. Solana's political skills and NATO experience make him a good choice.
Europe's total armed forces are already larger than those of the United States. But for the most part, they are poorly suited for crises like Bosnia or Kosovo. More mobile and flexible forces are needed that could fight for months at a stretch. Europe must also increase its capacity to ferry troops where needed, reducing its reliance on American transport planes. Additionally, European armies need modern command and intelligence tools.
Modernizing European forces will require breaking down bureaucratic fiefs and pushing through politically difficult increases in defense spending. Applying force will also require changes in European attitudes. Since the end of World War II, Germany and Italy have been understandably reluctant to use military force.
Europe's inability to carry its military weight in NATO has been a standing source of trans-Atlantic friction. More than a half-century after the defeat of Hitler and more than a decade after the cold war, American troops should not be expected to help extinguish every local European conflict.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Contemporary Art in a Factory Setting

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG 

 BODY:
From a window on the second floor of Mass MOCA, the newly opened museum of contemporary art in North Adams, Mass., you can look out over a side street in that once-industrial town. Water slides from a storm drain into a massive concrete spillway that is actually one branch of the Hoosic River. Above the spillway there is a row of old-fashioned two-story houses whose porches have gone slack with time. A grocery-store clerk walks down the block gathering stray shopping carts and stacking them in the back of his pickup. Beyond the block, the hills rise sharply in the near distance, as they do everywhere in North Adams, which is set in a deep crease in the northern Berkshires.
The gallery from which all of this is visible is a small room located just past the end of Robert Rauschenberg's enormous ongoing artwork called "The 1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece." This work hangs in the largest of Mass MOCA's rooms, a place called Building 5, once used for dyeing and drying textiles by the Arnold Print Works, one of several industrial companies to make use of this outsize complex of buildings along Marshall Street. The absorbing detail of Rauschenberg's piece is set against a long white wall, which is a way of protecting the work from the absorbing detail of the building it is housed in. If there is something kinetic about the way Rauschenberg has revised himself in "The 1/4 Mile or 2 Furlong Piece," it is a kineticism entirely matched by the way the old factory and mill buildings that form Mass MOCA have themselves been revised over time, by economic change, by fire and flood, by use and disuse. 
 Mass MOCA was first proposed in 1986, a year after Sprague Electric, the last major occupant of these buildings, shut down, leaving the industrial center of North Adams vacant. The reconstruction necessary to accommodate a museum of contemporary art has exposed the inadvertent artistry of the setting itself, the sheer profusion of surface -- columns and struts and beams, a galaxy of bricks, each one burning with a color rediscovered by the light that has been admitted. By definition, the art that works at Mass MOCA is an art that is not intimidated by its surroundings. The scale of these spaces is what first made the idea of this museum attractive. But what will keep it interesting is the way the vibrancy of the buildings challenges the work itself.
It is an old habit to think of a museum as the silent, blank walls that allow painting and sculpture to be heard in their full voice, undisturbed by anything but the sounds of visitors walking by. Mass MOCA turns that old habit inside out. You cannot walk through it without thinking of the countless gestures, some meant, some unmeant, that turned the blank brick of those factory buildings into the cumulative life's work of the many thousands of North Adams residents who toiled on this site for more than two centuries. This is a museum designed to honor the labor of artists, but one that inevitably honors the labor of the townspeople in whose midst it has been set. VERLYN KLINKENBORG

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Shares Rally,Indicating Investors See Higher Interest Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stock prices rallied yesterday and bond prices moved slightly lower as investors signaled that they were ready for the rate increase that many expect when Federal Reserve policy makers meet at the end of this month.
The selloffs in stocks since May 18, when the Fed first indicated it was leaning toward a rate increase, have been enough to compensate for higher interest rates, in the view of many investors. Sectors that had been hit particularly hard, including drugs, banks and technology stocks, helped lead the rally yesterday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 136.15 points, or 1.28 percent, to 10,799.84, behind rallies in American Express, up 3 5/8, to 125 1/4; DuPont, up 3 5/16 , to 70 1/4, and Procter & Gamble, up 3 1/8, to 96 5/8. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 28.21 points, or 2.17 percent, to 1,327.75.
The Nasdaq composite index, which had dropped 10 percent from its recent high, jumped 75.02 points, or 3.12 percent, yesterday to 2,478.34, led by Microsoft, up 3 3/16 , to 79 9/16 ; Cisco Systems, up 6 1/16 , to 114 7/8, and Intel, up 2 11/16 , to 53 3/16 .
There was little change in the bond market, where yields had shot sharply higher in the last two months as the economy refused to slow down. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond inched up to 5.96 percent, from 5.95 on Thursday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped 3/32 , to 90 5/32 . The yield on the two-year Treasury note, which is very sensitive to fears of Fed rate increases, rose to 5.53 percent from 5.52 percent.
This performance came after the Labor Department said that only 11,000 new jobs were created in May, an increase that was sharply lower than Wall Street forecasts of a gain of nearly 220,000 jobs.
Normally, such an unexpectedly weak report would have sent bond prices higher as investors figured that a slowing economy would lessen the risk of a Fed rate increase. Stock prices, in such a situation, could go either way, with some investors buying because of the reduced risk of a rate increase while others sold on worries that slower growth would curb corporate earnings.
But yesterday, investors decided that despite the weakness of the jobs data, the outlook for the economy had not really changed. This means that growth has not slowed enough for the Fed to ignore the jump in consumer prices that was reported for April and is likely to be seen again in the May data due out in a week and a half. Next week's retail sales data could also show that consumers, who have been the driving force behind the economy's rapid growth, have not cut back.
"Whatever you thought about the labor market before this number, you still think about the labor market," Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said. Other data released earlier this week, including automobile and light-truck sales and a key manufacturing index, all showed that the economy was still surprisingly strong last month.
But the run-up in interest rates already, which has seen the yield on the two-year note jump two-thirds of a percentage point in two months, has given the Fed a green light to raise interest rates, he said. The yield on the two-year note is nearly half a percentage point higher than it would be if no rate increase was expected.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist for Gruntal & Company, agreed. "Nothing much will happen," he said, after a quarter of a percentage move up in the Fed interest rate target, which is now 4.75 percent. But he said that if there were indications that the Fed would move interest rates still higher, there might be more reverberations.
Mr. Battipaglia also said stocks were likely to get support from what he expects to be very positive earnings news for the second quarter, which would begin to be reported in July, just after the next meeting of Fed policy makers.
The First Call Corporation, which tabulates corporate earnings estimates, says Wall Street analysts currently expect second-quarter earnings for the S.& P. 500 index to rise by 12.8 percent from a year ago.
In addition, Mr. Battipaglia said, the global financial crisis that shook the financial markets last summer, is gone. "The landscape for this summer looks dramatically different than last summer," he said, "and that has to be good for stocks."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: REBUILDING;
A Relief Plan for Yugoslav Neighbors

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Officials from the United States, the European Union and international aid agencies stepped up their planning today for the formidable job of repairing the physical and economic damage wrought throughout the Balkans by the conflict in Kosovo.
In the first official public assessment of the costs, Romano Prodi, the incoming president of the European Commission, said today that the European Union alone might have to budget as much as $6 billion a year for the next five years to deal with the problems. 
 But other officials said that any cost estimates at this point were little more than educated guesses. There has yet to be any comprehensive study of the costs of rebuilding homes, power and water systems, roads, schools and businesses in Kosovo. There are only sketchy estimates of what it will take to accomplish the first major goal, moving nearly one million refugees back into the province, and housing and feeding them through next winter.
President Clinton has said the United States expects Europe to finance most of the costs of putting the Balkans together again. Administration officials said they did not yet know precisely what contributions the United States would make, or how much money the Administration might have to request from Congress for rebuilding and relief assistance. A bill passed by Congress last month included $1.1 billion for relief.
"We've obviously done a lot of thinking about this already," said Harriet C. Babbitt, the Deputy Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, which plans to send a team into Kosovo as soon as allied military forces begin moving in. "But you can't do a lot of very specific planning until you know the environment in which you're going to be working. There are rooms full of frantic people putting together scenarios and budgets."
One indication of the scale of the problem came in a study released today by the International Monetary Fund. The study concluded that the economic damage to the six countries neighboring Yugoslavia from disruptions to trade, plus the costs of helping the refugees, would exceed $1.25 billion this year, and could be as high as $2.25 billion, without even considering the costs of making Kosovo habitable again.
In the longer term, the rebuilding job seems likely to be far bigger than the $5 billion, five-year international effort to rebuild Bosnia after the end of the conflict there, officials said. And both the United States and Europe are studying plans to go beyond physical rebuilding in Kosovo to bolster the economies of countries throughout the region and bring them economically and politically closer to the European Union.
"If we do not give a message of long-term stability linked to the European Union institutions, there will never be peace in the Balkans," Mr. Prodi said in an interview with CNN today.
For now, though, both the United States and Europe have all but ruled out providing any aid to help repair the tremendous damage done to Serbia by months of NATO bombing. In an apparent attempt to foster popular discontent with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, officials in both Washington and in Europe said they would not provide help to rebuild Yugoslavia as long as Mr. Milosevic remained in power.
"There is no question of dealing with Milosevic," Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, told Reuters Television. "There is no place for Serbia in the true family of nations while Milosevic remains, and they cannot be part, in my judgment, of a Balkan reconstruction program whilst Milosevic remains in office."
Although its economy was relatively poor and rural, Kosovo has clearly suffered tremendous physical damage that is certain to be costly and time-consuming to repair. The only international group to have gotten a good look at the province since the conflict began -- a United Nations team that spent less than three days there last week -- reported that 80 percent of the homes in some areas had been destroyed.
The delegation found "a depressing panorama of empty villages, burned houses, looted shops, wandering livestock and unattended farms," Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations Under Secretary for Humanitarian Affairs, told the Security Council on Wednesday.
There is a host of political, economic and logistical problems to be overcome before any large-scale rebuilding effort can get under way. While neighboring countries like Albania and Macedonia are already receiving assistance from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Kosovo is technically ineligible for aid from the international financial institutions because it is not a country, and remains part of a nation, Yugoslavia, that was kicked out of the World Bank and the monetary fund seven years ago.
It is also unclear how much rebuilding work will be done by allied military forces.
The experience in Bosnia indicates that physical rebuilding goes much more quickly than the complex task of creating a new economy. Christiaan Poortman, Balkans coordinator at the World Bank, said more than 90 percent of the planned road network in Bosnia is complete, more than 90 percent of a new phone system is up and running, elementary school enrollment is higher than before the conflict there, nearly three-quarters of the electrical generation system has been restored -- but the country's economic output is still less than half of what it was in 1990.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE SERBS;
In Milosevic's Government, Resignation Over Pact, Confidence in His Strength

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 4

 BODY:
As soon as Russia agreed with NATO on the principles for a peace settlement for Kosovo, President Slobodan Milosevic understood that he had no choice but to accept the terms put in front of him, senior Yugoslav officials said today.
But they expressed deep concern that the international force being assembled by NATO would not move into Kosovo quickly enough to protect the Serbs there from separatist Albanian guerrillas. And they worry about the enormous task of reconstructing Serbia, for which Belgrade expects little Western help. 
 Despite these problems, the officials added, Mr. Milosevic will retain his grip on power, and the ultranationalist leader of the Radical Party, Vojislav Seselj, has agreed not to vote against the Government even though he might resign as deputy prime minister of Serbia to protest the Kosovo deal. Mr. Seselj has also promised not to lead demonstrations against the pact.
The Russians won some important concessions for Mr. Milosevic, the officials said, which made the final offer better for Belgrade than the earlier Western plan presented to the Serbs and the Albanians at Rambouillet, France. The Albanians accepted that plan; Mr. Milosevic rejected it.
"But we knew that when the Russians came in with this plan, that was it," said one official close to Mr. Milosevic and his influential wife, Mirjana Markovic. "We knew it from the beginning. We knew that the carpet bombing of Belgrade would start the next day after we refused, so what was the choice?"
The NATO alliance had threatened to take out the rest of Serbia's bridges, electrical supply and telephone system, and the Yugoslav officials said there was no longer any reason to wait. Continuing the unequal war was pointless, they said, and obviously posed greater risks to Mr. Milosevic's hold on power.
"The alternative to acceptance was not a humane one," the official said. "We couldn't be reckless and risk elimination of the state, the army and the people for the sake of rhetoric, and without any substantial support in the world."
The key part of the proposal that made it acceptable for Belgrade, the officials said, was the limitation on the movement of the international forces, mostly NATO and Russian troops under a United Nations flag, to Kosovo itself.
Under an annex of the Rambouillet accord, a purely NATO force was to be given full permission to go anywhere it wanted in Yugoslavia, immune from any legal process. "NATO personnel shall enjoy, together with their vehicles, vessels, aircraft and equipment, free and unrestricted passage and unimpeded access throughout the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia including associated airspace and territorial waters," the annex read.
The officials also noted that the new proposals did not recommend a re-examination of Kosovo's sovereignty after three years, or any referendum on that topic, as the Rambouillet agreement did.
Yugoslav officials also said their resistance had forced NATO to find a solution within the United Nations and with the participation of the Russians. And they emphasized the international guarantees of Serbia's sovereignty over Kosovo, unlike the temporary sovereignty proposed at Rambouillet.
On a more personal level, the officials expressed deep concern that up to 200,000 Serbs and Gypsies in Kosovo would flee the province rather than "wait for the K.L.A.," as one official put it, referring to the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army.
"I fear that Serbs won't be in Kosovo any more," the official said. "How many international troops are ready and how quickly can they deploy over this burned land? We pretend that NATO controls the terrorists of the K.L.A., but truthfully no one really controls them."
And he predicted that large numbers of poor ethnic Albanians from Albania and Macedonia who had never lived in Kosovo would try to move into the province as refugees, attracted by the large Western presence and promises of aid.
The mood of the officials was resigned and at moments even bleak. They understood that the West was unlikely to provide reconstruction aid for Serbia so long as Mr. Milosevic was in power, but they expressed few doubts that he would remain.
They offered few clear ideas for coping with Yugoslavia's dire economic problems, other than motivating Serbian self-reliance and ingenuity. Already weakened by eight years of international sanctions, Yugoslavia's economy has been blasted by NATO's war against bridges, highways, factories and refineries.
Russian help would be required, they said, to get enough natural gas for the winter and the gasoline and fuel needed to complete this year's harvest. And they said they expected Yugoslavia to continue to have to pay well over market price for the goods it was able to import or smuggle past the sanction monitors.
"People are now happy with the simple fact that the bombing will stop," said another senior official. "And the day after that no one knows. People have responded to the war in a remarkable fashion, and now we must organize people to act in a positive way."
The Yugoslav United Left party, which is led by Ms. Markovic, has spoken of the post-war period as a time of renewal, but it will likely be a period of lower living standards, poverty and a slow rebuilding of infrastructure.
Yet most analysts here -- including Zoran Jelicic, the former editor of the Belgrade magazine Vreme -- say that while the domestic political situation will become more tense, the difficulties of everyday life will make widespread political unrest less likely.
"We have a very hard time ahead," said Mr. Jelicic, who lost his editing job when he opposed Mr. Milosevic. "We will have inflation, shortages and severe unemployment," he said.
Those factors, said Mr. Jelicic, who is also an economist, will force the Government either to open up the economy to the world market, despite international sanctions, or to turn to a socialist-style economy to get through the most difficult periods. "But hard times will just strengthen the authorities," he said. "In our experiences, there are no protests during the worst times."
As for the West's effort to "bribe the population into overthrowing Milosevic," he said, "it even makes me resentful, and I've tried to bring him down from day one."
If the senior officials have concerns about the post-war economy, they add that Mr. Milosevic faces little internal political threat. Mr. Seselj has a history of being the Government's in-house nationalist.
Early Thursday morning, when he met with party leaders to tell them he would accept the Russian-NATO proposal and urged them to vote for it in Parliament later that day, Mr. Milosevic asked Mr. Seselj to at least abstain in the voting.
But Mr. Seselj, meeting with his party before the vote, ended up opposing the pact and later said he would quit the government once Western troops arrive in Kosovo.
"Certainly we won't stay in the Serbian government to see a possible entrance of troops from aggressor countries into Kosovo," he said.
But Mr. Seselj also promised Mr. Milosevic that he would support the Government in Parliament or not vote against it, and that he would not organize any demonstrations against the Kosovo deal in the streets, the officials said.
They noted that Mr. Seselj has few firm supporters of his own, but tends to draw defectors from Mr. Milosevic or from Vuk Draskovic, a former leader of the democratic opposition and now the head of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Milosevic Remains, Souring A Victory

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Like the war in the Persian Gulf, the war in Kosovo appears to be ending with major issues unresolved, not least the future of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and what the United States ought to do about him.
Although air power apparently achieved one of its greatest successes in the 10-week campaign in the Balkans, it did not bring about a change in government in Belgrade -- something that only an invasion by ground forces and a prolonged occupation could be expected to accomplish. So for the time being, the United States is stuck with a Serbian leader it neither likes nor trusts. 
 The parallels with Iraq are intriguing: Once again, a rogue leader, demonized by Washington, is emerging from a conflict with an apparently firm grip on power, with a significant part of his military forces fighting fit and with sovereignty over his country's territory technically intact.
President Clinton acknowledged today that NATO's terms for peace did not in any way address the question of Mr. Milosevic's staying in office.
"That question is left open," the President said. "He is subject to the terms of the international war crimes tribunal, which means that if he comes within the jurisdiction of any country that is cooperating with the United Nations, they would have an obligation to turn him over."
But a senior Administration official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, acknowledged, "That is not going to happen." On the one hand, Mr. Milosevic has been indicted in The Hague as a war criminal; on the other, he is for the moment NATO's indispensable partner in the effort to stabilize Kosovo.
"It's an awkward, embarrassing situation," said Michael Mandelbaum, a professor at Johns Hopkins University who advised Mr. Clinton on foreign policy issues during the 1992 election campaign. "Nobody's about to arrest him, but it's hard just to say, 'Never mind.' How can you let it pass when you went to war because you had to stop this evil man from committing genocide?"
The situation is complicated by the international tribunal's plan to send investigators into Kosovo when NATO and other peacekeepers enter that shattered province. Presumably, they will amass forensic evidence pointing to war crimes committed by soldiers and paramilitary groups operating under the direct orders of President Milosevic and his associates in Belgrade.
Ruth Wedgwood, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations who specializes in international law, said it was "incongruous but not illegal" for a person indicted as a war criminal to hold high office and conduct a nation's business. "The facts of life," she said, rule out an arrest of Mr. Milosevic.
"The Administration's best hope is slowly to marginalize him politically," she said. "They would like to put him away like Greta Garbo."
Neither of the two Bosnian Serb leaders who were indicted as war criminals, Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, has been turned over to the authorities, even though NATO has tracked their movements and they have traveled through parts of Bosnia patrolled by allied troops.
Mr. Clinton has made clear that he expects the Europeans to pay the bulk of the cost of restoring Yugoslavia to economic health -- a rebuilding program that could cost as much as $6 billion. How much Congress would authorize in aid while Mr. Milosevic retains power could be a complicated question.
Richard N. Haass, the director of Foreign Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution, who worked at the National Security Council during the Bush Administration, said economic help other than food and medicine should be linked directly to the ouster of Mr. Milosevic.
"We want to give the Yugoslavian people every incentive to get rid of him," Mr. Haass said. "Every morning, they should get up, go out into the streets and see the results of this man's actions around them."
At one time, Mr. Milosevic appeared to be preparing the way for an escape to Greece or even South Africa, but that now appears to be unlikely.
An uprising against Mr. Milosevic, perhaps abetted by covert NATO operatives, remains a possibility, of course. Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski of neighboring Macedonia suggested on Thursday that Mr. Milosevic would be ousted in a matter of weeks. But he gave no evidence to support that opinion, and Mr. Milosevic's grip on the army and secret police remains firm, American officials said.
One thing that might make an uprising in Serbia more likely than one in Iraq, which has often been predicted by American officials but has never taken place, is this: Yugoslavia is a much more developed society. The lives of ordinary people in cities there are more disrupted by bombardment.
If the pact as now constituted takes effect, Mr. Milosevic will have an "agreed number" of troops in Kosovo and more on the border. That troubles some Republicans, including Senator John McCain of Arizona, a candidate for his party's Presidential nomination. In a statement today, he asked several questions: How many Serbs? Permitted to do what? Based where? Armed, and if so, how heavily armed?
"Those are loopholes big enough to drive an armed battalion through," Senator McCain declared. "I don't know how you can convince Kosovars" -- ethnic Albanians expelled from their homeland -- "to return, much less give up their weapons, while there are armed Serbs in the neighborhood."
Signaling Republican hostility to the tentative agreement, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said he would use hearings this month to discuss "this Administration's misguided policy of appeasing Slobodan Milosevic" in Bosnia and Kosovo.
