HEADLINE: House Speaker to Shift Tacks on Spending Bill

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, his bills stymied and his control of the House insecure, has decided to rewrite Republican spending plans and shift some money for increased military spending to ease cuts in social programs like health and education, key aides said today.
Mr. Hastert will tell the House Republican caucus on Monday that "we're going to trim off some of the allocations for Defense, Treasury, the legislative branch, and feed some of that back" into bills financing programs for labor, health and human services, education, housing and veterans' affairs, a senior Republican aide said. 
 "This will be a work in progress," said John Feehery, a spokesman for Mr. Hastert. "We are going to have to fight each bill." So far, the House has failed to pass a single one of the 13 appropriations measures that finance the Government for fiscal year 2000, which begins Oct. 1.
The Speaker, five months into his tenure, is having a hard time carrying out the Republican strategy: to be the party of national defense and fiscal discipline, pour new billions into Pentagon spending, freeze or cut everything else, preserve budget surpluses to underwrite promised tax cuts and pass the spending bills on time and in good order.
Today, only the Pentagon's windfall seems assured.
Under the original plan for the coming year, the Defense Department was to receive $19 billion more than it did this year; domestic programs were to receive $26 billion less. Under the evolving plan, several billion dollars would be transferred from the military ledger into domestic programs. Military spending would still rise and domestic spending would still fall, but by less than first planned. No final figures are set.
The new goal is to restore domestic spending cuts that moderate Republicans find intolerable, keep at least some conservatives happy and win over enough moderate Democrats to pass the bills. Until the House reconvenes on Monday, and the Republican caucus meets to discuss his plan, Mr. Hastert has no way of knowing how influential conservatives might react to it.
The shift would bring the House spending plan closer in line with the Senate's, which could help avoid another fiscal fiasco in September. But with a perilously slim 223-to-212 majority in the House, Mr. Hastert needs Republican unity to pass anything. He lacks it. And House Democrats will do little to help him achieve his goals.
When he became Speaker, Mr. Hastert vowed to make the money trains run on time. The trains had barely left the station last week when his own right wing began blowing up the tracks.
The year's first major spending measure, a $60.8 billion agriculture bill, was stalled last week by fiscal conservatives who, in the name of austerity and Social Security, vowed to block any bills that provided for an increase in spending. Then a $289 billion defense authorization bill imploded when Mr. Hastert could not summon the votes to bring it to the floor because Republicans demanded language barring ground troops from Kosovo and Democrats were denied a variety of amendments they had sought.
Now the Republicans' spending bills are in the lurch, their conservatives in revolt, their moderates frustrated and their leadership red-faced. They recall the 1998 budget breakdown and the 1995 Government shutdown and worry that their slim majority may be threatened by the appearance of ineptitude.
Peter Sperry, a budget analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think-tank in Washington, said that if Republican leaders "can't communicate a strategy to their members, they can't communicate a strategy to the American people, and if they can't do that, they are going to be in a world of hurt when they go up against the Democrats in 2000."
In the House, where spending bills traditionally originate, Republicans have allocated $270 billion for the Pentagon and $268 billion for every other arm of the Government combined. That $538 billion is what is left of the $1.75 trillion budget after paying for mandatory programs like Medicare.
And the way the pie was divided among the 13 House appropriations subcommittees set moderate Republican chairmen howling that the wealth was spread too thin. To Mr. Hastert's left, liberals warned that the Republican plan starved needy people and worthy programs. To his right, conservatives promised to hew to the cuts, stop dipping into surplus Social Security revenues and keep the spending caps enacted by Congress and the White House in 1997.
The caps held the budget down and helped create the surplus, but both Republicans and Democrats are asking if they still make sense in an era of economic prosperity. Mr. Hastert says the caps were a solemn promise to the American people.
This week, Mr. Hastert, prodded by his two Texan colleagues, the majority leader, Dick Armey, and the majority whip, Tom DeLay, went back to the drawing board and came up with two new ideas.
One aims to shift responsibility, or blame, for increased spending to individual members. A key Republican aide said the idea would "keep the caps but insert a trigger" to blow them away. "If members want to, they could vote on cap-busting amendments," he said.
The other idea "was changing the allocations, working with chairmen to take a whole new approach," another senior Republican aide said.
That would redistribute billions from the bills financing the Department of Defense, Congress, the Treasury Department and the Postal Service. The money would be shifted to two other bills. One finances the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, which took a $10.7 billion cut in this year's plan, to $78.1 billion from $88.8 billion. The other, for housing and urban development, veterans and several independent agencies, took a $5.7 billion cut, to $66.2 billion from $71.9 billion.
The Commerce, Justice and State Departments, which face a $3 billion cut, and the Interior Department, cut by $2.6 billion, might also have some money restored.
Conservative Republicans have promised to stop the spending bills unless each one is cut or frozen at last year's level. That forces Mr. Hastert to find 13 magic numbers: sums that will allow the 13 bills to win 218 votes in the House.
If he cannot, he will face a reprise of last year's last-minute free-for-all spending bill, loaded with $21 billion in extras financed from the Social Security surplus, or a repeat of the 1995 Government shutdown. In each event, House Republicans lost face, President Clinton gained political capital, and programs the Republicans wanted to cut or kill won new life.

Stocks Rally as Investors Expect a Fed Rate Increase
Stock prices rallied and bond prices moved slightly lower as investors signaled that many expected a rate increase when Federal Reserve policy makers meet at the end of this month. The selloffs in stocks since May 18, when the Fed first indicated it was leaning toward a rate increase, have been enough to compensate for higher interest rates, in the view of many investors. Sectors that had been hit particularly hard, including drugs, banks and technology stocks, helped lead the rally yesterday. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 136.15 points, or 1.28 percent, to 10,799.84, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 28.21 points, or 2.17 percent, to 1,327.75. The Nasdaq composite index, which had dropped 10 percent from its recent high, jumped 75.02 points, or 3.12 percent, to 2,478.34. Page C3.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond inched up to 5.96 percent, from 5.95 on Thursday. C3.
 
Bankers Trust Acquired; Jobs Cut
Deutsche Bank, sealing its position as the world's largest bank, completed its $9 billion acquisition of Bankers Trust and said it planned to phase out use of the Bankers Trust brand name. A round of layoffs also began at Bankers Trust with large job cuts in the fixed-income business. Deutsche has announced a plan to lay off 5,500 people from both companies over a three-year period. C2.
 
Merrill Lynch Starts Deal Talks
Merrill Lynch said that it would begin settlement discussions or seek additional information on about one-third of the 904 sexual discrimination claims filed against it by current or former employees. C4.
 
Japan Closes an Insurance Company
Japanese authorities suspended operations of the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company, which has a link to GE Capital of the United States. Although Toho is only the second major insurer in Japan to go out of business since World War II, its trouble underscores industrywide problems. C2.
 
Philippine Airlines Raises Capital
Debt-ridden Philippine Airlines met the deadline to raise $200 million or face liquidation. But half the money comes from its largest shareholder, Lucio C. Tan. Creditors have been increasingly hostile toward him and may not support his bid to keep control of the carrier. And Cathay Pacific Airways is preparing for talks with its pilots to resolve a dispute that has grounded many of its flights since May 28, but analysts were cautious about the outlook for the talks. C2.
 
Resolution Sought on Gold Sales
The head of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, said that he hoped the thorny issue of sales of gold from I.M.F. reserves could be resolved before the fund's annual meeting in September. The sale proceeds would be used to create a trust fund to aid poor countries. C2.
 
U.S. Tries to Undercut Microsoft
Microsoft introduced a host of evidence this week to show that the Netscape browser was still healthy and thriving. But in a single stroke, a Government lawyer undercut Microsoft's strategy by producing a Microsoft E-mail written in January suggesting that the company had cynically and selectively produced data to support this point of view. C4.
 
Amazon.com Seeks Court Ruling
Amazon.com sought a ruling in Federal court to allow it to continue posting the New York Times best-seller lists on line after the newspaper had demanded that the Seattle company stop publishing the lists in the absence of a licensing agreement. C3.
 
Patent Fraud Complaint Dismissed
A judge dismissed a Government complaint accusing Visx, the maker of vision-correction lasers, of patent fraud. C3.

HEADLINE: Mayor and City Council Leaders Reach Budget and Tax Agreement

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
After two weeks of relatively painless negotiations, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders agreed yesterday on a $35.3 billion budget that takes advantage of record high tax revenues and contains only a smattering of tax cuts.
Mr. Giuliani and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone gleefully announced the agreement in the City Hall rotunda, boasting that they had easily reached a consensus while politicians in Albany were still struggling to adopt a state budget that is now 66 days late. 
 In another swipe at state lawmakers, the two leaders said their only hurdle had been the Legislature's repeal of the city's tax on New York commuters last month, which could punch a hole of up to $360 million in the budget.
The sudden loss of revenue forced the Mayor and the Speaker to jettison many of their own tax cut proposals, they said, including cuts that would have helped businesses, working parents, home buyers and car owners.
But their budget plan still includes modest tax cuts, and spending increases for the Board of Education, the Police Department and many other agencies for the city's fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
"It's sweet because we were able to do an awful lot to enhance the quality of life in our city," Mr. Vallone said of the budget. "It's bitter, also, because in spite of all we've been able to do, for the first time ever we have had a hostile act from our brethren in Albany."
The agreement follows the framework of the budget that the Republican Mayor proposed last month, although Council leaders won some concessions. Mr. Giuliani allowed them to restore $165 million in cuts he had planned for cultural institutions, libraries and community programs. The Council extracted an additional $80 million for those programs, including $9.5 million for a summer reading program in libraries and $17 million for services for the elderly.
Mr. Giuliani also modified his plan to accelerate a class of 1,500 police recruits, agreeing to delay their hiring by three months. And he agreed, as he had been expected to do, to at least temporarily abandon his plan to use city funds for an experimental school voucher program, instead agreeing to spend $6 million to study several education ideas, including vouchers.
"I just ask that they keep their mind open," Mr. Giuliani said of the Council leaders who rejected his voucher plan, "because I'm going to come back and try to persuade you on the rest of it."
For its part, the Council accepted the Mayor's controversial plan to set aside millions of dollars for stadium construction in the future. But Mr. Vallone insisted that the amount come down to $90 million, from $96 million. And he demanded that the money come from the general budget, instead of from commercial rent tax revenue, as Mr. Giuliani had proposed. The Mayor also agreed to let the Council have a say in how the money is eventually spent.
Mr. Vallone also compromised in the area of tax reductions, agreeing to $348 million in cuts instead of the nearly $700 million he proposed in March. The most significant cut -- eliminating the sales tax on clothing and shoes that cost less than $110 -- was Mr. Giuliani's idea. That cut, which will take effect in December, will cost the city $134 million next year, growing to $237 million in 2001.
The budget agreement also extends a tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums, worth $166 million a year, and provides an earned income tax credit for the working poor, worth $48 million a year. New York would be the first city in the nation to offer its own earned income tax credit, which would save the average family $100 a year. Both cuts would need approval from Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature, which is by no means assured.
The city has sued to overturn the commuter tax repeal, and Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that if the suit succeeded, he might use that money to cut more taxes. "It's unfortunate that we couldn't do more tax cuts," he said, "but given what was done in Albany with the commuter tax, I think we've taken the responsible road."
The budget agreement still requires the approval of the full 51-member Council, but that is a formality because Mr. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, wields tight control over the Democrats, who have a majority. The Council is scheduled to vote on the budget on Monday. Mr. Giuliani, who has all but declared himself a candidate for the United States Senate, heaped praise on his own spending practices yesterday, saying he had dramatically improved the city's fiscal health by keeping spending under the rate of inflation and reducing budget gaps in the future.
"Even though they are still substantial, they are all below $2 billion," Mr. Giuliani said of the projected deficits for the next few fiscal years. "That is enormously important to the fiscal stability of the city, and it's something that was a perennial problem for the city of New York for 20 or 25 years."
Independent budget monitors said yesterday that future budget deficits remained a serious problem, especially since Mr. Giuliani's estimates do not account for potentially costly settlements with municipal workers. They questioned whether the $629 million that the Mayor is setting aside for unanticipated needs is enough, given that the local economy, driven mostly by Wall Street, could weaken.
The monitors also criticized Mr. Giuliani's use of the record $2.5 billion surplus to balance a budget that they said included some excessive spending, saying he should instead spend it to improve the city's crumbling infrastructure or to retire some of the city's $37 billion in long-term debt.
"In the best possible economic times, we shouldn't be using the surplus to help balance the budget," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "This is a case of a strong economy camouflaging some bad budget decisions."
While Mr. Giuliani proclaimed that spending would decrease by 3.2 percent in the coming fiscal year Ms. Fortuna and other budget watchdogs said it would actually increase by about 4 percent. The city is not projecting a spending increase because, under its own accounting rules, the surplus is counted as being spent in the current fiscal year, even though the Mayor is using it to balance next year's budget.
But Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone both insisted yesterday that the new budget was the most responsible spending plan in decades. Their chumminess -- the Mayor not only pumped the Speaker's hand, but kissed several Council members on the cheek -- contrasted sharply with last year's stormy budget negotiations, which broke off when Mr. Vallone refused to abandon a plan to hold a referendum on the future of Yankee Stadium.
The Mayor and the Speaker barely mentioned that battle yesterday. Instead, they emphasized that this time around, they had agreed on a new budget before the legal deadline of June 5. And they smugly hinted that the State Legislature should study their techniques. "More than anything else, we set an example as to how a legislature and a chief executive officer can work together collaboratively and adopt a budget on time," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council Finance Committee. "Not in a contentious manner, but with a view toward benefiting all the people."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
Bombing of Serbs Could End This Weekend, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
President Clinton declared today that he was "anxious to end the bombing" in Yugoslavia, and the Pentagon said the 10-week-old air war could end as early as Sunday if Serbia begins a troop withdrawal from Kosovo.
As Washington became more optimistic that peace in the Balkans was in fact at hand, Mr. Clinton also sought to assure the American public that the nation had pursued a "goal that has been worth fighting for" -- stability in Europe and the return of more than 800,000 ethnic Albanians to their homes in Kosovo. 
 "There is an enormous opportunity to be seized here," the President said in the ornate East Room of the White House, "a chance to shift our focus from defeating something evil to building something good, a chance to work with our allies to bring a stable and prosperous and democratic southeastern Europe in which people are never again singled out for destruction simply because of their religious faith or their ethnic origin."
With a meeting set on Saturday to hammer out a timetable for withdrawal and verification procedures, NATO kept up its bombing campaign for a 73d day -- hitting 51 targets in 24 hours, according to the Pentagon.
 Agence France-Presse reported Saturday morning that a NATO source said NATO and Yugoslav officials met at Djeneral Jankovic, on the Serbian side of the Kosovo-Macedonia border, at the border post at Blace, northwest of Skopje.
United States officials emphasized that most of the latest bombing was focused on forces in the field in Kosovo, and they said that they had yet to see any evidence of Serbian withdrawals. Yugoslav Army units clashed today with rebels trying to hold a strategic mountain called Pastrik. The Pentagon reported Serbian counterinsurgency operations against Kosovo rebels but said the intensity of the fighting seemed to have eased. But there were also reports that the Serbs were still forcing people from villages, officials said.
"I think it's important that we continue the military action against the military targets until we have some evidence that there are more than words here," Mr. Clinton said. The first article of the international peace plan accepted by Belgrade on Thursday requires the "immediate and verifiable end of violence and repression in Kosovo."
But there were clear signs that NATO was wrapping up its war effort and preparing to send a peacekeeping force into Kosovo.
For instance, the Pentagon's spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said the United States had suspended the deployment of 36 F-15 fighters to Turkey.
If the end of the air war looked imminent, the political debate raged on over just what NATO and Mr. Clinton had accomplished with a military campaign that was limited from the start to an air war that would carry little risk of allied casualties. More than 800,000 ethnic Albanians were expelled from Kosovo by Serbian forces and now need to be returned to a devastated land requiring a vast reconstruction effort.
Democrats said this week's diplomatic breakthrough was a vindication of the President's policy and persistence with the air strikes. "It's clear the air campaign has been effective," said Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader. "It has forced Milosevic to acknowledge that his options are running out."
One beneficiary of the accord was Vice President Al Gore. If all goes as planned, he will be able to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination free of the shadow of the air war, or of the possibility that American ground forces would invade Kosovo.
Republicans, however, were critical of the accord, emphasizing that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, indicted on charges of war crimes, had not been toppled from power.
"I think it is right and proper that all parties work to find peace and justice in the troubled Kosovo region," said the Speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert. "However, we should not let exuberance get in the way of the hard reality that Slobodan Milosevic is still in control of Serbia."
Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Republican Presidential contender, pointed to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as the model for the problems caused by leaving a dictator in power after a war. "The fact that it was an air campaign virtually guaranteed that he would remain in power," he said of Mr. Milosevic.
Similarly, Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, said: "It seems to me that the practical effect of this being a U.N. mission is that it would seem to guarantee Milosevic's continuation in power. Is that a good outcome, given the fact that we have labeled him a modern-day Hitler and he has been indicted in The Hague?"
The Belgrade agreement says that an international force in Kosovo would have "fundamental" NATO participation but be authorized by the United Nations. Senator McConnell and Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, both warned that could mean that Russia and China could have too much control over the force.
Administration officials insisted that the force would have NATO troops at its core, with a NATO general in charge.
Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, demanded that the President seek formal approval from Congress before sending any troops into Kosovo.
He also served notice that he would use confirmation hearings, planned for this month, on the nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as chief American diplomat at the United Nations to scrutinize American policy in the Balkans. He said the committee would explore Mr. Holbrooke's "role and responsibility for this Administration's misguided policy of appeasing Slobodan Milosevic." Mr. Holbrooke negotiated the Dayton accord that halted the war in Bosnia in 1995.
A senior Administration official said Mr. Clinton did not need Congressional approval to send troops and said the Kosovo force could be deployed in a matter of days.
The State Department spokesman, Jamie P. Rubin, argued that the 10 weeks of NATO air strikes had dealt a great deal of damage to Mr. Milosevic. "Clearly he is weaker," he said. "He is indicted. His country has been set back decades economically. His military has been largely broken through the air campaign. The reputation of Serbia has suffered mightily around the world."
Administration officials said there would be no Western assistance to rebuild Serbia until it became more democratic, and strongly suggested that Mr. Milosevic would have to be turned over for prosecution in The Hague before Serbia would be allowed access to international financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
"It's fair to say we cannot imagine a situation in which President Milosevic remains in Serbia and all of the different pieces of the puzzle get put together," Mr. Rubin said.
The Pentagon said the vanguard of American troops for the Kosovo operation was aboard a three-ship Marine group en route to Salonika, Greece. About 2,000 marines would be the first American troops to move into Kosovo, as part of an international force that is to grow to 50,000. The United States has pledged to send a total of 7,000 troops.
Once they reach Greece, the marines will travel by road to Skopje, Macedonia, and wait for NATO to order them into Kosovo after the alliance can verify that a significant Serbian withdrawal is under way.
Mr. Bacon said Serbian forces would pull out of Kosovo from west to east. A buffer zone will separate Kosovo from the rest of Serbia, and will help insure that remnants of the Serbian forces cannot re-enter Kosovo or fire at NATO troops.
The Pentagon said the marines would patrol a section of eastern Kosovo assigned to the United States. They would then yield to Army troops and heavy armor from bases in Germany.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Presses Japan on Phone Network Fees

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration threatened today to bring a trade case against Japan if Tokyo does not honor commitments to expand sales opportunities for American telecommunications companies.
"We want to insure that Japan adopts pro-competitive market-opening reforms consistent with its obligations," the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said in a statement. 
 She said the United States would monitor how Japan honored a pledge made last month to reduce fees charged American and other foreign companies to connect with Japanese phone networks, as well as a pledge to ease curbs on leasing telecommunications sites.
The AT&T Corporation and other American companies have long complained that Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company charged high interconnection rates to stifle competition in such areas as long-distance service.
Ms. Barshefsky said that the Administration expected the commitments made during Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's meeting with President Clinton last month to translate into "substantial reductions" in those charges.
If they do not occur, she said, the United States will begin preparing a case to bring before the World Trade Organization in Geneva.
Trade tensions between the world's two largest economies have been growing as America's trade deficit with Japan has increased, reaching $64 billion last year.

HEADLINE: Occupancy Falls Slightly As Hotel Room Prices Rise

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Despite the tourist boom, the occupancy rate for New York City hotels has dropped for the first four months of this year compared with the same period last year, in part because the average cost of a night's stay has climbed above $200 and because more hotels have opened.
But industry experts say the hotel business in New York remains robust, with the highest occupancy rate in the country. 
 Throughout the city, hotel room occupancy for January through April stood at 76.5 percent, compared with 78.8 percent for the same period last year, according to figures compiled by PKF Consulting, a company that monitors the hotel industry. But prices have increased. The average daily room rate was $205.51 for the first four months of the year, compared with $195.93 during the same period last year.
Jason N. Ader, a lodging analyst for Bear, Stearns, said New York's hotel prices, which are the highest in the country, were depressing the occupancy rate. "As a hotel customer you say, 'These prices are exorbitant,' " he said. Whether consumers can expect to see lower room rates will depend on whether the occupancy rate continues to go down, industry analysts said.
Several other reasons were cited for the decline in occupancy, including the recent opening of several new hotels, including the Benjamin on East 50th Street and W on East 49th Street, and a decline in visitors from countries with unfavorable currency exchange rates.
But it is too early for the industry to panic, several analysts said. "As long as the economy stays strong," said Chuck Ross, a vice president of Smith Travel Research Inc., a Hendersonville, Tenn., company that tracks industry trends, "I think that people will travel, and New York is high on the list of destinations."
Still, the trend has caused some consternation among hotel executives, who have become accustomed to occupancy rates that have risen almost every year since 1993.
Bill Dunphy, the director of marketing for the Mark, a hotel on Madison Avenue whose rates run as high as $475 a night, said: "What everyone is complaining about is we had such a great year last year that everyone budgeted relatively aggressively for this year. You're disappointed when you're not bettering your numbers every year." Last month, the Mark had an occupancy rate of 84 percent, compared with 88 percent for May 1998, Mr. Dunphy said.
The decline in occupancy rates has not been accompanied by a decline in visitors to the city, said Fran Reiter, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. She said that about 35 million people are expected to visit the city this year, up from an estimated 34.1 million last year. (A visitor is defined as anyone who comes to New York from more than 50 miles away, even just for the day, who is not a commuter.)
But Ms. Reiter said that fewer visitors were coming from some of what she described as "key feeder markets" such as Germany, Brazil, Japan and Canada. The loss of tourists from those countries is being more than offset by the domestic market, she said.
Jurgen Giesbert, a vice president of New York and Connecticut Marriott Lodging, which operates or manages 10 hotels in New York, said the expanding supply of rooms accounted for what he described as "minute decline" in business. Marriott alone added 1,000 rooms in New York last year.
And more hotel rooms are coming. Even so, no one expects the hotel market to become oversaturated. John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF, the firm that tracks the hotel industry, said that about two dozen new hotels are expected to open by 2002, but the city might be able to support even more, depending on where they are.
Although the hotel market has softened, Dexter E. Wood Jr., a senior manager at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm, predicted that the industry would do very well during the final quarter of the year -- historically its strongest period -- especially because of the excitement over the millennium. In fact, he said, the market may already be bouncing back.
"I was trying to get a hotel room in New York last week," he said, "and I couldn't get one."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;

DIPLOMACY
 
* The British general who is to direct NATO forces in Kosovo is to meet today with his Yugoslav counterpart on the Serbia-Macedonia border to plan the Serbs' withdrawal and verification of the withdrawal.

* The Pentagon and the allies reported continuing Serbian attacks against Kosovars, but said the tempo of the attacks seemed to have lessened.
 
* Serbian artillery shells hit Albania along a 12-mile stretch of border and four people were injured, local police and international monitors said.

HEADLINE: U. of Chicago President to Return to Teaching

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The president of the University of Chicago, Hugo F. Sonnenschein, whose moves to expand and modernize one of the nation's most revered universities became controversial, announced yesterday that he would step down next year and return to teaching.
Mr. Sonnenschein, a 58-year-old economist, came to Chicago in 1993 from Princeton University, where he had been provost. He soon began updating the University of Chicago, which has long nurtured a reputation for intellectual rigor. 
 He won acclaim for improving finances and modernizing the campus and the university's management, but some of his efforts to increase the size of the student body, trim the core curriculum and make the institution's image less severe met with the indignation of some students, professors and alumni.
The plans even led to the formation of a group of conservative intellectuals called Scholars for the University of Chicago that sought to block the changes. Among those involved were the author Saul Bellow, the sociologist David Riesman and the educator Mortimer J. Adler.
Mr. Sonnenschein's opponents expressed satisfaction yesterday and said the board of trustees had urged him to step down because it had grown weary of the controversy.
But the chairman of the board, Howard Krane, praised Mr. Sonnenschein and said it was going ahead with his plans.
"The board was fully informed about all of the issues involved in these initiatives, and our goal in approving them was to preserve and enhance our university well into the future," Mr. Krane said in a statement that was also signed by his designated successor as chairman, Edgar Jannotta. "Our resolve remains unchanged."
Mr. Sonnenschein issued a separate statement saying he had accomplished what he had set out to do, and adding, "I have come to feel that it is time for another president, one who is less a symbol of change and who has less reason to initiate change, to carry the momentum forward."
In a telephone interview, Mr. Sonnenschein acknowledged the existence of what he called "noisy minorities," but he said they had nothing to do with his decision to step down as president in June 2000.
"We have begun a collection of initiatives that couldn't be going better," he said. "The selectivity of the college is up, we have strong building programs and in 13 months I'll be nearing my 60th birthday and will go back to the best economics department in the country."
Aleem Hossain, 21, of Bolton, Conn., who is finishing his third year at the university and has helped lead a student movement opposed to the changes, said: "I see his stepping down as a concession that our points were serious. think that the expansion he started will go ahead but more slowly."
The university said the trustees would establish a search committee to find a new president.
Since early winter, when Mr. Sonnenschein's plans gained attention, some students and faculty members have agitated against them.
On April 20, Mr. Hossain and others organized a day of protest, called a "fun-in" to satirize the administration's emphasis on lightening the college's image. It drew 1,700 people. The university has 10,000 undergraduate and graduate students.
Undergraduates at Chicago take what is one of the most demanding core curriculums in the United States. Some say that is what drew them to the university, so that the plan to reduce the number of courses was unwelcome.
The courses are taught by professors in a small seminar style, and Mr. Sonnenschein's plan to increase the number of undergraduate students from 3,500 to 4,500 over 10 years without clear plans to increase the size of the faculty caused some to worry that such courses would be in danger of growing unwieldy.
But Mr. Sonnenschein's administration said the increase was manageable and necessary to insure the long-term economic health of the university. While the university's faculty is regarded as among the nation's best, its endowment and applicant pool are much lower than those of the top Ivy League institutions.
Mr. Sonnenschein believed that the university needed to attract a broader range of applicants, and thus had to make clear to high school students that life at Chicago was neither dreary nor a grind. To that end, colorful marketing brochures were drawn up; applications rose 25 percent this year.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
State Budget Spending Is Approved by House

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
With economic good times and a $550 million surplus in the bank, the State Legislature yesterday approved a a $23.78 billion, two-year budget with more aid to schools and towns, $273 million in tax cuts and $50 rebate checks for most residents.
The budget passed with only two no votes and the tax cuts passed unanimously, despite lawmakers' persistent protests about the rebate and funding for favored projects. 
 Republican Gov. John G. Rowland has said he supports the budget and tax cuts.
The budget would increase about 4.8 percent to $11.62 billion next year and about 4.7 percent to $12.16 billion the following year. The budget would be under a spending cap that is imposed by law.
Most of the $550 million surplus was to be spent on one-time expenses, including extra payrolls, computer work, health care and to settle lawsuits.
About $110 million of the surplus would go back to taxpayers in the form of $50 rebates for any adult in the state who paid income taxes or collects Social Security, disability checks or other benefits. Checks would be sent this fall.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
In Defense Of the Single and Childless

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst is a novelist and financial journalist. His column tilting at conventional business wisdom will appear the first Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IMAGINE working for a company that bases compensation on family status. If you have a spouse and children, you are paid more, even though single, childless employees seem to work longer hours. Singles hardly ever reach the highest levels of management. And the company does just about everything it can to discourage single employees from mating.
Outrageous, no? You'd expect activists to be screaming about such blatant discrimination, and lawyers to be filling the courts with briefs. 
 Strangely, though, many American companies, hectored from almost every side to make the workplace "family friendly," are moving in exactly that direction. Magazines heap laurels on the best workplaces for working mothers, with their flexible hours, on-site child care and so forth. But who extols companies that treat everyone equally, regardless of family status?
Many companies blithely discriminate against childless singles by offering employee benefits that are worth most to people with families: health and life insurance, subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits and so on. Those goodies add up to a major workplace inequality that stands unchallenged despite universal obeisance to the concept, at least, of equal pay for equal work.
Workplace favoritism for "family men" over "career girls" has historically been a nemesis of equal-rights advocates. Remember the episode of "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" in which Mary learned that a man in her job was paid more? The reason should be obvious, Lou Grant replied, as bosses have for decades: The guy's got a family.
If the equal-pay part of the equation is skewed, so is the idea of equal work. Who stays behind, after all, when the mom-and-dad exodus begins at 5:30 P.M.? Who shoulders the extra office burdens when a co-worker stays home with a sick child?
All of this buys singles no altitude on the corporate ladder. Unmarried chief executives are a theoretical possibility, but are rarely found in nature.
It's a miracle that most childless singles -- nearly one-third of all workers -- don't stay that way. In recent years, frantic efforts to desexualize the workplace may have had the unintended effect of forestalling matrimony for singles who spend so much time on the job they can't possibly meet people anywhere else. For every harasser or adulterer deterred by the reintroduction of taboos against office romance, dozens of potential healthy relationships must be nipped in the bud. Talk about a hostile work environment.
Policies that hurt singles probably land hardest on gay people, who cannot marry their partners, and, in most jobs, cannot even obtain benefits for them. It's a rare company these days that will acknowledge paying less or denying a promotion because an employee is gay, even in states with no laws forbidding it. Yet companies are proud of pro-family policies having the same effect.
Workers almost never claim discrimination for being single and childless. One reason is that they lack the protected status of other groups. Another may be that single, childless people like the environment at companies with family benefits. Lisa Levey, a management consultant with WFD Inc. in Boston, cites a "halo effect" that makes everyone feel better about companies that treat families well.
To be sure, the work burden may not be as unequal as people think. Mary B. Young of Boston University, who is writing a book about work-life issues for singles, surveyed employees at two large companies and found no difference in work time between childless singles and others, though nearly all thought singles worked longer.
THERE are signs that market forces are alleviating the problem. Many companies, especially small ones, are shifting the costs of employee benefits to workers or scrapping benefits entirely, producing a kind of equality of misery.
And for the growing legions of self-employed in the new "free-agent economy," it's strictly fee for services, regardless of one's home life. So you may get the fairest shake when you work on your own.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS/HARLEM;
Tenant Dispute Becomes Battle Of Bedsheets

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
Tenants of two buildings on the same gritty block in Washington Heights are waging a battle of the bedsheets. At 515 West 174th Street, residents have draped spray-painted bed linens from their fire escapes accusing a community advocate, Victor Morisete-Romero of trying to evict them. Two doors over at 503 West 174th where Mr. Morisete-Romero is the well-liked building administrator, the sheets defend him as honest and capable.
In 1996, the city turned management of No. 515 over to Quisqueya Housing, a joint venture between the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans, of which Mr. Morisete-Romero is executive director, and the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation. Under the Neighborhood Revitalization Program, Quisqueya was to repair and manage the property for its low-income residents. After architects reported severe structural flaws, Quisqueya ordered the tenants to relocate temporarily so the building could undergo a gut renovation. 
 Five families voluntarily moved into apartments provided by the organization, but the rest, some of whom have lived in the building for 25 years, refused to go.
Manny Alvarez, 57, the president of the tenants association, called the test results "a pack of lies" and said the building was in excellent shape after the city spent $242,100 on renovations during the last five years. Many residents said they feared that if they left they would face higher rents on returning.
Tenants at 503 West 174th Street have praised Mr. Morisete-Romero for turning their building around. "The place is cleaner, we're recycling for the first time, every day they're doing something to improve someone's apartment," Fior Escano said.
Ms. Escano admitted that Mr. Morisete-Romero's own staff had made the signs to counteract negative publicity down the block but said the tenants were happy to display them. "Mr. Morisete is a professional and honorable man," she said.
The residents at No. 503 are not the only outsiders to be drawn into a political free-for-all. Mr. Morisete-Romero, an ally of Councilman Guillermo Linares, has lashed out at Mr. Linares's archrival, Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat, for supporting the tenants at No. 515. "If that building is left behind," Mr. Morisete-Romero said, "he will have to pay the price." An Espaillat aide responded that the Assemblyman had helped the tenants find legal counsel because it was his job to help them.
Spanish-language news organizations have covered the dispute, including one raucous episode on the cable program "TV Revista" in which Mr. Morisete-Romero and Mr. Alvarez shouted at each other. On another program, "Que Pasa New York," a resident, Dominga Gomez, blamed Mr. Morisete-Romero for "sucking the blood from poor Dominicans." A reporter called the situation "a tremendous scandal."
Residents at No. 503 and other buildings defend their hero staunchly. Still, the 515 West 174th Street Tenants' Association has vowed to maintain the pressure until Quisqueya Housing drops the project. The two organizations are scheduled to meet in housing court this Thursday. SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
More Wealth, More Stately Mansions

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE beige, three-story mansion fills a one-acre lot on Clover Street in Memphis. Roof turrets, tall windows, columns that frame the front door at the head of a majestic, sloping driveway all heighten the impression of a palace incongruously placed in an ordinary suburb. The ranch house next door seems, by comparison, like a shack. It is empty, however, soon to be torn down so that another mansion can rise. And a neighborhood of small homes on large leafy lots gradually becomes a neighborhood of million-dollar mansions cheek by jowl.
"Such houses are conspicuous proof that a family has achieved a level of wealth way beyond its physical needs," says Kenneth Rosen, chairman of the Fischer Center for Real Estate at the University of California at Berkeley. "A mansion, more than luxury cars or anything else, shows everyone in the community that you are rich." 
 A wealthy doctor and his family recently moved into this particular six-bedroom brick mansion, with its cathedral ceilings, balconies, stately fireplaces and elegant rooms. But there are many Clover Streets springing up in the United States today, in new suburbs as well as in older ones where the demand for trophy mansions not too far from downtown has made the land more valuable without a home than with one.
So the homes are bought for the land by America's growing population of multimillionaires, who replace the existing houses with mansions. "In-fill," it is called in Memphis, and "teardown" in the Northeast. In the San Francisco area, it is known as the "scraper" phenomenon -- you buy a house, scrape it off the lot and build a bigger one.
THE million-dollar mansion -- or multimillion-dollar mansion, in some cities -- is emerging as a high-profile badge of the gilded late 1990's, not just in the traditional pockets of wealth, but also in Middle American cities like Memphis where such homes had been rare.
They are emblematic of an economic divide: The wealth generated in the boom that began in late 1995, while touching many people, has gone disproportionately and in huge quantities to the richest 5 percent of the nation's households. They have pocketed most of the gain from the stock market run-up, which has created thousands of multimillionaires overnight. And they have conspicuously channeled a big chunk of their gains into mansions.
There have been stock market run-ups in the past, of course, and mansions to show for it. But not since the 1920's, Mr. Rosen said, has mansion-building been as widespread as it is today. So much so that in some suburbs -- Scarsdale, N.Y., and Westport, Conn., for example -- restrictions have been placed on the teardown phenomenon, or are being considered.
One survey of large metropolitan areas turned up 9,257 new and existing homes that were sold for $1 million or more last year, up from 3,427 in 1996. And that did not count all the mansions custom-built by the families that occupy them.
Just how skewed is wealth creation in the late 1990's? And how many rich people have emerged to create such a historic surge in mansions?
A new study by Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist who tracks the distribution of wealth in the United States, found that 4.1 million of the nation's 102 million households had a net worth of $1 million or more last year. That compares with 3 million such households out of 99 million in 1995, when the stock market really began to gain steam. (Net worth is calculated by first totaling a household's cash savings, the market value of its stocks and bonds and the value of a house and other holdings -- then subtracting all the debt, including mortgage debt.)
Rarely in history has there been such a rapid minting of rich people, Mr. Wolff said. While the number of American households rose by 3 percent over the three-year period, the number of million-dollar households jumped 36.6 percent. Make the wealth cutoff $10 million or more, and 275,000 households qualified in 1998, up from 190,000 in 1995, a 44.7 percent increase.
 FROM his analysis of Federal Reserve data, Mr. Wolff gleans another insight: While net worth grew for the richest 10 percent of the nation's households in recent years, the remaining 90 percent lost ground.
"The story is debt," he explained, referring to the source of so much consumer spending and home buying in recent years. "The middle class in particular has mortgaged itself to death, basically."
What if wealth had somehow been distributed more evenly -- and income, too, for that matter? Would there have been so many mansions? Probably not. A mansion that simulates a palace, in which a few family members rattle around in too many rooms, makes an unequivocal statement.
"Everyone," said Richard Sennett, a New York University sociologist, "understands this prize that only a few can afford."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
Bengali Woman Writes Book, Takes Heat

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Mina Saha Farah, a Bengali dentist who lives and works in Queens and has written for Bengali newspapers, insists that when she started out to write a book last November, she planned it as a critique of organized religion.
But the final product, which Dr. Farah is spending some $8,000 of her own money to publish next week, singles out Islam for the toughest criticism. It argues that a growing fundamentalism is blinding Muslim Bengalis, preventing them from joining the "high-tech revolution" and prospering economically, and relegating women to subservient roles. 
 "People should have the freedom to speak and to think," she said in an interview last week. "We are become more of a mosque-based society rather than a free-minded society."
Dr. Farah's thesis has been raised by many Western scholars But what is different is her role as a well-known member of the city's Bengali immigrant community. Since February, when word of her book and its title, "God on Trial," began circulating within that community, she has been criticized by some immigrant groups whose officials disagree with Dr. Farah's assessment of Islam.
The book, and the angry pre-publication reaction it has provoked, has brought into sharp relief divisions between religious and more secular Bengali immigrants over what role religion should play in America and how freely Bengalis should criticize Islam or their own community.
"Mina Farah should spend her money and her talents to help her community, not to divide it," said Showkat Ali, the president of the Bangladesh Journalists Association of North America, who lives in downtown Brooklyn. "We all have a responsibility to our culture."
Dr. Farah, who was born into a Hindu family and married a Muslim, said she does not consider herself a member of any particular faith. In the last few months, she said, telephone callers to her home have cursed her, called her a nonbeliever and made vague threats against her family.
The owner of the city's largest Bengali-language bookstore, Bishawajit Saha, said he had also received threatening calls, although he planned to stock "God on Trial" at his shop, Muktadhara, on 74th Street in Jackson Heights, Queens.
"Already some people have called, they say you don't do this," Mr. Saha said. "I know it is a controversial book but we respect democracy."
Mr. Saha said his store was vandalized in 1992 when he sold the novels of the Bangladeshi writer Taslima Nasrin, an outspoken critic of Islam.
But Dr. Farah's critics say she should not be compared to Miss Nasrin. "People might demonstrate and boycott against her, Abdul Quddus Chaudhury Mohammad, the director of the Muslim Foundation of America, said of Dr. Farah. "They might even excommunicate her. But I don't believe any illicit action will be taken. People enjoy the freedom of America. People are not going to jeopardize that." JULIAN E. BARNES

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
An Uneasy Standoff in a High-Fashion War

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WHAT the Gucci Group really wanted was to get clean away from the dreaded embrace of Bernard Arnault. What it got was the uncomfortable prospect of a future with his company, its biggest rival, as its biggest minority shareholder.
A takeover battle over Gucci was decided a bit ambiguously on May 27, when a Dutch court approved the sale of a $3 billion controlling stake in Gucci to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute of France. Gucci, which is based in the Netherlands for tax reasons but has most of its operations in Italy, had agreed to the deal with Pinault to thwart the hostile bid by Mr. Arnault, chairman of the luxury goods maker LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton. But the decision did not affect the 20 percent stake in Gucci that LVMH has amassed. 
 Gucci is a hot property, and buying it would have given a needed jolt to Mr. Arnault's empire, which was hard hit by the economic crises in Asia. But Gucci's management thought being sucked into the corporate culture of LVMH would be deadly. Domenico De Sole, Gucci's chief executive, has ambitions far above being a satrap of Mr. Arnault: He wants to create a powerful multibrand luxury group big enough to challenge LVMH, whose portfolio includes Louis Vuitton luggage, Christian Dior fashions and Guerlain perfumes. To advance Mr. De Sole's plans, Pinault intends to sell to Gucci the Yves Saint Laurent couture and perfume business, which it had just acquired for $1 billion. Pinault, controlled by Francois Pinault, is also the owner of French department stores and Christie's auction house.
Mr. Arnault, who has not conceded defeat, is threatening to appeal the court's ruling and ask that the Pinault deal be declared illegal.
Moreover, while Gucci may be red-hot, its stock price has been cold lately, falling 6 percent the day of the court decision and then drifting downward. (It closed on Friday at 62.45 euros.) That is partly because speculators who had bet that Mr. Arnault would raise his bid for Gucci after the decision have sold in disappointment. But the decline also reflects investor hesitance about Gucci's ability to digest a mouthful the size of Yves Saint Laurent.
One analyst, Nathalie Saleur of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, estimated that the Yves Saint Laurent takeover could dilute Gucci's profits by 10 to 15 percent. Gucci lacks a track record in integrating big acquisitions, she said, and "the market prefers to wait for evidence."
 Mr. De Sole is in a hurry to supply it. He met with Mr. Pinault last week to discuss the start of legal groundwork for the Gucci-Yves Saint Laurent combination; barring surprises, that agreement could be signed by the end of July. Mr. De Sole, meanwhile, is arranging a trip to the United States to explain his plans to institutional investors who are among Gucci's most fervent backers.
SUCH quick acceleration is in line with Mr. De Sole's record. Since he took Gucci public in 1995, sales have exploded -- to just under $1 billion in 1998, from $264 million. Crises in Asian economies caused luxury goods sales to crumble last year, but Gucci used a timely expansion in the United States and a shift from accessories to ready-to-wear garments to maintain growth.
Despite its recent weakness, the price of Gucci's stock has grown more than fourfold since it went public in 1995. Mr. De Sole, together with Tom Ford, the designer of the hour, have built Gucci into a fast-growing fashion darling.
By contrast, profits at LVMH, the luxury market leader, sank 29 percent last year, dragged down mostly by weakness in Asia, though its recovery in the first months of this year has been remarkably strong.
But analysts say the gap between Gucci and LVMH is largely a question of fashion leadership, with Italian houses like Gucci, Prada and Armani rivaling the French. "Italy has a tremendous degree of creativity and resources," said Henry Welt, an expert on luxury goods at the New York law firm of Kronish, Lieb, Weiner & Hellman.
Indeed, LVMH shares leapt Friday on a report, denied by the company, that it was in talks to acquire a stake in Armani. The stock closed at 276 euros, just off its 52-week high.
To revive LVMH's ateliers, Mr. Arnault turned to Britain, hiring young designers like John Galliano at Christian Dior and Alexander McQueen at Givenchy. But Italy, Mr. Welt said, "brings to the table a number of things the French don't have," like related technologies in fabric and leather finishing. That, in part, was why Mr. Arnault wanted Gucci in the first place, he said.
Mr. De Sole says that, though integrating Yves Saint Laurent will be a challenge, his plans for Gucci are far from exhausted. Last year, Gucci paid $150 million to acquire the Swiss company that supplies its watches. Gucci has already introduced a line of jewelry in its own stores, and next year will begin selling it in 300 top-of-the-line stores worldwide. And it continues to open new stores in Japan, Europe and the United States.
ALL that expansion should please shareholders, making it relatively unlikely that Mr. Arnault could make much trouble from his 20-percent shareholding stronghold. Mr. De Sole categorically rules out a board seat for LVMH, and while Gucci bylaws permit shareholders with more than 10 percent of the company to convene an extraordinary shareholder meeting, it is unclear what such a gathering could accomplish for Mr. Arnault as long as Gucci is thriving.
According to Mr. Welt of Kronish, Lieb, LVMH could make a nuisance of itself by requesting privileged financial data, but Mr. De Sole said no single shareholder would be favored. "We're an incredibly transparent company," he said.
More likely, Mr. Welt said, the effect of Mr. Arnault's restive presence will be to keep Gucci management from becoming complacent.
Some analysts say the biggest challenge for Gucci, awash with acquisition cash, may be finding suitable brands to swallow. "Italian families seem quite content," said John Wakely of Lehman Brothers. "What is Gucci going to do with the cash?"
Still, Mr. De Sole says he will begin massaging prospective takeover targets right away, given the slowness with which Italian family-run companies with prestigious names tend to make decisions. John Grace, executive director of Interbrand, a brand consulting company in New York, said that, at any rate, Gucci was on the right track, adding that "as Cecil B. DeMille said, everything's negotiable."
"Gucci's doing the absolutely right thing," Mr. Grace said. "They're building a portfolio."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
The Case for a Rate Increase is Still Strong

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
INVESTORS, it seemed, were ready to concede that the Federal Reserve would have to raise interest rates to slow growth and curb inflation.
But when the May employment report was released on Friday morning, there was a surprise. Job growth was unexpectedly weak. Instead of an increase approaching 220,000 new nonfarm jobs, as Wall Street had forecast, there were only 11,000. 
 "It didn't give you closure," lamented Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. "We can't say we're done."
Yet this surprising report should not change the outlook for the economy. (It is still strong.) Or interest rates. (They should move higher.) Or the intent of the Fed. (It should raise rates soon.)
Of course, one could conclude otherwise by focusing on the nonfarm jobs data, which were weak in May and have not been disturbingly strong for the year, increasing at a monthly average of 197,800. But that focus would be deceiving.
Consider the rest of the economic data released last week, although with much less fanfare than the jobs report.
* The factory index of the National Association of Purchasing Management jumped to 55.2 in May, its highest level since October 1997. Prices paid to producers also rose.
* Car and truck sales are soaring, with the annual rate in May hitting 17.1 million, a May record and the fifth highest ever.
* Sales of new homes in April jumped 9.2 percent, to an annual rate of 978,000, the second-strongest month on record.
* Sales in stores open at least a year rose 5.6 percent.
All this indicates that consumers are still spending while the nation's weakest sector, manufacturing, appears to be rebounding.
On top of this, the underlying data in the May jobs report were stronger than indicated by the meager nonfarm jobs increase.
The reason for that surprisingly small overall gain was a decline of 40,000 in construction jobs and a plunge of 45,000 in manufacturing. In addition, the service sector created just 71,000 jobs, well below its average of 125,000 over the last 12 months.
Construction jobs have been rising and falling with the weather, jumping 44,000 in April before last month's decline, on a seasonally adjusted basis. Since March of last year, 453,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost as recessions in Asia and Latin America slashed demand for American goods.
But while jobs have been declining, the growth rate of average hourly earnings in manufacturing is rising again. For all of last year, average hourly earnings for manufacturing were up just 1.6 percent. So far this year, they are up 4.3 percent at an annual rate.
The slowdown of wage increases in manufacturing had helped restrain overall wage increases, allowing the growth rate to decline while the economy was booming. That mitigating factor now appears to be gone.
The closure sought by Mr. Barbera must wait for the release of other key data ahead of the Fed's policy-making meeting on June 29 and 30. Those include the Government's formal tabulation of retail sales for May, to be released on Friday, and the Labor Department's measure of consumer prices for last month, due on June 16.
If they are strong, retail sales will serve to prove that the consumer has bounced back after a weak March and April. The Consumer Price Index for May will show whether the April gain of 0.7 percent, the largest monthly jump in eight and a half years, was a fluke. And if it is possible to scrutinize Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, any more closely, investors will do so on June 17, when he is scheduled to testify before Congress's Joint Economic Committee on monetary and economic policy. Many expect him to use the occasion to signal that a rate increase is coming.
BEYOND the data, there is another reason the Fed should move rates higher. Based on the movement of the many market barometers of investor sentiment, a quarter-percentage-point increase in the Fed's short-term interest rate target, to 5 percent, is already expected.
That means the Fed could raise the rate on overnight loans between banks -- the Federal Funds rate -- without too much disruption, argued Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. In fact, he added, "the Fed might cause more questions if they do not."

HEADLINE: The World;
New U.S.-Iran Dialogue: Psst. Mumble. Huh?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
TEHERAN is abuzz again, divided now over whether America really is still the Great Satan. And as usual, the ferocity of Iran's internal power struggles make it hard to know just what is going on.
This time, though, the confusion seems to run two ways. This Iranian row seems to have been prompted by American mixed signals -- tantalizing but ambiguous all the same -- about whether the United States is ready to go easier on Iran. 
 Unless you are in the Middle East, you may have missed all this; just about everywhere else, the crisis in Kosovo has exhausted people's attention. So here's a quick primer on the latest in American-Iranian relations -- the winks, nods and backhanded slaps that may amount to a lot or to absolutely nothing at all.
First, on April 12, President Clinton told a White House audience that Iran had been subjected to "quite a lot of abuse" over the years; it was important to tell people, he said, "Look, you have a right to be angry." In Iran, ears perked up, particularly among political moderates. Was this a first step toward a long-sought American apology?
Ten days later, a State Department official showed a colder hand. Certainly, said Martin S. Indyk, an Assistant Secretary of State, the United States wants dialogue with Iran, but first on the agenda would be those old subjects that make Iranians cringe: terrorism and weapons of mass destruction. Aha, Iranian conservatives pronounced. A good-guy-bad-guy routine, nothing more than American mischief!
At the end of April came a flurry of paper from the American Government. One rule eased the way for Iranian scholars to travel to the United States, another softened sanctions half a notch by allowing food and medicine to be sold to Iran. Then came a State Department report that again identified Iran as a sponsor of terrorism -- but not, as in the past, as the world's leader in that field.
It all amounted to nothing more than a "diplomatic smile," complained Iran's Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharazzi. A better summation might have been that it simply left just about everyone more confused.
"These Americans are crooks," Ayatollah Ahmad Jannati, the head of Iran's judiciary, warned in one Friday sermon as he sounded the conservative line. "Why are some people so naive as to believe in them?"
By contrast, the moderate Iran Daily said it saw the beginning of "a new chapter" and declared: "It is high time to insure practical steps for normal ties."
It seems clear that Iran's President, Mohammed Khatami, is open to warmer ties with the United States. But he remains hemmed in by Iran's conservatives, led by the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. As recently as mid-May, a delegation of senior clerics appointed by Mr. Khamenei presented Mr. Khatami with a petition saying that the time was not right for Iranian-American relations to be restored.
Ever since those ties were broken off after the Iranian revolution of 1979, conservatives have tried to squelch talk of a detente. They have reminded just about anyone who would listen that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic Republic, once likened Iranian-American relations to those between sheep and wolf.
But for a year and a half now, Mr. Khatami's moderate Government and the Clinton Administration have been cautiously swapping hints of a willingness to explore moving toward warmer ties. And some Iranians, eager for improved trade, have begun to read into the American overtures a reason for rapprochement.
"The United States may still be a wolf, but Iran has turned into a lion," Mehdi Karrubi, a longtime anti-Western firebrand who has become a Khatami ally, declared last month, neatly suggesting that Mr. Khomeini's warnings belonged to a distant era.
Officially, Iran's Government has ruled out direct talks until Washington redresses past wrongs, presumably by lifting economic sanctions and unfreezing millions of dollars of Iranian assets held in America.
WASHINGTON, for its part, has said it is ready to talk -- but that there can be no revival of economic ties until Iran takes the concrete steps that Mr. Indyk outlined in his April 22 speech: halting support for terrorism, abandoning opposition to Middle East peace and giving up efforts to acquire weapons of mass destruction.
In practical terms, that leaves the two countries at loggerheads, despite the feelers each has sent since January 1998, when Mr. Khatami, in a CNN interview, called for a "dialogue of civilizations" and in effect apologized for the November 1979 takeover of the United States Embassy in Teheran.
Still, every subtle signal is carefully digested, and Mr. Clinton's remarks in April were hailed by moderate Iranian newspapers and some politicians as at least a first step toward an American apology.
The President's statement, which surprised even his foreign policy advisers, included this sentence: "I think sometimes it's quite important to tell people, 'Look, you have a right to be angry at something my country, or my culture, or others that are generally allied with us today, did to you 50 or 60 or 100 or 150 years ago.' "
In Iran, provincial governors welcomed the words as Mr. Clinton's "acceptance that the demands of the Iranian people are just." Mr. Khatami's Government, on the other hand, has had to be more circumspect; its continuing war with the powerful conservative bloc has left Mr. Khatami wary of being portrayed as bowing to the United States. In its official statements, Iran has gone so far as to say only that America might be showing "greater realism."
And, certainly, the hesitation also runs both ways. No matter how the Iranians or analysts of the Iranian-American relationship have tried to interpret this murky dialogue, Administration spokesmen keep insisting that American policy has not changed.
