SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2835 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Still FeedingAn Internet Frenzy

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
THE ink on the first draft of the history of the Internet stock boom isn't yet dry, and the revisionists are already having their say.
Even as Internet shares were tumbling from their highs, three of the companies backed by Accel Partners, a venture capital firm, went public last month. Though their net losses total $56 million, the three now have a combined market capitalization of $10 billion. "Astounding," James W. Breyer, the firm's managing partner, calls that performance, echoing the giddiness common in Silicon Valley when people talk about the Internet. 
 But in the same breath, Mr. Breyer decries the shortcomings of the crop of new offerings following in his companies' footsteps. "We've had far too many low-quality companies go public," he scoffed. The recent market turmoil that has sliced the value of many Internet stocks in half is making investors more discriminating, he added approvingly: "Investors can more easily distinguish between companies building a long-term business and those which have been merely opportunistic."
Ah, to be a master of the Internet universe and not only make business history, but spin it, too. As some of the air leaks out of the Internet stock bubble, the same people who manufactured the feeding frenzy -- the venture capitalists, entrepreneurs and investment bankers who have been the biggest promoters of the phenomenon -- are beginning to say it may have spun out of control. Stocks not ready for prime time were foisted on a welcoming public lusting for the big score, they now say. In Silicon Valley's effervescence the past few months, discretion lost out to greed.
And yet even as they apply the rhetorical brakes to careening Internet mania, those same financiers are stepping on the gas, racing to bring companies to market before the Internet euphoria disappears. Some investment bankers say clients are asking them to pull together "road shows" -- in which executives pitch their companies to prospective buyers -- in little more than two weeks, half the usual time. And many of the bankers, supposed arbiters of a company's market-worthiness, are only too happy to oblige.
"Right now it's hang onto the rocket ship and giggle all the way to the moon," said Mark G. Shafir, an investment banker at Merrill Lynch in San Francisco.
 Already, 59 Internet companies have gone public this year -- compared with 30 in all of 1998, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data, which tracks such numbers. Fifty-six percent of the 212 Internet and Internet-related companies filing plans to go public with the Securities and Exchange Commission since January 1994 did so in the last six months. May was the busiest month on record, as 35 companies registered with regulators.
That pace concerns David Menlow, who, as the longtime president of IPO Financial Network, a firm in Milburn, N.J., that tracks new offerings, has seen his share of hysteria on Wall Street. Even he is stunned at the crush of companies rushing to go public since Internet stocks hit a record high in mid-April.
Mr. Menlow's most recent newsletter is chock-full of comments on the new crop, and few are charitable. "Right church, wrong pew," he writes about one Internet-related medical concern. "Talk about swimming upstream," he says of a company that creates computer operating systems.
The market for Internet stocks is still fertile, Mr. Menlow said, but companies like these will be judged more harshly in coming months, since the euphoria over the sector has ebbed. "Before, the window was wide open," he said. "Now the window has a fine mesh screen."
Yet with Silicon Valley still working overtime to generate excitement -- and the transformative power of Internet innovation a genuine, powerful lure -- investors can be said to share a new caution only if their behavior is judged against the hysteria of the last few months.
In January, according to Securities Data, initial public offerings of Internet companies averaged a first-day gain of 248 percent. By the end of May, with so many deals to choose from and appetites waning a bit, that gain had dwindled to 73 percent.
Fearlessly, though, Silicon Valley financiers are developing ways to institutionalize the Web frenzy. Venture capitalists are demanding that shares of some new companies be sold on line, where Internet-hungry investors are abundant. And some neophyte investment firms see that as an opportunity to supplant the more established banks. Looked at innocently, they are aiming to democratize investment. Looked at cynically, they are looking to give every investor equal standing in the hype.
Some Silicon Valley veterans believe it is time for some cooling.
"I actually despair what is going on in the Valley," said Judy Estrin, chief technology officer at Cisco Systems, herself an entrepreneur who was a co-founder of three companies. "It used to be if you had good products and you took care of your clients and customers, you'd win. That's not enough anymore. Today it's more about marketing hype and rising above the noise level."
That may be overly pessimistic. Most here are ecstatic at the speed and breadth of innovation that the Internet has unleashed. But for the financiers, one thing is certain, even with Web shares down: It doesn't get much better than this.
 
Grabbing for a Slice of Ebay
Many of Silicon Valley's venture capitalists and investment bankers ply their trade in Menlo Park, not far from grassy pastures dotted with cows and an occasional deer. There, in the 2700 block of Sand Hill Road (more aptly named "Stand Still Road" when rush-hour traffic clogs the four-lane route), two of the fiercest competitors in investment banking have set up shop. A small, flower-filled courtyard separates the offices of rivals Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the Goldman Sachs Group, their buildings connected by a covered walkway 100 yards long.
It's an intimacy rare even in a place where deals are cut at Saturday-morning soccer games. "We have a pact not to go through the trash," joked Eff W. Martin, a Goldman partner, pointing at Morgan's offices through a slit in the window blinds.
Still, the arrangements seem a bit cozy, as if what the bankers have in common -- their insider status in a very rich game -- trumps any antagonisms. Bradford C. Koenig, Goldman's co-head of high technology, employed the same nanny later hired by Rex Golding, a Harvard Business School classmate and his counterpart at Morgan Stanley. And it is not uncommon to see bankers from both camps schmoozing at the same Valley soirees.
On Wall Street, investment bankers sit at the top of the financial pyramid; here they mainly play the role of courtiers. The true princes of finance are the venture capitalists, who invest in start-ups with the hope of a big payoff when a company goes public or is sold.
More Internet venture dollars are chasing deals than ever before. Funds raised by venture capitalists have blossomed in the past four years, from $774 million in 1995 to $4.9 billion last year, according to the VentureOne Corporation. Jonathan Lee, an entrepreneur in Redwood City, Calif., who last September started a company called Corio that distributes business software over the Internet, said he was approached by no fewer than 20 venture capital firms, including the godfather of Silicon Valley venture capital, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.
In the 1980's, "there wasn't a countervailing presence to the lunacy of the bankers," said Gary Rieschel, managing general partner at Softbank Technology Ventures, an early investor in Yahoo, the Internet directory service. "Now you have the lunacy of the venture capitalists to counter the lunacy of the bankers."
Indeed, this decade's venture capitalists have much in common with bankers of a decade ago who hired publicists to promote themselves and their successes. In keeping with the spirit of the companies they finance, most have their own Web sites and are skilled at creating a buzz loud enough to rise above the Valley static.
One of the more accomplished is Robert Kagle, a venture capitalist at Benchmark Capital in Menlo Park. Benchmark was an early investor in Ebay, the on-line auction company that has seen its share price climb more than 1,000 percent since going public last year.
Mr. Kagle, 43, a Michigan native who, like many Valley veterans, moved to Palo Alto to attend Stanford Business School and never left, is self-deprecating. "Some venture capitalists see themselves as the center of the universe," he said. "We see it as a service business."
Yet even as he shares credit with colleagues for his successes, Mr. Kagle is an adept salesman for the companies he backs. In a recent interview, for instance, he readily volunteered that he collects antique fishing decoys -- bought through Ebay, of course. And he strained to use the term "Ebaysian" ("pronounced e-BAY-ze-an," he said) no fewer than five times in a 35-minute telephone conversation.
Why? It is his attempt to introduce Ebay culture -- which advocates the equal standing of every bidder -- into the new language of the Internet, a bit of manipulation that he doesn't deny and even laughs about.
No other Internet company has been so hotly fought over as Ebay, and the story of its public offering suggests how eager bankers are to hook up with a company they think will be a winner.
In May 1998, when Mr. Kagle and Ebay's chief executive, Meg Whitman, invited investment banks to pitch for the job of taking the company public, Goldman and Morgan jumped at the chance. Ms. Whitman had one peculiar demand: When they came calling, each bank had to bring an item bought on Ebay.
A team of eight Goldman executives entered Ebay's headquarters, bags crammed with charts, market data -- and Tank the Armadillo, a Beanie Baby that Mr. Koenig had bought for his 7-year-old son, Austin, for $32.75 in an Ebay auction. Michael K. Parekh, an analyst, had a 25-year-old Parcheesi game that he had bought for $110. He also presented the Ebay executives with a sample research report before the Goldman team swept them off to dinner.
"It was clear they would be a leader in this market," Mr. Koenig said, explaining the avid campaign. "The more time we spent on the site, we realized it was a whole new dimension in personal trading."
Goldman's inventiveness struck a chord with Ebay, though Morgan Stanley was dogged, too. Its executives also logged hours on Ebay's Web site, buying fine French wine and a couple of piggy banks in which Ebay could stuff its newfound money. But "they didn't display as deep an understanding," Mr. Kagle said. And it cost Morgan the job.
The bankers were devastated. "We walked out of the meeting right then and knew that it didn't click," said Mary Meeker, Morgan's celebrated Internet analyst -- "Queen Mary" to her fans, "Bloody Mary" to her detractors and a stock-moving powerhouse in the eyes of both. Ms. Meeker was convinced that Ebay would be a market leader, and after Morgan lost, she quickly went to work repairing the relationship.
She spent hours getting to know Ms. Whitman, including a dinner at Logan Airport in Boston last July, one of several meetings over a period of months. In August, Ruth Porat, Morgan's co-head of global technology and Ms. Meeker spent an evening on the phone with Ms. Whitman, critiquing Goldman's road-show presentation. They suggested that the company demonstrate its users' enthusiasm better; as a result, Ebay created slides listing some of the thousands of items for sale related just to the baseball superstar Mark McGwire.
Ms. Meeker also took the unprecedented step of publishing a favorable research report the day after Ebay began trading last September. (Analysts usually like to wait until the company has a track record before giving an endorsement.) Goldman was legally barred from talking up the stock for 30 days after the offering, Ms. Whitman noted, "so Mary became the one the press called. She became associated with Ebay."
Morgan Stanley's hard work paid off. In March, Goldman lined up investors for Ebay's $1 billion secondary stock offering but was forced to share the business with Morgan. Goldman chafed at the concession but was powerless to prevent it.
"Morgan earned it," Ms. Whitman said.
 
Marketing to the Mania
 If there is any question that technology is transforming business, investors need look only at the most staid rite of passage on Wall Street: going public.
It used to be that for a standard 7 percent underwriting fee, bankers would herd management onto a chartered jet for a two-week road show, cram in 10 to 12 meetings a day with mutual fund managers and other investors and hope to end up with a list of interested buyers -- with a tiny portion of the stock reserved for mom-and-pop investors.
Now, investors' mania for the stocks minted by Silicon Valley financiers -- along with the growing trend toward do-it-yourself investing on line -- has banks scrambling to find new ways to get stock in I.P.O.'s into the hands of individuals. And the new on-line banks, without armies of bankers and salesmen, expect to charge companies fees of 5 percent or less.
"First you had the discount brokers," said Michael Moritz, a venture capitalist at Sequoia Capital in Menlo Park. "Now you have the emergence of the discount investment banker."
Established firms like the Charles Schwab Corporation and DLJ Direct, the on-line affiliate of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, already distribute shares on line and help underwrite stock offerings. But the emergence of on-line investment banks -- like the Wit Capital Group of New York (which itself went public on Friday) and E*Offering, which is backed by Sanford Robertson, a co-founder of Robertson, Stephens & Company of San Francisco -- could open the process further, with new stocks available on a first-come, first-served basis.
The most revolutionary concept is being championed by William Hambrecht, co-founder of another San Francisco investment bank, Hambrecht & Quist. Housed in a former warehouse in the city's design district, his firm, W. R. Hambrecht & Company, sells new stocks over the Internet in a so-called Dutch auction, with investors setting the price.
Investors place bids for the number of shares they want at a price they are willing to pay. After a few weeks of bidding, a clearing price is set at the lowest offer at which all shares can be sold. Those bidding above the clearing price get all the shares they asked for. Investors bidding at that price may get only a percentage of the shares they want. Those who bid too low are shut out.
The concept, while by no means proven, appeals to venture capitalists like Bruce Dunlevie, a partner at Benchmark Capital. "I think the trends favor it," he said. "It is the rise of the consumer in the I.P.O. market."
But the mechanics may serve only to feed the frenzy further, encouraging overbidding. "If you guess the actual price, you run the risk of not getting stock," acknowledged Ian H. Zwicker, president of W. R. Hambrecht. Plus, it is unclear whether many analysts will follow the companies and offer investors needed guidance. Ravenswood Winery, the first company whose stock was auctioned this way, got a tepid reaction from investors. But most experts believe the logical users of Hambrecht's services are Internet entrepreneurs.
 
A Case of Caution
If the market for Internet stocks remains weak, Silicon Valley may have no choice but to pause and catch its breath. That would please Mr. Lee, the founder of Corio.
Corio's fiercest competitor, a Maryland company called USinternetworking, was grabbing headlines after its stock price shot up from $21 to a high of $60 on April 9, the day it went public. Though USinternetworking had $33 million in net losses and a still-developing business model, the first day's trading gave it an eye-popping market capitalization of $2.4 billion and, Mr. Lee worried, instant credibility.
He was faced with a decision: Should Corio go public, too? It had promising sales but couldn't guarantee the same success in the coming months. And while Wall Street analysts may not require profits, they do demand predictability. "That doesn't come without processes, people and tools in place," Mr. Lee said. After an agonizing two-hour board meeting in April, the company chose to hold off.
"We definitely felt the pressure," Mr. Lee said. "You get caught up in the hype. Given that we could do it, of course we thought about it. A lot of people do. We are fighting a clock."
A month later, he doesn't regret the decision. USinternetworking's market capitalization has fallen to $1 billion, and investors who bought in the first day's euphoria are facing losses of more than 58 percent.
"My philosophy is that an I.P.O. is a measure of doing something well," Mr. Lee said. He hesitated for a moment, reconsidering the thought. "But it's also about being at the right place at the right time."

LENGTH: 3001 words

HEADLINE: At the King Ranch, a Way of Life Is Riding Into the Sunset

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex.

 BODY:
CROSSING a shady creek bed in South Texas nearly 150 years ago -- in the middle of what many people called the Desert of the Dead -- Captain Richard King had a vision.
Although he was a steamboat pilot with a thriving business on the Rio Grande, Captain King saw an opportunity to raise cattle on the parched, untamed land that surrounded him. He bought 15,500 acres, about 20 miles southwest of Corpus Christi, from a land grant known as Rincon de Santa Gertrudis. And he began carving out a ranching enterprise that would become an American legend. 
 His descendants built on his dream, creating one of the largest ranches in the country, with 825,000 acres in Texas and operations around the world. Over the years, family members developed the Santa Gertrudis, the first new breed of cattle to be produced in the United States; advanced new methods of clearing brush; perfected the American quarter horse (not to mention breeding a line of thoroughbreds that included Assault, a Triple Crown winner in the 1940's), and refined a system of land management and preservation.
But in recent years, as the cattle business has become less profitable and the family has grown larger and more costly to support, the vision seems to have blurred. Many think it faded altogether when the last King descendant to work the ranch, Stephen J. (Tio) Kleberg, 53, was dismissed in April 1998 by the professional manager brought in three years earlier to lead the company.
In the year since, at least eight key employees have quit or been dismissed. At a place where employees have been well tended for generations, managers say they feel uncertain about their future, with their work scrutinized and their decisions second-guessed.
"Maybe these changes have to happen," said Bill Baxter, a computer technology specialist at the ranch for 17 years until he resigned in November, dissatisfied after Mr. Kleberg's departure. "I just wonder if there's a good way to do that without destroying the legacy. It's sad to see the traditions die."
In fact, tradition has been under assault at King Ranch for years, maybe decades. Captain King's rule -- the guiding principle of many of the white settlers of Texas -- was that bigger was better. When he died, in 1885, the ranch had grown to more than 600,000 acres. It now consists of four units sprawled across five counties, one of them named for his Kleberg descendants. At one point, he imported the residents of an entire Mexican village to work his cattle; the children of these kinenos, as they became known, were educated on the ranch, and generations were guaranteed jobs.
But traditional ranching activities have been a diminishing part of King Ranch's business, as Americans have reduced their consumption of beef and as more profitable uses have been found for the land, from oil drilling to quail hunting to tourism. And a portfolio of nonranch holdings has been developed to generate the dividends demanded by the 84 family shareholders.
Since Jack Hunt, who has an M.B.A. from Harvard and a background in agribusiness, took over as chief executive and president in May 1995, he has sold the ranch's lumber operations, a cotton warehouse in Galveston and a horse farm in Kentucky. He terminated some farming leases in Arizona. The ranch is now looking to merge or sell King Ranch Energy, an oil and gas company.
In the meantime, King Ranch has bought a 5 percent stake in Agraquest, a Davis, Calif., company that makes natural pest controls for crops. Last year, the company led a consortium, Consolidated Citrus, in the acquisition of Turner Foods, one of Florida's largest citrus growers.
The company, which is privately held, does not divulge financial information about its operations. But people close to it have said that in a good year, pretax profit from cattle can range from $1 million to $3 million. Hunting, they say, can bring in $3 million a year; sod, $16 million. A 1998 article in Texas Monthly magazine quoted "company insiders" as saying that overall revenues were $183 million in 1994, up from about $100 million in the late 1980's. The company has some 600 employees globally, about 160 of them working the Texas ranch land.
"I think we are very interested in continuing to grow and provide and meet the expectations of the shareholders," said Mr. Hunt, a reserved man who runs King Ranch from the company's office in Houston. "At the same time, we're absolutely committed to operate and maintain the South Texas property."
The family says that it, too, is committed to the ranch and that the best way to assure its future is by securing its viability.
Captain King's descendants will gather in South Texas this week for their annual summer camp and shareholders meeting, a time when family members get reacquainted with the land and one another. They also consider the ranch's future -- and with each passing year, that seems to become more of a challenge.
 
Calling In the Professionals
The ranch has struggled to support itself since 1977, when the shareholders laid claim to 75 percent of the royalties coming from gas and oil reserves on the ranch. That cash flow had given the ranching operations breathing room, and once it was gone, many operations were deemed unsustainable. The thoroughbred racehorses were put up for sale, as were most of the overseas ranches. Only a 50,000-acre ranch in Brazil remains, run by Mr. Kleberg's son Chris, 28.
Corporate management at the ranch predated Jack Hunt. In 1988, seeing a need to diversify, the family hired Darwin E. Smith, the chairman and chief executive of Kimberly-Clark, the paper maker, as its first outside chief executive. He lasted only a year, and was replaced by an oil executive, Roger Jarvis. During their tenure, the ranch added a citrus grove and sod farm in Florida, an alfalfa hay farm in Arizona and a cluster of offshore oil and gas wells in the Gulf of Mexico.
While the family deferred, for the most part, to its professional managers, Tio Kleberg ran the ranching operations. A fifth-generation descendant of Captain King, with a bushy red mustache and a penchant for chewing cigars, he had grown up on the ranch. Descendants of the original kinenos gave him his nickname, which means uncle in Spanish, because they saw him as cut from the same cloth as his uncle Robert J. Kleberg Jr., who led the ranch for more than 50 years, helping to save it in the 1930's when an estate tax bill posed a mortal threat.
Tio Kleberg went to work here full time in 1971, when he was 25, after serving in the Army. "I was given a car and a set of ranch keys, and they said, 'Go to work'," he recalled. "All I ever wanted to do was cowboy."
Already familiar with cattle, from his childhood on the ranch, he set out to master other aspects of the operations: brush-clearing, fence-building, the location of windmills. He learned every square inch of the land and participated in every roundup, happiest when he was out working the ranch rather than sitting in an office minding the books.
By 1977, Mr. Kleberg was head of ranching operations. But the ranch was already unprofitable, he said, and land management was becoming an increasingly important part of the business. He oversaw a shift from cattle to fostering wildlife development, for everything from hunting to bird watching, and expanded farming operations on parts of the ranch. Under his stewardship, the ranch brought in experts on cattle fertility and continued to build on the Santa Gertrudis, breeding them to be more productive.
People who know both Tio Kleberg and Jack Hunt, the Harvard-trained chief executive, are not surprised that they clashed. Both are said to be strong-willed, and each had a well-cultivated sense of how a ranch should be managed. Often, those visions conflicted.
In addition to his Ivy League credentials, Mr. Hunt came to Texas with more than 20 years of experience in agribusiness -- 14 of them at the 270,000-acre Tejon Ranch in Southern California, long controlled by the Chandler family, owners of The Los Angeles Times.
Their final confrontation, Mr. Kleberg said, came after he was asked to examine whether the ranch's agricultural operations -- sod, cane and citrus in Florida and cotton and sorghum in Texas -- should be split from the ranching operations. After talking to the head of the Florida business, Mr. Kleberg concluded that the time wasn't right. The man had a young family, he explained, and a reorganization would require him to travel much more.
Soon, though, Mr. Kleberg said, he realized that his opinion wasn't being sought, that he was being told to split the operations. Shortly after reporting his findings, Mr. Kleberg said, he was called to a meeting with Mr. Hunt and the chairman of the ranch board, Abraham Zeleznik, a psychoanalyst who is professor emeritus at Harvard. They asked him to resign.
Mr. Hunt plays down the resignation, noting that Mr. Kleberg joined the board of directors of the company at the time and still lives on the ranch. Keeping Mr. Kleberg involved "was an important element of the move," Mr. Hunt said.
Still, Mr. Kleberg's removal from the day-to-day operations unleashed some doubt about the stability of employment at King Ranch, a worry foreign to a company in which jobs have remained in families -- both of Kings and kinenos -- for generations.
Among the eight people who have departed in the last year were several ranch managers and Mr. Hunt's own secretary, who had been with the company about nine years.
Mr. Hunt said that most of the people who left were pursuing better job opportunities. But the handful who were willing to discuss their departures described feeling under constant scrutiny, and they expressed frustration at what they saw as a lack of direction in King Ranch's operations.
Outsiders, too, felt the sting. "The best beating heart they had is gone," said Gus T. Canales, whose family was ranching here before Captain King put down roots in the area, speaking of Mr. Kleberg. "It's hard for those of us who have grown up with this life style. We have more emotional ties, and maybe not so economically feasible feelings. But I think that the next generation should give us a lot of credit for trying to change as fast was we can and still keep the affection for the land."
 
'Small, Gradual Changes'
Stripped of the romance of the West, what is happening at the King Ranch doesn't seem that different from a typical story of the corporate world: New management comes in and scrutinizes the operation for ways to make it more profitable.
In the case of King Ranch, that means asking questions like: What is the optimal mix of ranching and hunting? What is the best kind of feed grass? Should helicopters be brought in at $275 a day for rounding up cattle, or is the job best done the old-fashioned way, on horseback?
"It isn't like we're going to change the world," said Paul C. Genho, who was hired away from the Mormon Church's 300,000-acre Deseret Ranch of Florida to head King Ranch's ranch and livestock operations after Mr. Kleberg's resignation. "It's going to be small, gradual changes."
To illustrate the point, he stopped at a field where men were setting fence posts for a new weaning lot. The lot would be near grain bins, to eliminate the 12-mile round trip previously required, saving as much as $100 a day.
Another change, Mr. Genho said, involved the ranch's developing a mineral supplement for cattle and producing it through outside contractors, for half as much as a commercially produced supplement had cost.
On a larger scale, Mr. Genho, who at Brigham Young University earned a doctorate in animal science with a specialty in cattle reproduction, continues to work on cross-breeding the Santa Gertrudis to develop cattle with higher weaning weights and greater growth potential. He also hires consultants to advise him on maintaining the most productive mix of bush and grazing land.
"Running a big ranch can't be intuitive," he said, glancing over acre after acre of scrub land.
A knowledgeable man with a good sense of humor, Mr. Genho, 57, takes a more hierarchical approach than his predecessor to running the ranch. Just a handful of managers report directly to him, compared with the dozen or so who reported to Mr. Kleberg. Those who have left the ranch since his arrival, he said, represent a mere 2 percent turnover rate.
For those who have stayed, he has introduced up-to-date incentive programs. For example, a cowboy, likely to be making around $20,000 a year, can make an additional 10 percent if he does three things: build three miles of fence, help cut production costs and get his high school equivalency diploma.
Also on Mr. Genho's agenda is getting back to some traditional ways of working cattle -- putting in more time on horses and spending less money on the helicopters that have become popular in recent years for herding.
Asked about the observation by former employees that people were feeling nervous about their jobs, Mr. Genho said, "I can understand people's concern, but there's no intent to do anything but to treat those people right."
Doubts remain, however, about the ranch's future course. With the arrival of Mr. Genho, a Mormon and 17-year veteran of the church's Florida ranch, came rumors that the Utah church was positioning itself to buy King Ranch, too.
"That's totally ridiculous," Mr. Genho said.
Local cattlemen, too, say they see nothing to the rumor. But in the next breath, they'll tell you they never expected to see a day that a Kleberg wasn't running the ranch, either.
 
Hunting Down Some Profits
The pressures on King Ranch affect the entire Texas cattle industry. Cattlemen have stabilized American beef consumption after years of decline and have stepped up their search for export markets. But cattle ranching remains a low-margin business.
"The last several years, it's been extremely difficult in some years to make a profit, and in some years we don't make a profit," said Hilmar G. Moore, who serves on the King Ranch board of directors and is himself a fifth-generation rancher in Fort Bend County, just outside Houston. "You have to run a much leaner, meaner operation."
And it isn't just the cattle; ranchers also need to get more out of their land. Indeed, many ranchers view themselves more as land managers -- on the prowl for profitable, sustainable uses of their acreage -- than as cattlemen.
In Texas, for the most part, that has meant hunting.
King Ranch, historically rather secretive about its operations, came relatively late to the business of marketing its land as an attraction. But in the last decade, it has embraced the notion, leasing more than 500,000 acres to hunters at $6 to $12 an acre annually. In some cases, hunters lease the land directly. Outfitters also work in conjunction with the ranch to put together organized hunts.
"There are two kinds of hunters: those who have hunted on King Ranch and those who want to hunt on King Ranch," said Luther Young, an outfitter who has a contract to guide groups of quail hunters on the ranch.
Hunters, he said, are willing to pay as much as $850 a day for the privilege. For that fee, they must bring a gun, shells and an appetite; he provides lodging and gourmet meals at his bed-and-breakfast nearby, as well as transportation and dogs. The general stay is three days, he said.
Beyond the hunters, some 50,000 people visit the ranch every year, most of them for scheduled tours of the property, who pay $7 for each adult and $2.50 per child; others for bird watching or wildlife tours. The company is exploring additional ways to use its natural resources.
"If you told me 25 years ago King Ranch would be hosting bird watching and hosting tours, I'd say you've got to be kidding," said Steve Munday, vice president of the Southwest Texas Cattle Raisers Association. "But that's using their resources."
 
More Life to the Legacy?
Sitting in the bleachers of the rodeo arena at King Ranch, Jamene Toelkes reminisced as she watched Adan Alvarez put cattle in chutes for roping practice, his 4-year-old daughter, Clarissa, in the saddle in front of him.
"When we moved here 20 years ago, we could have survived a holocaust right out here," said Mrs. Toelkes, whose husband is the veterinarian at the ranch. There were four commissaries, one in each of the ranch's four units, to serve the needs of the hundreds of people who lived on the ranch.
Today, while some 100 people still call the ranch home -- and more than 130 children from the ranch and neighboring Kingsville attend a school on the property -- many of the employees commute to work; the commissaries have all closed.
On her little finger next to her wedding band, Mrs. Toelkes, whose family came to the ranch from Abilene, Tex., in 1978, wears a ring made from some of the diamonds her husband received, on tie tacks, for his 20 years of service. He gave each of his sons -- Philip, 34, and Dell, 33 -- a diamond-studded tie tack, as well.
Mrs. Toelkes, who works in the ranch museum, said her husband told them: "When we made the commitment to go to South Texas, we all became a part of King Ranch history."
Can that heritage be preserved? "My children, neither ever wanted to be cowboys," she said. "Their tastes were too expensive." Dell is a land developer in Colorado City, Tex., and Philip is a partner in an engineering firm in Brentwood, Calif.
But watching Mr. Alvarez, a fifth-generation ranch resident, and his daughter, Mrs. Toelkes nonetheless saw something that she hopes will never die. "This is what King Ranch is all about -- the old teaching the young," she said as Clarissa guided her horse through the arena. "It's in her genes. It's horse heritage. Generations before her did this."
And the generations that come -- what will they make of King Ranch? Ms. Toelkes paused, then came up with a knowing answer. "It will be," she said, "what the shareholders want it to be."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Building a Cosmic Tape Measure

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT the century, scientists have had to rely on maddeningly oblique methods, laden with assumptions, for measuring the size of the universe. They've had to guess, from purely theoretical considerations, how bright a star or galaxy really is. Then, from its apparent brightness, dimmed by the journey of the light through space, they judge its distance.
These interpretations have been so open to debate that the universe seems to expand and contract like an accordion. With uncertainty long considered the norm, it was remarkable when astronomers boldly announced on Tuesday that they had gauged the distance of a galaxy a full 23.5 million light-years away using a stunningly direct approach that relied on little more than simple trigonometry. 
 "This measurement is the golden meter stick in the glass case," Morris Aizenman, executive officer of the National Science Foundation's Division of Astronomical Sciences proclaimed in a news release. The results came from Dr. James Herrnstein of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory in Socorro, N.M., and a team of scientists from the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and other institutions.
Scientists are already confident that they can measure how fast galaxies are receding from the primordial big-bang explosion. If they can more precisely know the distances, they can finally close in on the long-disputed number called the Hubble constant, the key to how rapidly the universe is expanding and to calculating its age and size.
It was a week for dramatic -- and conflicting -- announcements. The previous Tuesday, astronomers from the Carnegie Observatories in Pasadena, Calif., made headlines by announcing that, using the orbiting Hubble Space Telescope, they had narrowed the age of the universe to 12 billion to perhaps 14 billion years old.
Estimates from competing astronomers, which used to be off a full 100 percent, were said to have been pared down to a mere 10 percent. In a widely quoted line, one astronomer said that it was as if scientists, accustomed to arguing over whether the universe had one foot or two, were now quibbling about a single toe.
Then came the measurement by the Herrnstein team, using the Very Long Baseline Array, a network of dish antennas that capture stellar radio waves instead of visible light. If their results hold up, the Carnegie estimate could be 15 percent (a toe and a half) too high. There is still plenty of wiggle room in the calculations. Determining the universe's age also depends on how much gravity slows the expansion and how much something called the cosmological constant speeds it up. But with this splash of cold water, the earlier euphoria suddenly seemed premature.
Since the late 1920's, when the astronomer Edwin Hubble began observing the expansion from the big bang, there has been nothing very constant about his constant. According to Hubble's law, the farther a celestial object is from Earth, the faster it will appear to be receding. Pick an object in the sky and measure its velocity and distance. Dividing one by the other gives the Hubble constant -- and with that you have a grip on the rate at which the galaxies are flying apart. From there you can work backward, estimating how long ago everything was compacted into the primordial bomb.
Astronomers feel certain that they can directly determine one of these numbers, the velocity of an object's recession, by its red shift: The faster something is moving away, the more its light waves should be stretched toward the red end of the spectrum -- a phenomenon based on the well-known Doppler effect. It is the other number, the distance of an object, that causes most of the consternation.
Since ancient times, astronomers have measured the distance of nearby planets and stars by using trigonometry. Gauge how much their positions in the sky seem to shift as one moves from one part of the Earth to another, or as the Earth moves around the sun. From this "parallax" one can calculate how far away something is.
But estimating distances beyond the range of parallax -- recently set at a mere few hundred light-years -- has required more imagination. The Carnegie observations rely on stars called Cepheid variables, which blink at a rate believed to vary with their brightness. If two of these beacons are pulsating at the same pace and one appears dimmer, then it is assumed to be farther away. But the system is fraught with uncertainty. To confidently measure absolute as opposed to relative distance, you have to calibrate the yardstick by directly measuring how far away the nearest Cepheids are. Astronomers have tried to do this using parallactic observations by the European Space Agency satellite Hipparcos. But the measurements are tricky and the data unsure.
And there are other problems. A Cepheid's rhythm may be thrown off by its metallic content. More guesswork comes in when astronomers try to judge how much of the dimming of a Cepheid's light comes not from distance but intervening cosmic dust.
THE results from the Very Long Baseline Array cut through these assumptions, measuring the distance of a galaxy (NGC 4258 in the constellation Ursa Major) with old-fashioned parallax. By using computers to coordinate the data from 10 radio telescopes, ranging from Hawaii across North America to the Virgin Islands, the astronomers essentially simulated a dish antenna thousands of miles wide. This let them measure the galaxy's radio wave emissions with a resolution so fine that it puts even the Hubble telescope to shame.
The astronomers focused on a rotating disk of gas at the galaxy's core. First they calculated how fast it was spinning by measuring how much the Doppler effect stretched and squeezed its radio waves. Then they compared this intrinsic velocity to how fast the disk appears to spin from Earth. The farther something is, the slower it seems to move -- parallax again. Think of how a jet plane seems to inch across the sky. Trigonometry then yields the distance.
Though this new method greatly expands the power of parallax, it still has its limits. The galaxy was measured at 23.5 million light-years away; the universe is billions of light-years wide. Reaching farther will still require Cepheids and other indirect methods. But now there may be a better way to ensure the accuracy of these yardsticks, putting a more solid foundation under astronomers' feet.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 717 words

HEADLINE: The Kremlin Looks West

 BODY:
When the war in Yugoslavia started nearly 11 weeks ago, it threatened to rupture relations between Russia and the West. Instead, it brought Moscow and Washington closer together as they collaborated on a diplomatic settlement. Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin should find ways to build on the partnership. The Kremlin's willingness to part company with Slobodan Milosevic and throw its influence behind the West's peace terms in Kosovo is one of the more hopeful international developments since the end of the cold war.
The war did not come without a price in overall relations with Russia. The NATO bombing angered many Russians, who identified with their Slavic cousins. Anti-American sentiment sharply increased across Russia, as did fear that NATO, long a defensive alliance, had become a threat to Russia itself and a potential factor in Russia's own ethnic conflicts in places like Chechnya. The political fallout may be felt for years, as Communists and nationalists seek to exploit the resentment in parliamentary and presidential elections. They greeted the peace agreement with scorn, and even some of Mr. Yeltsin's aides distanced themselves from it. 
 But Mr. Yeltsin was not moved by such concerns. There were doubtless many reasons, not the least of which was Moscow's desperate need for Western financial assistance. The White House will likely look more kindly on Moscow's request for additional loans from the International Monetary Fund now that Mr. Yeltsin has leaned on Mr. Milosevic.
But Mr. Yeltsin's action bespeaks a larger vision of Russia's future as a democratic society. Mr. Milosevic may be a fellow Slav, but he is also a political fossil, just the kind Mr. Yeltsin has dueled with in Russia since the last days of the Soviet Union. Mr. Yeltsin recognized that continued alliance with Mr. Milosevic's dictatorship was a political and economic dead end for Russia. As logical as that decision might seem in the West, it was a bold act of leadership in Moscow.
Mr. Yeltsin has often been a maddeningly erratic leader, but throughout his years as President he has fought valiantly against a resurgence of Communism in Russia and a revival of cold-war hostilities between East and West. Now, with a year remaining in his final term, he has once again edged Russia closer to Europe and the United States, and has put in place a new Government in Moscow that seems prepared to consolidate that shift.
Formation of the Government has not been smooth -- it never is in Moscow -- but Prime Minister Sergei Stepashin has put economic and foreign policy largely in the hands of pragmatic men, many of whom favor further reform. The dismissal of Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov last month looks increasingly like a wise decision that allowed Mr. Yeltsin to pursue his Balkan diplomacy freely and opens the way for renewed economic change.
All of which affords the White House a chance to bring Russia into closer partnership with the West. President Clinton wisely saw the possibilities of enlisting Russia's help in Kosovo, and Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, skillfully helped turn the opportunity into a joint peace plan.
The cooperation can be advanced in the weeks ahead. Russian forces are likely to serve as peacekeepers in Kosovo, along with NATO troops. Further Russian assistance may be needed in dealing with Mr. Milosevic as the war ends. But Mr. Clinton should be looking beyond the Balkans for other ways to work with Russia and to help Mr. Yeltsin.
The first chance will come later this month in Cologne, Germany, when Mr. Yeltsin joins Mr. Clinton and the leaders of Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan at the annual economic summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies. Though Russia's feeble economy makes it an odd addition to this group, it belongs there because of its political weight. By making Russia a full-fledged member, and working to diminish its economic distress, Mr. Clinton and the other leaders can provide tangible benefits for Mr. Yeltsin and overcome Russian doubts about the West. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin, two men headed into the final months of their presidencies, can leave an enduring gift to their countrymen if they capitalize on the collaboration that began in Kosovo.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 19; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: A Conditional Surrender

BYLINE: By William E. Odom; William E. Odom, director of the National Security Agency under President Ronald Reagan and a retired Army general, is a fellow at the Hudson Institute.

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
Are we witnessing a diplomatic victory that will bring peace to the Balkans? Or will President Clinton win the Neville Chamberlain memorial umbrella trophy for accepting a phony peace? Let us hope for the former -- although much evidence suggests the latter will come to pass.
It would have been difficult to achieve peace even if Slobodan Milosevic had fully accepted NATO's demands: stop the ethnic cleansing, pull all Serb forces out of Kosovo, allow all Kosovo refugees to return home, accept a NATO military force in Kosovo and accept a politically autonomous Kosovo and an eventual plebiscite for full sovereignty. 
 But these demands were not fully met. Although the details are yet unclear, it seems that Mr. Milosevic and his Russian adviser, Viktor Chernomyrdin, have introduced sufficient ambiguity to undermine a stable settlement. Consider just these points.
First, there will be no future referendum on Kosovo sovereignty, as the original peace plan in Rambouillet, France, had demanded. Although the current proposal guarantees Kosovo "substantial autonomy," NATO has also agreed to take into account Yugoslavia's "sovereignty and territorial integrity."
Does this mean that NATO must now guarantee permanent Serbian rule over Kosovo? If NATO forces had occupied Serbia by force of arms, then it would have been possible to create a Serbian regime acceptable to an autonomous Kosovo. But this is not the case. And now NATO could find itself in the paradoxical position of defending Mr. Milosevic's formal rule of Kosovo.
Second, the peace plan calls for the demilitarization of the Kosovo Liberation Army. It is unclear whether the K.L.A. will give up its arms without a fight. If it resists, many Kosovars and Albanian groups would probably support it. Again the paradox of letting Mr. Milosevic use NATO to disarm his opposition is difficult to exaggerate.
Third, the military command arrangements are vaguely described, but it seems that they require a United Nations commander with at least some separate national contingents, most important the Russian forces. How NATO stands within the United Nations command is not clear, but if the NATO commander does not also wear the hat of the United Nations commander, the international force in Kosovo could be rendered ineffective. This would allow Mr. Milosevic to retain de facto local control. Something similar happened to the United Nations force in Bosnia. Moreover, a confused or disputed military structure will be unable to return all the refugees.
The role of Russian troops is also a troubling factor. During the negotiations, Romanian spokesmen have called them an unwanted and threatening presence in the Balkans. If Russia were a politically and economically stable country with considerable military power, Moscow's involvement would be understandable. But it is not. It is a weak, frustrated and unpredictable country with vengeful and mercurial politicians who wish NATO no success. Although Boris Yeltsin may use Russian troops responsibly, their presence in Kosovo will give the next Russian president undue leverage for all kinds of troublemaking. He could use troops to increase Belgrade's influence in Kosovo. He could threaten to pull them out, in an effort to undermine the legitimacy of the United Nations presence. He could demand that NATO's official presence be abolished.
No less critical for the multinational military force is a large United States contingent, large enough to insure that American diplomats are backed with adequate power to enforce occupation policies. Returning the refugees, creating a new Kosovo government and bureaucracy and disarming the K.L.A. will try the wits of a fully unified command. If it faces divided political counsel it will flounder.
These three aspects of the apparent deal with Mr. Milosevic should give anyone pause. Far more troubling, however, are the larger implications for the Balkans, European security and United States leadership in the world.
President Clinton's failure to make the overthrow of Mr. Milosevic a war aim leaves the Serb leader free to destroy the pro-NATO regime in Montenegro, to repress the Hungarian minority in Vojvodina and to cause trouble elsewhere, especially in Kosovo. Macedonia remains fragile, and its own Albanian minority is now probably larger. It could become a majority if a couple of hundred thousand Kosovar refugees remain there. Albanian ambitions in the region are also not to be discounted. Tensions could rise between Bulgaria and Greece over Macedonia. In other words, the present peace deal could only be a truce that allows all sides to prepare for the next and larger war.
Consider European security. Because of Mr. Clinton's repeated hesitations and equivocations, and his general failure since 1993 to get ahead of spreading disorder in the former Yugoslavia, Europe faces great uncertainties at the very time it should be most self-assured. The war in Kosovo has convinced many Europeans that the United States is no longer reliable. The American inability to lead the alliance and to use military power effectively is the talk of Europe.
Now, a purely European military, outside NATO, is being planned. The leaders of 15 European countries decided last week to make the European Union a military power for the first time in its 42-year history, with a command headquarters, staff and forces. It will probably lead nowhere, but lack of confidence in Washington won't disappear.
Thus, the lasting legacy for President Clinton and his diplomats could be that under their leadership, the demise of NATO began, even in its years of maximum relative power.
At the global level, decreasing confidence in American leadership will soon be manifest elsewhere, outside of Europe. Already the bombing-only strategy, which reflected a fear of a ground war and its attendant casualties, has undercut America's moral standing. Anti-American dictators are probably recalculating their own limits for successful actions against United States interests.
The potential legacy of the impending settlement with Slobodan Milosevic, who has been indicted for war crimes, is painful to contemplate. It is easy to satirize this episode as Mr. Clinton winning Neville Chamberlain's umbrella, but it will not be easy to live with the realities if the satire is accurate. Let us hope it is a gross distortion.

HEADLINE: The World: Democracies Built on Rays of Hope;
In Indonesia, The Voting Is Only A First Step

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
WITH drums, whistles and war whoops, with dancers, tumblers and female impersonators, Indonesians have grasped the first great truth about free elections: They can be lots of fun.
But there is another truth as well. One election does not make a country a democracy. Institutions, traditions and social cohesion do. So the big question on the eve of Indonesia's first free election in 44 years is whether it will set the world's fourth most populous nation on the path toward democratic stability or toward new turmoil. 
 One foreign election expert wishes, in fact, that the parliamentary election scheduled for tomorrow could be a trial run. People are learning about democracy here by trial and error, the expert said, and the stakes are far too high.
"One year ago, Indonesians were political naifs," said the expert, a foreign diplomat. "Now that picture is changing."
Since Suharto was forced to resign the presidency in May 1998, Indonesia has been learning fast, moving from street demonstrations to party organizing, from utopian philosophizing to the beginnings of coalition building. Still, nobody knows what patterns the voting will take or how this nation of more than 200 million jostling and often feuding people will manage the outcome.
Perhaps the people will vote freely, or perhaps they will continue to answer to the village headman, as they have for generations. Maybe the losers will accept the outcome or maybe the results will trigger a new wave of demonstrations, followed by riots and the use of military force.
How effectively will a new government begin the building of democratic institutions? Will it respond to the public demand for an end to what is known as K.K.N. -- the Indonesian initials for corruption, collusion and nepotism?
"I don't see a transition to democracy as inevitable, despite the holding of elections," said David Timberman, an American electoral expert. "There is nothing inexorable about this process. Its outcomes depend a lot on the leadership and behavior of the new political parties in Parliament."
The hard work still lies ahead, said Jusuf Wanandi, the head of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, an independent policy institute. "I am much more optimistic about the election than about what comes after," he said. "I am dreading the difficulties we will have in creating a real coalition government -- animosities, jealousies, prima donnas."
Still, worst-case scenarios have so far not been realized, beginning with the largely peaceful and raucously enthusiastic three-week election campaign that is now ending.
Some analysts warn that the campaign revelers may be setting themselves up for harsh disappointments when the results come in. But Indonesia has shown a great deal more political maturity in the past year than many people -- notably Mr. Suharto -- gave them credit for.
Just to get this far has been an extraordinary achievement. Indonesia had no revolution. It did not overturn its Government, only the man at the top. It did not change its constitution or its basic laws, reform its institutions or bring any but a few low-ranking soldiers to trial.
Democratic reform in Indonesia, so far, floats on air. Yet it is undeniably a force in play, a clear expression of popular will. The force appears to have begun building even when Mr. Suharto was in power, and to have burst forth since he departed.
A newly free press has emerged, even as the politically intrusive military has been humbled and the Government has shown a new responsiveness to public opinion. The elections themselves, created by Mr. Suharto's holdover Parliament, are the results of this reformist pressure, which the Suharto men who still run Indonesia have been unable to ignore, political analysts say.
The country has avoided calamity over the past year, remaining far more stable than many had expected. A surge of pre-election violence was widely predicted, but it did not materialize except for clashes in some already unstable areas. There has been no wave of religious warfare. Student demonstrators have withdrawn from the streets to participate in the campaign.
Though the economy has not recovered yet from a battering during East Asia's financial crisis a year ago, the harvest has been good and there have been no food riots; the currency has stabilized at double its lowest rate 18 months ago and there is a glimmer of hope for better times. But Indonesia still lacks the solid middle class that would form the foundation of a thoroughgoing democracy, said Juwono Sudarsono, the Minister of Education and a leading political analyst. Politics remains a battleground between haves and have-nots and between factions and ethnic groups, rather than a true discourse, he said.
"We have a long way to go," Mr. Juwono said, noting that Indonesia's middle class is far more shallow than those of the emerging democracies of Thailand, South Korea or the Philippines. "It could be 25 years before we can achieve their level of 30 percent of the population being middle class."
THE first free election in a newly independent Indonesia was also its last, in 1955. Shortly afterward, the country's founding President, Sukarno, decreed that parliamentary democracy was not working and instituted in its place an authoritarian model he called "guided democracy."
He was responding to the political realities of the day but also to the popular mood, which demanded firm leadership.
"My sense is that there is a cyclical aspect to this whole thing, that authoritarianism and democracy are popular at different times and that we are now in a very anti-authoritarian point in the cycle," said Herbert Feith, an Australian political scientist who was here during the 1955 election.
Yes, he said, new democratic institutions are not yet in place. But he said the mood of the nation -- the public discourse -- can be a powerful force in its own right.
"The Suharto crowd lost control of the public discourse, and the discourse has a life of its own," Mr. Feith said. Whatever happens, he suggested, the tide of democratic reform in Indonesia is not likely to be easily reversed.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Mental Illness Hits The Money Trail

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
SHOULDN'T people with mental illnesses, which can destroy lives and families, be entitled to the same amount of insurance coverage as those with physical illnesses? On the face of it, that sounds like a fairly simple question.
But as in all things having to do with health care, and especially the often vaguely defined area of mental illness, the issue can be maddeningly complicated. 
 Tipper Gore, the wife of the Vice President, will open a White House conference tomorrow to draft new health-care policies that would require employers and insurers to provide coverage for outpatient and in-patient mental health comparable to that for other kinds of medical care -- "parity for all," in the words of Mrs. Gore.
Along with similar proposals pending in Congress, the White House initiative would face head-on what Mrs. Gore, who has a master's degree in psychology, calls the destructive myth that those seeking greater mental health coverage are "out to rip off the system."
At stake is a significant slice of the total United States health care budget. About $80 billion -- nearly 10 percent of total annual health care spending -- now goes into mental-health treatment, according to the Center for Mental Health Services, a Federal research agency.
About a third of that amount, mostly from Medicaid, Medicare and other Government sources, pays for clinical treatment of the severely mentally ill, whose illnesses often render them poor and unemployed and who often "end up in the public system," according to Mary Rappaport, a spokeswoman for the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, an advocacy group for the severely mentally ill. In any year, according to the group, about five million Americans suffer from severe and persistent mental disorders, including schizophrenia, bipolar disorders and major depression.
Few seriously question the need for clinical treatment for those with the worst mental illnesses, about 250,000 of whom are homeless. So the debate over the potential cost of providing comparable insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses is focused on those whose treatment consumes the remaining two-thirds of the $80 billion total, most of which is paid by employer-provided health insurance.
This segment includes the "worried well," as they are called by those who question the employment of psychiatric therapy to address many less severe emotional distresses and addiction problems. For the past 25 years, most of the increases in mental health spending have gone to this group of patients, who are the easiest and most profitable to treat.
Proposed Federal laws to establish comparable insurance coverage for mental illness seek to give priority to the severely ill. But some employers and policy analysts worry that once mandates for expanded mental health coverage are in place costs could rise sharply above the modest levels projected by the drafters of the parity bills. The concern is that the legislation would provide profit incentives to tailor diagnoses and to recruit new pools of patients.
Advocates of comparable insurance coverage cite studies showing that the additional cost would be minimal, while providing a major public-health benefit. The National Institute of Mental Health predicts that mandating parity through managed-care plans would add less than 1 percent to the total annual national health care bill.
BUT such studies could be flawed by "very low assumptions on induced demand," said Paul Fronstin, a senior researcher at the Employee Benefit Research Institute, whose clients include employers, labor unions and pension plans. Induced demand refers to marketing by the mental health industry, usually among patients with health insurance who can be successfully treated for a wide array of mental disorders defined in the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual.
For employers and others worried about potential cost increases in mental-health therapy, induced demand raises a red flag. In the late 1980's, when expanded psychiatric and substance-abuse therapy was heavily promoted and advertised among the general population, annual costs for such treatments rose 20 percent to 30 percent faster than costs in other areas of health care, employers found.
Fraud also became a problem. In the early 1990's, for-profit psychiatric hospitals and addiction centers paid over $500 million in Federal fines to settle charges of profiteering and diagnostic fraud in recruiting patients with generous mental health insurance. Many health maintenance organizations responded by tightening benefits for inpatient hospitalization and other mental-health treatment.
For their part, advocates for comparable insurance coverage cite evidence that they say shows that more money is needed for additional mental health treatment:
* In any year 30 million Americans suffer from clinical mental disorders, but only about 20 percent currently seek treatment, according to studies cited by the National Institute of Mental Health.
* According to the American Society of Addiction Medicine, 11.3 percent of Americans will at some point require psychiatric treatment for various addictions. In an April report, the group called for more spending on addiction therapy.
* The National Institute of Mental Health recently launched a national television and radio advertising campaign to encourage more people to seek treatment for anxiety disorders, which the agency describes as "frightening mental illnesses" affecting 19 million Americans.
* The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill cites studies asserting that of the nation's 63 million youths under 18, about 7.5 million have diagnosable mental disorders -- but only about a fifth now receive treatment.
* Post-traumatic stress disorder, which is prompted by memories of traumatic events, is now widely diagnosed among victims and witnesses of crimes, natural disasters and even marital problems. The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that 4 percent of the population suffers from it. But that number could grow. The Justice Department recently stated that some people who are swindled by telemarketing fraud and other white-collar crimes develop post-traumatic stress disorder and require psychiatric intervention.
POLICE departments across the country refer officers with troubling memories to therapists who specialize in treating post-traumatic stress disorder. Last week, Robert Volpe, the father of Justin A. Volpe, the New York City police officer who pleaded guilty to savagely assaulting a suspect in a precinct bathroom, employed the sort of therapeutic language found on Internet sites devoted to police post-traumatic stress disorder to defend his son. He likened police work to combat and suggested that his son suffered memories of traumatic experiences on the job.
As a diagnosis, post-traumatic stress disorder "just started taking off in 1985 and it keeps growing," said Allan Young, chairman of the department of Social Studies of Medicine, Anthropology and Psychiatry at McGill University in Montreal.
If the pool of patients grows and parity laws require insurers to pay for all demands for treatment, something will have to give, experts say. A 1997 study by the Employee Benefit Research Institute warned that as mental-health parity causes employer costs to rise, workers can expect to see erosion in other benefits, and that some employers could react by dropping health-insurance coverage altogether.
The correct approach, said Ms. Rappaport of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, is "redirecting money already in the system for those who have the most severe disorders."
The priority is simple, she said: "You save the neediest first."

HEADLINE: The World: Tug of War;
Now, Onward to the Next Kosovo. If There Is One.

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF the goal of the allied bombing of Yugoslavia was to force Slobodan Milosevic to pull his troops out of Kosovo and cede control of that unhappy province to NATO, it appears to have been a success, and more -- a refutation of the common wisdom that air power alone could never make a despot back down.
But if the purpose was also to warn evildoers in other lands that the United States and its allies now stand ready to enforce peace with bombs, it is a message that has brought more concern than comfort. 
 From India to Israel to Indonesia, countries with their own unresolved ethnic conflicts -- and they are of epidemic proportions in the post-Communist universe -- have scrutinized the Balkan conflict for some indication of how this might affect their own fates.
India, whose contested control of Kashmir has led in recent days to new clashes with Pakistan and fierce clampdowns on the Muslim population of the province, has been fiercely critical of Washington and Brussels for presuming the right to interfere with force in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. Israel, which prefers to see itself as a victim of Arab aggression rather than an occupying power in lands along its borders, has welcomed NATO's new assertiveness. One high Israeli official happily reported that Israeli intelligence had noticed that American willingness to bomb Yugoslavia into submission had stirred considerable discomfort among some despotic Arab leaders of neighboring states.
Yet it remains far from clear whether the capitulation of the Serbs -- if, indeed, it is a capitulation, and not another maneuver by the wily Mr. Milosevic to gain time and consolidate his gains -- heralds the acceptance of a new global police mission by the West, however bold the pronouncements and self-congratulation last week.
From the outset, the United States and its NATO allies have couched the bombardment of Yugoslavia in high moral terms, as a crusade to restore the rights of a maligned population and to prevent the spread of chaos beyond the borders of Serbia. But all along, many experts and foreign leaders have questioned whether the allies would have acted had Kosovo been in Central Asia, and how much the operation really had a tightly focused purpose -- to define the reach, the role and the credibility of NATO and the United States in post-Communist Europe.
Now new questions can be added to the mix: Does the apparent success of the air war change the logic? Will a newly confident West be tempted to expand its horizons? Should tyrants in far-flung parts of the globe think a second time before unleashing mayhem?
Graham Allison, head of the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard, is among those who see the bombing of Kosovo as a strictly European phenomenon. "I think that this was an accident, a combination of circumstances which partially have to do with Europe, partly with NATO, partly with guilt about the earlier Bosnia story, partly to do with the notion that more things are doable in the European setting," he said.
"This is not likely to initiate a new messianic crusade," he added, even though some people will inevitably ask why the West doesn't take action "when the next horror arises in Rwanda or Indonesia."
THE charges of selectivity have already been leveled, raising the questions of where NATO was during the genocide in Rwanda, and why it is complicit with Turkey's repression of the Kurds or Indonesia's repression of separatists in East Timor, and why it has kept silent about Kashmir. The notion of NATO planes bombing Israel to get its troops out of the West Bank, or Canada to free Quebec, or England to get it out of Northern Ireland, have become the stuff of comedy routines based on the inconsistencies of NATO's Kosovo rationale.
Yet the fact is that separatist movements along ethnic and religious lines and conflicts like the ones in the crumbling Yugoslavia are likely to be the dominant problem of the near future, and the temptation for interference by the West or other powers will always be there.
The notion that well-meaning nations can and should try to jointly resolve conflicts has been a leitmotif of this century. The creation of the League of Nations and the United Nations Security Council were followed by various regional or individual efforts at peacekeeping, including Syria's takeover of Lebanon with the consent of the Arab League, Nigeria's efforts at stanching civil wars in West Africa and American operations in Haiti, Somalia and elsewhere.
One outgrowth of the Kosovo operation was the announcement last week that the 15 members of the European Union intend to form their own military force for such missions, freeing the United States of at least part of the burden of playing global cop.
But the peacemaking efforts have always been selective, and only rarely successful. The Security Council has been wary of using its powers to employ military force under the United Nations Charter. Most United Nations peacekeeping missions have been created largely to formalize agreements, and lasted only so long as the warring parties needed them.
The NATO action on Kosovo marked a new approach. First, the allies claimed the right to use force against a sovereign state only because it refused to sign a proffered agreement. Second, instead of sending in troops, NATO chose a campaign of progressively more destructive bombing, thus sharply lowering the chance of casualties among allied soldiers, and the resistance back home that body bags provoke.
HOWEVER effective the approach in the immediate term, it has also been the source of considerable irritation abroad, and considerable uncertainty about the future. One accusation rarely noted in the American press, but extensively accepted as truth abroad, was that the bombing of Yugoslavia was a flagrant violation of sovereignty and international law. In the third world, where boundaries are often in dispute and governments weak, these principles are held to be virtually sacred.
Among other nations, most notably Russia, the entire campaign has been perceived exclusively as a power play by NATO, with the Kosovar Albanians only providing a pretext. Coupled with the expansion of NATO, the campaign has seriously lowered the standing of the United States in Russian eyes.
So the diplomatic costs of repeating the exercise too often would be high, even if the prospects of military success were good.
In addition, there is a sense among American and foreign analysts that even if the Kosovo operation did achieve its aims, it did so at an exorbitant cost in armaments and destruction. A million Kosovars were homeless, Serbia's economy lay in ruins and thousands of Serbs and Albanians were dead.
"We just overwhelmed them with destruction," said Earl H. Tilford Jr., a former Air Force officer who now teaches at the Army War College. "It was technically excellent, but strategically bankrupt." The question this poses elsewhere, of course, is how many times the West will have the stomach to repeat the destruction and the resources to repair the mess afterward.
THERE was also the fact that having entered Bosnia and now Kosovo, the United States is likely to remain mired in the south Balkans for a generation. It is not the kind of garrison duty likely to be repeated in too many places.
And there are also doubts about the effectiveness of the Kosovo operation as a deterrent. "Does this mean that the next bad man, whether an African potentate or someone in Asia or even Uzbekistan, is going to think, 'Oh my God, here they come?' I don't think so," said Mr. Allison. "It wouldn't significantly affect the calculus, though it would at least demonstrate what could happen."
What may happen, argued Susan Woodward, an expert on the Balkans at the Brookings Institution, is that dictators or even troubled countries, fearing that their internal conflicts make them ripe targets for a NATO onslaught and unable to resist it with conventional arms, will be tempted to turn to nuclear or chemical arms. "People will not say, 'I will think twice before I do horrible things,' " Ms. Woodward said. "Rather they will think, 'I better prepare better defensively against external interventions of that kind.' "
"I'm not comfortable with the argument that if we compromised we would lose our credibility," said Dmitri Simes, head of the Nixon Center in Washington. "That's not the kind of credibility we need. Everybody understands that the United States, especially with NATO, is a global force. We have to understand how different our actions look elsewhere."
