HEADLINE: A Script for the Senate Race

 BODY:
It is not surprising that almost all the discussion about the upcoming Senate race in New York concerns personalities. The cast of characters is, after all, larger than life. First Lady Hillary Clinton has all but officially announced her candidacy, as has Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. If Mr. Giuliani has to fight for the Republican nomination against Representative Rick Lazio of Long Island, chances are that the Mayor's combative persona will be the focus of that primary as well.
But New York is a state with more than its quota of economic and social problems. It deserves a campaign that includes a full discussion of the issues that will affect it in the next millennium. 
 Education is a critical concern, and even at this early date, Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton have been sparring gingerly about school vouchers, which the Mayor supports and the First Lady opposes. But New York deserves a broader debate about how to improve the quality of its educational system. What is the proper role for the Federal Government in supporting local public schools? Should there be national standards to measure teacher qualifications and student success? What part could a United States senator play in debates about social promotion, remedial education and the proper role of teachers' and principals' unions?
Candidates for the Senate always promise to bring home more bacon, but Mrs. Clinton will have to explain why it would be in the state's interest to have two Democratic senators when the Republicans appear to have a hold on majority control. Her opponent should be challenged to describe what he would do when his Sunbelt-dominated party pushed legislation that threatened the Northeast on matters like acid rain and transportation spending.
The welfare reform bill, which Mr. Lazio supported and Mr. Giuliani opposed in part, is now the law of the land with wide backing even among the Democrats. But New York's role as a haven for immigrants and the presence here of so many second- and third-generation welfare recipients will make it hard for the state to proceed to the next step, when time limits kick in and families start being ejected from the system. The candidates should tell us what changes they would endorse to help states with large populations of recent immigrants and the very poor.
Past experience suggests that when it comes to foreign policy, the Senate campaign will focus on the Mideast, with each candidate trying to grab the mantle of best friend to Israel. We would like to see a broader discussion that focused on the proper international role for the United States. Under what circumstances should Americans intervene in other countries' affairs? How much should we rely on the United Nations and NATO to represent our interests? How important are human-rights issues when it comes to relations with trading partners like China or Indonesia?
On campaign finance reform, Mrs. Clinton would have a great deal of explaining to do about the abuses of existing laws that went on during her husband's Administration, some of which involved her close associates, including her senior political adviser, Harold Ickes, and members of her White House staff. Mr. Giuliani ought to discuss how far he would be willing to buck his party, which has been blocking serious reform in Congress. Mr. Lazio, who has voted to strengthen the campaign finance laws, would have to tell voters why he declined to join his party's reform wing to force those bills to the floor.
Mrs. Clinton has already said that she would not try again to create the sort of sweeping solution to the nation's health care problems that she advocated in her early days as First Lady. But about 43 million Americans remain uninsured, including 3.1 million New Yorkers, and many of those who do have coverage express dissatisfaction with the restrictions of managed-care programs. Last year, during the exciting but not always enlightening Senate race between Charles Schumer and Alfonse D'Amato, the candidates were asked how health care costs could be kept down if insurance companies were forced by Congress to cover more and more procedures. The candidates, who had been vying to appear toughest on health maintenance organizations, both avoided the query and went back to arguing about who was more of a liar. With more than a year and a half before the Senate election, the candidates should have plenty of time to answer serious questions.
Personalities are not irrelevant to this race. Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Lazio would have every right to question whether Mr. Giuliani has the temperament to be an effective senator. Mr. Giuliani, who has already been harping on the carpetbag issue, is not out of line in wondering whether New York should be represented by someone who has actually lived here. Voters would naturally want to know how Mrs. Clinton plans to balance her role as Senate candidate with her duties as First Lady, and we have confidence her opponent will bring the matter up on their behalf.
But it would be a shame if this contest, which may be the focus of almost as much attention as the Presidential race, should degenerate quickly into a sound-bite battle. Besides being national personalities, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Giuliani are intelligent and thoughtful political veterans with very different takes on the proper role of government. Mr. Lazio, who seems intent on depriving the national media of their dream race, is a serious legislator who has surprised people in the past with his ability to topple a high-profile politician.
It is not too early to ask that the candidates, as they announce, commit themselves to a series of issue-based debates throughout the campaign, each focusing on a single topic, like education or foreign policy. The campaign will inevitably make compelling theater, but the candidates will need to give serious topics their due.

HEADLINE: Scene of the Crime Revisited

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "At the Scene of a Crime?" (Working, May 2), about how an employee who discovers questionable and maybe illegal practices in his division should protect himself: 
 As a lawyer who has represented institutions accused of wrongdoing as well as individuals blowing the whistle, I was dismayed at some of the advice. First, in suggesting that, as a last resort, the employee consider talking to in-house counsel, the column fails to note that the company's lawyer represents the company's interests. An employee who divulges information to that lawyer is exposing himself to the person best placed to harm him: the lawyer who may eventually defend the company.
Second, going to the boss is almost always a mistake in these situations. If he is so unscrupulous as to sanction such activities, he is not going to have moral qualms about quashing the whistle-blowing employee.
If the activities are clearly illegal, the employee should seek outside counsel. If they are questionable, he should consult in confidence with someone he trusts at the company, who can act as an intermediary with the in-house counsel or others there.
 
RICARDO GUARNERO
Bellevue, Wash., May 3
 
The writer is a managing member of Garcia & Guarnero P.L.L.C.

HEADLINE: Hospitals Can Cut Costs, Too

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Insurers and Uninsured Put Hospitals in a Squeeze" (May 9), which looked at hospitals' recent cash-flow problems after years of profitability: 
 As a practice management consultant to physicians and dentists for over 36 years, I have seen the high rates charged by hospitals. The industry is now getting a dose of its own medicine. No tears need be shed.
 Before Medicare, most hospitals were owned by governments, charities and foundations. Now the industry is controlled by business, and costs have climbed, putting Medicare, Medicaid and the health insurance industry in jeopardy. That means trouble for patients.
When money gets tight, most people try to make more money or spend less. Hospitals face the same choice, and while they are already good at making money, they are not so good at spending less. We cannot force hospitals to reduce bureaucracy, but we can tell our third-party payers (Medicare, insurance companies, etc.) to pay less to them. We still have by far the best and least expensive health care delivery system in the world. Let's just allow our economic system to work.
 
ROY W. HUNTSMAN
Gainesville, Fla., May 11

HEADLINE: Prosecution That Spared Espy Leaves a Top Aide in Ruins

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4

 BODY:
At first glance, Ronald H. Blackley, a high school graduate who says he never earned more than $30,000 a year back home in Mississippi, does not seem like the kind of target Congress had in mind when it created special prosecutors.
A decade ago in his home state, he worked for a Congressman named Mike Espy on farm issues. When Mr. Espy was named Secretary of Agriculture in 1993, Mr. Blackley was hired as his chief of staff for $115,000 a year. 
 "He came to Washington as an idealist," Mr. Blackley's lawyer, Sheldon Krantz, said the other day.
Mr. Blackley left Washington a convicted criminal, owing more than $300,000 in legal fees and loans, his suburban Virginia house lost to foreclosure. And soon, unless his appeals are successful, he will go to prison for 27 months.
His wife, Sharon, sat beside him and cried as Mr. Blackley told of being swept up in an investigation aimed at Mr. Espy, who was accused but ultimately cleared of taking favors from companies who did business with the Agriculture Department. The special prosecutor in the case, Donald C. Smaltz, had hoped Mr. Blackley would help him convict his former boss. "I could have," Mr. Blackley drawled, "if I'd lied."
Instead, Mr. Blackley himself became a target of Mr. Smaltz and, his lawyer says, another victim of a statute that has spawned boundless multimillion-dollar investigations that have often gone on for years.
Now many in Congress are considering letting the independent counsel law lapse when it comes up for renewal in Congress this month.
Mr. Blackley, who is 48, was convicted in late 1997 of three counts of making false statements about $22,000 in outside income he received while serving as the Agriculture Secretary's chief of staff.
Mr. Smaltz convinced a jury that Mr. Blackley took the money from longtime Mississippi friends in return for helping them get Agriculture Department subsidies, then lied about it, first on financial-disclosure forms and later to investigators for the department and for the United States Agency for International Development, where he worked after leaving the department in 1995.
Mr. Blackley was guilty of nothing more than "being in the wrong place at the wrong time," Mr. Krantz said, adding that what happened to his client "is an example of what is wrong with the independent counsel statute," and why it should be allowed to die.
To compare the prosecutor's version of the case with the defense lawyer's is to wonder whether they are talking about the same man and the same events.
Mr. Krantz said $10,000 of the $22,000 was a loan from an old friend who wanted to help Mr. Blackley get settled in the Washington area. About $10,000 more came in installments for the sale of a rice brokerage Mr. Blackley owned before coming to Washington, and another $1,000 was a high school graduation gift to Mr. Blackley's son, the lawyer said.
Mr. Blackley simply tried to cut through red tape and get subsidies for people entitled to them, Mr. Krantz said.
At the trial, Mr. Krantz elicited testimony that many people have trouble with the financial-disclosure forms. He tried to show that Mr. Blackley's violations, if any, were technical and attributable to the documents' baffling language, including ambiguous wording on how to list money earned in a certain year, compared with money actually received in a given year.
The prosecutors characterized those explanations as ludicrous and said there was overwhelming evidence that Mr. Blackley had cashed in on his position.
No matter which version is true, or whether the "truth" lies in some undiscoverable terrain in between, this much is clear: If there were no independent-counsel law, Mr. Blackley would not have been prosecuted.
Passed in 1978 when memories of Watergate were fresh, the Ethics in Government Act provides for court-appointed independent counsels to go after wrongdoing at the highest levels of Government. The statute has been endlessly debated. Its critics complain that some special prosecutors stray far from their original missions, spending millions to pursue people on the periphery of scandal, as well as the truly guilty.
In 1994, Mr. Smaltz was appointed to investigate Mr. Espy, who resigned amid suspicions that he had accepted tickets to sporting events, luggage and other gifts worth thousands of dollars from people and companies he was supposed to be regulating, like Tyson Foods, the giant poultry producer based in Arkansas.
Mr. Smaltz went after Mr. Blackley mainly to get information to use against his former boss. "Blackley was a link in the chain to Secretary Espy," the prosecutor said in a television interview last year.
Mr. Blackley said: "They wanted me to do for them what they couldn't do, which was convict Mike Espy. I didn't have anything."
Mr. Blackley said he made that clear in several interviews with investigators. He said they told him, at first, that he was not a target. But the questioning became less friendly, and Mr. Blackley said he began to hear from friends in Mississippi that investigators were checking on him.
Mr. Blackley's financial-disclosure forms came under scrutiny only because Mr. Espy was under investigation, Mr. Krantz said. Attorney General Janet Reno unsuccessfully opposed Mr. Smaltz's request for authorization to pursue Mr. Blackley, reminding the Federal judicial panel overseeing the counsel's office that Mr. Blackley was not covered in its original mandate. Ms. Reno expressed alarm at a special prosecutor's potentially "unbridled power."
Moreover, the Department of Justice and the Agriculture Department's inspector general's office had earlier examined Mr. Blackley's forms and found nothing to prosecute. That decision was in keeping with the Justice Department's policy of not prosecuting financial-disclosure violations, Mr. Krantz said, but rather allowing filers to correct the forms, or settle cases civilly.
Mr. Blackley was indicted on April 22, 1997, and was tried in Federal District Court in Washington. Mr. Blackley did not testify on his own behalf; his lawyer thought that there was no need, and that the prosecution had not proved its case.
Mr. Blackley was convicted on Dec. 1, 1997. On March 13, 1998, Judge Royce C. Lamberth sentenced him to 27 months in prison, departing from sentencing guidelines that indicated probation for a defendant like Mr. Blackley, whose offense was his first of any kind.
"The defendant was a high-level Government official," Judge Lamberth said, calling his conduct "despicable" and saying he wanted to send a message to other officials who might be tempted to be greedy and lie.
Mr. Krantz lost an appeal before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. He has asked the Supreme Court to review the case, on the grounds that the independent counsel should never have pursued Mr. Blackley, and that the sentence was excessive.
Mr. Blackley was was never called as a witness against Mr. Espy, who was acquitted on Dec. 2, 1998, a year and a day after Mr. Blackley was convicted.
After the acquittal, Mr. Smaltz defended his four-year, $17 million investigation. He noted that his office had gained more than a dozen convictions and garnered some $12 million in fines, including $6 million from Tyson Foods, which pleaded guilty to making illegal gifts to Mr. Espy, who was acquitted of taking them.
On April 27, the Supreme Court overturned one of the convictions obtained by Mr. Smaltz, setting aside a verdict against a California agricultural cooperative that had given the Secretary gifts. Simply giving gifts without a demonstrated link between the gifts and an official's actions did not violate the law against illegal gratuities, the Court held.
Mr. Krantz has prosecuted organized crime in Miami, taught law at Boston University and was dean of the University of San Diego Law School before settling in Washington to defend white-collar defendants. "I have never seen an injustice like this," he said of Mr. Blackley's case. "It shakes my confidence in the administration of justice."
Mr. Blackley and his wife are living in her mother's house in Mississippi, for now. His friends hold occasional fund-raising dinners.
He said he is not bitter. Is he afraid of prison? "No. I'll just go do it."
Afterward, he said, he will probably go back to Mississippi and return to farming. "I can't make too many long-term commitments," he said.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Won Uphill Battle to Build Train to the Plane

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
In its all-out campaign to win approval for a rail line linking Kennedy International Airport to local subways and trains, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey recently treated some City Council members to a bus ride through Queens. It even provided some entertainment along the way: a brief clip from an old "Seinfeld" episode.
But the clip was hardly chosen at random. It showed one of the characters, Elaine, explaining her elaborate plans to reach Kennedy on time, only to be foiled by the perpetually clogged expressway leading to the airport, the roadway whose very name is a punch line: the dreaded Van Wyck. 
 And then, as if to demonstrate that life is too short to waste time imitating art, the bus load of Council members, who were heading to the rail line's proposed transfer point in Jamaica, got stuck in traffic on the Van Wyck.
The bus trip was just one aspect of the Port Authority's intense and ultimately successful mission to win a $1.5 billion project to connect the airport to the city's mass transit system -- a plan that its representatives agree is both imperfect and a hard sell.
Community boards in Queens questioned the disruption that building an elevated rail line down the middle of the Van Wyck would cause. Some transportation experts deplored the failure to link the system to La Guardia Airport in northern Queens and doubted its overall practicality. The staff of the City Council issued a report that described the project's purported economic benefits as illusory.
The authority also had to overcome the problem of its own reputation. One of its lobbyists described that reputation as "the evil empire." One of its executives went further: "We are the big fat bloated bureaucracy."
To overcome those perceptions, the authority hired a SWAT team of lobbyists, made expensive promises to various communities, showered southeastern Queens with marketing studies and fact sheets, and -- in the last days -- tinkered with the design to appease Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the City Council.
It also had on its side a simplistic but nevertheless persuasive argument: Something is better than nothing.
One by one, the pieces fell into place. Very reluctantly, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cut a deal that propelled the project forward. The Planning Commission described the project, called Airtrain, as a disaster-in-waiting, but then approved it. And despite the devastating Council report, two Council committees gave near-unanimous approval last week, clearing the way for the full Council to grant final approval this week.
In the end, they were all spurred by the realization that New York City lags far behind other cities in providing quick, convenient access to its airports. Travelers can reach Kennedy by public transit, but only circuitously. The trip involves taking the A train to the Howard Beach-Kennedy stop in Queens, about an hour from midtown Manhattan, and then a free bus to the terminals, which takes another 10 to 15 minutes.
John D. Sabini, the chairman of one of the Council committees that endorsed the Airtrain plan, reflected the lawmakers' general sentiment this way: "It's not the best project I've ever seen. But on the whole, weighing pluses and minuses, we thought this was the best thing -- and we voted for it."
"It's just one of those things: you hold your nose and vote for it," said one of the Port Authority's lobbyists, Martin McLaughlin. "But sometimes a flawed project is better than nothing at all."
For more than three decades, city officials, transportation experts and everyday travelers have cited the need for a dedicated mass-transit link to the city's two airports. But the proposals, which numbered at least 20, came up against what one authority official described as a regional attitude of "vote this down and do another study."
The last defeat came in 1995, when political opposition and rising costs led the Port Authority to kill plans for a 22-mile railway connecting Manhattan to La Guardia and Kennedy. New York officials at the authority considered the decision especially disturbing because plans were already in place to connect Newark International Airport to Pennsylvania Station.
Then, early last year, the authority held an elaborate press conference at which it unveiled a scaled-down proposal to build the Airtrain, a light-rail line over the Van Wyck that would link Kennedy with the Long Island Rail Road, subways, and buses in Jamaica, Queens. It announced that it had also awarded more than $1 billion in contracts to a team of companies to build and maintain the system, one that would require a transfer at Jamaica and not be the "one-seat" ride that most people preferred.
Mr. Giuliani initially balked at the plan, citing the need for riders to change at Jamaica and the lack of any link to La Guardia as flaws. But several months later he grudgingly gave his approval after an agreement was reached to dedicate $100 million to study a link to La Guardia.
Once the authority had the approval of the Mayor and Queens Borough President Claire Shulman, it needed the land-use endorsement of more entities: the community boards in Queens whose districts would be affected by construction, the Planning Commission and the City Council.
And at each turn it faced the heated opposition of the Airport Transport Association, an airline trade group. The group contended that Federal law prohibited using a $3-per-ticket surcharge imposed on all flights from Kennedy, which is providing the financing for the Airtrain, from being used for such links, and argued that the surcharge should be used to improve the airport.
"We also think it's a stupid project," a spokesman for the trade group said, pointing out that the Port Authority expects only 7,000 people a day to use the link from Jamaica, and another 4,000 to use a separate rail connection to be built from the airport to the subway station in Howard Beach.
The lines were drawn. The Port Authority eventually spent at least $185,000 to retain three lobbyists, and was joined in battle by the powerful General Contractors Association, which saw as many as 4,000 jobs in the offing. The airline group also spent more than $100,000 on lobbyists, and hired a public relations firm to spread its message.
Throughout the winter, the controversial proposal prompted shouts of protest at the hearings held by the community boards, especially those of Community Board 12 in Jamaica.
One Board 12 member, Ruth DuBerry, charged that rules of procedure were routinely flouted at the meetings, and that when she tried to restate a motion opposing the plan, someone pulled the microphone's plug. "The problem with these community organizations and boards is it's very hard to get legal help" to make their arguments, "whereas the Port Authority is well armed," said George Haikalis, a spokesman for the Committee for Better Transit, a nonprofit group trying to derail the Airtrain. "The message is, 'You don't take on the Port Authority.' "
The committee considered experiences like Ms. DuBerry's to be so pervasive that it put together a report called "Irregularities," which it has forwarded to the Attorney General's office.
But Sid Davidoff, one of the authority's lobbyists, dismissed the charge as frivolous. "Whenever someone loses a vote they always yell, 'Irregularities,' " he said. It was perfectly legitimate."
The authority eventually won over many in the Queens community with promises that went beyond beautifying the Van Wyck after construction. It also plans to build a new subway station in Howard Beach, renovate the Jamaica Long Island Rail Road station, which will be the transfer point to the Airtrain, set aside $150 million of the construction work for businesses owned by minorities and women, and spend $800,000 to enhance an aviation studies program at York College in Jamaica.
"It was critical that the Port Authority demonstrate a level of responsiveness to community concerns that broke the image of a distant bureaucracy," said Chris O. Ward, the authority's chief of planning and architect of its Airtrain campaign.
After winning approval from the three community boards involved, the Port Authority's next stop was the Planning Commission, whose members could not conceal their disdain. Its chairman, Joseph B. Rose, went so far as to say that "this project as currently conceived is clearly not a successful project."
Nevertheless, Mr. Rose and others voted to authorize the city to acquire property needed for the Airtrain tracks, which allowed the project to move on to the City Council, whose staff had already issued a report called "Train to the Plane or Money Down the Drain." The document tore the proposal apart: it cast doubt on its supposed economic benefits and ridiculed its logistics, painting a scenario in which passengers would have to carry luggage up and down stairs to make their connections.
"The report boxed him in," said one of the people representing the authority's interests, in reference to Mr. Vallone. "I thought that the work we had done would potentially stumble at the Council, and that we had a real shot at losing it."
But the authority continued on. Its lobbyists huddled with Council leaders, while its executives provided sandwiches and refreshments to Council members who had gone along for the bus ride. Most of all, it relied on the strength of its what-else-is-there argument.
After his own tour of the Jamaica station, Mr. Vallone suggested changes to the design that one of the authority's lobbyists emphasized to the agency had to be met for the proposal to win Council approval. Authority executives responded, and suddenly the plan included a baggage check-in area at the station, wider elevators, and an automated walkway to ease the transfer for riders with luggage.
Those changes, announced last week, permitted Mr. Vallone to join so many others in giving the Port Authority project the political equivalent of an air kiss.
"While it's clear that this project is not perfect, modern and improved access to our airports is vital to our city," he said. "Therefore, the Airtrain should proceed."

HEADLINE: Putting a Price on the Brooklyn Bridge

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
New York City will have to dust off decades-old files to determine the value of the 116-year-old Brooklyn Bridge. California will have to value hundreds of miles of eight-lane freeways. And, hundreds of cities will struggle to tally up the cost of schools, jails and sewers built many years ago.
The group that sets the standards for how the nation's 84,000 state and local governments keep their books is expected to approve a plan this week that would require them to operate more like businesses, providing taxpayers with a complete picture of what their dollars buy. 
 The proposal, which has attracted little publicity, has nonetheless prompted hundreds of cities, towns and other local governments to deluge the rule makers with letters predicting how difficult and costly it will be to comply. Municipalities say they are already overburdened by work associated with the Year 2000 computer problem.
But citizens groups laud the plan, saying it will eventually arm taxpayers with new information that will help them understand when their politicians are spending too little, as well as when their ambitions have grown too large.
The plan would fundamentally change the way government officials look at almost all financial decisions, from spending on infrastructure to borrowing money to selling properties. But most significantly, it would make many costs that are now hidden and shifted to future administrations far more apparent.
"We think this is a major step in the right direction," said Roland Calia of the Governmental Research Association, which represents dozens of taxpayer groups across the nation. "This will help people raise questions about what their government is doing."
For many government officials, who until now have been allowed to live in the moment -- recognizing cash only when it comes in and costs only when the checks have been sent -- the changes are nothing short of momentous. Even officials who applaud the new rules say that the task of complying is daunting. Under the most significant and controversial change, governments will for the first time have to calculate the value of nearly every major asset they own, from roads to bridges to prisons to hospitals, even if those assets were acquired or built decades ago. Until now, the value of those projects vanished from view on the financial statements almost the moment the money was spent.
To comply, governments say they will have to hire armies of accountants, engineers, consultants and appraisers to come up with the numbers, money that could be spent on worthier causes.
"People are starting to think, 'I'm just not sure what I'm going to do,' " said Jake Lorentz, assistant director at the Government Finance Officers Association, a Chicago-based group of more than 14,000 state and local officials. That group has opposed the new rules because of the costs it would impose, especially on the smallest cities and towns.
The Governmental Accounting Standards Board, which is at the heart of the firestorm, has not been the object of such heated debate since it began setting rules in 1984. Based in Norwalk, Conn., the group's seven voting members are scheduled to approve Statement No. 34 on Thursday. Its 200 pages of particulars are expected to impact nearly every government in America, except the Federal Government, which writes its own rules. Tom L. Allen, the chairman of the board and the former auditor of Utah, said he expected unanimous approval.
Unless the board retreats, the largest governments would start using the rules for fiscal years beginning after June 15, 2001. Smaller governments would have one or two more years to comply.
The rule makers have already made concessions in a few crucial areas to appease critics.
Governments with fewer than $10 million in annual revenues will not be required to go back and put a value on their existing infrastructure. Those small governments account for about two-thirds of the nation's total state and local governments. But in future years, they would be bound to the same rules as everyone else. And all governments would be exempt from having to establish values for assets that were acquired more than 25 years ago, unless significant renovations have taken place. Thus, the Brooklyn Bridge might have escaped the process, but it was renovated around the time of its centennial in 1983.
In another concession, the board is prepared to let the governments estimate the cost of historic projects if that is easier than going through old records and determining the actual expense. And governments will have another four years from the effective date of the rules to include the cost of projects built before the new rules were adopted.
Even then, much work will be required. In New York State, for instance, officials must value 37,000 miles of state-owned roads and 7,800 bridges as well as assign values to hundreds of university classrooms, state hospitals and prisons.
In Florida, Sam McCall, the state's deputy auditor general, said accountants would have to determine the cost of the giant Sunshine Skyway Bridge that spans Tampa Bay and was built in 1987. "In the past, we've taken the position that bridges were not going to be sold, so we haven't recorded it," he said.
By forcing states and cities to include the cost of bridges and roads on their annual financial statements, Mr. McCall said, it would not be so easy to put off crucial repairs when money is tight. "If you don't fix a pothole, it only gets bigger," he said. "This is progress."
The board can not legally enforce its rules. But most state and local governments are now required to abide by the board's standards as a condition of the municipal bonds they issue. And, in some states, lawmakers have passed legislation requiring cities and towns to follow the accounting board's rules. And unless they comply fully, governments could not expect their outside auditors to endorse their financial statements, a red flag that would invite taxpayer scrutiny.
The new rules move governments beyond a decades-old system where money is put into accounts, called funds, designated for categories of spending like construction or operations. The method helps officials stay in budget, but does little to show the governments' true financial position.
The board has been debating the wisdom of these new rules almost since its inception, especially since there is no easy answer just how to arrive at the values government officials are now expected to produce. Should a bridge be reported at how much it cost to build, or how much it would cost to replace or at some combination? Should those numbers be adjusted for inflation?
For now, the board has settled on relying largely on what governments actually spent in building or acquisition costs. Those numbers would decrease for each year of wear and tear, or increase if the government was spending on meaningful improvements. As vexing as all that is, governments also have to hazard a guess on how many years those highways, bridges, prisons, schools, firetrucks and other assets might last.
With that information, governments' willingness to undertake certain projects -- and what taxpayers understand about those projects -- will almost certainly change.
For example, a state that builds a prison for $100 million and expects the building to last for 50 years would show $2 million in building costs each year under the proposal. Currently, however, the state would just report a one-time expense of $100 million in the year the prison was built. In later years, voters who look at the financial statements would see salaries for correctional officers but nothing for the prison walls.
"We haven't known in the past what it cost to operate a prison," Mr. McCall said. "This will help people understand what it costs to operate the government."
Under the proposed system, voters would see the total cost of operating the correctional system, allowing them to weigh the trade-offs between building prisons and, for instance, paying for projects that keep people out of prison.
In yet another significant break with the past, governments would no longer be able to shift a cost to the next year simply by delaying payment. Until now, governments have been allowed to wait to record an expense until a bill was paid, a financial maneuver that is like allowing consumers to pretend they did not owe money on credit card purchases. But the new rules will require governments to accrue costs in the same way businesses do. For example, a cost will be recorded when office supplies are delivered, not when the bill is eventually paid.
"The system has been like a little family checkbook," said Wilbur L. Ross, executive managing director of Rothschild Inc., who has advised New York City on some financial matters in the past. "That is no way to run a thing as big and complicated as a city like New York."
Less controversial is a plan requiring governments to prepare one comprehensive financial statement to account for all the money coming in and going out. Now, governments account for their services in many different funds, which has confused both citizens and financial experts.
But governments would also be encouraged to provide detailed breakdowns on specific services so that taxpayers can see how much it costs to provide police protection, run the schools, pick up garbage, or offer amenities like public golf courses.
The accounting board is also poised to require government managers to answer for themselves, much the way executives of public companies do. Each fiscal year, elected officials would have to give taxpayers "an objective and easily readable analysis" of the government's financial performance. It would have to explain such things as why they sold a large piece of land or issued millions of dollars in bonds. And for the first time, officials must explain why they spent more than was approved in the budget at the beginning of the year.
"Citizens will be able to see government as a whole so that there can no longer be any games played simply by moving things around," said Andrew S. Rein, who has spent years trying to track how the governments of New York City and New York State spend taxpayer money as a research analyst for the Citizens Budget Office, a nonprofit group. "They will have a much better view of what is going on."

HEADLINE: As Welfare Rolls Shrink, Cities Shoulder Bigger Load

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
Welfare rolls are shrinking more slowly in big cities than elsewhere in their states and, as a result, welfare recipients are increasingly concentrated in urban areas, state and local officials and welfare policy experts say.
"The largest American cities are becoming home to a larger and larger share of the nation's welfare recipients," said Bruce Katz, director of the Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy at the Brookings Institution here. 
 Urban counties containing the 30 largest American cities have 20 percent of the nation's population, but 39 percent of the welfare recipients -- up from 33 percent in 1994, Mr. Katz said. He recently completed a two-year study of welfare rolls in America's cities, methodically tabulating caseload data for each city after finding that the Federal Government no longer collected such information.
From 1994 to 1998, the number of families on welfare declined 35 percent in the big cities (those with populations of more than 470,000), compared with a decline of 44 percent for the nation as a whole.
Federal, state and local officials offer many explanations for the disparities.
Donna R. Cooper, a Deputy Mayor of Philadelphia, said: "Philadelphia, the city proper, has had a weak economy with a slow recovery from the last recession. The proportion of welfare recipients who have been on the rolls for two years or more is higher here than in the rest of the state."
Philadelphia had 39 percent of the families receiving welfare in Pennsylvania in 1994, but the proportion reached 47 percent last year.
A booming economy has created millions of jobs across the country. But Ms. Cooper said that job growth in Philadelphia had been stunted because of "an extraordinarily high business tax burden," which includes a 4.7 percent tax on wages. A recent report from Mayor Edward G. Rendell, a Democrat, said that Philadelphia's "oppressive tax structure" had driven hundreds of businesses from the city and caused the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.
In addition, Ms. Cooper said, auto insurance premiums are extremely high for many inner-city neighborhoods of Philadelphia, so it is difficult for poor people to afford cars to get to jobs in the suburbs.
Michael Kharfen, a spokesman for the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, said: "Three-fourths of the people on welfare live in inner cities. But two-thirds to three-fourths of all new jobs are being created outside urban areas."
New York City has aggressively reduced its welfare rolls, converting welfare offices to job centers and emphasizing "work first."
From 1994 to 1998, the number of families on welfare in New York City declined 28 percent, to 225,651, while the total number of families on welfare in New York State declined 30 percent, to 323,723. The city now has 70 percent of the state's welfare cases, up from 68 percent in 1994.
Likewise, Los Angeles County now has 37 percent of the families on welfare in California, up from 34 percent in 1994, while Chicago (Cook County) has 74 percent of the Illinois caseload, up from 66 percent in 1994.
In general, Mr. Katz said, people who remain on welfare are those with the most problems. They are more likely to have mental illnesses, learning disabilities or histories of alcohol and drug abuse. They tend to have fewer job skills, less formal education and less work experience. Many of the women suffer abuse from husbands or companions.
Mr. Katz found that Baltimore's share of the Maryland caseload rose to 56 percent in 1998, from 48 percent in 1994, while Detroit's share of the Michigan total rose to 48 percent, from 42 percent. Shelby County, Tenn., which includes Memphis, has 35 percent of the state's welfare families, up from 28 percent in 1994. Cleveland has 24 percent of Ohio's cases, up from 19 percent in 1994.
In theory, states now have more money to spend on each welfare recipient because they receive a fixed amount of Federal welfare money each year, a "block grant," even if the number of welfare recipients declines. But Ms. Cooper noted that the money goes to the state, and she said there was no guarantee that the governor and the state legislature would provide money to cities in proportion to their needs.
"There's a bias in Harrisburg against appropriating resources to the City of Philadelphia," Ms. Cooper said. "That's a historic bias. It's like a mantra: no state money in Philadelphia." Disagreements over welfare policy have caused "considerable antagonism between the city and the state," which cooperate on many other issues, Ms. Cooper said.
B. J. Walker, director of operations at the Illinois Department of Human Services, said Chicago and Cook County had initially lagged behind other parts of the state in responding to the landmark welfare law approved by Congress in 1996. But that has changed, Ms. Walker said, and the city accounts for much of the recent decline in the state's welfare rolls.
"Month after month in the last year," Ms. Walker said, "we've seen a rise in the number of welfare recipients who are working in poverty-stricken communities of Chicago."
A few cities, defying the national trend, have reduced their welfare rolls faster than the states in which they are located. These cities include San Jose, Calif., in Santa Clara County.
Steven C. Szalay, executive director of the California State Association of Counties, said, "Santa Clara came out of the recession early and did a tremendous amount of work to anticipate welfare reform," using its own money to provide job training, child care and transportation for welfare recipients.
The growing concentration of recipients in big cities coincides with changes in the racial and ethnic profile of families on welfare. Whites are leaving the welfare rolls much faster than black and Hispanic families, and the minority share of the caseload has, as a result, risen to the highest level on record. Black and Hispanic welfare recipients together outnumber whites by about 2 to 1.
Federal officials carefully monitor the number of welfare recipients in each state. But Mr. Kharfen, from the Department of Health and Human Services, said the Federal Government stopped collecting welfare data on counties and metropolitan areas about five years ago, when officials placed a higher priority on carrying out changes in welfare.
Mr. Katz said his research on the cities should serve as "a cautionary note for states that are boasting a bit too loudly about the dramatic declines in welfare caseloads."

HEADLINE: Mayor's Task Force Says CUNY Is Adrift and Needs an Overhaul

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Saying that the City University of New York is "an institution adrift" and is "caught in a spiral of decline," a mayoral task force is calling for a total restructuring of the university.
In a report released yesterday, the task force also assailed the New York City public school system, charging that "CUNY is inundated by New York City public school graduates who lack basic skills." 
 Conceding that the criticism was valid, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew unveiled initiatives yesterday to bolster the school system, including cash incentives for teachers and principals who agree to work in troubled schools. Borrowing language from the CUNY report, Dr. Crew said it was time to reinvent the school system and called it a "wonderful opportunity" to act. Page 44.
With CUNY's new chairman pledging to build on the recommendations in the report, and with backing from Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the report appears to have laid the groundwork for intensive discussion and coordinated efforts to remake the city's public education system from kindergarten through college.
The report reaffirms CUNY's historic mission of providing access to higher education for the city's diverse population. But it says that if the university is to educate New Yorkers effectively, it must be transformed from a loosely managed confederation of scattered institutions with no direction and few standards into a tightly managed operation that measures what its students know when they enter, what they learn and which approaches are most effective in teaching them. Excerpts, page 44.
With nearly 200,000 students and a budget of almost $2 billion, City University is the nation's third-largest public university system. "The word chaotic doesn't even begin to describe it; it's moribund," Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the task force chairman, said in an interview on Friday. "That suggests a huge opportunity, but first CUNY needs to invent itself."
While the report is highly critical of CUNY, as expected, it assigns some blame for the university's problems to the city and the state, and particularly to New York City's weak public schools. It also says the state's system of financial aid forces many students who are not prepared for college work to enroll at CUNY, because that is the only way they can receive financial support for their remedial work.
Unlike many reports, which end up sitting on the shelf after they are issued, the Schmidt report has an unusually good chance of becoming a blueprint for change. The panel was handpicked by the Mayor, who along with Mr. Pataki has been pressing to overhaul the university, and a majority of the university's trustees support that goal.
Speaking at Belmont Race Track yesterday, the Mayor called the report "an excellent work," adding, "What we want to do is make it into a real college, a college where when someone gets a degree it means something."
In addition, Herman Badillo, a member of the task force who was promoted to the chairmanship of the board of trustees last weekend, is in a unique position to press for the task force's recommendations. He said the report would serve as the university's "goal posts."
The panel offers many recommendations, including the following:
*The state and the city should provide separate, additional financing for students needing remedial instruction so they can receive it free and not use their college aid while they learn reading, writing and mathematics skills they should have learned before college.
*City University should continue to offer remedial courses, but only at its community colleges, and it must test students more carefully before and after the courses to find out which approaches work best.
*The university should designate at least two of its senior colleges as flagship institutions that can attract students of high academic promise.
*The university must work with New York City's public high schools to try to raise their quality.
"At the eve of a new century," the report says, "the United States urgently needs a model of the urban public university, and CUNY should be that model of excellence."
The study comes as many universities, particularly urban universities, are struggling to cope with a flood of poorly educated high school graduates and with immigrants who speak little or no English but are desperate for a college education to help them prosper.
The Mayor created the task force in May 1998 to force greater change at CUNY, which he contended had unacceptably low standards. At the time, there was widespread skepticism that the panel would do anything more than recommend shrinking the university and turning its work over to private universities and corporations, since many of the panel's seven members were critics of CUNY or advocates for privatization of government functions.
Mr. Schmidt, for example, is chairman of the Edison Project, a private company that manages public schools for profit. Richard Schwartz, another member, is a former senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani who helped plan New York City's welfare-to-work initiatives and privatization efforts. And Mr. Badillo and Heather MacDonald, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute, have been two of the university's most vocal critics.
Nonetheless, the report argues forcefully that the university is critically important for New York, and, if anything, should be expanded. "CUNY's historic missions -- to provide broad access to a range of higher education opportunities of quality, suited to New York City's diverse population and to the city's needs -- will be more important in the 21st century than ever before," it says.
In addition, the task force was measured in its response to the Mayor's request to tell him how to privatize the university's remedial functions. Rather than urging that such instruction be shifted to private companies and private colleges, as the Mayor has advocated, the report calls for experiments to stimulate competition.
The report largely steers clear of delicate political issues. One is whether years of public budget cuts by the state and the city have left CUNY too lean to run a first-class academic institution. Another is what responsibility the Mayor, the Governor and the trustees bear for setting CUNY adrift.
The Governor's and Mayor's trustees have controlled CUNY's board for nearly three years, and Anne A. Paolucci and Mr. Badillo, Mr. Pataki's appointees as chairwoman and vice chairman, have led the board for two and a half years. One of the panel's research papers relates some of the board politics. But the findings are not incorporated into the panel's report.
One surprise to some task force members, including Mr. Badillo, was the poor test scores of students at the university's most selective colleges. The report said that although those schools still received some top students, the average Scholastic Assessment Test scores at those colleges were below the national average for high school students.
"CUNY gets very few students from New York City's best high schools," the report said. "Students with choices go elsewhere."
Mr. Schmidt said that in an era when a college degree has become "virtually the only source of opportunity," he hoped that the report would offer important help not only for CUNY but for all urban universities.
"CUNY has the chance to be the model for great public urban universities for the next century, the way land-grant institutions were in the last century, and it's absolutely vital to make it right," he said.
Many CUNY supporters have characterized CUNY's decision to remove remedial students from the senior colleges as an assault on open admissions, the policy CUNY adopted in the late 1960's to allow all high school graduates to enter.
Mr. Schmidt said the report was not an attack on open admissions. "This affirms the principle that CUNY is for anyone with a high school diploma and for immigrants and for returning adults; it is the way CUNY goes about it that is very, very flawed."
Besides briefing the Mayor, Mr. Schmidt personally briefed Governor Pataki. On Friday, the Governor's press secretary, Michael McKeon, said Mr. Pataki was pleased with the report.
"This sets such a positive tone for change," he said. But he said he could not comment on how the Governor would respond to the report's recommendation for additional financial aid for remedial students because the Governor's staff was still going over the details of the report.
The Mayor's office said the 109-page report would be posted on the city's Web site (www.ci.nyc.ny.us). The task force made copies of the report and its 10 volumes of supporting studies available to newspapers on Friday on the condition that no articles be published until tomorrow. It lifted the embargo after The Daily News printed articles about the report yesterday that it said were based on an earlier draft.
Mr. Schmidt, formerly dean of Columbia University's Law School and president of Yale University, approached the panel's investigation like a research project, making it into virtually a second full-time job.
Over the course of a year, he met twice a month and sometimes more frequently with the other members. He and staff members visited all of the university's 17 undergraduate campuses and interviewed hundreds of students, professors, administrators and others. They held several public hearings, some marked by outraged protests by students and professors. And they commissioned reports from the Rand Corporation and PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm.
The task force raised $300,000 from eight foundations to help pay for the $600,000 in consulting work, and is still trying to raise more.
A large section of the report concerns the university's structure and governance. Although City College was established in 1847, CUNY was not put together in its current form until 1961. "As far as we can tell, no one ever tried to say what this system should be as a system," Mr. Schmidt said. "This is a system that's never been constituted."

"THE TASK FORCE: Designing a New University"
The Mayor's Advisory Task Force on the City University of New York was appointed on May 6, 1998. The panel's mission was to study the system in an effort to bring about change at a university that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani argued had unacceptably low standards.
 
The Charge
*To study how CUNY spends its city subsidy.
*To examine the effects of open admissions and remedial education on CUNY's ability to provide a high quality education.
*To determine the best means of arranging for other institutions to provide remedial education so that CUNY students can perform college level work before being admitted to the university.
