HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DOING THE DEAL -- A special report.;
A Long Struggle That Led Serb Leader to Back Down

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic kicked off the negotiations with his usual historical harangue.
The Serbian strongman lectured a Russian envoy, Victor S. Chernomyrdin, and President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland on Wednesday on the meaning of Kosovo to the Serbs. 
 Finally, Mr. Ahtisaari cut him off.
The Finn wanted to know what Mr. Milosevic was going to do.
He and Mr. Chernomyrdin had come to Belgrade with a take-it-or-leave-it deal. They told Mr. Milosevic that there could be no changes. They told him, too, that if he left, NATO's pounding of Yugoslavia would continue and the terms of any future agreement would only be more painful.
"We accept your terms," Mr. Milosevic said, stunning the negotiators with his abruptness.
So ended a 10-week struggle to compel Mr. Milosevic to say uncle. It had begun with a disastrous assumption: The American-led NATO alliance guessed wrongly that Mr. Milosevic would cut his losses in Kosovo after just a few days of bombing. But that blunder was corrected slowly, and often imperceptibly, as the Serbs, both soldiers and civilians, were punished by high-tech air power.
The turning points were NATO's ability to stick together, its tactical embrace of Russian negotiating help and a Russian-American epiphany at breakfast in Washington. That brought on board Mr. Ahtisaari, from neutral Finland; he was acceptable to Mr. Milosevic and the Russians even as he played hardball for NATO.
It was a curious mismatch of a war.
In the near corner stood the richest, best-armed military alliance in history: the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which had been around for 50 years without having to fight a war. It was big, but bulky. All 19 of its members had to agree before it could throw a punch.
In the far corner stood a wily Balkan dictator who answered to no one but himself: President Milosevic specialized in using thugs and his antiquated army to fight hugely destructive wars that he ultimately lost, but that whipped up nationalist fervor inside Serbia. They had kept him in power in a new Europe that has no stomach for dictators.
Equally odd were the rules. As President Clinton laid them down on Day 1: "I do not intend to put our troops in Kosovo to fight a war."
Because of White House skittishness about American combat deaths, NATO was obliged to do what had never been done: win a war without risking its own soldiers on the ground.
If the peace deal holds up, the curious war comes out this way: The bulky alliance won, but at a savage cost to the people who were supposed to be protected. Much of Kosovo has been razed, more than one million of its Albanian residents have been uprooted, and thousands of innocents have been killed. The West will have to spend many billions of dollars to rebuild what NATO bombs and the Serbs have destroyed.
The dictator lost, but he stays on in his shrinking Yugoslavia. If his bad habits hold and if the Serbs do not depose him, he may well cause trouble another day.
And just possibly a new lesson in war has been learned. Thanks to the wonders of high-techology weaponry, an overwhelmingly powerful alliance can crush a small nation's aggressive will without having to risk its own soldiers, if it is willing to spend enough money and if it can stomach mistakes that kill innocent civilians.
In the end it was a 72-day campaign of violent accretion.
As bombs did their work, diplomats from the United States, Western Europe and Russia ignored the West's oratory about Mr. Milosevic's being a latter-day Hitler and went about the delicate business of offering him an exit.
As the bombs did their work, Mr. Milosevic's forces did what damage they could in Kosovo; then he prepared his people for another lost war. As soon as he was offered a way to stay in power while losing, he jumped on it.
 
The Bombing Begins
'Lessons' of Bosnia Did Not Apply
Generals and politicians often learn the wrong lessons from the last war. The wrong lesson that American officials took from dropping bombs to end the war in Bosnia in 1995 was that Mr. Milosevic would fold after a few days of air strikes.
In a last-chance attempt to head off war in Kosovo on March 23, Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States special envoy to Yugoslavia, failed to scare Mr. Milosevic with the threat of imminent bombing.
On his way out of the country, Mr. Holbrooke was asked if he feared that NATO's air attacks would push the Serbs into ever more vicious "ethnic cleansing."
"That is our greatest fear by far, by far," he replied.
Asked what NATO, operating only from the air, could do to prevent a catastrophe, Mr. Holbrooke went silent and shrugged.
The bombing began on March 24 and on Monday, March 29, in the Oval Office, the grim faces of the President's top foreign policy advisers, captured in official photographs and in the memories of participants, told the story: War in the Balkans was going to be brutish -- and not short. Hundreds of thousands of Kosovo Albanians were being terrorized and bullied out of Kosovo by Mr. Milosevic's forces and NATO seemed helpless to stop it.
The President and other officials insisted in public that they had anticipated Mr. Milosevic's defiance and had expected his brutal ethnic assault on Kosovo.
But in private they acknowledged their shock, disappointment and miscalculation. "It's one thing to say we expected this," a senior adviser said. "But living it is not the same as thinking about it."
Not only had Mr. Milosevic refused to give in; Yugoslav antiaircraft gunners had downed an American F-117 stealth fighter the night before. The loss of the aircraft, one of the jewels of the American arsenal, was a propaganda coup for Serbia and an embarrassing display of the vulnerability of high-technology weaponry.
Mr. Clinton concluded that his top aides -- including the Secretaries of State and Defense and the Director of Central Intelligence -- needed an injection of fighting spirit.
"Guys, let's not lose sight of why we did this," the President told the group, according to one participant. "Let's not forget what prompted us to do this and who is responsible."
The responsible party, Mr. Milosevic, had been the principal provocateur in the collapse of Yugoslavia. He had orchestrated the bloodiest explosion of violence Europe has endured since World War II. During the 10-week war in Kosovo, he presided over a grisly forced exodus that outraged the world, and he was indicted by an international court on charges of war crimes.
But he is not a fool, and he had compelling reasons for fighting, many of which made popular sense in Serbia. Kosovo has genuine religious and historical meaning to 10 million Serbs. Peacefully surrendering control to the Kosovo Albanians would have been a national humiliation.
As important, at least to Mr. Milosevic, Kosovo was where he found his feet as a strongman. In 1989, when he was President of Serbia, he stripped the Albanian majority of its power by revoking the autonomy that the province had been given and tapped a deep vein of rage among Serbs who for decades had resented the influence of other ethnic groups in Tito's Yugoslavia.
At the Rambouillet conference outside Paris in February, after 12 months during which an armed rebel movement in Kosovo killed several dozen Serbian policemen and Serbs committed atrocities against civilians, the West presented Mr. Milosevic with what he and many Serbs regarded as a "capitulate or be bombed" agreement. "If there had been any 'cake,' Mr. Milosevic might have cut a deal," said Vuk Draskovic, then a minister in the Yugoslav Government.
There was no cake to offer, as Mr. Holbrooke, looking defeated and deeply worried, acknowledged on his way out of Belgrade. The next day, March 24, the bombs began to fall. To Washington's astonishment, Mr. Milosevic was more than ready for war.
 
Stage 2
The Only Alternative: More Fire Power
The day the bombing began, one top Air Force general in Washington fretted privately about a "new Vietnam." On June 2, the day before the peace deal was announced, another very senior Pentagon official expressed doubt that the air war could ever be won and predicted that the bombing could go on for years.
It was a "hope to win" strategy, said Colin L. Powell, the retired general and architect of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, which was won with a combined air-land-sea strategy of overwhelming force.
The hope was that just a few bombs would push Mr. Milosevic back to the bargaining table. But the Serbian leader had begun a blitzkrieg of ethnic purges, burning and looting Albanians' homes and killing and mutilating enough Albanians to send hundreds of thousands of others fleeing at the first sound of rifle butts against their doors.
But the White House did not have a Plan B.
Mr. Clinton came to realize that his ruling out of ground troops was a mistake, according to a White House official, and the President last month made a point of saying he was keeping all options open.
"The President has never been prepared to lose," this official said. "From the first day, he said we have to win this. It was absolutely clear. Because of the consequences for the U.S., for NATO, for his responsibilities as Commander in Chief, we had to win this."
NATO's only alternative, then, was to bomb -- a lot.
More than 33,000 missions were flown, and during 12,500 of them, bombs were dropped or missiles were fired. Hampered by bad weather and political fears in the alliance, the air campaign started out slowly and ineffectively.
But over time more precise weapons allowed NATO to destroy virtually any major target it wanted at minimal risk to its pilots. Only two aircraft were lost, and both pilots were quickly rescued. While three Americans were captured on the ground -- abducted, Americans believed, by Macedonians sympathetic to Yugoslavia -- they were eventually released.
In the last weeks of the war, a rebel Albanian offensive flushed Serbian forces out of hiding places along the Kosovo borders and NATO aircraft were able to cut many of them down.
 
'Collateral Damage'
Making Mistakes, Mending the Rifts
Mistakes in the air campaign -- the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and attacks on passenger trains, buses, hospitals, bridges and apartment buildings that killed 1,500 civilians, by Yugoslav estimates -- brought apologies from NATO, but no change in tactics. As weeks passed, NATO commanders were given increasing license to go after targets like electricity grids and water supplies. For the first time in a decade of war in Yugoslavia, the suffering was brought home to the Serbs.
"Nobody in the Administration said we have to rethink this campaign, absolutely not," a senior White House official said.
The mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy on May 7 threatened to splinter the alliance; some members, notably Greece, Italy and Germany, faced mounting domestic protests over the steadily climbing civilian death toll.
As orchestrated violence erupted in China, with mobs trapping the American Ambassador in his embassy, the allies realized that there was no turning back on the bombing.
In fact, the Chinese Embassy debacle marked a turning point, one at which formerly reluctant NATO members agreed to widen the range of targets.
"They wanted the bombing to come to an end quickly but realized we needed to intensify to make that happen," an official said. "The flip side of intensification was there would be more collateral damage."
Long before the bombing campaign began to bear fruit, the Clinton Administration had to orchestrate the 50th anniversary of NATO in Washington so that the alliance would not be torn apart by divisions on how to find an endgame in Kosovo.
By the time of that late April meeting, the Greeks and Italians were already making noises about a halt in the air campaign. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain was making even louder noises, giving speech after speech about how NATO ought to capitalize on the bombing. He wanted to send in ground troops after the Serbian forces were demoralized and crippled, but before there was an agreement to withdraw.
The alliance, though, held together. Mr. Clinton pushed the issue of ground troops off the table by convincing NATO's Secretary General, Javier Solana, to announce a formal assessment of ground-troop options in the weeks after the summit ceremony.
The NATO leaders presented a united front, cobbling together a set of core demands that the White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, summarized in four words, "Serbs out, refugees back." These demands, plus the nonnegotiable insistence that Kosovo be occupied by an international force with NATO at its core, formed the basis of the peace plan that Mr. Milosevic signed six weeks later.
But there are two crucial differences between what he accepted and the Rambouillet plan, from Mr. Milosevic's point of view.
Rambouillet called for a referendum that could have led to Kosovo's independence after three years -- a provision put in at the insistence of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to persuade Albanian leaders to sign the agreement.
That was anathema to the Serbs. Kosovo's future is left vague in the current settlement. Another difference is that the international force is not composed solely of NATO soldiers and is to operate under United Nations auspices.
 
The Russians
Trying to Sidestep Slavic Allegiances
There remained, though, a towering brick wall between NATO and any peace settlement with Mr. Milosevic: the Russians.
The night the bombing began Russia denounced it as an act of brazen aggression and suspended cooperation with NATO. Yevgeny M. Primakov, then the Prime Minister, made a dramatic U-turn in the sky, turning his plane back from a trip to Washington at which Russia had hoped to win loans from the International Monetary Fund for its crumbling economy.
As it happens, the U-turn was staged to appease an angry Russian public that sympathized with the Serbs, according to a Russian adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin. He said Mr. Primakov had been informed before his plane took off that the bombing would start. But an aide to Al Gore said the Vice President had informed Mr. Primakov by telephone when the plane was over the North Atlantic that allied bombing of Yugoslavia would probably begin within days.
Mr. Milosevic, desperate for a partner in his war against the West, seized on Russia's support and demanded that its traditional Slavic ally become a player in any deal.
But the Russian Government's enthusiasm for Mr. Milosevic, notwithstanding its bravura show of solidarity as the bombing began, has always been tepid. Mr. Milosevic, after all, had supported the Communist generals who sided against Mr. Yeltsin in the 1991 attempted coup against the last Soviet President. Mikhail S. Gorbachev. As Mr. Chernomyrdin, Russia's envoy to the Balkans, later told German officials, "Russia cannot identify with this guy."
Moscow was squeezed between a domestic political need to appear to be defending the interest of the Serbs, and a compelling economic need to secure more financial help from the West.
After the bombing began, many Western European leaders tried to entice Mr. Yeltsin back into cooperation with NATO. Since the peace agreement, officials in Bonn and Washington have both claimed that they had played the pivotal role.
Germany, it seems, had greased the diplomatic track before serious contacts were made between Washington and Moscow. Michael Steiner, chief diplomatic adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, was driven at first by the conviction that the Russians had to be brought on board for a political solution to be reached. Otherwise, Mr. Milosevic would always have wriggle room.
A political solution was the only viable way out for Germany because if NATO moved toward a ground invasion, Mr. Schroder's coalition Government would almost certainly fall. The Green Party, a key part of the coalition, adamantly opposed a ground war. Because Germany, then, would not back a ground invasion, a political solution was needed to avoid a hugely damaging rift in NATO.
But there was a central difficulty in winning over the Russians. It was Mr. Primakov, whom the Americans had long distrusted since his attempt to interject himself as a mediator on behalf of Saddam Hussein during the gulf war in 1991.
"Internally, we never said 'the Russians,' " Mr. Steiner said. "We said 'Yeltsin and Primakov,' because we knew there were different positions and different possibilities there. And we always had the sense that Primakov might go before the end of the crisis."
Mr. Primakov's first visit to Bonn on March 30 was a disaster. He had been in Belgrade on March 29 and came straight from Mr. Milosevic to meet with Mr. Schroder. His position shocked the Germans. He was supportive of Mr. Milosevic and denounced the "illegality" of the NATO bombardment.
"He spoke in this turgid bureaucratic language of the old Communist past," Mr. Steiner said, "and what he had to say was essentially that Russia defended Milosevic's position."
Almost from the outset, however, German contacts with Mr. Yeltsin suggested that he saw little sense in putting Russia's standing in the West on the line for Mr. Milosevic. Mr. Yeltsin's appointment of Mr. Chernomyrdin on April 14 as special envoy to the Balkans was the first concrete sign that the Russian position was shifting. He fired Prime Minister Primakov a month later.
Mr. Chernomyrdin was quickly invited to Bonn, where the meeting with Mr. Schroder went much better. Mr. Chernomyrdin was no pushover, but he made clear from the start that he had no special sympathy for Mr. Milosevic.
 
The Mediation
Breakfast With Gore, Picking an Outsider
On April 25, 11 days after Mr. Chernomyrdin's appointment, Mr. Yeltsin called Mr. Clinton. The NATO anniversary summit meeting was still going on, and Mr. Clinton was in a secure holding room at the Mellon Auditorium in Washington preparing to address the closing session.
According to Administration officials, Mr. Yeltsin had decided that he had to reassert Moscow's position as a major world power or risk being marginalized in the most important conflict in Europe since the end of the cold war.
The two leaders spoke for 90 minutes, with Mr. Yeltsin presenting a variety of ideas for ending the Balkan war on terms acceptable to Moscow and Belgrade, according to an American official who spoke to Mr. Clinton immediately afterward.
Mr. Clinton rejected most of Mr. Yeltsin's suggestions as incompatible with the simple NATO principles: Serbian forces out, Kosovar Albanians back under the protection of a force with NATO at its core.
This rejection of Russia's ideas for ending the war while embracing Russia's desire to once again be a big league diplomatic player became a defining and productive pattern of the talks that produced the peace deal.
But one of Mr. Yeltsin's ideas did take root -- the reopening of the dormant channel of communication between Vice President Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin, who had met regularly when Mr. Chernomyrdin was Prime Minister in what became a prime channel of American-Russian communication. They spoke twice by telephone during the following week, with Mr. Gore repeating the NATO position and Mr. Chernomyrdin replying that Mr. Milosevic was unbending in his resistance to the occupation of Kosovo by NATO forces.
With matters at a standstill, Mr. Yeltsin called Mr. Clinton again on Sunday, May 2, telling the President that he wanted to send his envoy to Washington.
Mr. Clinton said he would be happy to receive him, and did so the next day. Mr. Chernomyrdin met for 90 minutes in the Oval Office with the President and his foreign policy team, then traveled the three miles to Mr. Gore's official residence on Embassy Row.
That evening Mr. Chernomyrdin and his small delegation spent three hours with Mr. Gore; Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser; Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, and Leon Fuerth, Mr. Gore's top foreign policy aide. Little progress was made, but the door was left open for new ideas.
At 7:30 the next morning, the Russians called Mr. Gore's staff. Mr. Chernomyrdin wanted to meet for breakfast. He had a new idea.
Over muffins at Mr. Gore's house, Mr. Chernomyrdin proposed a team of himself and someone who would be both acceptable to Mr. Milosevic and trusted by NATO. The idea excited the White House team, which had been joined by Ms. Albright. "I thought it was good to come at Milosevic from two angles," she recalled.
Someone suggested Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, but Ms. Albright quickly vetoed that idea. She had another name: President Ahtisaari of Finland, a patient negotiator who had worked 13 years for a peace in Namibia and a diplomat who for years has urged Europe to be patient with Russia. As the leader of a neutral nation, he could meet with Mr. Milosevic and, according to a senior Administration official, Ms. Albright trusted him not to compromise on NATO's demands.
"Voht!" Mr. Chernomyrdin replied in Russian. "That's it!"
In the coming weeks, after Mr. Ahtisaari was persuaded to come on board, the State Department devised what it called a double-magnet strategy with the Russian and the Finn.
As an Administration official put it, "they bring the Russians closer to us and in turn bring the Serbs closer to a deal."
The arrangement suited the Russians, who had warned that they would never serve as a mere "postman" for NATO's demands. Mr. Chernomyrdin could play good cop in negotiating with Mr. Milosevic, setting down general principles of peace, while Mr. Ahtisaari, the bad cop, could insist on the unpalatable details of surrendering Kosovo to a NATO-controlled force.
Ms. Albright busied herself stamping out what she called envoy envy. To that end, she made scores of phone calls -- to the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, to members of Congress, to Czech and Greek leaders -- demanding that they stay out of Belgrade. Her aides say she was determined not to let Mr. Milosevic play envoys off against one another.
She was particularly adamant that the United Nations be kept backstage and out of Belgrade. Her aides say she put pressure on Secretary General Annan to delay appointing an envoy. After he selected Carl Bildt, a former senior official in the Bosnia peace deal, and Eduard Kukan, the Foreign Minister of Slovakia, Ms. Albright convinced the Secretary General to limit their role to carrying out a peace settlement after a deal was done.
She distrusted the United Nations because she felt that in the past, its negotiators had been played for fools by Mr. Milosevic. She feared that such envoys would complicate and possibly derail the work of Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Ahtisaari.
Also in early May, Germany's cultivation of the Russians paid off. At a Bonn meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations plus Russia, the first joint statement about ending the conflict in Kosovo was issued. It was extremely vague on all the most contentious issues, particularly NATO command of a peacekeeping force, but its political message was clear: The Americans, the Europeans and the Russians were trying to work together. In this sense, it amounted to a breakthrough.
 
The Agreement
Marathon Sessions Across the Continent
To hammer out the wording of the peace agreement, Mr. Talbott, the State Department's senior expert on Russia, met with Mr. Chernomyrdin and Mr. Ahtisaari four times in marathon negotiating sessions. In these and other meetings, whenever Mr. Chernomyrdin persuaded Mr. Talbott to change the wording of the peace deal, he would ask, in Russian: "What about Mother Boss? Will she be O.K. with this?" (He was referring to Ms. Albright, who said Mr. Chernomyrdin never called her "Mother Boss" to her face, but only in reference to her when he was negotiating with Mr. Talbott.)
The first marathon session was at the official residence of the Finnish President in Helsinki. Two sessions were held on the grounds of Stalin's dacha outside of Moscow, and the final one took place over the first two days of June near Bonn, at the Petersberg, a palatial former government guest house.
This meeting was the longest and most fraught. Working out a two-page, take-it-or-leave-it peace plan took until 4 A.M. on Tuesday and much of Wednesday, until the hour the negotiating duo was scheduled to leave for Belgrade. The trickiest part was persuading Mr. Chernomyrdin to accept the NATO conditions -- referred to by Mr. Talbott as the "family jewels" -- in front of Mr. Milosevic.
It helped that Mr. Chernomyrdin was heading off for his fifth trip to see Mr. Milosevic, and he did not want to leave Belgrade with only "jaw jaw" as the result, an American official said.
After a dinner with Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Ahtisaari and their host, the German Chancellor, Mr. Talbott slipped away to talk to Mr. Berger and Ms. Albright. He then proposed a footnote to the document that was being prepared for Mr. Milosevic.
The footnote spelled out demands that the Russians had been resisting for weeks: NATO command and control of the peacekeeping force with control of the operation in the hands of the North Atlantic Council, the chief decision-making body of the alliance.
The footnote allowed NATO to make its demands without Russia's having to formally endorse them, an American official said.
Mr. Chernomyrdin pledged not to argue when the document was presented.
Just as important, the Russian envoy promised to remain silent when the Finnish President told Mr. Milosevic that if he did not accept the conditions, the demands would only get more stringent as the war wound on, an Administration official said.
 
In Belgrade
An Edgy Final Round With Milosevic
When the negotiators met with Mr. Milosevic in Belgrade on Wednesday night and Thursday morning, they found him "serious and calm," according to an American official. "He did not seem under excessive stress, as Chernomyrdin had reported from his previous visit," the official added.
Mr. Milosevic was respectful, correcting one of his colleagues when he failed to address Mr. Ahtisaari as President Ahtisaari.
The two visitors immediately set the ground rules. They were mediators, not negotiators. They explained the document. As they had expected, Mr. Milosevic asked if there could be revisions.
He was told, flatly, no.
In the first sign of acquiescence, Mr. Milosevic told them he would send the document to his Parliament for approval. In an odd effort to create more cover for himself, Mr. Milosevic invited Mr. Ahtisaari to address the Parliament; Mr. Ahtisaari declined.
At the end of the first evening session, Mr. Milosevic offered a meal, but the visitors said no thanks and went off to consult their delegations.
The next morning, Mr. Milosevic appeared to be more agitated and his military chiefs looked fairly distraught, Mr. Ahtisaari later reported. But when Mr. Ahtisaari put his blunt question -- What next? -- the Serb replied, "We accept your terms."
After this capitulation, to seal the deal the Yugoslavs were given the telephone number of Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the NATO commander, along with several other numbers at NATO. They were told that they should call one of the numbers to begin the military negotiations. No mention was made at the meetings of Mr. Milosevic's indictment on charges of war crimes.
The negotiators then flew to Cologne, Germany, on Thursday to brief Mr. Talbott and the heads of the European Union who were meeting there. Later that day, Mr. Talbott went to the North Atlantic Council in Brussels to brief the 19 NATO delegates. The meeting started at 8:30 P.M., and General Clark was late. When the general walked into the room about 30 minutes later, he announced he had just received a call from the Yugoslav military.
The Yugoslavs, according to General Clark, suggested that they have their first meeting on Sunday to work out precise details of the Serbian withdrawal. The general reminded them that the bombing would continue until there was a verifiable withdrawal of their troops. "How's Saturday morning?" the Yugoslavs replied.
"There was a plan, a strategy, a concept with regard to the Russians," Mr. Talbott said on Friday. "What happened this week has played out impeccably."
 
The Serbs
A Leader Patches His Political Fences
Waiting in Belgrade, Mr. Milosevic was eager to make a deal. Weeks before he had started to prepare the public for a political solution as early as the first week of May. That it took another month may have been due less to his unwillingness to make a deal than to the West's slowness to grasp that he was serious.
The signs were everywhere. The visit of Mr. Jackson, during which Belgrade handed over the three American soldiers, was shown endlessly on Belgrade Television, complete with praise for his calls for peace and for an end to the bombing.
All of Mr. Chernomyrdin's visits were given broad coverage, as the state-controlled press abruptly shifted from obsessive coverage of NATO bomb damage to an emphasis on diplomatic progress.
The two top generals in charge of the operation in Kosovo came to Belgrade to report to Mr. Milosevic that their work was done. The Kosovo Liberation Army, they said, had been routed, and the sovereignty of Kosovo was assured.
The propaganda machine that had aroused public opinion for war in Kosovo began heralding the end of the military campaign and preparing Serbs for a peace deal.
Mr. Milosevic reportedly prepared a major announcement of a troop withdrawal on May 9, a day when Mr. Chernomyrdin was due to visit Belgrade.
But the Russian envoy did not come, and the announcement the next day was played down, while being dismissed in the West. When Mr. Chernomyrdin delayed his trip for a whole week, he was criticized sharply in the official newspaper, Politika, a sign of Mr. Milosevic's displeasure.
At the same time, there were signals in May that the Serbian people, who had rallied around Mr. Milosevic in March, were fed up with the war and growing angry. Demonstrations in the southern towns of Krusevac, Aleksandrovac and Raska began after the delivery on May 14 of 10 bodies of soldiers killed in Kosovo.
At the funerals, crowds gathered and protests erupted at the bus stations as more reservists were due to leave for Kosovo.
Only women protested at first, defying the ban on demonstrations during the state of war declared shortly after the NATO bombing began. They were careful in their demands. Not wanting to appear unpatriotic, they asked for their sons and husbands to be granted leave, or at least be allowed to serve in shifts.
Since the Government had announced a withdrawal from Kosovo, they asked that their men be allowed home first. Some said they did not want their men to die in a war they no longer supported.
The authorities tried to order the women home. When that did not work, the top general, Col. Gen. Nebojsa Pavkovic, traveled to meet with the women personally. He also allowed many of their men to go home.
A few days later as the demonstrations continued and even spread, General Pavkovic went to Raska to meet with soldiers and their families again. After still more demonstrations, the authorities moved in and made arrests. The Government, though, seemed shaken by the protests.
For many in the cities, the loss of water and electricity brought home how miserable life was going to be if the war carried on. Ordinary Serbs began to think that civilian deaths did not mean very much to NATO. They said, too, that NATO did not make mistakes and that it hit hospitals in Belgrade and Nis on purpose.
"For me it doesn't matter how they end it," said Momir Karadarevic, 72, who was busy retrieving wooden beams and window support from the rubble of his home in Valjevo. "If you ask me, this shouldn't have started in the first place."
In the end, Mr. Milosevic appears to have decided that months of bombing were more likely than ground troops and that there was little to be gained from enduring it. Experts on Belgrade and diplomats believe that Mr. Milosevic calculated that peace was better suited to his personal survival than war.
Before the bombing had even started, there were whispers in Belgrade that Kosovo would be lost after a war that cost the Serbs dearly. It had happened twice before, in the former Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Bosnia, when Mr. Milosevic abandoned the Serbs there.
In an uncanny bit of prophecy before NATO's bombing campaign began, a Belgrade journalist, Bratislav Grubacic of the VIP news agency, described Mr. Milosevic as a realist who knew that it would be better for the people of Serbia to cut a deal in Kosovo before bombs fall.
"But it is not his way," Mr. Grubacic said. "Milosevic's way is to stretch it out, make it as messy and nasty as possible, and then still lose it."

HEADLINE: STRINGS ATTACHED -- A special report.;
For Subjects in Haiti Study, Free AIDS Care Has a Price

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The impoverished patients who step from the dirt sidewalk into the modern AIDS research clinic run by Cornell Medical College in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, are offered a seemingly simple arrangement.
"We would like to test your blood because you live in an area where AIDS may be common," the English version of the clinic's consent form reads. "We will provide you with medicine if you fall sick and cannot afford such care."
But the transaction is not as straightforward as it sounds. Many Haitians who visit the clinic are at once patients and subjects of United States-financed medical research, and circumstances that are bad for their health are sometimes best for research results.
That conflict is especially true in Cornell's most tantalizing research in Haiti, a study of sex partners, only one of whom is infected with the AIDS virus. Researchers, seeking clues to developing a vaccine, study the blood of both partners, particularly the uninfected ones who continue to be exposed to the virus through unprotected sex. They are trying to find out whether some people have natural protections against infection with the AIDS virus that could be replicated in a vaccine.
The Haitians are ideal research subjects, largely because they are not receiving the kind of care now standard in the world's developed countries. Condom use is low in Haiti, for cultural and other reasons. Anti-retroviral drugs that are successful at suppressing the virus are unavailable except to the very wealthy, and are not included in Cornell's promise to provide medicine.
Nearly 20 years after Cornell opened the clinic, it provides some of the best AIDS treatment available in a country devastated by the epidemic, fighting the myriad illnesses that result from AIDS. But that is a lower standard of care than patients receive routinely at American institutions, including the hospital affiliated with Cornell in New York City.
If the research were done in the United States, experts agree, the physicians would be obligated to prescribe the anti-retrovirals and deliver the most effective possible counseling against unprotected sex.
The ethical questions posed by Cornell's work among Haiti's poor are at the heart of a global debate about AIDS research that is roiling international health organizations from Geneva to Thailand, challenging ethics formulations established decades ago.
"It's really like a Faustian bargain," said Marc Fleisher, a member of the committee at Cornell that reviews research on humans. "It's like, since we're making this a better place, we're going to exploit it in a way we could never get away with in the United States," said Mr. Fleisher, the outside member on a board made up mostly of university employees who are doctors.
Cornell doctors defended the couples study as vitally important and stressed that its subjects receive the same counseling about the dangers of AIDS and the same care as other patients at the Haitian clinic.
United States standards for research on humans were strongly influenced by outrage over the Tuskegee syphilis study earlier this century, which misled impoverished black subjects for years while tracking their disease, and withheld treatment even after penicillin was discovered.
Today's subjects are not to be pressured to participate in research, according to Federal regulations. They are to be fully informed about the research's purposes and risks. They must receive the best available therapy for their illnesses and be told about any findings relevant to their health.
In theory, the same rules apply to federally financed studies overseas. But an examination of 15 years of records related to the Haiti couples research shows that it has received scant scrutiny from Government officials in Washington.
And the Government's rules barely address the moral ambiguities of AIDS research in indigent countries.
Should participants receive the best treatment available in the United States or in Haiti, one of the poorest countries on earth? How forcefully should researchers who are documenting the progress of the AIDS virus warn subjects about the dangers of rejecting condoms?
Dr. Warren D. Johnson, the chief of international medicine and infectious diseases at Cornell, called the couples study "a very high priority," though he said it had been temporarily suspended while the university concentrated on other research in Haiti. "This is the critical group in the world -- couples -- that's where the war is to be fought," he said.
At least 97 couples have been enrolled in the blood study since 1991, records show, but Dr. Johnson said only 30 couples are still being followed. The study will be expanded to new couples early next year, he said, and coordinated with AIDS vaccine trials, which are expected to start in Haiti this fall using similar couples as subjects.
Cornell's clinic in Haiti offers strong inducements to subjects. It is the only center in the country providing free screening and treatment for H.I.V., venereal disease and tuberculosis, a common complication of AIDS. The thousands who flock to it are too poor to buy food, let alone the simple medicines and vitamins that serve as "a powerful incentive for study participation," in the words of one Cornell grant report.
The head of the clinic, Dr. Jean William Pape, is a Haiti native and Cornell professor who has studied AIDS in Haiti for two decades. Dr. Pape, who trained at Cornell, defended the treatment of research subjects in the couples study, saying they benefited from the same counseling and free condoms available to everyone who visits the clinic.
Dr. Pape said that offering the life-saving drugs to the handful of research subjects would be an unethical lure to participate. Treating all H.I.V.-infected citizens, he said, would cost 10 times Haiti's health budget.
If the research on couples succeeds, he said, it could help lead to a vaccine against AIDS. "You have to take into account people who mean well for their country and not impose on them things that you feel are good for Western ideas," he said.
 
The Research
Tracking the Path Of an Epidemic
Cornell's presence in Haiti dates from 1979, when Dr. Pape returned to his native land and took a job at a pediatric hospital where 40 percent of the babies were dying of endemic diarrhea.
"A man would come to pick up the bodies three times a day, with a big bag," he recalled, bending his tall frame in a scooping gesture. "The noise of the skulls in that bag was unbearable."
Using the latest treatment, oral rehydration, Dr. Pape cut the death rate to 1 percent. But the next year his Haitian colleagues asked him to help fight an enemy that would prove far more formidable.
Adults were mysteriously falling ill with persistent diarrhea, harbinger of a new, deadly disease. Suddenly, Dr. Pape and Cornell found themselves on the front lines in the fight against a global epidemic: acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, or AIDS.
Dr. Pape had the credentials to lead the effort. Part of an elite Haitian family long prominent in medicine, he had received an undergraduate degree from Columbia University and a medical education from Cornell. Supervised by Dr. Johnson, his Cornell mentor, Dr. Pape set up a local group to study the new disease and soon won Federal financing. In 1985, Cornell was awarded a major Federal grant to conduct a study, "The Natural History of H.I.V. Infection in Haiti." A succession of these five-year grants eventually brought Cornell more than $7 million in research money and hundreds of thousands more in related training grants.
The studies produced some important early findings. Researchers dispelled an early theory that Haitians were unusually vulnerable to the disease. They also helped show that AIDS could be transmitted through heterosexual contact.
AIDS testing at the research clinic followed the United States model of the mid-1980's. Haitian patients with the virus, mostly heterosexual men, were offered condoms and counseling. It was left up to patients to inform their sexual partners, and at least 60 percent never did so, researchers said.
The hope was to get Haitians to practice protected sex, but by the early 1990's it appeared this approach was not working. Dr. Pape said the data persuaded him that only a vaccine could stem Haiti's epidemic, then speeding from high-risk men to women whose only risk was an unfaithful partner.
Looking closer at several hundred couples in which only one partner was infected, he found that AIDS was transmitted annually in about 7 percent of the couples having unprotected sex. That was about twice the rate of similar couples in the United States and Europe, but even so, it suggested an unexplained resistance to infection.
The Haitians were valuable for another reason. Unlike AIDS patients in the United States and Europe, they were not receiving the anti-retroviral drugs that proved effective in halting the disease's progress.
The lack of those drugs "may allow identification of novel findings not easily studied in the U.S.A.," Dr. John L. Ho, a Cornell immunologist, wrote in an application for Federal funds. In 1995, the Federal Government awarded Cornell an extra $60,000 to expand this part of the Haitian couples study.
Grant records show that by 1996, 5 of the 31 previously uninfected partners studied most closely by Cornell tested positive for the AIDS virus. But Cornell's blood tests found something to ponder: In two of the cases there was a substantial delay between transmission of the virus and actual infection -- 11 and 49 months. And among those who still tested negative, it seemed in several cases that a version of infection had occurred but that the virus had disappeared again, at least temporarily.
Cornell researchers called these results, similar to findings by scientists elsewhere, "tantalizing" and "intriguing." They hypothesized that certain levels of sexual exposure to H.I.V. might be triggering an infection that blocked transmission, aborted infection or at least weakened the effects of disease -- all clues to vaccine development.
Research plans approved last year include further study of 19 high-risk Haitian partners who still test negative for H.I.V. but show intermittent signs of the virus in their blood samples. Cornell researchers estimated that over five years, at least 36 partners would contract the virus. One report to the National Institutes of Health anticipated that 15 to 20 H.I.V.-infected women from the study would become pregnant each year. Those children, Cornell officials wrote, could be subjects for another study examining the high mortality rate of H.I.V.-infected infants.
 
The Subjects
Offering Counseling Of Its Own Design
Outside the gates of the research clinic at 33 Truman Boulevard, the dirt sidewalk is crammed with people by midmorning. Charcoal smoke, flies and sewage stench mix with cooking smells as vendors sell beans by the scoop to waiting patients.
Thousands of men and women have made their way to the clinic over the years, many desperate for relief from sickness, others sent by lovers to be tested for venereal disease and the AIDS virus.
All are potential research subjects. But the most interesting to science are patients like the couple identified in clinic records as No. 1986, a man with AIDS, and No. 1986C, his uninfected, pregnant wife.
Ethical standards for Federally financed studies require that patients be told why researchers want to study them. But the written consent form approved at Cornell and read aloud in Creole to each potential subject does not mention that the study focuses on couples in which one sexual partner has tested positive for H.I.V.
The form tells subjects their blood is being tested because "you live in an area where AIDS may be common." It promises all patients that H.I.V. test results will be kept confidential.
Dr. Pape said that in the case of the couples study, the clinic makes a practice of disclosing results of AIDS tests to the uninfected partners. He said they are informed orally by a doctor at the clinic that their spouse or lover has H.I.V.
Research subjects, Dr. Pape said, are given the same counseling about the dangers of AIDS as other patients. The clinic offers free condoms, and videos about protected sex are shown in the crowded waiting room.
Those who contracted the virus while being studied by Cornell "have no one to blame but themselves, because they were provided with everything," he said.
Researchers in Europe, the United States and Africa said consent forms and research outlines in comparable studies typically spell out detailed procedures for informing partners and dealing with the clashes that might arise. A joint consent form used as early as 1988 in Zambia, for example, specifies: "One of you is infected with the virus and the other is not," adding, "It is possible that during the study, the partner who was uninfected will become infected with the AIDS virus. This is distressing and can cause depression, anger and marital problems."
A review of Cornell's materials found no written procedures for disclosing a partner's infection, or for forcefully counseling partners as a couple about the dangers of their situation. Dr. Pape said study subjects choose to reject condoms even though they are fully informed of the risks. To demonstrate, he provided a one-page questionnaire dated Dec. 3, 1992. It belonged to patient No. 1986C, then three months pregnant.
"Are you still sexually active with your partner?" it begins. The only record of the woman's replies are a clinic worker's check marks and scribbled notations. Yes, said the woman, she planned to continue having sex with her husband. No, they were not using condoms. No, she did not want a free supply. The reason was scrawled in English: "He does not like it and she's afraid of condom."
The document, administered at three-month intervals to subjects gathered from their shantytowns by social workers paid by the United States, did not contain the word AIDS or H.I.V. It asked, "When have you been aware of the infection of your sex partner?" The answering notation: "At entry into the study."
After reviewing clinic materials, Marie Saint Cyr, a native of Haiti who now directs an AIDS program for women in Harlem, said there was a "clear conflict of interest" between the desire to collect information from research subjects and the obligation to effectively warn patients at risk.
"If you know somebody is positive and is having sex with a partner who is negative, you have a life and death situation in front of you," she said. "You have to do individualized counseling to really tap into what those people value in life, to confront them with the reality of H.I.V. and AIDS. This in no way addresses those serious things."
 
The World Debate
Balancing Sickness And Science
When Cornell researchers came to Haiti to collect blood, they stayed high above the swarming slums of Port-au-Prince, at a colonial, gingerbread-style hotel called the Kinam, where purple bougainvillea spills over a sunlit swimming pool.
At a conference at the hotel in April 1998, the president of the National AIDS Council of France challenged Dr. Pape to rethink the way the disease is treated in Haiti, particularly in patients who are research subjects.
The French official, Dr. Alain Sobel, said the French Government could provide anti-retroviral drugs to Haiti, as it does already for nearby French islands like Martinique and Guadeloupe.
Dr. Pape, according to both men, replied that the multiple drug cocktail that had been so effective in treating the disease in developed countries could not be feasibly used in Haiti. The country's health care system, he insisted, was not organized enough to properly distribute the drugs or make sure that patients too poor to eat regularly take a pill before or after certain meals, as the demanding regimen requires.
Dr. Sobel did not disagree. But he argued that Dr. Pape's clinic, with thousands of patients enrolled in various long-term studies, was the obvious place to make a start.
"They are really the only institution that can do this in Haiti," Dr. Sobel said later in a telephone interview from Paris. He said that since Cornell's patients are participating in research, "they deserve to be treated."
Dr. Pape disagreed. Asked about this argument in an interview, he said offering such treatment to clinic patients would be "an inducement to become infected." He questioned how long a foreign government's commitment to provide such expensive drugs -- about $15,000 yearly per person -- would endure in an economic or political downturn.
The clash between Dr. Pape and Dr. Sobel reflects a larger international debate over clinical trials in third world nations, which has intensified in the era of AIDS.
In 1997, The New England Journal of Medicine sharply criticized research in Thailand and Africa that gave placebos to pregnant women infected with H.I.V. as part of a search for a cheaper way to stop transmission of the virus to newborns.
The placebo trials were halted in February 1998, when one of the studies in Thailand showed that transmission could be prevented with a short course of the drug AZT costing as little as $50.
The finding came at a price. Pregnant women pass on AIDS to their children in about 35 percent of cases, and in the studies, half the women were given dummy pills, the others given much less AZT than in the proven regimen used in the developed world.
Dr. Marcia Angell, the editor of The New England Journal, had likened the trials to the Tuskegee study of syphilis, in which public health officials withheld effective treatment from a cadre of black men for 40 years.
Many research scientists defended the placebo trials as a shortcut to giving poor nations a new weapon against AIDS.
More recently, world health officials have clashed over how to test AIDS vaccines whose effectiveness is best assessed with subjects exposed to the disease and not treated with anti-retrovirals because of poverty.
"If in Malawi, why not Appalachia?" asked Dr. David Rothman, a professor of social medicine at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. "You have serious investigators trying to do good, trying to save hundreds of thousands of lives, but I consider it ultimately destructive of the investigator's integrity and the well-being of all of us to have an ethic of human experimentation that changes as it travels."
Dr. Pape said decisions about treating third world patients can be unusually complicated. For example, he was critical of a proposal by a United Nations group to give pregnant women at the Haitian State Hospital AZT last year.
That proposal, he said, did not address the problem of H.I.V. transmission through breast-feeding. The danger, he said, is that infected Haitian women who are told of the risks to their children will not nurse their infants. In a country where safe formula is a relative rarity, he said, this could put children at an even greater risk of death.
"The ethical issues sometimes are torturing me," he said.
Dr. Sobel attributed Dr. Pape's lack of enthusiasm for anti-retrovirals at least in part to his commitment to developing an H.I.V. vaccine. In 1998, Dr. Pape became the principal investigator in a $619,000 Federal contract to prepare for preliminary vaccine trials in Haiti as early as this year.
"I told him this was completely utopic, since the vaccine is not ready and will not be ready for many years," Dr. Sobel said.
The experimental vaccines, which have been developed elsewhere, are at best only partially protective, many scientists say. Even so, Dr. Pape said he considers it crucial for Haitians to be among the first in line to test them to establish Haiti's moral claim to an affordable supply of an effective vaccine when -- or if -- one is developed.
Dr. Frantz Large, the vice president of the Haitian Medical Association, which is collaborating on the plans for vaccine trials, called Dr. Pape a great patriot.
"He would never do anything unethical," Dr. Large said. "But if he had to choose between the survival of 10 people and the survival of a nation, he would probably choose the survival of a nation, and I would, too."

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks of $25 Million for Media Conglomerate

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has struck a tentative deal to give Bertelsmann A.G. a $25 million package of tax breaks and other subsidies for a new office tower at Broadway and 55th Street to house the company's Random House publishing division, city officials and company executives say.
Although city officials say Bertelsmann did not threaten to leave New York this time around, it did in 1992, when David N. Dinkins, then the Mayor, gave the company an $11 million tax break to move to its headquarters at 1540 Broadway in Times Square. Bertelsmann is now promising to build a 30-story tower and add jobs. 
 Tax incentives or subsidies have become so common under the city's so-called job retention program that some of the city's largest corporations no longer bother to threaten to pull out of Manhattan before seeking a reduction in sales taxes as well as low-cost electricity from the State Power Authority. Critics say the special benefits have little bearing on corporate decision making but deprive the city of tax revenue.
"It's a form of blackmail by the companies and a clear case of corporate welfare by the politicians," said Brian Backstrom, vice president of Change-NY, a conservative antitax group. "The state and the city could stop giving tax breaks and companies would still want to and need to be located in New York City."
The Giuliani administration has granted more than $2 billion in tax breaks and other subsidies in the last five years to more than four dozen of the city's blue-chip corporations.
Bertelsmann, a German media conglomerate, has about 1,500 employees in Manhattan, although people in the publishing industry say they expect the company to lay off workers as it merges Random House and the Bantam Doubleday Dell publishing group.
Deputy Mayor Randy Levine denied last week that the tax deals amounted to a form of corporate welfare. He said the incentives were intended to encourage new construction and job growth in the city. The project would also provide hundreds of construction jobs, Mr. Levine added. Bertelsmann would receive only some of the benefits if its work force failed to grow.
"This strategy of creating jobs with incentives is working," Mr. Levine said. "If you're going to build a new tower, we look very favorably on that."
But the Citizens Budget Commission, the Regional Plan Association, the Fiscal Policy Institute and other civic groups contend that companies will grow or shrink regardless of special tax breaks. The subsidies shift the tax burden to small and medium-sized companies that do not have the political clout to get the special deals, critics say.
In any event, corporate tax deals have become so prevalent, critics and real estate executives say, that companies like CBS are demanding tax breaks simply because their competitors got them.
Once a critic of special tax breaks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been cutting deals at a steady clip since 1994.
As with Bertelsmann, the Giuliani administration is providing some corporations with second rounds of tax breaks. In 1997, Bear Stearns Companies got a $75 million incentive package for a new office tower under the city's corporate retention program. Presumably, some of those jobs were saved in 1991, when Mr. Dinkins gave the investment bank a $40 million tax break after the company threatened to move to New Jersey.
More recently, Mr. Giuliani gave CBS a $10 million tax break after the company threatened to move some operations to New Jersey. Six years earlier, CBS received a $40 million tax break to upgrade its studios, a $300 million project it began only in 1997.
Both Reuters and Conde Nast Publications got tax breaks to move to new Times Square office towers that already had an extraordinary level of subsidies. The city is now negotiating with Ernst & Young, which has demanded a $67 million incentive package for a third subsidized tower in Times Square.
"It's the gift that keeps on giving," said one executive who negotiates tax breaks on behalf of corporate clients.
In 1992, in the midst of a devastating recession that left many office buildings vacant, the city gave Bertelsmann an $11 million tax break for its new headquarters at 1540 Broadway after the company threatened to move 500 jobs to the Midwest. Bertelsmann had bought the empty 1 million-square-foot tower for the bargain-basement price of $119 million, or 53 percent of what it cost to build.
Bertelsmann is now negotiating for a larger tax break for a smaller deal while the city's economy is surging.
Last year, Bertelsmann sought to build a new home for Random House next door to its headquarters in Times Square as part of an effort to raise the company's profile in the United States. But when that deal fell through in November, the company opened negotiations with the Related Companies, which had a development site at the northwest corner of Broadway and 55th Street. Under the terms of the deal, which may be announced as early as this week, Bertelsmann would buy a 650,000-square-foot condominium in the planned 850,000-square-foot tower. There would be stores on the ground floor and condominiums at the top of the building, according to real estate executives involved in the project.
Bertelsmann is expected to sign its deal with the city tomorrow.
"This is about enhancing our commitment to midtown and New York City," said Stuart Applebaum, a senior vice president at Random House.
