HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Environmental Conservation;
Economics, Pro and Con, of Making Buildings Green

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
TEN years ago one of the nation's premier environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council, bought an old industrial loft building at 40 West 20th Street and decided to demonstrate its contention that constructing a building designed to be environmentally sound could be financially sound as well.
Working with the architect Randolph Croxton, the council produced a design that emphasized energy savings through insulation and the use of natural light from windows and skylights that spread through the top three floors of the building, and distributed the light via an atrium and glass strips at the top of interior walls. 
 This is in contrast to most conventional designs, where executive offices block light from outside and where interiors are blasted with artificial light that generates heat that requires the consumption of still more energy to cool. The installation also included the use of natural materials that do not exude toxic gases, and furniture made from nonendangered species of wood.
The council estimates that it saves $65,000 a year in energy costs for its 25,000-square-foot national headquarters. Since the group deliberately used only products readily available in the market, the offices were intended to be an example to other designers interested in producing structures more in tune with the environment.
It has had an impact on other environmental groups, with the Audubon Society and the Environmental Defense Fund building out their offices using similar materials and approaches. "We have had 5,000 design professionals and policy makers through here over the last 10 years," said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the council.
And it captured the attention of the Durst Organization, which has installed fuel cells, which convert natural gas into electricity without a flame, and photovoltaic panels, which convert sunlight to electricity, in its soon-to-be completed office building at 42d Street and Broadway.
But other developers, even ones eager to be seen as progressive and green, say the economics of such technologies are still unfavorable compared to more conventional approaches. (Environmental advocates counter that this is so only because the production of raw materials enjoys billions of dollars of subsidy by the Federal Government, but developers and builders have to live in the world as it is.)
In an effort to change that balance, at least slightly, the Pataki Administration has proposed a "green building" tax credit that could be claimed by building owners and tenants in New York State who invest in measures to improve energy efficiency, improve indoor air quality and reduce the environmental impact of commercial and residential buildings in the state.
The measure is backed by an unusually diverse coalition of business, environmental, labor and real estate groups, including the Real Estate Board of New York. As currently drafted, the credit would be limited to $25 million, so a few big projects could drain the fund quickly. But advocates of the measure say the important thing is to establish the principle and seek greater funding later.
This is evidently the first time legislation has been introduced to promote the use of environmentally friendly technology in the state's construction industry, said Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the real estate board. "I think it will happen and I hope it happens sooner rather than later, which means this year," she said.
Timely passage is important, Ms. Beck said, because the industry is in the midst of a construction cycle, so the credit could influence projects now under way. Once the cycle passes, such a law would be just words on paper, she said.
"Most developers are risk averse," she said. "They figure they are so far out on a limb with new development, they want to avoid anything that adds to costs. The credit would create a reason for conservative people to use new materials or use them in different ways."
Ms. Beck said that there does not appear to be any organized opposition to the bill, but that it is difficult to distinguish this particular piece of legislation from all the other issues swirling around in the state capital. "It's just not easy to do given the political climate in Albany," she said.
THE basic credit would be 5 percent of the capitalized costs for eligible types of construction with an additional 2 percent credit available if a base building and all its tenant spaces complied with the listed criteria. The bill is also written to encourage the use of fuel cells and photovoltaics, with a credit available for 30 percent of the installed cost of fuel cells and 100 percent of the cost of photovoltaics over the cost of ordinary building panels.
Photovoltaics work by adding material that converts sunlight to electricity to the panels that shield a building in places where there are no windows. Environmentalists say the reason for the emphasis on fuel cells and photovoltaics is that both technologies are available now and the prospect of an increase in demand could spur investments in new plants to manufacture them, which typically lowers the costs of the products.
To be eligible forthe credit a building could not use more than 65 percent of the power allowed by the state's Energy Conservation Construction Code and would also have to meet indoor air quality standards for the amount of ventilation and content of the air. This is ironic, because many designers and engineers say it was stiffer energy standards that led to the reduction in the amount of fresh air flushed through buildings, allowing toxic gases and particles to build to concentrations that made people sick.
The eligibility criteria also include the use of building materials and finishes that have minimum percentages of recycled content and systems to handle waste disposal and reduce water use.
According to a report prepared by the real estate board, the developer of a 500,000-square-foot building worth $110 million could qualify for tax credits worth over $7.5 million, under the provisions of the bill. The credits would be spread over five years in equal parts and would be transferable to subsequent owners and tenants. Naturally, the project would have to stay in compliance with the criteria during any years when the credit is claimed.
John Gilbert, the chief operating officer of Rudin Management, which is building a headquarters building for the Reuters news and information company at 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, said environmental considerations have become part of quality construction.
He said that when the Rudin family took an empty building at 55 Broad Street, rewired it for advanced telecommunications and filled it with high-tech tenants, the objective was to develop a "smart and ready building."
Today, he said at a recent conference at the Natural Resources Defense Council, the goal for the Reuters offices at 3 Times Square is to produce a "green, smart and ready building."
He said 3 Times Square is designed to save 30 percent of the energy consumed by a typical office building. But he said what happens to the tax bill may affect the decision on whether to go ahead with installations of fuel cells and photovoltaics.
"The tax credit bill is very important when it comes to photovoltaics and fuel cells," he said. "The raw economics do not makes sense, but if you change the economics using the tax code, maybe they do."
He said the building was being wired in such a way that it can accept power from either source as the economics improve and the technology advances. As a result, he said, the Rudin organization is not biting its nails waiting for legislators in Albany to take up the bill.
"Because we're prepared to plug in these alternate energy sources, we can wait until the legislation passes or the technology becomes more efficient," he said.
While the council benefited from the energy savings because it is its own tenant, Mr. Gilbert noted that electricity costs are typically passed on to tenants by landlords, so investment by a building owner to reduce power consumption is a dubious proposition, at least on the surface.
But Robert Fox, a principal in Fox and Fowle Architects, who is doing both the Durst and the Rudin projects, said the benefits are real, if more subtle. Reducing power costs makes a building more attractive to tenants, who are concerned about their total cost of occupancy.
"Durst and Rudin spent a lot of money on these buildings that they did not have to and the tenants are getting the payback," he said. But he said they are creating a desirable asset that will be attractive to tenants, particularly in tough economic times.
"They will have full buildings in a bad market," Mr. Fox said.

HEADLINE: Belmont Park, on the Line;
Track Hopes to Parlay Triple Crown Excitement Into a Revival of the Era When Big Crowds Roared There Every Day

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: ELMONT

 BODY:
"YOU gotta be here" is Belmont Park's current advertising slogan, though it shouldn't take much inducement for thousands of horse racing fans to heed the call this weekend, with Charismatic vying to capture the fabled Belmont Stakes to round out his upset wins in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness and become the first Triple Crown winner in 21 years.
But in Belmont Park's executive suite, officials have their eyes on a different challenge: parlaying the latest excitement into reviving the crowds of the track's glory years. 
 Although Belmont is considered by many experts to be the nation's premier track, its attendance and betting handle have dwindled sharply over the decades. The track's popularity has been hurt by the advent of live telecasts of Belmont races at off-track betting parlors and at other tracks, and by the Meadowlands track and the proliferation of state-run lotteries and casinos.
"I think it's the most beautiful track in the world, but there is far more competition than in the past for the gambling and entertainment dollar," said Bennett Liebman, a member of the state agency that regulates the tracks, the Racing and Wagering Board.
Like an old champ charging to regain the lead, Belmont has been trying for a comeback. "It's the best track in America -- there's nothing comparable," said Angel Cordero, the legendary jockey who won 7,200 races. Now he's an agent who matches horses and jockeys; last weekend he was at a practice starting gate behind Belmont's backstretch, training a rambunctious horse ridden by his wife, Margie.
To attract families, Belmont has spruced up its grandstand. Its "backyard" park has new picnic tables, playgrounds and refreshment stands and offers bands and pony rides for entertainment. Reflecting shifting demographics, special programs salute various nationalities. Vendors now include Chinese and West Indian food stands. Attuned to the electronic era, the track has more than 1,000 television screens for close-up views -- and some 800 conveniently placed computerized betting machines.
The efforts are scoring some success. Yearly attendance, which had dropped to 698,434 in 1997, rose last year to 736,740. That reversal was aided by another Triple Crown contender that drew 80,162 fans to the Belmont Stakes -- nearly matching that event's record of 82,694 in 1971. But the improved annual total was far below the turnout in the 1960's, which was about two million a year.
Betting also bumped up a bit in 1998, to $171 million from $169 million the year before. Yet 15 years earlier, it was $351 million -- more than double, even without being adjusted for inflation. The real action has been in simulcast betting, which on the Belmont Stakes alone grew about 55-fold to nearly $26 million last year, from $465,950 at its inception in 1981. Belmont gets a cut of such betting, but less than if bettors had come to the track.
Some of the track's immediate neighbors -- in the unincorporated community of Elmont on the south and the Village of Floral Park on the track's north side -- feel shut out of the effort to promote the track. They are especially upset that the track leaped two communities away to co-sponsor a big street festival in Garden City on the eve of the race, with horses, antique cars, bands and other entertainers.
"It's been my view for a long time that the track does very little to involve the community," said the president of Floral Park's Chamber of Commerce, James F. Whalen, who owns Suzanne's Bistro. "We had urged a parade involving Floral Park and Elmont, and they chose for whatever reason to have a festival in Garden City. We haven't been able to figure out what the connection is. It certainly doesn't leave a good feeling for anybody in Floral Park or Elmont."
Belmont Park officials say they do cooperate with local groups. "We want to do everything to be a good neighbor," said a track spokesman, William Nader. "So many of the people who work here live or shop or dine in Floral Park and Elmont, so it's important to have a good relationship.
"Maybe they don't realize some of the things we are doing," Mr. Nader continued. "We did have a Floral Park 5k run on Sunday, which we have every year, and then on Friday we have a special breakfast-at-Belmont field trip with free doughnuts, milk and juices for 400 students from Floral Park and Bellerose where they go on tram tours and see veterinarians, blacksmiths and jockeys. So there are things we're doing."
As for the festival, Mr. Nader said, "Garden City came to us and suggested we do this to commemorate a thoroughbred history going back to 1665." That was the year of the first recognized thoroughbred race in America, at a nearby site. But the site is in what is now New Hyde Park, not Garden City. In coming years, he said, the track hopes to expand its Belmont Stakes festival to other communities.
ELMONT'S Chamber of Commerce president, Paul Sapienza, who runs the Sapienza Bake Shop, also voiced disappointment. "We're a little jealous of Garden City having a festival," he said. "Obviously they have the Garden City Hotel, and nobody can argue that Garden City isn't a better name than Elmont. But still, we would like the opportunity to have a similar thing."
Generally, however, Mr. Sapienza praised the track. It installed a "Welcome to Elmont" sign, provides flowers for the median of Locustwood Boulevard across from the main entrance to the track, and advertises on the cover of the chamber's annual directory.
"We're proud to have the track here," Mr. Sapienza said. "I've never had them turn me down. They've always been supportive when we ask. I guess we just have to keep asking."
For Belmont Park to pick Garden City over Elmont is in keeping with a widespread public perception. Many racing fans have long argued that Belmont Park's operator, the New York Racing Association, has ignored the $2 bettor clutching his Daily Racing Form and other loyal railbirds whose support is vital to the track's survival.
Critics have called NYRA the private domain of wealthy horse owners who see themselves as keepers of the Sport of Kings who frequent the jackets-required Turf and Field Club. Indeed, clubhouse hallways are lined with pictures of Gold Coast names like Whitney, Vanderbilt, Phipps and Payson. (There is also a photo of the Bouvier family's sweet teen-age daughter, Jacqueline, posed on the track fence.)
"Most of the people in the village say that NYRA lives in an ivory tower," said Mr. Whalen from Floral Park, whose father was a blacksmith at the track. "The fact that they've taken a parade that we suggested to Garden City shows where their focus is."
But Belmont is also projecting a friendlier image and more common touch these days. Its special events have featured a country music day, a 110-foot balloon in the shape of a tire sponsored by Uniroyal, street entertainers like stilt walkers and a spoons player, and a fair with a roller coaster, a Ferris wheel, arm wrestling, martial arts and even high-diving pigs. Families are free to lug picnic coolers into the track's backyard, feed the ducks in the pond and sunbathe on the grass.
A track spokesman, Francis LaBelle, said, "The whole thing is, we want to get people close to the horses."
At the paddock, a Valley Stream family was making its first visit. "Our daughter just loves horses," said Ann Marie Skellington, who joined her husband and three children in watching the horses being walked a few feet away.
Nicholas Tallerico, a 10-year regular who said he bets about $150 a week, was carrying his 3-year-old, John. "It's a lot nicer and a lot cleaner now," he said the of the grounds. "It's definitely better."
Belmont's new face is the product of the team that took over at NYRA four years ago, Chairman Kenneth Noe Jr. and President Terence B. Meyocks. At the time, NYRA's fortunes had sunk so low that it had considered moving into Belmont the racing from its nearby sister track at Aqueduct in Queens, and shutting Aqueduct down for redevelopment. That plan is no longer active.
"The new management under Kenny Noe and Terry Meyocks has done a good job in reaching out and creating new fans," said Howard DeMartini, former president of Suffolk County's off-track betting agency. "It's a new era that has brought about the idea that the track need to be customer-friendly. It's an enlightened management."
A lobbyist for horse owners and trainers, Stephen M. Bochnak, said: "Gone are the days when it was just a rich man's sport."
The Belmont Stakes is a focal part of the track's strategy. "We're trying to make it not just a race," said Mr. Meyocks, "but an event for people to come here from all over the country and the world."
Industry experts say that Floral Park and Elmont are unlikely to become major recipients of dollars spent by globe-trotting patrons of the Belmont Stakes, especially with the attractions of Manhattan so close, but that there may be room to lure more track regulars to linger in the neighborhood before hopping on the adjacent Cross Island Parkway.
A broader industry strategy is to televise more racing to drum up attendance and betting, rejuvenate the sport's aging corps of fans and attract more women. Mr. Bochnak said: "It's a game, a sport, a business, it's all of those things."
From the beginning, horse racing in general and Belmont in particular have been intertwined with business, government and politics. Some NYRA trustees are among the state's leading political donors.
The park itself is named for August Belmont, a prominent leader in business, society and politics. The first Belmont Stakes ran in 1867 in Jerome Park in the Bronx and was won by a filly named Ruthless. The stakes of 1880 started the custom of the post parade of horses around the track at each race. In 1890 the stakes moved to Morris Park, also in the Bronx. The track opened at the current site in 1905, opening to a crowd of 40,000.
A 1908 statute outlawed betting at tracks, leading to a suspension of racing in the state in 1911-12. After the tracks reopened, a fire in 1917 destroyed most of Belmont's buildings. Racing switched from clockwise to counterclockwise in 1921. Bookmaking was authorized in 1933. The public address system and photo-finish camera came in 1936. Parimutuel betting laws took effect in 1940. Belmont closed from 1963 to 1967 for a $31 million rebuilding.
To draw more and better horses into competition, the State Legislature voted to help expand the winning purses. A shortage of horses to fill the racing cards has forced Belmont, which used to run seven days a week during its spring and fall meets, to drop Monday and Tuesday racing. That has hurt both attendance and handle.
Although the state and NYRA have long disputed which of them actually owns the tracks, the issue is moot for now. Governor Pataki signed a law in 1997 that extended to 2007 the association's franchise to operate Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga.
Today's Belmont covers 430 acres, with parking for 18,500 cars and terminals for buses and the Long Island Rail Road. The verdant infield with its landscaped ponds is surrounded by a mile-and-a half outer dirt oval track and two inner turf courses, with six television camera towers. There is also a training track and pony track.
The 61 barns have stalls for 2,200 horses. The grandstand and clubhouse building extends 1,266 feet -- longer than the Empire State Building is high, the public relations folks like to say. The dining capacity is 3,100. There are three kitchens and 42 concession stands. The dormitories house up to 865 people, and the medical office has 14 beds.
"It's a little city all its own that runs around the clock, with cooks, carpenters and electricians and everything else," said NYRA's chief financial officer, Alec Ingle.
The track's economic impact is big, but hard to pin down precisely. NYRA's annual payroll is $44 million, covering some 7,000 full- and part-time workers at all three tracks. Many of those employees live in western Nassau and eastern Queens, near Belmont and Aqueduct, where they work most of the year. From the end of July to early September, the whole circus moves up to Saratoga.
Besides NYRA's workers, thousands more work on site for caterers, or for trainers, or for off-site allied businesses like suppliers of feed, hay and straw. At the Tack Room on Hempstead Turnpike across from Belmont, Ramon Santana, who worked at the track until allergies forced him out, hand tools fine leather saddles costing up to $1,500.
Belmont pays $9 million in property taxes alone to local governments in Nassau County, and a small fraction of that to New York City for a slice of the property that extends into Queens.
THE track is part of the local fabric in Floral Park and Elmont, where most everyone seems to have a relative, friend or neighbor who has worked there. Yet somehow the track does not have as big a profile as might be expected.
"In the normal day-to-day operations of the track, it goes pretty much unnoticed, maybe a little extra activity when the workers let out," Mr. Sapienza of Elmont said a few days before the Stakes. "We do have a spike this week, of course. People are calling the chamber looking for hotels and restaurants. Unfortunately we don't have any hotels -- but the restaurants will experience a lot of extra business."
In Floral Park, Mayor Steven W. Corbett said, "The track has talked about developing a Saratoga type of environment here. The problem is we're not Saratoga, but there is still a lot we could do."
Mr. Whalen said Belmont should follow the lead of the Derby and Preakness with a prolonged local celebration. "You look down our main shopping streets, and it's business as usual," he said. "We get no business from the track," he added, ignoring for the moment the hundreds of Belmont-related paychecks that are spent at local grocery stores, dry cleaners and gas stations.
On Hempstead Turnpike near the track, the former O'Brien's bar is displaying the kind of hope that springs eternal in racing people by renaming itself the Triple Crown Bar. Its corner television is tuned in to the racing action across the street. "Of course we have to have that on," said the bartender, Deborah Krieger.
At the Belmont Diner across from the track, a waitress, Diane Jacobelli, gave her take on the Belmont Stakes. "One day a year is a madhouse," she said. "Last year I worked 15 hours and almost had a nervous breakdown. We were pushing customers away, people were waiting for cabs for hours and I made more than $300 in tips."
This year she is dropping her weekend shifts -- but not till next weekend.
For 40 years Ronald Falk, an insurance worker and retired police officer from Little Neck, has been coming to Belmont to do a little betting.
"I come every Saturday -- well, not every Saturday," Mr. Falk said, correcting himself. His wife, Aileen, interjected: "Fifty out of 52." The track is much improved lately, Mr. Falk said, "but I don't think it'll ever go back to the big crowds."

HEADLINE: How Art Museums Help Children Learn

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH ATTEBERY 

 BODY:
ABOUT 20 elementary students sat in rapt attention at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven before an 18th-century painting of a family drinking tea and working jigsaw puzzles. There was no accompanying video and no loud music. And the only fast-action scenes were of alternating arms shooting into the air when Paula Brown, a docent for the gallery, asked the students a question. "They're drinking tea," said Ms. Brown. "Where does tea come from?"
A hand shot up. "China!" 
 "Yes. So if you could afford tea, you were wealthy, right? Tea was the rage, and this was polite society."
The students were learning about 18th-century English society as part of a program designed to complement their school studies and compare life in England with that in America during the Revolutionary War period. Follow-up visits would focus on landscape painting and the art and architecture of English cities.
Jennifer Wells, a third grade teacher at the Helene Grant School in New Haven, brought her students to the Yale museum last week.
"My students were overwhelmed by the different types of paintings they saw, and they've taken some of what they've learned and related it to artwork they see in their every-day lives," she said. "A lot of them want to go back to the museum with their Moms and Dads."
The gallery offers nearly a score of thematic tours to students and also works with teachers to design their own tours or helps them take advantage of the many teachers' workshops throughout the year.
The Yale Center for British Art also works with the Yale University Art Gallery to offer programs for students from kindergarten through college. Some programs also combine art tours with attendance at New Haven theater productions that relate to current museum exhibitions.
Docent-led tours and educational programs designed for school groups, families and teachers are growing at Connecticut art museums. While the Yale Center for British Art focuses specifically on gallery experiences, other museums -- such as the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, and the New Britain Museum of American Art -- also offer studio classes and activities for children and their parents.
While school trips often introduce children to museums, Connecticut museums are seeing a significant increase in family visits, as well.
At the Wadsworth Atheneum, Shelly Casto, the acting director of education, attributed the increase to "families looking for more constructive activities to do together."
"The idea of drop-in activities in a museum, where parents drop kids off for a studio course and pick them up later," Ms. Casto said, "has been around awhile. But the concept of activities that parents and kids can do together is more recent."
Studies suggest that children exposed to art at an early age go to museums as adults. Jane Alexander, an actress and the former chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, stressed the importance of arts education while appearing recently at the Connecticut Forum in Hartford. Ms. Alexander said that, with increased "corporatization and mallization, we are losing authentic experiences day by day in this country," and suggested that parents exposing their children to experiences more stimulating to their imagination.
"Art education at an early age and continued exposure to art throughout a child's school years," she said, "is going to make the difference in creative thinking in our society -- exposure, exposure, exposure."
Many children, according to Linda Friedlaender, curator of education at the Yale Center for British Art, grow up on a steady diet of what she calls the "Sesame Street syndrome," which incorporates fast action and quick changes designed to hold viewers' attention.
"Looking at art requires concentration," she said. "Kids have to be reminded, you really have to look hard at this and focus on it. These are skills that children are losing. We also have a lot of competition with technology today. Art and music are still considered extras. Priorities need to be rearranged in this country."
A healthy Connecticut economy, combined with demands from parents and teachers for increased arts instruction, is helping to do just that. Robin Garr, curator of education at the Bruce Museum, has noted an increase in museum attendance as schools use art collections as a resource for teachers. The museum said about 21,000 student attended its 1,129 programs this school year, up from about 12,000 students and 491 programs in the 1989-1990 school year. About half of its programs deal with art, the museum said.
"Fifteen years ago," said Ms. Garr, "there was a severe lack of art education and museums served as the art educators. That has changed drastically now," she said. "Teachers are working art into their curricula and art becomes an enhancement and extension of the curriculum."
Ms. Garr also credits the Goals 2000 Project, a Federal program that established national standards for learning in the arts as well as other subject areas, with helping to bring art to the forefront.
"I think that helped museum educators a lot," she said, "because we can plug ourselves into the curriculum and into what teachers' needs are. I think museums as a whole are working closely with the schools on developing specific areas of the curriculum." Many museum educators follow the theory of multiple intelligence, which was developed by Howard Gardner, professor of cognition and education at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. The theory critiques the notion that there is a single standard for assessing human intelligence.
"Everyone learns in a different way," Ms. Casto said. "There's a significant population that learns best visually. Our society operates visually, so you have to learn to read cues out there in order to navigate effectively in our society. Those children who learn best visually, if not given art training, are not given the opportunity to develop their skills effectively. When children come here they have to make judgments about what works of art mean to them. It's good for their reasoning and critical-thinking skills."
Successful museum visits often result when parents and teachers prepare children ahead of time by talking about what they will be seeing and discussing art-related terms. For children ages 3 to 8, a book called "Molly Meets Mona and Friends" introduces young people to more than a dozen well-known artists while telling the story of a young girl who visits a nearby museum when she needs inspiration for her own artwork. At the museum, Molly interacts with the Mona Lisa, as well as with paintings and sculptures by such masters as Picasso, Calder, Seurat and Van Gogh. The book is a Connecticut collaboration, written by Gladys Walker of Stratford, conceived and illustrated by Denise Bennett Minnerly of Rowayton, and published by Greene Bark Press of Bridgeport.
"We've had a wonderful reaction from teachers, many of whom haven't had anything like this before," said Ms. Walker. "They say it's a good way to introduce art and to reinforce different concepts with their students."
Mary Kordak, curator of education at the Yale University Art Gallery, says the book has been used in several programs at the gallery and is regularly stocked by the gallery store.
"It's a very nice book and certainly one way for children to enter the world of the museum," she said.
Museums also offer activities to give children a stimulating social experience.
"You can see movies using a V.C.R. or go to the theater and have the experience of being in a real place with other people," said Dorothy Cantor, the coordinator of education at the New Britain Museum of American Art. "Families need a varied experience when visiting a museum. They can't go from one gallery to the next and expect young children to keep going. So we give them chances to take a little time out, to play a game or do something in addition to just looking at art."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 15; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Blowing the Fuse On Family Squabbles

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
THE Schoolhouse in Croton Falls, N.Y. has unearthed lost plays to potluck effect. But "Precious Sons," an eight-week Broadway failure in 1986, is its coming-of-age production.
Under Pamela Moller Kareman, who has earned the right to be called the theater's artistic director, a flawed play that was dismissed as dated and derivative 13 years ago, is re-interpreted by a terrific cast so that it rips into contemporary life. 
 No staging at the Schoolhouse has had such professional sheen and solid performances throughout. With its new Actors Equity contract, Ms. Moller Kareman's production of George Furth's little-known play is now a standard bearer for a valuable theater that, having taken the leap, can no longer afford to coast or compromise a newly set standard.
On the battleground of Fred and Bea Small's marriage, their 14-year-old son, Freddy -- an aspiring actor -- is the passive resister, shielding his eyes, holding his ears, cowering. But he's an active participant in the sibling war with the self-described "slightly older, more handsome" Artie, who is less sensitive and less entrapped by the "Father Knows Best" culture.
Ms. Moller Kareman's staging is subtly overtaking in its impact. Before long, the fuse blows on the light-headed comedy about family squabbles and horseplay. More even-handed than in its original production, Mr. Furth's play is now more sustained and dramatic, and far funnier, hilariously so when Bea wildly and crazily cues Freddy in the Evening Star newspaper delivery boy scene from "A Streetcar Named Desire," later going on about her son's show-stealing turn. That's because the audience is so tired of Blanche's yammering by the time he makes his entrance.
In the original production, Bea (then played by Judith Ivey) was perceived as a controlling monster who belittled her blue-collar husband into giving up an advancement opportunity, so that Freddy could be an actor. The play was presumed to be an autobiographical statement in the conventional mode of 50's-style kitchen sink playwriting. Now that tales of domestic violence are no longer unspoken, Fred is as scary as he is stereotypical and Bea's neurosis is more complicated and resonant. Her eruptions become harrowing, his responses more helpless, cruel and defensive.
Fred Small may be a Tennessee Williams or William Inge type stud but he's Willy Loman inside, looking for some recognition through his sons, ultimately resigned to being a nonentity.
Keith Barber's many-shaded Fred is as good as Ed Harris's award-winning performance in the New York production. Nancy Hess, who has filled in for both Roxie and Velma, the two leads in "Chicago" on Broadway, is expert at capturing the shifting dramatic and comic duality in a conflicted woman.
As "It's a Wonderful World" is playing on the radio, Bea stops at nothing to keep her family together. So what if her husband can no longer dare to dream? Maybe he'll die.
If Bea is the 50's prototype of a good wife ("Have dinner ready," "Make the evening his" in the words of an excerpt from a 50's home economics textbook in a Schoolhouse program insert), she is as well the agitatorand the "patron saint of complainers" Fred calls her. "Old Lady Breakdown" isn't far behind. Her incessant barbs, signifying repression or retaliation, illuminate the conscious and unconscious maneuvers of a passive-aggressive personality.
Ms. Hess traverses the route of a mad housewife -- by turns manic, high pitched and out of control -- as well as controlling and enabling. She mixes insidious put-downs, sexual come ons and the excesses of the martyr mother ("Maybe I'll die and make everybody happy").
Bea is there when the man of the house needs her to pick him up so she can knock him down again, and she feeds him (always for the last time) the addictive stomach-ulcer soother he's not allowed to take.
Bea and Fred are mutually abusive, and Fred shoves Freddy (Tim Rizor in a poignant first post-school play appearance) around -- a lot. Father is only kidding, though. This is man stuff.
If "Precious Sons" promises a happy ending, it is as forced as it is unsettling, reflecting eternal family compromises and how little those have really changed, since 1949 (when the play takes place) or 1986 (when it was first produced).
In Ms. Moller Kareman's deft hands, "Precious Sons" is a loser no more.
 
"Precious Sons," The Schoolhouse, Croton Falls, N.Y. (914) 277-8477. Performances through next Sunday.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 10; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Precious Sons' on Stage at the Schoolhouse

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: CROTON FALLS

 BODY:
THE Schoolhouse has unearthed plays to pot luck effect. But "Precious Sons" by George Furth, an eight-week Broadway failure in 1986, is its coming-of-age production.

The play was presumed to be an autobiographical statement in the conventional mode of 50's-style kitchen sink playwriting.

Fred Small may be a Tennessee Williams- or William Inge-type stud, but he is Willy Loman inside, looking for some recognition through his sons, ultimately resigned to being a nonentity.
Keith Barber's many-shaded Fred is as good as Ed Harris's award-winning performance in the New York production. Nancy Hess, who has filled in for both Roxie and Velma, the two leads in "Chicago" on Broadway, is expert at capturing the shifting dramatic and comic duality in a conflicted woman.
As "It's a Wonderful World" is playing on the radio, Bea stops at nothing to keep her family together. So what if her husband can no longer dare to dream? Maybe he will die.
If Bea is the 50's prototype of a good wife ("Have dinner ready," "Make the evening his" in the words of an excerpt from a 50's home economics textbook in a Schoolhouse program insert), she is, as well, the agitator and the "patron saint of complainers" that Fred calls her. "Old Lady Breakdown" isn't far behind. Her incessant barbs, signifying repression or retaliation, illuminate the conscious and unconscious maneuvers of a passive-aggressive personality.
Ms. Hess traverses the route of a mad housewife -- by turns manic, high pitched and out of control -- as well as controlling and enabling. She mixes insidious put-downs, sexual come-ons and the excesses of the martyr mother ("Maybe I'll die and make everybody happy").
Bea is there when the man of the house needs her to pick him up so she can knock him down again, and she feeds him (always for the last time) the addictive stomach-ulcer soother he is not allowed to take.
Bea and Fred are mutually abusive, and Fred shoves Freddy (Tim Rizor in a poignant first post-school play appearance) around -- a lot. Father is only kidding, though. This is man stuff.
If "Precious Sons" promises a happy ending, it is as forced as it is unsettling, reflecting eternal family compromises and how little those have really changed since 1949 (when the play takes place) or 1986 (when it was first produced).
In Ms. Moller Kareman's deft hands, "Precious Sons" is a loser no more.
 
"Precious Sons," produced by the Schoolhouse, 1 Owens Road in Croton Falls. Performances through next Sunday. Box office: 277-8477.

HEADLINE: Making Polluted Land Come Alive Once More

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
ENVIRONMENTALISTS and the forces of economic development have seldom agreed, but in a curious marriage, they have joined together in the aging mill towns of the Naugatuck River Valley to restore polluted industrial properties and make them available for development again.
Through a partnership with environmentalists, municipal officials, industrialists and developers, the Naugatuck Valley Brownfields Pilot Program has cleaned up former dump sites and industrial properties from Derby to Torrington, making them attractive for redevelopment in a region that has suffered greatly from the loss of jobs and tax revenue. 
 The program has enabled Seymour to prepare its old municipal landfill as the development site for the Haynes Construction Company and the former Seymour Specialty Wire Company property for a new Stop and Shop supermarket. In Derby, the program has cleared the way for the redevelopment of the closed Farrel Company foundry. These new businesses will add tax revenues allowing the communities to pay for other municipal improvements, including open space purchases.
"We wouldn't have done it if someone else hadn't come forward to do the study," said Thomas Haynes of Haynes Construction, referring to an environmental study conducted by the brownfield program. "The site was too much of an unknown."
The program has also opened up public access to the banks of the Housatonic and Naugatuck rivers in these communities, creating recreational opportunities and offering the possibility of eventually creating a footpath extending from Long Island Sound to the Massachusetts border.
The reuse of the so-called brownfield properties also diverts development from other undeveloped land, thus preserving the state's dwindling supply of open space and agricultural land while eliminating the expense of extending utilities, sewer lines, highways and other infrastructure.
"Without meaning to, or without having it as its sole intent, brown fields draw together environmentalists and businesses," said Jane Stahl, an assistant commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
Brown fields are former industrial properties that are contaminated with hazardous chemicals that must be cleaned up before the land can be reused. Contaminants found on these properties may include heavy metals like mercury, solvents, or petroleum products in the soil, or asbestos or lead-based paint on buildings.
Although these properties are not polluted enough to be a public health hazard, the chemicals may be carried by the rain into nearby rivers and streams, and the cost of cleanup makes them too expensive for redevelopment.
The Naugatuck Valley's communities were disproportionately affected by this problem, according to Representative James Maloney, whose Congressional district includes much of the valley. Although the region is only 10 percent of the state's land area, it has 20 percent of its brownfield properties, he said.
As a State Senator in 1994, Mr. Maloney sponsored the first brownfield legislation in Connecticut and helped Waterbury win $30 million in bond funding to redevelop a closed brass mill as the new Brass Mill Center shopping mall, which opened in 1997. After his election to Congress in 1996, he co-sponsored Federal brownfield legislation with Representative Christopher Shays, whose Fairfield County district also has many such properties.
The state brownfield legislation relaxed environmental requirements so that the land did not have to be restored to pristine condition but could be made only clean enough for the use that was intended. The legislation provided money for environmental assessments so that developers and investors knew what the clean-up costs would be, eliminating an uncertainty that had been a major impediment to redevelopment. And it created qualifications for environmental professionals to eliminate bureaucratic bottlenecks that were another impediment to property development.
Federal brownfield laws added money and tax credits to offset the cost of assessments and cleanup.
Mr. Maloney said the programs make use of properties that are in prime locations for development, cleans up the environment, helps economically revitalize cities, and takes pressure off the development of woodlands and farms for industry.
The history of the Naugatuck Valley pilot program began in response to the recession in the late 1980's when a coalition of civic, religious and labor groups, concerned about the loss of jobs from factory closings and the effect on families in the region, formed the Naugatuck Valley Project. It encompasses the entire Naugatuck Valley from Torrington to Derby.
Although it was unsuccessful at stopping the loss of jobs, the broad reach of the Naugatuck Valley Project made it the perfect vehicle to move the brownfield project forward, and it became the governing board for the pilot program in 1994.
Recognizing that environmentalists had a stake in the brownfield pilot project, the board invited two environmentalist groups that had long worked to clean up the Housatonic and Naugatuck rivers, Trout Unlimited and the Housatonic Valley Association, to join as members.
"We came to this very skeptically," said Albin Weber, president of the Naugatuck Valley Chapter of Trout Unlimited. "Who's going to make sure when these properties are cleaned up there's going to be greenways established along the river?"
It turned out that the involvement of the environmentalists was extremely helpful. The improvements that Trout Unlimited and the Housatonic Valley Association wanted fit in with the redevelopment plans of the municipalities. The greenways along the river banks make the brownfield properties more attractive, provide a buffer to keep pollution from washing into the rivers during rainstorms, and create a place for people to walk and fish, said Elaine LaBella, a spokeswoman for the Housatonic Valley Association.
The economic development program brought in the government financing necessary to create the greenways the environmentalists wanted, and the environmentalists gave the project credibility it would not otherwise have.
"The old-timers in Waterbury still remember when the river used to run different colors depending on the color of the sneakers they were making at the Uniroyal plant," Mr. Weber said. It's difficult for the towns to "resell the river," he said, but if the environmentalists say it's clean, then the public is more likely to believe it.
"Each side is helping the other. That's the greatest part of it."
From the outset, the pilot project focused on O'Sullivan's Island, actually a peninsula, at the confluence of the Naugatuck and Housatonic rivers. Illegally dumped chemicals were discovered there in the 1980's, and more than 90 drums of pollutants have been removed.
The spit of land is potentially important to Derby, which wants to turn it into a park and has plans to build a marina there, according to Mayor Marc J. Garofalo. O'Sullivan's Island is also the starting point for the riverbank greenways that the environmentalists want.
Mr. Garofalo said Derby is the smallest and one of the oldest municipalities in Connecticut. Nearly the entire city is developed, leaving very little opportunity for open space. When 144 acres of woodlands with two reservoirs was offered for sale in 1997 by Birmingham Utilities, the local water company, the city jumped at the chance to buy it rather than let it be developed.
Similarly, in Seymour, Birmingham Utilities offered to sell the town a 229-acre parcel, said First Selectman John A. O'Toole. But, like Derby, Seymour is small with a tight budget. The two communities have to pursue economic development to be able to afford open space, their chief executives said. In both cases, their brownfield redevelopment successes gave them the money needed to buy the land.
From the state's point of view, the cooperation between environmentalists and economic development interests in the Naugatuck Valley is just what it wanted to see. "We're looking for collaboration and partnership," Ms. Stahl said.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Residential Developer Vs. Community Groups on Upper East Side;
A 31-Story Building, or Two 8-Story Buildings?

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
A battle is shaping up on the Upper East Side.
In a joint venture, the Denihan Company and the Albanese Development Corporation want to build a 31-story apartment building on a block bounded by East 75th and 76th Streets and York Avenue and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The mid-block site, running from 75th to 76th, is owned by Denihan. 
 The building, which would have 150 to 175 units -- probably medium- to large-sized condominiums, a spokesman said -- needs a zoning change. The low-slung buildings now on the site, which is zoned for manufacturing, include a parking garage, an auto dealership and a chocolate-making factory.
The developers of The Gardens, as the condominium at 506 East 76th Street would be called, want to change the overall zoning to allow them to set their new tower back from the street and install landscaping and a through-block driveway.
But the most powerful neighborhood groups object, saying the proposed building is way out of context for the neighborhood. And, in an unusual action, they have filed their own application with the City Planning Department to change the zoning to permit buildings no taller than eight stories on the site. Because of the size of the parcel, they say the developers could build two eight-story buildings, one on 75th Street and one on 76th Street, and offer a total of 156 smaller apartments.
Community Board 8, along with Friends of the Upper East Side, Civitas and other groups, have joined to file the application; Community Board 8 will meet Wednesday to vote on the developers' proposal. But as Barry Schneider, the board's chairman, said last week: "Since we did make our own application, I imagine we'll vote down the developers' application."
But Vincent M. Albanese, the vice chairman of Albanese Development, which built 100 United Nations Plaza and is constructing a 30-story rental building on the site of a former flea market on Sixth Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets, said that even if the community board voted against them, its vote would be only advisory. The matter goes next to the Borough President, then to the City Planning Commission and finally to the City Council.
Mr. Albanese said the partners showed an earlier proposal to the community groups a year ago. Because of criticism, he said, the building design had been changed: several stories were lopped off the plan and the driveway was added because neighborhood residents were concerned about the traffic increase into the cul-de-sacs at the end of East 75th and 76th Streets.
Mr. Schneider said the two eight-story buildings would be "economically feasible." But Mr. Albanese said the site had certain disadvantages, including the nearby Con Edison steam plant and a city incinerator. To make money, he argued, the partners must offer exactly this kind of building: a large luxury condominium or, depending on the market at the time of construction, a luxury rental building.

HEADLINE: WORKING;
Calming The Butterflies

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. Help! I've just been promoted to a position that will require me to give presentations to clients, trade organizations and even our board of directors. Unfortunately, I'm one of those people who freezes in front of a group. I've tried picturing the audience in its underwear and a half-dozen other tricks, but the moment the spotlight falls on me, I start babbling. I'm thinking of signing up for public-speaking lessons, but I've got a big speech to get through in a couple of weeks. Any survival tips?
 
A. Scrunch your toes together several times. Seriously. "It's an isometric exercise that diverts a bit of the adrenaline edge," said Frank Carillo, president of the Executive Communications Group, a consulting firm in Englewood, N.J. "When a person starts freaking out, it's because their adrenaline response is getting the best of them. You don't want to shut off that response, but you need to get the edge off." 
 Other ways to reduce stress include warming up your voice for a few minutes before a presentation and, during your speech, talking a bit louder than usual, Mr. Carillo added. "This gets you breathing more vigorously," which can help ease the tension, he said.
As for the presentation, make sure the key points are clear in your mind and stick to them, said Pam Keyzer, district governor of the New York and New Jersey branch of Toastmasters International, an organization that helps members sharpen their public-speaking skills. "Say what you have to say and then stop talking," she said.
Mr. Carillo agreed that the best talks are focused and succinct. At high-level meetings in particular, he advised, "don't go in planning to make an hour presentation with 75 slides." Your listeners will become impatient and start interrupting you with questions to get the information they want. "And you will feel victimized," he added.
To avoid babbling, learn the value of strategic repetition. Many speakers start rambling because they've lost their train of thought and want to cover their lapse, Mr. Carillo said. Instead, pause and reiterate a snippet of what you just finished saying. "Most people are such bad listeners they won't notice," he said, "and it will give you a second running start at the thinking process."
Similarly, if someone asks you a tough question, repeat it aloud. That not only insures that you (and the rest of the audience) are clear on the question, but it also buys you valuable thinking time, Ms. Keyzer said.
Feel free to take a few seconds to formulate an answer. "You don't have to hit the button like you're on 'Jeopardy,' " Mr. Carillo said.
Finally, because many speakers feel overwhelmed by a sea of faces in front of them, try focusing on just one person at a time. "Don't ever try to talk to 'the audience,' " he said.
And forget about that picturing-people-in-their-underwear trick. "That's not a pretty sight with most senior management groups," Mr. Carillo said with a laugh.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 2468 words

HEADLINE: As Buildings Rise, So Do Their Rents

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
MONEY was not the main problem for Andre Abucham, a 23-year-old from Brazil, when he went apartment shopping in Manhattan a few months ago.
Although he is working in a training program at Salomon Smith Barney for under $30,000 a year, Mr. Abucham was able to rent a one-bedroom midtown apartment at the Sheffield on 57th Street off Eighth Avenue for $3,000 a month. His father, who owns a civil engineering company in Sao Paulo, is helping with the rent. 
 If builders had to rely on parental largesse to help tenants rent in any of the new luxury buildings rising in midtown Manhattan these days, the renting process would be slow indeed. But they do benefit from the prevalence of two-income households when they seek rents that stretch the levels previously obtained in the locations of some of the new projects.
The expectation that it can attract higher-income professionals has entered into the calculations of Rose Associates in launching a residential project called the Madison Belvedere, a building that is a departure for its immediate neighborhood in size as well as market ambition. It is a 48-story tower in the middle of the block between 29th and 28th Streets, east of Fifth Avenue. The entrance will be on 29th Street.
"We're in a transitional neighborhood between the Flatiron District and midtown," said Adam R. Rose, president of Rose Associates. He said he refers to it facetiously as NoFlaWeMu (north of the Flatiron District and west of Murray Hill). "We believe it will eventually fill in with other new buildings," he said. Commercial brokers would call the area the Midtown South office district, and in fact office growth has helped give zip to the residential market.
Rose Associates has already found that it is getting rents averaging $47 a square foot per year (about $2,450 to $2,750 a month for a one-bedroom apartment) upon vacancy for the handful of rental apartments it still owns a few blocks away at Madison Green, the condominium it built in 1983 in what was then the untested market at 23d Street off Madison Square Park, now called the Flatiron District.
Accordingly, the company will go on the market at $47 to $48 a square foot at the Madison Belvedere in July. Bringing in a "high-end" apartment with expensive finishes, Rose will offer one-bedroom apartments in a rental range of $2,400 to $3,200 a month. The one-bedrooms -- in six varieties, with and without balconies -- account for 54 percent of the apartments. The 79 two-bedroom apartments will rent from $3,800 to $5,500 a month, and the 99 studios from $1,850 to $2,350.
Rose Associates is by no means alone in the 90's in finding a slightly offbeat location for a new residential building and then attempting to demonstrate that it can command rents that are higher than the norm in the area.
With the healthy economic climate that has prevailed over the last few years accompanied by a strong stock market, the developers have been successful so far. Yet there are voices of caution as the inventory of new buildings reaches the market in a steady flow, and price resistance is reported by management groups.
The Zucker Organization has made a specialty of choosing locations where major builders have not ventured. Two recent examples are SoHo Court, at Elizabeth and Houston Street, which came on the market three years ago, and CD 280, on East Second Street between Avenues C and D.
Now the company has gone into construction in another unusual location, Broadway between Worth Street and Catherine Lane, two blocks north of Chambers Street. It will be a 16-story building with 147 apartments plus stores, and a parking garage for 114 cars, for which a special permit was obtained. The main entrance will be on Worth Street. Renting will start in February or March, with occupancy in 10 or 11 months.
"The percentage of people who can afford to pay $45 a square foot is very small," said Donald Zucker, principal in the company. "Once you're down to $40, apartments are like hen's teeth." At $45 a square foot a year, a typical one-bedroom, with 700 square feet of space, would rent for $2,650 a month. At $40 a square foot, it would rent for $2,300 a month.
"There are a lot of new buildings coming on the market," Mr. Zucker said. "We may get back to the point where we're selling condominiums again." Selling rather than renting is a last resort for an investment building company, whose business is to hold property longterm and build up equity for future projects. But in an overbuilt market, it is the path many builders take.
The Brodsky Organization concentrated on the Lincoln Center area when it began building a large inventory of rental apartments. Now it runs a total of 2,200 rentals in four properties in the area. Its latest midtown project is One Columbus Place, with 729 apartments in two towers that share a large lobby, between 58th and 59th Streets at Ninth Avenue. It opened in 1997.
Sandy Rotkoff, director of leasing for the Brodsky Organization, said she handled about 400 re-rentals a year in Brodsky buildings. Typical rents for a vacancy at present are about $1,800 for a studio apartment, $2,450 for a one-bedroom and $3,900 for a two-bedroom. It works out to about $41 a square foot a year. At One Columbus Place rents are somewhat higher, but "it's hard to get $45 a foot," Ms. Rotkoff said.
In another location, the Resnick Organization said that it completed the rent-up of the 440 market-rate apartments in the Gershwin, at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, only this month. The process took 11 months and the average rent is $45 a square foot per year, said Scott Resnick, executive managing director. "We have a substantial percentage of singles with incomes over $100,000," Mr. Resnick said.
And Glenwood Management, builder of the recently completed Paramount Tower at 240 East 39th Street, says that its 464 apartments were "99 percent rented" as of May, seven months after the rental program began. Apartments tend to be larger on average than in most new luxury buildings, so that rents, which the company says have averaged $46 a square foot per year, tend to be higher on a dollar basis per apartment than in most other new buildings in east or west midtown.
Most rents ranged from $2,800 to $5,000 a month, said Gary Jacob, executive vice president of Glenwood Management, and most tenants have incomes between $150,000 and $250,000 a year.
Figures worked up by the Real Estate Board of New York last month show that there are 4,000 new market-rate apartments under construction in Manhattan for completion this year, the highest figure since 1989, when there were 4,248 completions.
"When you've got 4,000 luxury rental apartments coming on the market you of course have got to be a little bit concerned whether you're going to find all the tenants you need to rent them out," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board.
In Manhattan, the tenant of a one-bedroom apartment renting at $45 a square foot a year ($2,625 a month for 700 square feet) probably should have an income of at least $150,000 a year, Mr. Spinola said. This is a recommended rent-to-income ratio of about 21 percent, far lower than the standard 30 percent used elsewhere in the country but an acknowledgment that Manhattan living, housing costs aside, is expensive.
"It's a stretch," conceded Margaret Kuczynski, who moved in January with her husband, Edward, and two children -- Justin, 17, and Alena, 11 -- into a $2,850-a-month apartment at Le Rivage, Rose Associates' reconstruction of a former office building at 21 West Street in lower Manhattan. "But we've been so transient until now that I hope I die here," she said.
Mrs. Kuczynski and her husband, a medical researcher in obstetrics and gynecology at New York University, had been living part-time in a Manhattan rental for four years before they moved to West Street. It took them two and a half years to sell a house they owned in Coconut Grove, Fla., where they lived when Dr. Kuczynski was working in Florida in the early 90's. The family has joined a home-school group to educate their children at home in cooperation with educators and other parents.
The 21 West Street apartments are generally larger than Rose's midtown apartments, and they also have unusually high ceilings. Prices are considerably lower on a square-foot basis than they are in midtown, reflecting both competition from other buildings and the deep tax abatement that the city put in effect to stimulate residential conversions of obsolete office buildings in the financial district.
Apartments at Le Rivage went on the market last year at about $35 a square foot a year ($2,550 for a 900-square-foot one-bedroom and $3,650 for a 1,150-square-foot two-bedroom), and rose to $37 a square foot toward the end of the nine-month renting period ($2,700 for the one-bedroom and $3,850 for the two-bedroom), Rose said.
The financial standards that new renters must meet reflect the developers' sensitivity to the affordability issue. Besides needing a good credit record, incoming tenants generally must show an annual income of anywhere from 40 to 50 times the monthly rent, with different managements holding to different standards. Rose Associates is using the 48 multiple, said Jack Levy, senior managing director for rentals and sales.
This means that the renter of a $2,745-a-month 725-square-foot one bedroom on the 30th floor of the Madison Belvedere, for example, would have to show an annual income of $130,000. To rent a 1,250-square-foot two-bedroom apartment on the 42d floor for $5,075 a month would require an income of $243,000.
Mr. Levy presides as rental director over an inventory of 3,000 Rose Associates apartments, and witnesses a turnover of about 600 apartments a year. Almost all the new renters of two-bedroom apartments have incomes over $180,000 a year, he said.
Moreover, almost all the new renters come in as free-market rather than rent-stabilized tenants, usually because the building's 10-year Section 421a tax abatement has already expired. In pre-1985 Section 421a buildings, apartments are deregulated when the regulated tenant moves out. In post-1985 Section 421a buildings, apartments are deregulated after 10 years even with the regulated tenant in place.
IN buildings that were converted to co-ops or condominiums all rental apartments are decontrolled after a vacancy, and in pure-rental buildings they are decontrolled if the first rent after vacancy exceeds $2,000. Two-thirds of the Rose Associates rental inventory is now free market, and one-third remains rent-stabilized, Mr. Levy said.
On average, 20 percent of the free-market apartments become vacant every year, and probably three-quarters of the re-rentals each year are of apartments that were already deregulated before the vacancy. "People's lives change," Mr. Levy said. "Some people are sharing and they later want their own home. Other people decide to buy an apartment, or a home."
Apart from the issue of affordability, the Madison Belvedere represents architecturally a style of building that is gradually being phased out in Manhattan -- the straight tower behind a street-level plaza.
The Madison Belvedere is on a 21,000-square-foot lot in a zone that with no bonuses would have allowed only 220,000 square feet of construction on the building lot itself. But the project got a bonus for its 12,700-square-foot public plaza (though not the full 20 percent that zoning allows, since that large a plaza was impractical) and also additional development rights from neighboring properties -- the Carlton Hotel and two other buildings. It also got a bonus of 9,300 square feet for including four apartments for low-income tenants.
The resulting 48-story project has 348,000 gross square feet of space and is built to a floor-area ratio, or FAR, of 11 on its zoning lot, less than the 12 FAR allowable. The floor-area ratio of the project to the property on which it stands, however, is 16.6.
The architect is the firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron, with James S. Davison, a senior partner, as design architect. The building's landscaped public plaza, facing 28th Street, has been designed by Thomas Balsley of Manhattan.
"It may be the last of its genre," said Mr. Davison. The "tower in the park" style, in conjunction with unrestricted transfers of development rights from adjacent lots, sometimes lends itself well to extremely tall buildings, sometimes resembling an intruder in the environment.
The tallest of all has gone into construction on First Avenue between 47th to 48th Streets north of the United Nations complex. The Trump Organization is building a condominium there that is to be 861 feet tall to the top of its squared-off superstructure. It will have 72 floors, many of them with ceiling heights of 10 or 13 feet.
Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission (and Adam Rose's cousin), alluded to this project in a speech last April in which he condemned the "trail of exceptions, caveats and interpretive gymnastics" that tower-in-the-park zoning had spawned. He said that a new set of bulk regulations would soon be proposed to respond to this problem, while still allowing zoning to provide for growth and change.
The Madison Belvedere will be 454 feet tall from street level to the main roof (and 554 feet to the top of its decorative crown). Among new buildings at or near completion, only Glenwood Management's Paramount Tower is in its height class. It is 51 stories high -- 526 feet to the main roof and 567 feet to the top of its superstructure. For zoning purposes, "height of the building" traditionally means the height to the main roof.
For Rose Associates, the $150 million Madison Belvedere marks another step in what might be called an overhaul of the residential inventory. The company undertook a major co-op conversion program in the early 90's, converting nine buildings and selling, in the first two years, about 600 apartments for about $100 million.
The conversion effort required new investment in old buildings and ultimately cost as much as it brought in during those years, said Mr. Rose, who led the campaign with his cousin Amy Rose, a managing director of the company. Rose Associates has kept the management of all these buildings, even though they are now controlled by the residents. It has continued to sell renter-occupied apartments upon vacancy of a regulated tenant, but still holds 900 apartments in these buildings. "The cash flow from our ongoing sales fuels our new development," said Mr. Rose.
Mr. Rose, 40, succeeded his uncle, Daniel Rose, now vice chairman of the company, as president last December. His father, Frederick P. Rose, continues as chairman, taking a hands-on role in new construction.

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB;
The DesktopFollies

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
Ah, the age of the computer. Remember the dream? The computer would be a work saver, a herald of the paperless office, a docile servant eager to lift burdens, solve problems, increase productivity and leave time for creative thinking. But some dreams, it appears, include comic nightmares.
 "Several years ago in my space agency office, we younger engineers saw the need to develop an award system for the most egregious computer malfunctions," writes Karen Bernstein of Houston, who works for NASA at the Johnson Space Center. 
 "We named the simple plaque award after one of the older guys in the office, a gentleman who never really got the hang of theelectronic age," she says. "The plaque was passed from desk to desk by a kind of informal laugh meter that measured the level of hysterical snickers following a computer disaster."
Once, while Ms. Bernstein was trying to delete a few documents from her computer, she was in the wrong directory when she typed in a command. The move, she says, "killed my hard drive forever." The award moved to her desk.
A colleague received the prize "for making smoke come out of her C.P.U.," she says. "We still don't know how that happened."
Someone else in the office called the "help" desk because his computer wouldn't stop beeping -- at least not until "he took the book off of his keyboard and released the pressure on the letter 'L,' " Ms. Bernstein says.
But she adds that her favorite award story was about a friend who needed to print a sketch of some special space agency hardware.
"We have a plotter in our building," she writes. "This is a printer that uses a large roll of paper and can print graphic images of any size." Her friend, she says, "sent a print command to the plotter to draw a picture of the International Space Station. Full scale."
"The laughter continues to this day," she adds, "and the award has been permanently retired."
About five years ago, Gerald Zuckier of New Haven was working for a health maintenance organization that was in the middle of a drive to sign up some new service providers.
In response to their applications, several of them received a letter that said, "Thank you for your application; we will be contacting you just as soon as we complete processing."
There was just one hitch. The bottom of each letter displayed the file name for the master copy. It read: "C:/letters/rejection. doc."
Steven E. de Souza of Santa Monica, Calif., a Hollywood screenwriter and director whose writing credits include "48 Hours" and "Die Hard," likes to remember what he calls "the infamously hectic writing" for the 1994 film version of "The Flintstones."
In one version of the screenplay, the slick villain, to be played by Kyle MacLachlan, was named Phil Lava.
"Before shooting, someone decided 'Jerry Lava' was catchier," Mr. de Souza says. "Simple global replace. No problem, except that the Philadelphia joke in the script (there's always a Philadelphia joke in a comedy) became Jerrydelphia.
"P.S.: In the end, he was called Cliff Vandercave."
David J. Kaplan of Gillette, N.J., who works for CBS, spotted something amiss on the stub of his computer-issued paycheck, so he decided to dial the appropriate extension to help resolve the problem.
When he did, he says, he learned just how testy computers can be. He received this automated greeting:
"Welcome to the CBS benefits office. Goodbye!"
