HEADLINE: HOUSING;
Residents Hold the Cards In Land War With Bank

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO 

DATELINE: HOLMDEL

 BODY:
In a state that loses 25,000 acres of land to development each year, local battles to preserve open space are about as common as Fourth of July picnics.
Take this wealthy suburb in Monmouth County, which is now warring over the fate of its largest remaining parcel of open space: a 416-acre historic farmstead scheduled for development as housing for the elderly. The arguments are familiar, pitting conservation against the economic benefits of building. Indeed, in this section of the state, the tract has become a symbol of encroaching suburban sprawl. 
 But what is unusual in this case is that the town is asking residents to decide what to do with the land, a process often left quietly to planners and lawyers. In a nonbinding survey mailed to about 5,000 property owners in April, taxpayers were offered four choices ranging from total development to conservation. As officials await the results, due to be released next week, nobody is sure which way the votes will fall.
"I don't really have a gut feeling on this," said Sharon Burnham, the executive director of the Monmouth Conservation Foundation, which has taken a lead role in lobbying to preserve the land. "What I'm hoping is that the residents of Holmdel can see through the propaganda and understand what they are really agreeing to."
The farm, a vast quilt of rolling fields segmented by dirt roads, century-old trees and brooks, is owned by the Chase Manhattan Bank, which paid $23 million in 1986 and 1987 for the tract with the intention of building a million-square-foot office campus. The site, on Holmdel Road, was zoned for offices and laboratories, and it offered the potential for another million square feet of building, enough eventually to house 3,500 employees, said Cesar J. Chekijian, who is in charge of corporate real estate for the bank.
Although Chase won preliminary approval for the project, it never went ahead with it, preferring instead to build a two-million-square-foot office park in Brooklyn and leasing the land here to a local farmer, Mr. Chekijian said.
The company's position changed drastically in 1994, when the town rezoned much of the undeveloped southern portion of the township, including half of the Chase tract, to prohibit offices and laboratories. The new law, which allowed one house on every four acres and denser housing in other sections, came as a backlash to a wave of approvals for large development projects in the late 1980's and early 90's, said Holmdel's mayor, David T. Chai.
"It was a revolt against the office space," Mr. Chai said.
Chase filed suit shortly afterward, alleging discriminatory zoning.
"It made it obsolete strategically for us, or anyone like us, to build support functions there," Mr. Chekijian said. "We had the right and the right was taken away."
Under the lawsuit, which is due to be heard on Sept. 21 by Monmouth County Superior Court Judge Robert Feldman, Chase is seeking approval to build its two-million-square foot campus. An alternative, which the company says would settle the suit and allow it to recoup its investment of now more than $25 million, is to sell the land to a developer.
The builder, Howard Schoor, chairman of S.G.S. Communities Inc. of Manalapan, has signed a contract with Chase, pending approval, to build a community for the elderly with 475 single-family homes priced from $250,000 to more than $400,000, a pool, tennis courts and clubhouse. In the latest of at least five versions of its plan, S.G.S. would donate 132.9 acres to the county for preservation, including a historic farmhouse, Mr. Schoor said.
"We've been looking for balance," Mr. Schoor said. "That's been our theme. Positive tax ratables and a provision for open space."
Holmdel officials initially welcomed the plan because it would not only end the litigation, but also increase the tax rolls by about $3.5 million a year, Mayor Chai said. Because the development would be restricted to people 55 years of age or older, Holmdel's prized schools would be spared an influx of children. The developer would also help pay for sewer lines in the largely undeveloped southern section of Holmdel, which still relies on septic systems, he said. But a group of residents has opposed the project, saying it will spoil a valuable resource and invite further sprawl. "If this goes, so goes the southern half of Holmdel," Ms. Burnham said.
Larry Fink, a founder of the Citizens for Informed Land Use, a group of several hundred Holmdel residents and supporters who oppose the development, said the farm is just the kind of open space that the state should be trying to protect.
Part of an original 1677 land grant to the Holmes family, for whom Holmdel is named, the property is part of the watershed of the Swimming River Reservoir, the source of water for northern and central Monmouth County residents. In addition, the land is a rich habitat for plants and birds like the bald eagle, the barred owl and the grasshopper sparrow. It also serves as a greenway, or link, in a chain of more than 1,200 acres of open space, including two county parks, two township parks, and a nature trail, Mr. Fink said.
"The qualities of this site are unique in Holmdel and Monmouth County," he said. "This is our pinelands, our highlands, our Sterling Forest. Why shouldn't the Chase tract be preserved?"
Conservationists scoff at the assumption that development will reduce property taxes. A survey commissioned by the Monmouth Conservation Foundation last year found that for every dollar Holmdel billed in residential taxes, it spent $1.38 on services like schools, sewers and the police. By contrast, it spent 66 cents for every dollar it earned on open space and 21 cents on commercial development.
For his part, Mr. Schoor contends that an age-restricted development will not affect school taxes, which account for much of Holmdel's budget. But opponents cite an increased need for emergency services for elderly residents. Also, retirement homes tend to attract local residents, who, in turn, are likely to sell their homes to people with school-age children, said Jeff Tittel, the director of the New Jersey Chapter of the Sierra Club.
"There will be financial impacts," Mr. Tittel said. "The best ratable of all is open space. It pays taxes and costs no services."
But preservation of the tract is not as easy as it may seem. Chase refuses to negotiate with other would-be buyers for fear it will appear to be breaking faith with Mr. Schoor, Mr. Chekijian said. And the developer's $25 million offer is difficult for conservationists to match.
The Monmouth Conservation Foundation, which has helped preserve 2,700 acres in Monmouth County, could come close to the figure, Ms. Burnham said, by mustering state, county and local financing, selling development rights and subdividing the land as farms.
"If Chase indeed wants to go by their slogan that relationships are everything and they are concerned about the community, then they should listen to what the people want and talk to us about finding a way to preserve this land," she said.
But until the questionnaire comes back, no one is sure what the people want. Residents have a history of backing open space, approving as recently as last year a local tax of one cent per $100 property valuation for parks and recreation.
For now, Mayor Chai said the township committee would be guided by the majority opinion but he could not guess what it would be. Asked how he voted, the Mayor replied, "Emotionally, I am all for these open space folks. But I'm a realist. I have a responsibility to the town. And one of these is taxation."

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
Concerned by Loss of College Students, State Tries to Makes Rutgers Alluring

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
When Jessica Roberts was considering colleges, Rutgers University was the last place she thought about. Like many high school seniors in New Jersey, she was planning to go out of state.
"It's the New Jersey instinct to flee the state," Ms. Roberts, a sophomore, said recently in her dormitory at Rutgers as she waited for her father to pick her up for the drive home to Denville at the end of the school year. "Most kids say, 'Oh, I just can't go to a school in my home state.' I had my sight set on other places." 
 But through an attractive financial arrangement that Rutgers offers to honors students, Ms. Roberts was persuaded to come here rather than attend such schools as Vassar, Wesleyan and Swarthmore. It is a decision she says she does not regret.
Through her choice, she became part of the fledgling effort to stem New Jersey's drain of college students, a phenomenon that is worrisome to state officials. In the fall of 1996, according to the Department of Education, 65,904 new high school graduates went on to college, but 24,439 of them attended colleges and universities outside of the state. That is a higher number than from any other state, and it is a trend that has been becoming more pronounced each year.
Experts such as Joseph J. Seneca, chairman of the Governor's Economic Policy Council, say the migration of the college-age population is hurting the state economically.
"In a very direct way, it means a loss of tuition, a loss of book dollars and all other expenditures associated with going to college that are not being spent in New Jersey," Dr. Seneca said.
Those costs come to about $1.8 billion a year, he said in a report the council prepared in 1992 called "Outmigration of New Jersey College Students: Causes and Consequences."
"But I wouldn't characterize that as the most profound effect to the state," said Dr. Seneca, who is also an economist and vice president for academic affairs at Rutgers. "The loss of human capacity is more important. We are sending a large number of our best and brightest out of state, and many of them are not coming back."
His report showed that about 70 percent of students who attend college out of state do not return to live in New Jersey after they graduate.
Dr. Seneca pointed out that with an economy that is knowledge-based -- with high-technology industries, research companies, and pharmaceuticals manufacturers -- the state needs a highly trained work force. As unemployment goes down around the country, fewer people are willing to relocate, he said, and the pressure for New Jersey to train its own citizens becomes more important.
At the same time that so many students were leaving for out-of-state colleges and universities, only 4,434 college students came to New Jersey from elsewhere to attend college in 1996, according to the Department of Education.
That compares poorly with other states that not only keep most of their students, but also attract large numbers from out of state. For instance, California lost 17,677 of its 277,373 students to out-of-state colleges in 1996, but attracted 17,703 from other states. In Michigan, 7,021 of 75,980 freshmen chose out-of-state schools but 7,257 students came from elsewhere.
Why do so many New Jerseyans choose out-of-state colleges? Part of the answer has to do with geography. In such a small state, and one near other states with outstanding schools, it is natural that students consider their options. Statistics compiled by the United States Department of Education show that about three-fourths of New Jersey's migrating students attend colleges within a 250-mile radius of Trenton -- Pennsylvania, New York, Massachusetts, Virginia, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Connecticut and Rhode Island.
"This is also a high-income state, so families here have the wherewithal to consider sending their children to private schools or to pay out-of-state tuition somewhere else," Dr. Seneca said.
But the loss to other states also has to say something about the scarcity of choices in the Garden State.
Jae Lee, 21, a sophomore sociology major, said he applied to out-of-state schools, but decided on Rutgers because undergraduate tuition is only $4,562 a year as against more than $20,000 for an Ivy League education.
"Initially I regretted staying in-state," he said as he sat in front of the student center, preparing for a sociology final. "I felt that a lot of people didn't want to be here, and that I had missed out on an opportunity to be with an elite group I might have been with at some of the Ivy Leagues. But not anymore. I've come to realize this is a personal choice. Rutgers is a good school. It's what you make of it."
To try to retain quality students, Rutgers developed the Outstanding Scholars Program two years ago, with financing from the State Legislature, to offer more financial incentives to attract high-achievers.
The program is open to students who score a total of 1350 or more on their College Boards and who rank in the top 15 percent of their class, said Nancy Winterbauer, vice president of enrollment at Rutgers. On average, only 7 percent of New Jersey students qualify each year.
The legislation, sponsored by State Senator Peter A. Inverso, Republican of Hamilton, has set aside $9 million a year for the program, which awards scholarships up to $7,500 a year for a student attending Rutgers, covering tuition as well as housing and books.
John Padden, an 18-year-old from Florham Park majoring in math and music, is one of the scholarship recipients. He said he would have attended Johns Hopkins University had it not been for the financial award from Rutgers.
"The money I would have spent there would have been outrageous," Mr. Padden said. "It's really a shame more kids who qualify don't take advantage of this program. Rutger's reputation is way below what it really should be."
The scholarships were awarded to 712 freshmen this year, Dr. Winterbauer said; the previous year 685 students got the awards. For next fall, the school has offered the scholarships to 805 students, which would make it one of the biggest scholarship programs ever in New Jersey for academic achievement.
In a survey of parents of scholarship recipients, 62 percent told the school their children would have gone out of state had it not been for the scholarship.
"I think it's important for us to say to students that academic achievement matters, that Rutgers values it, that the state values it," Dr. Winterbauer said.

HEADLINE: ROAD & RAIL;
Costly Battle Over a 'World-Class' View

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: WEEHAWKEN

 BODY:
The top of the Empire State Building hints at the view of midtown Manhattan as its art deco spire peers from above Weehawken's bluffs. But the real moment of visual impact comes moments later -- many moments, if traffic is bad -- as motorists enter the oval viaduct that siphons cars, trucks and buses down and around into the Lincol Tunnel's arching maws.
It is at that moment, still high above the sprawling toll plaza and curling around the portion of roadway known to local denizens as the helix, that a southeasterly view opens up on all of lower Manhattan. 
 "It's a national treasure," said Rick Kropp, director of land useat the state Department of Environmental Protection. "The view of Manhattan is one of those things that should be preserved."
To insure its preservation, the department has denied an application by Hartz Mountain Industries to construct two office buildings just east of the helix, at the company's Lincoln Harbor complex on the Weehawken waterfront. Other opponents of the 160-foot-tall structures include and environmentalists and local activists from the American Littoral Society and the Friends of the Weehawken Waterfront.
On March 1, an administrative law judge, Richard McGill, recommended that the commissioner of environmental protection, Robert C. Shinn Jr., reject Hartz's application. "The views in question are a world-class amenity that encourages people to live work and locate businesses in the area," Judge McGill wrote in his decision.
Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz Mountain, insists that the buildings would obscure only part of the river and New York Bay, not the skyline.
Under state guidelines, buildings require permits from the Department of Environmental Protection's division of coastal resources if the proposed location is within 500 feet of the Hudson River. But Hartz's lawyer, Irwin Horowitz, said the agency's reason for denying the permits -- that the view would be obscured -- is faulty because the helix is beyond 500 feet of the river.
"The D.E.P. is trying to expand its jurisdiction," Mr. Horowitz said. "The irony is, if New York did the same thing, there wouldn't be any view to protect."
Indeed, New York City has no regulations protecting views, according to a spokeswoman for the Department of City Planning. Nor does the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
So far, time and the law have been on the side of Hartz's opponents. Typical of the protracted battle, Mr. Shinn's original 45-day period to act on the judge's recommendation to reject Haretz Mountain's application has been extended twice, and he now has until Aug. 5. But even that deadline matters little, both sides agree, because the enviromental director's decision will be appealed.
The battle over the panorama of Manhattan's West Side pits one of the country's biggest commercial real estate developers against the administration of Governor Whitman, a potential Republican candidate for United States Senate next year who counts economic growth and environmental protection as cornerstones of her record.
Hartz, a Secaucus-based conglomerate built on flea collars whose holdings include The Village Voice, has one of the country's largest privately held commercial real estate portfolios, with 32 million square feet, mostly in New Jersey, Mr. Stern said.
Over the last 15 years, the company has contributed thousands of dollars to Republicans and Democrats, including former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, whose administration tried unsuccessfully to permit construction of the two proposed office buildings, and Governor Whitman, whose administration has fought them. Mr. Stern said Hartz has also contributed to local candidates, including Mayor Richard Turner of Weehawken.
Hartz first applied for a building permit in 1988 from the Department of Environmental Protection's Division of Coastal Resources. The staff had drafted a denial of the permit, but a predecessor of Mr. Shinn, Christopher J. Daggett, who was Governor Kean's environmental commissioner, granted the permit in 1989. Mr. Daggett wrote at the time that the view amounted to a "momentary glimpse" of the city.
But the American Littoral Society, a national environmental group based in Sandy Hook, persuaded the appellate division of State Superior Court to overturn Mr. Daggett's decision on the ground that his intervention violated procedures. Hartz reapplied in 1991, and this time was denied a permit by the environmental agency's Coastal Resources division. The company appealed the decision, but during the litigation the real estate market collapsed and the project no longer was urgent to Hartz. Judge McGill's decision in March was the latest round in the application fight.
In an interview, Mr. Stern insisted that a defeat for Hartz could establish a dangerous precedent for property rights cases. "This sort of regulation will prohibit all manner of private property development where waterfront views are interrupted," he said.
But another big developer of New Jersey's waterfront, Richard LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, had little sympathy for Hartz.
"If you say to me, 'Are the Sterns being discriminated against?' My answer is, everybody's being discriminated against. Those are the rules," said Mr. LeFrak, who this month broke ground on a 22-story office building at the company's Newport complex, situated between the Holland Tunnel and the Jersey City waterfront.
Mr. Stern puts the price of that discrimination at $63 million, the amount he says Hartz has lost, mainly in rent never collected. For area contractors, he said, construction spending on the two buildings, which would total 944,000 square feet, would be more than $150 million. For the economy, he said, the buildings would provide permanent jobs for about 2,000 people.
If Hartz has any sympathizers, they are at Borough Hall. The Weehawken Planning Board approved the entire Lincoln Harbor complex, including the two buildings. Mayor Turner, who was elected in 1990, after the complex was approved, said Lincoln Harbor's two existing blue-glass office buildings have generated $4 million in local property taxes since their completion in the late 1980's. Commuters on the helix generate carbon monoxide, noise and litter, he said.
But Mayor Turner has grown weary of the dispute, and he said he hopes a compromise can be reached. "Everybody's fighting for their principles, and that's all very well and fine," Mayor Turner said. "In the meantime, a small town has a very valuable piece of its property where nothing is happening."
Mr. Stern said the company has already provided certain amenities at Lincoln Harbor, like a waterfront walkway, and that he is willing to negotiate if he can proceed with construction of the buildings.
Claire Burke, a spokeswoman for the Friends of the Weehawken Waterfront, one of several groups opposed to the buildings, said preserving the view is fundamentally important for Weehawken, whose image is literally framed by the Manhattan skyline.
"That's the first view of New York that many people see when they drive here from the West," said Ms. Burke, 61, a longtime resident. "It serves as a psychological uplifter for people when they come in. I used to be a commuter for 32 years, and there's something about that vista, that horizon, that doesn't belong to Hartz Mountain. It belongs to the world."

HEADLINE: DATABANK: MAY 31-JUNE 4;
The Interest-Rate Watch Continues

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
Until the unemployment report on Friday, investors, worried that the economy might be growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, appeared to be playing ring around the rosy. But before anyone could fall down, markets rebounded in the United States and overseas.
 
 The Labor Department reported that jobs were created in May at a much slower pace than expected, while the jobless rate fell to 4.2 percent, from 4.3 percent in April. Meanwhile, average hourly earnings, a closely watched barometer of inflation, jumped 5 cents.
 "The market is trying to find its bearings to get a reading about what the Fed is going to do," Arun Kumar, senior United States equities strategist at Lehman Brothers, told Reuters on Friday.
 Robert Streed, a money manager with the Northern Trust Company, told Bloomberg News, "I would think the market has priced in a quarter-point interest-rate rise."
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2 percent, to 10,789.84; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 2 percent, to 1,327.75, and the Nasdaq climbed slightly, to 2,478.34. Shares were mostly higher overseas. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
A Hand-Me-Down 'Ring' Attracts A Star Director

BYLINE: By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH; Matthew Gurewitsch's most recent article for Arts and Leisure was on Shakespeare in current films.

 BODY:
ONCE again, the Wagnerites are descending on San Francisco for the four-day spiritual adventure that is the "Ring of the Nibelung," offered in four overlapping cycles, beginning on Wednesday. The production, unveiled in 1985, last saw service in 1990. Of the original principals, the Wotan of James Morris remains. Along with the new cast of other gods, giants, dwarves and assorted demigods -- among them, the redoubtable Jane Eaglen as Brunnhilde -- the current edition also introduces a new director, Andrei Serban.
For an original director, in this case Nikolaus Lehnhoff, to hand off a revival, even such an important one as this, is hardly unprecedented. In general, though, the grunt work of remounting the show falls to someone lower on the totem pole, not always with happy results. In 1989, Andrew Porter, then the music critic of The New Yorker, took the Metropolitan Opera to task for entrusting its first full traversals of its latest "Ring" cycle (several seasons in the making) to a lieutenant. Mr. Porter found little to admire in the concept of Otto Schenk, whose name was on the show, but it was the staff director Phebe Berkowitz, the subaltern, who bore the brunt of his indignation. His report ran under the headline "The Berkowitz Ring," a whole world of disapproval folded into the syllables of her surname. 
 Given how large the "Ring" looms in a director's resume and how great a reputation Mr. Serban enjoys in his own right, his willingness to accept a hand-me-down seems surprising in the extreme. Caught by telephone between rehearsals in San Francisco, he could only agree.
"I surprised myself by saying yes," Mr. Serban said. "I've never done anything like this before and will never again. But I thought, how often in life is one offered a 'Ring'?"
It was mid-May, with opening night just three weeks off. Mr. Morris had begun rehearsals only the day before. Ms. Eaglen would not arrive for another week. Deborah Voigt, the Sieglinde, would cut it even closer -- but then, she appears only in "Die Walkure," the second day of the "Ring." Yet Mr. Serban, who has never seen a complete "Ring" cycle in the opera house, had been operating at full tilt for several weeks with artists of the second cast (scheduled to sing in the third cycle): Jeffrey Wells and Alan Held, sharing the role of Wotan, devious chieftain of the gods; Frances Ginzer as his disobedient daughter Brunnhilde. In a given day, Mr. Serban said, he might work on "Das Rheingold" in the morning, "Die Walkure" in the afternoon and "Siegfried" in the evening: a sequence he likened to "Hamlet,""King Lear" and "A Midsummer Night's Dream."
"I'm as innocent in this as Siegfried was, but I hope I'll be a little more victorious than he," Mr. Serban said. "I spent six months preparing to do this production, but it's in rehearsal that I discover. Right now, I'm working like a doctor for a Broadway show. Every day, the assistants -- a separate set for each opera, a whole battalion -- show me the blocking as it used to be done. I watch and immediately see possibilities. Then I start interfering. By the end of rehearsal, the physical shape the scene takes is 95 to 100 percent different from what it used to be."
What of the visuals? In good post-modern fashion, John Conklin's original designs incorporated multiple strands of reference. The four parts of the cycle were tied to the four seasons, from a "Rheingold" primavera to an icebound "Gotterdammerung." The architecture took up monumental motifs of the 19th century. Much of this, Mr. Serban disclosed, will disappear. Mr. Conklin, according to the tape on his answering machine, was off on a new project in Sydney, Australia. Responsibility for revised sets and costumes lies with Robert Perziola, but as Mr. Serban made clear, funds for any major overhaul are not there.
"Reminiscences of the Conklin sets will remain, but the whole will be much, much simpler," Mr. Serban promised. "Sometimes, budget permitting, I've tried to bring in a different look. We're trying to purify what seemed to me overcharged and overcrowded."
Following the lead of Patrice Che reau and his centennial "Ring" for the festival at Bayreuth, which opened in 1876 with the premiere of the master's maximum opus, Mr. Lehnhoff and Mr. Conklin refracted the material through a sort of Marxist prism, emphasizing the economic and political conflict. (The concept was not new. George Bernard Shaw made the case for it before the turn of the 20th century.) Thus, as first conceived, the San Francisco "Ring" took its place proudly within a recognized intellectual tradition.
Mr. Serban knows his theater history and does not mind acknowledging his predecessors. "Why hide an influence?" he asked. "Being influenced, you bring in something of your own." On his watch, however, the priorities are more intuitive than theoretical. "Concept is not what I'm after, ever," he said. "What I'm after is a moment of living experience." Mr. Serban speaks as a disciple of that guru and seeker of theatrical essences Peter Brook, with whom he spent a formative season in 1971.
ASUBSEQUENT experiment has particular application to Mr. Serban's more recent excursions into opera. His celebrated "Fragments of a Trilogy" presented scenes from Greek tragedy in forgotten (and, in effect, invented) tongues -- incomprehensible except as the actors charged their lines with sharp, specific emotion. And so they did, keening, howling, stabbing with sarcasm, unstrung with woe. This quasi-operatic use of the voice was married to a detailed language of theatrical movement and gesture.
In Mr. Serban's experience, singers are not always apt to use the full arsenal of a nonsinging actor. "They think music alone expresses the drama, but that's not true," Mr. Serban said. "It has to happen through you. That's why the body is so important."
On their first day of rehearsal together, Mr. Serban reports, Mr. Morris (who in a decade and a half has portrayed Wotan for directors of every persuasion) found himself perplexed. "During the long monologue with Brunnhilde, for instance, he's used to sitting on the throne for a long, long time, longer than I thought it should be in a realistic telling." Mr. Serban explained. "I offered suggestions, and he said, 'But I've never done this.' I said, 'Is that bad?' And he said he would have to take it home and think about it. Tomorrow we may have a completely different solution."
It is unlikely, however, that Mr. Morris will wind up back on his throne, internalizing all his inner turmoil. "Physical action is a continuation of the music," Mr. Serban said. "It completes the connection. If I can make a moment of union between music and drama, and can make the singers really be completely alive on the stage, with a new energy, a new dynamic quality: if I can do that, I've already done my job. The symbolism will take care of itself."
Especially, Mr. Serban finds, in Wagner. "In Verdi or Mozart, what goes on in the orchestra is always so much better than what goes on onstage," Mr. Serban said. "It's hard to create an image on the stage with the same power as the incredible music in the orchestra. But in Wagner, a change of tempo or a crescendo will prompt me to show something in the relationship between the characters. What's in the orchestra is so absolutely logical. It's a musical narrative. It's epic music. It tells you what to do."
The creator draws the map, in other words. All the performers need to do is take the journey. In this conviction, Mr. Serban stands apart not only from Mr. Lehnhoff, whose staging of an opera is commentary made visible, but also from Zen masters like Robert Wilson, who create parallel events that converge with the score only incidentally (or in the eye of the beholder). Thus, whether the outward differences between earlier editions of the Lehnhoff "Ring" and its latest revival turn out to be as conspicuous as they look to the director or so subtle as to go unnoticed -- after all, no one has seen this show in nine years -- the results will have been achieved by a fundamentally different process.
"Kinder, schafft Neues," Wagner urged his disciples late in life: Children, create something new. What exactly he had in mind has been much debated (though he certainly did not mean that they should leave his own works behind). The injunction has become the motto of iconoclastic directors itching to leave their mark on what may well be the most protean allegory in the Western canon.
"I would never put my signature on this production," Mr. Serban said with becoming modesty. In the brochures, his name appears below those of the production's originators. Yet in spirit, he is making a fresh start. And therein lies the promise of something new. A Serban "Ring," perhaps? No irony intended.

SECTION: Section 14WC;Page 1;Column 2;Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1748 words

HEADLINE: New Arts Space Keeps Faith With White Plains

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE Westchester Arts Council has had many homes here: a cramped second-story walkup, the balcony of a train station, a converted armory, a corporate high-rise and a quaint Victorian house, isolated amid a sea of parking lots in the backyard of the business district. Now the council, a private, nonprofit organization serving hundreds of arts groups, artists and schools, has settled into its latest White Plains headquarters: a historic bank building in the slow-paced heart of the city.
The move represents far more than a change in location for the 34-year-old organization. It also symbolizes the hope, one of many, for the revitalization of downtown White Plains; specifically, the council hopes that the building, which it calls the Arts Exchange, will attract artists to the city center and that others will follow. 
 Gone are the cramped spaces, dark hallways and remoteness of former venues. This eight-story, 55,000-square-foot building, formerly owned by Chase Manhattan Bank, sits on Mamaroneck Avenue near the corner of Main Street. It is easy to find and even easier to see as it stretches toward the sky, dwarfing its neighbors. Built in 1928 in quasi-Colonial style, with details like brass doors and stone scrolls, the building offers sweeping views of a green and varied landscape.
"I look out and see downtown White Plains," said Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the arts council, who moved into her third-floor corner office in March. "It's like being in an urban loft in any of the great cities."
Never mind that the neighborhood has been deteriorating for years, plagued by problems similar to those facing other cities around the country. The failure of Mamaroneck Avenue to thrive has been attributed to malls like The Westchester, the departure of Macy's and the frustrations of downtown parking, among other things. If there is a bright spot, it is that prime real estate like the Chase Manhattan building, which was empty for 18 months, provided a rare chance for the arts council to fulfill its dream of becoming a true center for artists in the county's hub.
The bank sold the building to the arts group earlier this year for its market value, $1.35 million, according to Richard O. Jones, a senior vice president of Chase Manhattan and an arts council board member. Under the terms of the agreement, the council will not pay interest or principal on the mortgage for five years while the group seeks financing.
A plan to rent studios, workshops and offices to artists and arts-related businesses is related to an "arts incubator" model established in cities like New Orleans, Harrisburg, Pa., and San Jose, Calif., where low-cost or subsidized spaces and services have generated jobs and revenues for their regions.
First, however, there was the reality: an old building in need of much work. "We got the privilege of buying this building because there were so many things wrong with it," Ms. Langsam joked recently, as construction workers readied the place for its opening event, which was last Friday. The director said she was elated but weary from overseeing electrical and plumbing repairs and other construction work. The work is proceeding with a state grant of $550,000, as well as with a $150,000 loan from Chase Manhattan. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano said the grant recognized the arts council's key role in developing the $54.2 million arts industry in Westchester.
More than 150 artists dodged ladders and debris recently as they transformed six floors of the building into a temporary art gallery. The council decided to open the center Friday night with a fund-raising party for the council's education programs. The event offered Westchester artists an opportunity to gather and sell their work in studio space for the weekend, with 10 percent of sales earmarked for the arts council.
The artists, working in all media, responded to a countywide call for work from Rosemary Cohane Erph, an independent curator. For once on the competitive art scene, Ms. Erph said, since the goal was to be inclusive, the council rejected virtually no work. She coordinated the exhibition, reserving whole rooms for some artists and designating wall spaces for others.
The building was awash in denim as artists, carrying hammers and hooks and lugging their stretched canvases, sculptures and installation pieces, trooped in over a 10-day period to sweep floors, touch up walls and hang their works. Artists who usually labor in isolated studios said they enjoyed the camaraderie as well as the wide open spaces of the light-filled, nearly empty building. (Besides the arts council offices, which occupy one floor, some space is rented to the Alliance Francaise.) Some artists used leftover bank furniture as part of their installations. A sign saying, "Teller training, 6th floor," was still taped to a table.
The artwork is scheduled to be on exhibit for only a night and a day. Arle Sklar-Weinstein of Hastings-on-Hudson stood in a doorway, shaking her head. "This is the equivalent of having a three-week show somewhere," she said, speaking of the effort it took to hang her nearly six-foot tall fabric diptych and other pieces in a room of her own. Not that Ms. Sklar-Weinstein, who combines the traditional art of quilt-making with cutting-edge digital imagery, was complaining. Her room had one dark green suede-like wall, left over from bank days, which provided the perfect foil for her exhibition, "Cave Walls."
"It's very exciting to see these pieces up all at once," she said. "You rarely get a chance to spread it all out like this."
On the first floor, Joe Harris, a Croton-on-Hudson photographer who won the council's 1998 Heathcote Award, was preparing the former main banking room, with its teller's counter, vault area and large clerestory windows, for his exhibition: "Red, White, Black and Blue: A Visual Guide to Slang." Upstairs, Barbara Segal, a Yonkers sculptor who works primarily with stone, positioned her provocative bronze bustiers on a wall.
Another artist, Mary Ann Lomonaco of Larchmont, explained why she had bothered to set up a major show of her handmade paper and fabric works for such a brief show. "The arts council has been quite good to me, so I wanted to be supportive," Ms. Lomonaco said, surveying the group of tribal-like headdresses she had fashioned from kitchen mops. Also, she said, she wanted feedback on her latest work.
Some artists compared the scene with Soho, their eyes gleaming as they envisioned future possibilities. They said they were inspired by the 12-foot-high ceilings, the acres of white walls and the rough, unfinished floors, which had been stripped of five layers of carpeting to rid them of asbestos tiles.
Larry Frankel, a photographer from Harrison who seams together images in 360-degree views, said the building offered a "more vibrant arena" for viewing than the usual gallery.
Margalit Mannor, a photographer whose mysterious abstractions of envelopes have been exhibited in Israel as well as the United States, foresaw a genuine artists' colony, where people working under the same roof would draw creative sustenance from each other. Smiling at the bustling scene around her, Ms. Margalit, who lives in Scarsdale, said there was "a touch of madness" -- madness of the most fertile sort -- about it.
Ms. Langsam, a former painter, appeared frazzled but excited as she supervised the work. The council hopes to rent out a substantial number of offices and studios in the coming months; that means, the director said, that the exhibition extravaganza might never happen again. "This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, because the building hasn't been rented yet," she said. "It's like filling a department store with art."
 
A Long-Term Vision For Transforming Center
THE opening this weekend of the Arts Exchange, as the Westchester Arts Council calls the bank building it now owns on Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, is also the start of a 10-year project, Janet T. Langsam, the council's executive director, said.
"We'd like to see a building that's similar to other artists' projects around the country," she said, citing a former torpedo factory in Alexandria, Va., which has been converted to artists' studios, as well as a former cable factory in Helsinki, which is serving the same purpose. "We feel up to it, but it's not going to happen overnight."
Eventually, Ms. Langsam said, she hoped the eight-story building would be filled with rehearsal spaces, areas for poetry readings and performances of works-in-progress, exhibition and meeting spaces and, perhaps, lofts where artists will live as well as work. The council envisions shared resources, like printing presses, video editing equipment and a photography laboratory, which would help cut costs for individual artists and groups.
Another goal is converting the main floor of the former bank, with its high ceiling and high, arched windows, into a gallery.
The council's immediate goal, however, is to make the building -- with its $180,000 in maintenance costs a year -- self-sustaining by the end of the year, Ms. Langsam said. The group plans to achieve this by renting space on a short-term basis to profit-making organizations that may be unrelated to the arts. "We'll do this so we can afford to rent artists the space they need at an affordable price," she said, adding that many artists and groups had already approached her.
Each floor of the 55,000-square-foot building contains 5,700 square feet of usable space, divided into rooms ranging from 250 to 1,250 square feet. The current plan is to charge artists $10 a square foot, nonprofit groups $12 a square foot and profit-making groups $14 to $16 a square foot, Ms. Langsam said. "If someone wants to come in and take a floor, we wouldn't say no," she added. "We're on the third floor, and there are five more floors we'd like to lease out. If we can lease three floors this year, that would be a good goal."
Many music, dance and drama organizations constantly seek rehearsal space in the county, paying hefty prices for professional space or accommodating themselves to awkward schedules and cramped quarters in schools and churches. Ms. Langsam said one of the council's first priorities would be to develop rehearsal spaces for use by groups, first-come-first-served. "We'll have to develop a policy for rental space both per diem and for the long term," she said. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 2; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Their Man in Havana

BYLINE: By Carl Hiaasen; Carl Hiaasen is a columnist for The Miami Herald. His new novel, "Sick Puppy," will be published next year.

 BODY:

HAVANA BAY
 By Martin Cruz Smith.
 329 pp. New York:
 Random House. $24.95. 
 ARUSSIAN police detective, forlorn over the death of his wife, decides to kill himself. Yet he wishes to do so privately and tidily, in such a style as not to trouble his friends and colleagues in Moscow. So he chooses sunny, faraway Cuba for his suicide -- a story line worthy of Chekhov. Except that the grief-stricken detective is Arkady Renko, the taciturn hero of "Gorky Park" and "Polar Star," and the Havana that is to be his final destination is nothing like what Chekhov would have imagined. Cuba is tropical, to be sure, and exotically mysterious -- yet also in its way as maddeningly impenetrable and bleak as Moscow frozen into winter.
Renko has been sent to Havana to identify the body of a friend, a Russian Embassy employee found floating in an inner tube. Sergei Pribluda supposedly died of a heart ailment while fishing in the bay, but Renko is politely doubtful. Cuban authorities welcome him to the case as if he were the proverbial cockroach on a wedding cake. Russians were never a beloved presence on the island, but (Renko quickly learns) they have become openly despised since Moscow cut off the gusher of subsidies that had floated Fidel Castro's regime for decades.
Even Yankee imperialists are treated better than Russians in Havana, for at least the Americans bring cash -- and the Cuban economy in Fidel's waning days has become voraciously dependent on United States dollars, an irony that Renko has little time to ponder. He has, after all, come here to kill himself.
It's not the way many novelists would bring back their most popular character -- teetering bleakly on the abyss -- but after a one-book absence we are selfishly happy to see Renko again, in any state of mind, and we are grateful when his suicide attempt is rudely interrupted by a would-be assassin. The vicious and seemingly senseless attack rekindles Renko's professional curiosity. He shelves his gloomy plan for self-destruction and sets off to discover why somebody (besides himself) wants him dead.
It's a richly intricate mystery, made more compelling by its setting. There might be no other city in our time as simultaneously intoxicating and heartbreaking as Old Havana, and Martin Cruz Smith's panorama is both dazzling and dead-on depressing. "This is the first place where time does not exist," a disillusioned ballerina tells Renko. "People have been born and died, yes, but time has not passed because time demands fresh paint, new cars, new clothes."
The Russian's tour guide up and down the Malecon is a wary young Cuban detective, Ofelia Osorio. She is a cool delight, the best of many memorable characters. Loyal to Fidel and the revolution, Osorio will hear none of it when Renko uncovers evidence linking Pribluda's death to a scheme by Castro's Government to defraud Russia of $20 million in a sugar deal. But gradually Osorio softens toward the dogged Renko, and her investigative cleverness leads her to the same trails, if not to the same conclusions. There is indeed a secret plot, but it's much bigger than a sugar scam and involves two shadowy expatriate Americans -- a former airplane hijacker and a Robert Vesco-like fugitive -- and ultimately the Comandante himself.
It is not so farfetched. Vesco himself fled to Cuba, wheeling and dealing until he fell out of favor with Fidel. In 1996 he was convicted of "economic crimes" and sentenced to 13 years in prison. That the hemisphere's most defiantly die-hard Communist would have opened his doors to a capitalist swindler is perversely fitting. Cuba remains a land of boggling contradictions and contrasts. At night the local fishermen, or neumticos, paddle leaky inner tubes into shark-patrolled waters, grateful to snag the scrawniest snapper. Nearby at the Marina Hemingway, wealthy American marlin fishermen puff on Montecristos and salsa with teen-age prostitutes aboard million-dollar yachts.
As one of the visiting anglers confides to Renko, the last thing in the world he wants is for the United States to lift its economic embargo. "Cuba is cheap, beautiful, grateful. Take away the embargo and it'll be 'nother Florida in a year." Such vulgar dichotomies are noted by Renko, but unlike many novelistic sleuths he has never been a moralizer or a wit. He is a pure solver of crimes, vaccinated against irony, wonderment and even outrage by too long a career at the bottom of a suffocating and corrupt bureaucracy.
In fact, his earnest unsentimentality and calm tenaciousness on the hunt are what make Renko one of the most interesting detectives in modern fiction. What a clever stroke for Smith to dispatch him to Havana, where sentimentality and passion are in rare abundance.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 6, 1999

SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2943 words

HEADLINE: NEW ENGLAND;
A Sandy Stage For Many A Character

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS; MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS writes frequently about the arts.

 BODY:
IN the summer of 1915, World War I rendered Europe a risky destination for American artists who considered the expatriate experience an essential rite of passage. That summer, many artists and writers, including an obscure young playwright named Eugene O'Neill, instead sought exile in Provincetown, Mass. They were drawn to the tip of Cape Cod by Provincetown's pure northern light, the raven-haired exoticism of its Portuguese fishing population and, perhaps most importantly, cheap rent.
Artists had been a major presence in Provincetown since the 1870's, but they had not begun shaping the town's character until Charles Hawthorne opened his Cape Cod School of Art in 1899. Hawthorne, who had taught at the Art Students League of New York, attracted students from Manhattan and throughout the Northeast. They pitched their easels on the dunes outside town, where onlookers often gathered to watch the master and his students dash off quick oils and watercolors of seascapes and fishing life. 
 This summer, commemorating the opening of Hawthorne's school, Provincetown celebrates the centennial of its establishment as an arts colony. Most observances of the centennial, however, refer more directly to the exuberant Modernists, including Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko, who began taking over the town's art scene after World War I, and flourished from the 1930's to the 1950's. But these days, the starving artists of old are a rarer part of the Provincetown community, whose economy now is kept alive by the money of summer tourists, especially gays and lesbians.
I visited Provincetown in mid-May, when the village was still shaking off its winter slumber. By Memorial Day, the summer season begins, blazing with strangeness and freedom. The streets are packed with a mix of drag queens on six-inch heels, families on day trips from Boston, spandex-clad men from New York traveling in packs, and lesbian couples pushing babies in strollers. On busy weekends, Provincetown's official population of 4,000 can swell to 50,000 or more.
Getting the most out of a Provincetown visit requires plenty of walking, mostly along the main thoroughfare, Commercial Street. Parking is scarce, so even if you drive to the Cape, you're best off leaving the car at your guest house or motel. I rented a bicycle as insurance against blisters.
First stop was lunch at Clem & Ursie's Food Ghetto, a high-end clam shack on Shank Painter Road and the best seafood bargain in town -- a steamed lobster was about $10. Then it was off to the beach.
At the end of Snail Road, just across Route 6, I locked my bicycle to a fence and followed a well-worn but unmarked trail for 45 minutes over the dunes to the outer beach, on the Atlantic Ocean. To the left of the end of the trail, unmarked, is the former site of the Peaked Hill Life Saving Station, which replaced Eugene O'Neill's first home in Provincetown after it was washed down the beach by erosion.
O'Neill is probably Provincetown's most spectacular success story. He arrived and produced his first plays here in 1916, in a theater on the wharf that used the surf and sky for its sets; nine years later, he left town the most famous playwright in America, Pulitzer Prize in hand.
After his departure in 1925, he rented his house to Edmund Wilson, who had come to the Cape to pursue his beloved Edna St. Vincent Millay, a resident of nearby Truro. When Millay spurned him, Wilson drowned his sorrows in gin-soaked house parties with such friends as E.E. Cummings and John Dos Passos before the place was destroyed by a hard winter storm in 1931.
Nothing on the dunes remains to commemorate O'Neill or his house but the setting that inspired him -- the lunar white sand, fresh wind blowing over the Atlantic, and the comforting whisper of the incoming waves -- a clean, elemental landscape that can't help but give rise to creation.
For most of the last 30 years, Provincetown theater has been pretty quiet. This summer, however, several local troupes plan to revive this aspect of Provincetown's artistic history, with productions including a new musical by Edward Gorey, a 20th-anniversary production of "Torch Song Trilogy" and a revival of "The Glass Menagerie, which Tennessee Williams wrote in Provincetown.
After sitting on the dunes awhile with "On the Road" by Jack Kerouac, another writer who spent time writing on these beaches, I bicycled back to the center of town, where I climbed the hill to the Pilgrim Monument. The 252-foot granite tower, modeled after the Torre del Mangia in Siena, was dedicated in 1910 to mark the Pilgrims' first landfall in America, which took place here on Nov. 11, 1620 -- five weeks before their more famous landing at Plymouth.
At the monument's base, the Provincetown Museum features excellent exhibits on the Pilgrims (including one about the Mayflower Compact, the first document of American democracy, which was written before the Pilgrims' debarkation), the whaling and fishing industries that thrived here in the 19th century, and the history of theater and painting in town. It's an archetype of the small-town museum, pridefully crammed with quirky exhibits like 19th-century shell mosaics that sailors sent home as valentines ("Happiness Be Thine," declares one) and a collection of stuffed birds and mammals bequeathed by a Provincetown native, Donald Baxter MacMillan, who accompanied Robert E. Peary on his first successful trip to the North Pole.
The monument itself takes about 10 minutes to climb at a moderate clip. Its 116 stairs, mostly at the beginning and the end, are not steep, and the climb is made fairly easy on the legs by 60 connecting ramps. Breathtaking views from the top of the monument show the curl of the Cape. I was there on a very clear day, and even though the museum shop proprietor said it couldn't be so, I could have sworn I saw Boston's skyscrapers rising like the Emerald City 47 miles across Massachusetts Bay.
From the monument, I coasted on my bicycle back down to Commercial Street and stopped at the Portuguese Bakery for a croissant filled with linguica, the Portuguese sausage, and cheese, and a lemon custard tart called pastel de nata. Better comfort food was never had for $3.50.
I was staying at a guest house, the effusively elegant Brass Key. Its compound of Cape bungalows surround two heated pools, set in an impeccably manicured garden. The best rooms go for about $300 a night at the height of summer but can be had for $135 during the shoulder season -- April, May, September and October. I took a nap in my gigantic dark walnut Victorian bed, in anticipation of an evening out.
Ground zero of Provincetown night life is the Atlantic House, a large, rambling nightclub that has served as a courthouse, stagecoach stop and hotel since its construction in 1798. Like most of Provincetown's other clubs (the Boatslip, the Pied and Antro are among the most popular), the Atlantic House is primarily a gay bar. But the night I went, there were a fair number of straight couples and lesbians dancing under strobe lights early in the evening, around 10. By midnight, the place was mostly shirtless men with chiseled, creatine-inflated torsos.
Since the middle of this century, Provincetown has been among the most popular gay vacation spots in America. Today, a majority of homeowners are affluent summer residents from out of state -- a situation that brings huge infusions of cash here during the high season but leaves the local economy dead in the winter. Skyrocketing real estate and lack of year-round employment opportunities now make it increasingly difficult for struggling artists to afford to live in Provincetown.
For better or worse, this summer promises to be hopping. Townsfolk are predicting record-setting tourist traffic because of a new high-speed ferry service that runs two daily round trips from Boston, making a crossing in 1 hour 55 minutes (compared to three hours on the old ferry, which makee one round-trip a day). The new ferry, run by the Bay State Cruise Company, offers on-board videos, an air-conditioned deck and serves chowder and other light fare.
But shaving that extra hour off the trip involves some sacrifice. The ferry's sterile lower deck is blighted by metallic mirrored ceiling panels and garish multicolored carpets, and its upper deck is crowded with charmless molded metal benches. By contrast, if you have the time, the older ferry's varnished hardwood benches and massive, open top deck give passengers a seafaring foretaste of the free and easy feeling they'll find when they amble down the wharf to Commercial Street.
My second day in Provincetown started with a breakfast of eggs, homemade granola and delicious blueberry muffins at Cafe Heaven, where jazzy psychedelic murals of bosomy, Botero-inspired women woke me with even more of a charge than my cup of coffee.
Thus fueled, I cycled to 627 Commercial Street in the far East End for a look at the home of Provincetown's most famous living writer, Norman Mailer. (Mary Oliver and Stanley Kunitz are also residents of the area.) Mr. Mailer's is one of the few brick homes in town, a squat, solid, motley blend of Cape, Colonial and contemporary.
I spent most of the day wandering through galleries and shops on Commercial Street, lingering longest in galleries at the Fine Arts Work Center, the Provincetown Art Association and the Schoolhouse Center for Art and Design. The Provincetown Art Association has a strong collection of art from the Hawthorne era and from the days of Hans Hoffman's Summer School of Art, which opened in 1935. Hoffman's students, including Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko, mounted the first American exhibit of Abstract Expressionist art in Provincetown in 1949. The Art Association will stage an approximate re-creation of the 1949 exhibit this July.
At the Fine Arts Work Center, I found edgier expressions of Provincetown's current artistic renaissance. The center, managed with entrepreneurial rigor by Hunter O'Hanian, provides stipends, studios and free accommodations to 20 writers and artists each year, and shows artists' work in a funky raw space in a former lumberyard. The center also accepts applications for a series of reasonably priced summer writing and art workshops, taught this year by Michael Cunningham, Grace Paley, Michael Mazur and Paul Bowen, among others.
The Schoolhouse Center is interesting and appealing -- an old-fashioned atelier, with painting, music and theater studio space on the second floor, and two large public galleries on the first floor. The exhibit I saw was an anonymous group show of vintage snapshots -- somewhere between creative contrivance and found art.
I also asked to see some images that will be included in shows scheduled later this summer, including photographs of Provincetown by Fred W. McDarrah, the veteran photo editor of The Village Voice. The highlight of the Schoolhouse season, however, promises to be a show of prints by 76-year-old Paula Kotis whose commercial photography appeared in Vogue and Ebony in the 1950's. Most of her work -- European street scenes and portraits of Jewish Holocaust survivors -- has never been publicly shown. Her vintage silver prints have sat in boxes in her basement for the better part of 40 years.
When my eyes got tired, I stuck my head into a few of Provincetown's extraordinary shops and boutiques, though there are plenty of kitschy souvenir shops on Commercial Street. Dirty White Boy and MAP carry Provincetown's best selections of men's club wear, including both original designs and labels like Tom of Finland, Diesel and Dolce & Gabbana. Daniel Cleary's made-to-order knit sportswear in luxurious fabrics will make you feel like you stole the shirt off Cary Grant's back.
Around sunset, I had dinner at Chester, a soothing restaurant in the east end of Provincetown. In a 19th-century Greek Revival captain's house decorated with paintings by local artists (including a portrait of the eponymous Chester, the restaurant owners' Airedale terrier), I savored an appetizer of oyster stew and tender veal chop with a side of perfectly creamy wild mushroom polenta.
Down at the end of the wharf, I rested on a pile of fishing nets and looked back at the town and the Pilgrim Monument, under a sky full of stars and possibility.
 
Day and night, much to do in a small town
Information on travel, lodging and activities is available from the Provincetown Chamber of Commerce, Post Office Box 1017, 307 Commercial Street, Provincetown, Mass. 02657, (508) 467-3424. Two Web sites, www.provincetown.com and www
.provincetown.net, also offer information.
 
Transportation
The Bay State Cruise Company, (617) 748-1428, runs two ferries between Boston and Provincetown. The older, larger ferry takes three hours, leaving Boston at 9 A.M. and returning at 3:30 P.M.; $30 round trip. A new high-speed ferry takes 1 hour 55 minutes, leaving Boston at 8 A.M. and 4 P.M., and returning at 10:30 A.M. and 6:30 P.M.; $75 round trip. Bicycle passes are $5 each way.
Bicycles can be rented at Ptown Bikes, 42 Bradford Street, (508) 487-8735. Daily rentals range from $10 to $14, including locks and maps.
 
Where to Stay
In-Town Reservations, (800) 677-8696, and Provincetown Reservations System, (800) 648-0364, can arrange lodging in many guesthouses, as well as longer rentals of private homes or condominiums.
The most luxurious accommodations in town are at The Brass Key, 67 Bradford Street, (800) 842-9858, fax (508) 487-9020. It has 33 rooms for $195 to $375 in summer, including Continental breakfast and a beer-and-wine hour.
Land's End Inn, 22 Commercial Street, (800) 276-7088, is a glorious Edwardian full of antiques. It has 17 rooms, a gigantic porch, gardens and water views. Summer rates of $125 to $285 include Continental breakfast.
The Meadows Motel and Cottages,122 Bradford Street Extension, (888) 675-0880, fax (508) 487-4691, has 20 rooms, for $65 to $75 a night. It's not air-conditioned, and there are no room phones or pool, but it's close to the beach, quiet and clean.
 
Where to Eat
Chester, 404 Commercial Street, (508) 487-8200, serves a changing menu of seasonal American cuisine, featuring local seafood and lamb, and has an extensive wine list, mostly under $45. Dinner for two with wine costs about $110.
Cafe Heaven, 199 Commercial Street, (508) 487-9639, serves homemade muffins and granola for breakfast. Plain omelets cost $4.25. Open for lunch and dinner; overstuffed sandwiches cost $5.25 to $7.
Clem & Ursie's Food Ghetto, 89 Shank Painter Road, (508) 487-2333, serves inexpensive seafood (a sea clam pot pie is $6.50 and a choice of rolls generously filled with scallop, lobster or squid start at $5.99) in a relaxed atmosphere. Lunch for two costs under $20. Open daily for lunch and dinner.
The Portuguese Bakery, 299 Commercial Street, (508) 487-1803, offers over 60 kinds of pastries and light meals, and is open in summer till 11 P.M.
 
What to Do
Cape Cod National Seashore maintains more than eight miles of bicycle trails, about half of which is pretty strenuous. Maps are available at Provincelands Visitors Center, Race Point Road, Provincetown, (508) 487-1256, which also has natural- and cultural-history exhibits and issues beach fire permits.
Popular whale watch cruises are run by Dolphin Fleet, (800) 826-9300 ($19 and $16), and the Portuguese Princess, (508) 487-2651 ($16 to $20).
Pilgrim Monument and Provincetown Museum, High Pole Hill Road, is open 9 A.M. to either 5 or 7 P.M. Admission is $5, $3 ages 4 to 12.
The Atlantic House, 4-6 Masonic Place, (508) 487-3821, open nightly, is a club with three different areas. The crowd is somewhat mixed, but mostly gay men. The cover in the main club, where deejays play music, ranges from $5 to $10; the two other bars are free.
Vixen, 336 Commercial Street, (508) 487-6424, where the crowd is largely lesbian, has a bar with two pool tables and an espresso bar that is quiet enough for conversation. The back has a large dance floor, and there is live entertainment several nights a week. Cover is about $10.
The first annual Provincetown International Film Festival, June 18 to 20, features An Evening With John Waters, including the world premiere of the director's cut of his 1974 film "Female Trouble." Tickets cost $15, other screenings $5 and $8. Tickets: (800) 648-0364.
Provincetown Repertory Theater, (508) 487-5600, will offer "The Trip to Bountiful" (June 15 to July 3), "The Glass Menagerie" (July 15 to Aug. 8), "Goreyphobia" (Aug. 17 to Sept. 11), and "Barbara Cook in Concert" (Aug. 28). Tickets are $19 for the plays, $50 for the concert.
The American Theater Company's 20th-anniversary production of "Torch Song Trilogy" runs Thursday to Sunday, July 22 to Aug. 22 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall Theater. Tickets: $25 to $30, from (800) 648-0364.
The Fine Arts Work Center, 24 Pearl Street, (508) 487-9960, www
.CapeCodAccess.com/FineArts
WorkCenter, will exhibit work from the town's collection in a Centennial show July 1 to 19. Open weekdays 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Free.
Schoolhouse Center for Art and Design, 494 Commercial Street, (508) 487-4800, is open Friday to Sunday noon to 9 P.M. and Monday noon to 6 P.M., and in July and August 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily except Thursday.
The Provincetown Art Association and Museum, 460 Commercial Street, (508) 487-1750, is open daily noon to 5 P.M. and 8 to 10 P.M. Suggested donation is $3. A retrospective of Charles W. Hawthorne, founder of the Cape Cod School of Art, runs Aug. 20 to Oct. 31. MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS

HEADLINE: NEW ENGLAND;
A Sandy Stage For Many A Character

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS; MICHAEL JOSEPH GROSS writes frequently about the arts.

 BODY:
