SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Find Shortcuts to Federal Appeals by State Inmates Unacceptable

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
The Supreme Court shut the door tighter today on state inmates' access to Federal court, ruling that prisoners who have not first appealed to their state's highest court forfeit their right to Federal court review even if it was evident that the state appeal would be fruitless.
Under the Federal law governing habeas corpus -- constitutional review of a conviction or sentence -- a state inmate must first "have exhausted the remedies available in the courts of the state" before seeking a Federal court's assistance. The question for the Justices today, in a case from Illinois, was whether the available remedies that must first be exhausted include an appeal to a state high court where the criteria for selecting cases make it virtually certain that the inmate's case will not even be heard. 
 The 6-to-3 decision overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. That court held last year that because the Illinois Supreme Court's rules were clearly intended to discourage the filing of routine criminal appeals, it would be unfair to penalize prisoners who try to follow those rules by going directly to Federal court. In 1997, the Illinois Supreme Court reviewed only 33 of 1,072 criminal cases, a ratio roughly similar to the Justices' own rate of granting cases.
All convicted defendants in Illinois are guaranteed the right to an initial appeal before an intermediate court. The inmate in this case, Darren Boerckel, a convicted rapist, had raised six issues for appeal before the intermediate court, but presented only three of them to the Illinois Supreme Court. The Seventh Circuit ruled that the Federal District Court in Peoria could nonetheless consider all six.
Writing for the majority today, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that as a matter of Federal-state relations, as long as a state has given its supreme court the choice to review a case, Federal courts should require that state inmates make use of the available process so that the state court has a chance to exercise its discretionary jurisdiction. Any issues not raised in the state supreme court should be considered defaulted, she said. If the state declines to hear a case, the inmate can then appeal to Federal court.
The principle Justice O'Connor invoked was the doctrine of "comity," an aspect of federalism meaning that the Federal Government should respect state institutions.
"This rule of comity reduces friction between the state and Federal court systems by avoiding the unseemliness of a Federal district court's overturning a state court conviction without the state courts having had an opportunity to correct the constitutional violation in the first instance," Justice O'Connor said.
For nearly 20 years, the Court has been invoking federalism principles to cut back on the Federal courts' ability, through granting writs of habeas corpus, to review the quality of justice being administered by the states.
But the dissenters today, Justices John Paul Stevens, Stephen B. Breyer and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, objected that comity really supported the opposite result in this case, O'Sullivan v. Boerckel, No. 97-2048. If a state high court made it clear that it did not want to be burdened with routine appeals, Justice Stevens said in an opinion the other two dissenters also signed, then Federal courts should not adopt a rule that has the effect of forcing inmates to add to this unwanted burden.
"Most ironically," Justice Stevens said, the Court's decision "will undermine federalism by thwarting the interests of those state supreme courts that administer discretionary dockets."
Justice O'Connor's majority opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, Clarence Thomas and David H. Souter. Justice Souter also wrote a concurring opinion to say state supreme courts could insulate themselves from the impact of the decision by issuing more precise rules about the kinds of appeals they wanted to deflect to the Federal courts and did not want to hear themselves.
As the Court's momentum seemed to flag with less than a month to go in term, there were also these other developments today:
 
Methane Gas Ownership
The Court ruled that Federal laws dating to early in the century, which gave the Government ownership of coal found under millions of acres of Western land, did not apply to the methane gas that is also found in the coal beds. The property owners own the gas, Justice Kennedy said in a 7-to-1 opinion. Justice Ginsburg dissented, and Justice Breyer did not participate.
The decision, Amoco Production Company v. Southern Ute Tribe, No. 98-830, was a victory for a group of energy producers who owned the lands. It overturned a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver. The Government argued unsuccessfully that the Coal Lands Acts of 1909 and 1910 reserved to itself both coal and gas. Justice Kennedy said that was not the intent of Congress, because methane gas was seen at the time as a dangerous and unwanted byproduct, only much later acquiring economic value.
The Southern Ute tribe had been granted the coal rights by the Government and had been seeking ownership of the gas as well.
 
Juvenile Executions
Acting on an appeal by a Nevada death-row inmate who committed a double murder in 1993 at age 16, the Court asked the Clinton Administration for its views on the issue the inmate raised: whether Nevada is bound by an international treaty the United States has signed that bars executing those who committed their crimes before age 18.
President Jimmy Carter signed the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1977. When the Senate ratified it in 1992, it attached a "reservation," at the urging of President George Bush, declining to accept the capital punishment provision. An additional question raised by Michael Domingues, the inmate in this case, Domingues v. Nevada, No. 98-8327, is whether that action was valid.
The Supreme Court ruled in 1989 that the execution of someone who had killed at age 16 did not violate the Constitution.
The Nevada Supreme Court upheld Mr. Domingues's death sentence in 1996. Subsequently, his lawyers filed a new appeal seeking a "correction of illegal sentence." The Nevada Supreme Court rejected that appeal last year by 3-to-2 vote.
The Administration's views, expected next fall, are not binding on the Court, which will eventually make its own decision, if it chooses to hear the case.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The Dow Rises 109.54 Points as Merger News Continues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yesterday, lifted by a brace of merger announcements and an apparent sense that any move by the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates would be a one-time event rather than part of a prolonged tightening of policy.
Paced by Allied Signal, which said it was merging with Honeywell, the Dow Jones industrial average rose for the fifth time in the last six sessions, closing at its highest level since mid-May. 
 Sectors that have been battered recently, including computers, Internet stocks and financial services companies, rebounded, helping to push up broader market averages.
However, trading volume was quite light -- it was the second-slowest day of the year on the New York Stock Exchange -- leading some analysts and traders to question the significance of the rise in prices.
"We are getting a lot of movement on very thin volume," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "From an investment point of view, there is an extraordinary amount of risk in the market. But from a short-term perspective, it looks like people want to trade this thing higher."
By the close, the Dow was up 109.54 points, or 1 percent, at 10,909.38.
Gains in stocks like Dell Computer, American International Group and DuPont pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ahead by 6.77 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,334.52. Weakness in drug stocks like Pfizer and Eli Lilly limited the S.& P.'s advance.
The Nasdaq composite index soared 45.87 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,524.21, propelled by technology stocks. TheStreet.com's Internet index rose 32.41 points, or 5.9 percent, to 583.87. And small-cap stocks did well: the Russell 2000 gained 4.32 points, or 1 percent, to 446.65.
Some traders suggested that the increase in prices was a follow-through from the gains on Friday, after the release of May employment data showing that the nation's labor market remained robust.
But the bond market, which more or less shrugged at the job figures, failed to rally yesterday; traders appear convinced that the Fed will raise rates at the end of the month.
Some analysts were not so sure. "I am pretty clearly in the minority, but I don't expect the Fed to raise rates," said Henry Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Overland Park, Kan., a firm that manages more than $27 billion in assets, adding, "I see too many signs saying there is no inflation."
Financial service stocks, battered by the recent run-up in interest rates, recovered a bit yesterday.
Bank of America, a component of the S.& P. 500, rose 1 3/8, to 66 1/4. American Express, a Dow component, gained 2 3/4, to 128. Merrill Lynch was up 1 5/8 at 73 7/8. And Morgan Stanley Dean Witter jumped 3 1/16, to 94 1/16.
Allied Signal, the leading maker of flight systems, rose 4 7/16, to 62 13/16 after confirming that it would buy Honeywell, the world's largest maker of automated controls, for $14.8 billion in stock, plus the assumption of debt. Honeywell jumped 7, to 112.
Columbia Energy Group jumped 7 7/16, to 63 3/16, after disclosing that it had received a hostile takeover bid of $68 a share from Nisource Inc., a natural gas and electricity company. Nisource shares fell 5/8, to 27 9/16.
Among technology stocks, I.B.M. rose 4 1/2, to 120 1/2, after it announced an $8 billion technology sales agreement with Acer Group of Taiwan. Microsoft, which introduced Office 2000 yesterday, gained 11/16, to 80 1/4. EMC rose 1 13/16, to 53 3/4. Dell Computer rose 1 7/8, to 35 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard gained 3 1/2, to 94.
Internet issues, which have been in a correction phase in recent weeks, recovered some lost ground yesterday. At Home rose 9 1/4, to 103 3/4; Ebay was up 14 3/4 at 183 1/4; Yahoo gained 4 7/16, to 151 7/8, and Amazon.com rose 8 15/16, to 117 3/8.
Drug stocks fell on concern that pharmaceutical companies would be forced to cut prices if the Clinton Administration succeeded in its effort to offer drug benefits to elderly Americans insured through Medicare.
Pfizer fell 4 1/8, to 111; Merck was down 1 5/16 at 69 5/16; Eli Lilly dropped 3 3/8, to 71 7/8, and Schering-Plough was off 1 3/8 at 47 1/2.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries CloseUnchanged After an Early-Session Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Bond prices faltered yesterday after rising earlier in the session for the first time in more than a week as the higher yield level for Treasuries attracted investors.
As a result, at the end of New York trading, the price of the benchmark 30-year bond was unchanged, at 90 5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, remained at 5.96 percent. 
 The covering of short positions in midmorning trading pushed prices to session highs briefly, but concern that the strong economy will ignite inflation and a lack of sustained interest limited those gains.
"The market is also waiting for retail sales, which may well be stronger than the last couple of months and the Consumer Price Index," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "It has built in strong expectations of a near-term Fed tightening."
Referring to the Commerce Department's scheduled release of the Consumer Price Index, Mr. Fine continued, "Even if next week's C.P.I. is nonthreatening, the Fed is still likely to tighten on June 30, irrespective of the May C.P.I. because even a subdued C.P.I. would have to completely reverse market expectations in order to keep the central bank on hold, which is very unlikely."
Adam Blankman, an analyst at Standard & Poor's MMS in San Francisco, puts the chances for a Fed move at slightly less than even. "If you thought the May employment report would provide a clear sense of where the Fed would be headed in the month ahead, then think again," he said. "The data were far from bullish, but there were enough contradictions to prevent Treasuries from extending the recent slide."
Many market participants are already predicting a quarter-point increase and expect this week's economic reports to provide enough incentive for the 30-year bond to test the 6 percent level, though Mr. Blankman thinks that the final outcome will rest with the midmonth Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
"We believe the Fed will wait for a smoking gun to hike rates," Mr. Blankman said.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., said: "It's difficult psychologically to buy today when there is a chance it will be cheaper tomorrow. We have not seen the highest rates for the year yet."
During yesterday's weekly auction of new bills, the three-month bills were awarded at an average rate of 4.51 percent, down from 4.62 percent last week, while the six-month bills were awarded at an average rate of 4.76 percent, a tick higher than 4.75 percent in that same auction a week ago.

HEADLINE: Some Dismay in Honeywell's Hometown

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, June 7

 BODY:
Honeywell Inc.'s merger with Allied Signal would result in the loss of a corporate headquarters here, the loss of up to 1,000 local jobs, and the migration of one of the region's leading philanthropic institutions.
Known in millions of American homes for its thermostats, the company is rooted in the Twin Cities and is renowned here for making generous charitable donations, amounting to about $13.4 million last year. Honeywell said the merged company would maintain its financial commitment to the area, particularly to the low-income neighborhood in which its headquarters is situated. But local officials and civic leaders expressed dismay at news of the merger. 
 In the Phillips neighborhood, where Honeywell is based, and which is perhaps the poorest section of Minneapolis, there was a strong reaction.
"They've always given us grants on a large basis as long as we kept performing the tasks we set out to do," said Anna Bowlds-Perkins, chairwoman of the board of the Phillips Community Development Corporation, a job-training center. She added, "With them leaving, yeah, I think it's going to make a big difference. Their presence is important."
Largely to help bolster the Phillips area, the company established the Honeywell Foundation in 1957, and has funneled most of its charitable donations through the foundation, which will move to New Jersey, said Pearse O'Laughlin, the company's corporate public relations manager.
"The commitments we've made in the Twin Cities will be maintained," Mr. O'Laughlin said. The company, one of the 10 largest in Minnesota, will retain the headquarters building, he said, and continue to be the center of the home and building control division, which includes the thermostat operation.
Of more than 7,000 Honeywell employees in Minnesota, where the general economy is booming, more than 6,000 will remain, he said. The others will transfer to New Jersey or other locations, or be laid off.
Among Honeywell's philanthropic efforts is a high school, called New Vistas, which has operated within the headquarters since 1990. It will continue there, he said. New Vistas provides education to pregnant and teen-age mothers. Already, 142 women have graduated from the school.
Honeywell has also contributed $4.8 million, and thousands of employees donated their labor and helped build 51 new owner-occupied, three- and four-bedroom houses here. So far, 20 of the 51 houses are finished. They cost $60,000 to $90,000 each.
"We've been making dramatic progress," said Peter McLaughlin, a Hennepin County Board member representing the south Minneapolis area, who worked closely with Honeywell on the project. But he added: "Now we're being victimized by larger corporate powers over which we have no control. To lose that capacity is a huge loss for the community."
Amy Phenix, a spokeswoman for Mayor Sharon Sayles Belton of Minneapolis, said the departure of Honeywell would be very disappointing. "Honeywell has been a community partner in the city of Minneapolis," she said. "I think simply its presence in the city for 114 years as a major corporate powerhouse will be of a great loss, but we're not feeling completely gloom and doom."
And Mr. McLaughlin said: "I think that's true that the philanthropic contributions will continue. But after some time, the impetus, the energy will dissipate because Honeywell will no longer be in the neighborhood."

HEADLINE: It's That Time Again: Pay Raise Debated for City Officials

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY

 BODY:
Every four years, the world stages a Summer Olympics. Every four years, the United States elects a President. And every four years, a mayoral commission in New York City recommends pay increases for the city's elected officials.
That quadrennial moment for the city came yesterday, when a salary-review commission appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released several recommendations, including proposals that the Mayor receive an 18 percent pay increase of $30,000, to $195,000 a year, and that the members of the City Council receive a 27.6 increase of $19,500, to $90,000 a year, for what is considered to be a part-time job. 
 "Although New York City is by far the largest and most complex U.S. city to manage," the commission said in its report, "its elected officials currently are not compensated at a level commensurate with their responsibilities" in comparison with their counterparts in other cities across the country.
Mayor Giuliani, who was on a political trip to the Buffalo region, released a statement saying that he would issue "recommendations for approval, disapproval or modification" within 30 days to the Council, which has the final vote on the matter. But the Council is not likely to reject any formal recommendation of pay raises for its members.
"Obviously, the commission recognized that officials have not gotten raises in four years, and they don't get cost-of-living increases," Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for the Council, said. He added: "There has to be some incentive for people to want to seek office."
More than 30 years ago, in recognition of how pay raises for elected officials tend to inflame public passion, the city established a panel through which three private citizens would make recommendations. Just saying the panel's complete name could be counted as civic duty: Quadrennial Advisory Commission for the Review of Compensation Levels of Elected Officials.
Yesterday's recommendation marked the third time in this decade that the commission has released its report. And each time, the reaction it received reflected the city's position on the economic roller coaster that often affects its budget.
In 1991, for example, the commission said that elected officials deserved pay increases, but advised against giving them because of the city's budget crisis at the time. Both Mayor David N. Dinkins and Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, agreed.
In 1995, the commission recommended across-the-board pay increases for 64 of the city's elected officials, including the Mayor, the Comptroller, the Public Advocate, the 51 Council members, the five borough presidents and the five district attorneys. The recommendations came at a time when Mayor Giuliani was slashing spending during the tail end of the city's budget problems.
Everyone accepted the approved raises except Public Advocate Mark Green, who said at the time that he could not "in good conscience accept a large salary increase" when services to the poor were being cut and he was being forced to lay off members of his staff. Although the job's annual salary rose by $20,000, to $125,000, he did not accept the additional money.
Yesterday, however, Mr. Green indicated that the economy was good enough at this point to allow him to accept a $25,000 pay increase, to $150,000.
"The Public Advocate refused an earlier pay increase for three years because the city and his office faced a fiscal crisis," Richard Schrader, a spokesman, said. "Without such a budget problem now, he wouldn't refuse this legislative increase."
Richard Gelb, chairman emeritus of the Bristol-Myers-Squibb Company, returned as chairman of the commission. His report said that even with the proposed raise, the Mayor of New York would still earn less than the Mayor of Chicago, a much smaller city that presents nowhere near the same complexities (although Chicago's Mayor is not provided with the residential equivalent to Gracie Mansion).
The report also pointed out that the Mayor's salary is less than that of several other public executives, including Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Robert E. Boyle, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The overall arguments raised by the commission were so similar to previous reports, in fact, that some of the language was copied verbatim from the 1995 recommendations.
The report did not take into account the perks -- known as "lulus" -- that Council members routinely receive for heading various committees. These annual perks can range from a low of $3,000, for those out of favor with the leadership, to $35,000, the amount that the Speaker collects.
The report also compared the current Council salary of $70,500 a year to that in other cities. In Los Angeles, for example, full-time Council members receive $110,612, while part-time Council members in Washington collect $92,520.
"I don't begrudge city elected officials a raise after four years, but these seem on the high side," said Gene Russianoff, senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit watchdog agency. "And we think in exchange for the raise, Council members should agree to full-time service -- which means as a practical matter restricting the outside outcome they can earn."
But even Mr. Russianoff doubted that the Council would take up his suggestion at the public hearing it will hold on the proposals later this month.

HEADLINE: Budget Passes, Focusing on the Young and the Old

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
The City Council yesterday unanimously approved a $35.3 billion budget that uses the city's record tax revenue to provide a number of modest tax cuts and includes substantial spending increases on services for children and the elderly.
Council members said the city's buoyant economy and the subsequent tax surplus allowed them to restore cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to cultural institutions, libraries and other agencies. 
 "As many of my colleagues have said before me, this budget is a pleasure to vote for," Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a Democrat, said as she prepared to cast her vote. "A few years ago, the budgets we were looking at were draconian, but this is light years away from that."
Council leaders had hoped to include a host of tax cuts that would have helped businesses, working parents and home buyers, but they were forced to scale back their wish list when the State Legislature repealed the city's tax on New York commuters last month. That action will reduce revenue by at least $210 million a year.
Instead, Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, focused yesterday on the millions of dollars the Council added to the budgets of the Board of Education, the Department of Youth and Community Development and the Department for the Aging.
"This budget truly represents the people's needs," he said. "Its message is clear: education and our elderly are our priorities."
The budget provides $80 million for science and computer laboratories in public schools, $4.5 million for after-school and other youth programs, and $16 million for new centers and services to help keep the elderly out of nursing homes.
The tax cuts include a tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums, the elimination of the sales tax on clothing and shoes that cost less than $110 and an earned income tax credit for low-income families.
Council leaders had reached an agreement with Mr. Giuliani on the general terms of the budget last week, but individual Council members yesterday pored over the details of the spending plan for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1, to insure that programs they had lobbied for had been included.
These "member items" include projects ranging from neighborhood hockey and baseball teams to meals for elderly citizens and computers for local libraries. Member items this year totaled about $15 million.
In response to criticism that the budget did not go far enough to deal with the city's long-term debt of $37 billion, Councilman Alfonso C. Stabile, a Republican from Queens, said, "The bottom line is what we can bring home to your district and your constituents, and when you look at it that way, this is a good budget."
Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, a Democrat from Queens, offered the harshest criticism of the budget, saying it relied too heavily on the city's strong economy and did too little to narrow the long-term gap between the city's spending and its projected revenue.
In other action, the Council voted 47 to 3, with one member absent, to approve a proposed $1.5 billion rail link to connect Kennedy International Airport to local subways and commuter trains. Construction on the light rail train that is to connect all airport terminals and run to the subway station at Howard Beach and the Long Island Rail Road station in Jamaica is to be completed in 2003.

HEADLINE: CLINTON WILL SEEK A MEDICARE CHANGE ON DRUG COVERAGE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
President Clinton will soon propose revamping the Medicare program to offer prescription drug coverage to all beneficiaries, and he will contend that such coverage can actually save money for the Government by reducing the need for hospital stays and nursing home care, Administration officials said today.
The officials said the premium for the extra drug coverage would be less than $25 a month and could be as low as $10 a month. 
 The President intends to unveil his plan later this month, as an alternative to one proposed in March by the leaders of a 17-member advisory commission. His proposal will give a big push to efforts by Democratic lawmakers to cover prescription drugs, a change long sought by older Americans.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton would not try to impose Federal controls on drug prices. Rather, they said, under his proposal, the Government would hire private companies to help buy drugs and manage the new drug benefit. Such "pharmacy benefit managers" could control costs by obtaining discounts from drug manufacturers and drugstores, and by preventing overuse or misuse of prescription drugs, the Administration contends.
"We would never do price controls," a senior White House official said.
The proposed drug benefit is the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's plan to modernize Medicare and shore up the financial condition of the program, which serves 39 million people who are elderly or disabled. The Medicare trust fund is expected to run out of money in 2015, assuming no changes in current law.
Many Democrats say they will include prescription drug benefits as a major plank of their party's platform next year. They say they look forward to a fight over the issue with Republicans, who are also eager to provide drug benefits but fear that the cost of such coverage could soar.
John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, who has taken charge of efforts to draft the President's Medicare proposal, said the drug benefit would be "universal and affordable," would have "a modest premium" and would be "better than anything you could buy today in the open market."
Medicare beneficiaries now pay a monthly premium of $45.50 for coverage that does not include drugs. Administration officials said the extra premium for drug coverage under their proposal would be far less than what many elderly people now pay for such coverage under private insurance to fill the gaps in Medicare. Drug coverage premiums under such Medigap policies often exceed $80 a month, or $1,000 a year, the White House says.
The President's plan is an alternative to the one devised by the co-chairmen of the 17-member commission, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California. Under the Breaux-Thomas plan, the Government would offer a fixed amount of money to each beneficiary to buy a public or private health plan.
Just hours before the panel finished work in March, Mr. Clinton said its final proposal did not "provide for an adequate, affordable prescription drug benefit" and might cause excessive increases in premiums for people in the traditional Medicare program.
Confidential White House documents, outlining Mr. Clinton's proposal, assert that drug coverage can save money for Medicare, by reducing admissions to hospitals and nursing homes, and the need for home health care as well.
"A $1 increase in pharmaceutical expenditure is associated with a $3.65 reduction in hospital care expenditure," one document says. Moreover, it says, Medicare coverage of intravenous antibiotic therapy would virtually pay for itself, by reducing hospital admissions for treatment of infectious diseases.
Bruce Steinwald, an economist at the National Health Policy Forum at George Washington University, said: "In some cases, it's certainly true that a particular drug may save money on hospital care and other medical services. But it's extremely difficult to generalize. Some drugs will increase costs, and some will reduce costs."
Richard S. Foster, chief actuary of the Medicare program, is trying to estimate the cost of various options being considered by the President. White House officials said they had sent Mr. Foster many studies to support their contention that the proper use of drugs could save money elsewhere in Medicare. But one official said it was difficult to persuade Mr. Foster, because he was "very conservative" in his estimates.
Mr. Foster was not immediately available for comment tonight.
Senior Democratic members of Congress said President Clinton had not shared details of his proposal with them. "We haven't heard anything," said Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health.
Mr. Stark said he feared that the Administration would cut a deal with Republican leaders of the House and the Senate late this year, and that the resulting bill would be "dumped on our doorstep 48 hours before we have to vote on it."
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's plan would also include these elements:
* The Government would encourage price competition among health maintenance organizations, by requiring them to bid for the right to enroll Medicare beneficiaries. H.M.O.'s strenuously oppose this idea, because the original fee-for-service Medicare program would not be included in the competition.
* At least 15 percent of the expected Federal budget surplus would be pumped into Medicare over the next 15 years, to improve the program's financial condition and perhaps to help pay for drug benefits.
* Federal officials would have broad new authority to sign contracts with suppliers of goods and services who offer the best price to Medicare.
* Employers who now offer drug benefits to retirees would be allowed to buy drug coverage from Medicare, presumably at a lower price than they now pay.
Walter K. Moore, a vice president of Genentech Inc., a biotechnology company based in south San Francisco, said today, "We're encouraged when we hear that the President's plan won't include explicit price controls."
Pharmacy benefit managers and H.M.O.'s typically establish lists of preferred drugs, known as formularies, and recommend low-cost generic versions of brand-name drugs. Sometimes they also require doctors to get approval before prescribing certain drugs.
Mr. Moore said such restrictions were "not cause for concern" at Genentech because the company had been able to prove the value of its drugs to H.M.O.'s and pharmacy benefit managers.
For example, Mr. Moore said, Activase, a clot-dissolving drug made by Genentech, is used in the treatment of heart attack and stroke. "At $2,200 a dose," he said, "it's expensive therapy. But it can save tens of thousands of dollars in overall costs. Patients don't need to stay in the hospital as long, and they don't need as much rehabilitation."
Prescription drugs were among the benefits that would have been guaranteed to all Americans under President Clinton's ill-fated plan for universal health insurance coverage in 1993-94. Under that plan, the Government would have set payment limits for many drugs and would have required drug makers to provide discounts, in the form of rebates to the Government. Drug companies mobilized a small army of lobbyists against those proposals.
Historically, many Medicare beneficiaries have obtained coverage for prescription drugs by purchasing private insurance or by staying in health plans run by their former employers. But the White House contends that such coverage is eroding.
"Fewer employers are offering retiree health coverage, and Medigap is increasingly scarce and expensive," the White House says in a document defending its proposal.
"Only 23 percent of Medicare beneficiaries are expected to have private employer-based or Medigap insurance for drug coverage in 2000, according to the Medicare actuary -- down significantly from 1995," the White House says. Government actuaries estimate that, by 2000, only 17 percent of beneficiaries will have drug coverage from former employers, while 6 percent will have Medigap policies covering drug costs.
More than six million Medicare beneficiaries are in H.M.O.'s, and most have some type of drug coverage. But the White House says these benefits "are likely to be reduced or dropped in the future," as health plans cope with budget cuts made by Congress in 1997.
Senator Breaux's commission would have guaranteed drug coverage for low-income beneficiaries. But the White House rejects that approach. "Beneficiaries across the income spectrum lack drug coverage," says a White House document explaining the President's plan. "About 16 million beneficiaries are projected to have no drug coverage in 2000. Lack of drug coverage is not just a problem for low-income beneficiaries; 40 percent of beneficiaries without drug coverage have income above 200 percent of poverty (about $17,000 for a single person, $23,000 for a couple in 2000)."

HEADLINE: Smaller Families to Bring Big Change in Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 7

 BODY:
Like many old-style Mexican matriarchs, Emma Castro Amador bore so many children that she can't keep their birthdays straight. Sometimes she even loses track of whether Oscar, her 10th, came before David, her 11th, or vice versa.
"But I never regret having so many," said Mrs. Castro, 59, who had 14 children in 25 years. 
 Mrs. Castro's offspring, however, have a different view. In a generational divide repeated in millions of Mexican families, all 14 say they are determined to limit their families to two or three children.
"Small families live better," says Gloria Munoz Castro, Mrs. Castro's eldest daughter, echoing the jingle, broadcast incessantly on television here after the Government reversed its stance in 1974, and put a brake on exploding growth. Gloria has two children and says she will have no more.
Next year, Mexico's population is projected to reach 100 million, and the contrast between Mrs. Castro's family and those of her children illustrates the extraordinary changes under way in the country's family and population patterns, which hold important consequences for the rest of North America.
Because Mexican women like the elder Mrs. Castro traditionally had so many children, the population has quintupled since 1940, and will continue to surge at about one million people a year for nearly three decades. But because of people like her daughter, many forecasters predict that slowing fertility rates will mean that the country's population will virtually stop growing by 2045.
The tremendous reduction in fertility, from 7 children per woman in 1965, to 2.5 today, slightly below worldwide rates. The drop is resulting in a significant decline in the number of dependent children supported by each worker. It may also offer Mexico what population experts call a "demographic bonus," the opportunity to generate higher savings rates and domestic investments that can raise this country's standard of living and bring rapid development if the bonus is managed shrewdly.
"The drop in fertility is a spectacular change that has meant a revolution in mental attitudes," said Dr. Rodolfo Tuiran Gutierrez, secretary general of the Government-run National Population Council. "It's opening a demographic window of opportunity for Mexico."
Around the world, fertility rates have fallen from an average of 4.95 children per woman in the 1960-1965 period to 2.96 children in the first half of the 1990's.
But fast-growing populations are like speeding locomotives that cannot brake slowly, and even though Mexican birth rates fell dramatically, the population has kept surging.
For now, unemployment will remain high, since even when the economy is robust it cannot provide jobs for the 1.3 million new workers who enter the job market each year. Many of the jobless will continue to emigrate to the United States; during the next decade, some 3.5 million Mexicans are projected to travel to the United States to work and establish residence.
When Emma Castro was born in 1940, Mexico's population was 19.6 million, little changed from what it had been in 1910, at the outset of the Mexican Revolution. She married at 15 after a one-day courtship, and bore her first son the following year. For the next 25 years she bore one child, on average, every 21 months.
Her experience was typical. In 1956, the year Mrs. Castro bore her first son, an American anthropologist, Oscar Lewis, began collecting an oral history of a poor Mexico City family, later published as "The Children of Sanchez." When Mr. Lewis first interviewed the patriarch, Jesus Sanchez, he had 4 children, but when Mexican reporters interviewed him 14 years later, Mr. Hernandez had 16 more.
Government policy encouraged rapid growth, partly for historical reasons. Mexicans believed that the 19th century seizure of Mexican territories stretching from Texas to California by the United States would have been impossible had they not been so sparsely populated.
But in the late 1960's, as Mexico's postwar economic boom began to slow, the sheer force of the population figures began to alarm experts. In 1970, Mexico's population hit 48 million, and in an influential study several prominent Mexican demographers warned that unless policies changed it would more than triple by the year 2000, to 148 million.
Faced with the challenge to national stability those projections implied, President Luis Echeverria Alvarez in 1974 reversed course, establishing a National Population Council to control population growth and a network of Government clinics to help couples plan their families.
The reversal came as women's attitudes about birth control were already changing; ignoring the Government and the Roman Catholic hierarchy, many women in the 1960's and early 1970's were buying contraceptives on the black market. As a result, the Government's new offer of family planning services began satisfying a repressed demand, and Mexican families began changing dramatically, almost overnight.
"We were determined to have just two," said Mrs. Castro's eldest daughter, Gloria, who married in 1977. "We didn't want to spend all our money just to feed and clothe children."
Several of Gloria's married siblings and in-laws have no children. Eira Hernandez Ramirez, a 39-year-old sister-in-law with no children, explained : "Food is expensive, the oil is running out, water is scarce. The future's just too bleak."
But though Mexican birth rates have plummeted, the population has continued to expand. While none of Emma Castro's 14 children have borne even a quarter as many children as she did, they have produced 23 grandchildren so far. Millions of others in their generation have formed new families, too. That is why the population surged from 66.8 million in 1980 to 81 million in 1990 and is projected to reach the 100 million mark next year.
For more than two decades, the economy has failed to keep up with the exploding population. Jean Maninat, director of the Mexico office of the International Labor Organization, said that about 1.3 million new workers join Mexico's job market each year.
"That's the population pressure," Mr. Maninat said. "And despite the Government's efforts to generate investments, never in any year has the economy created that many jobs."
In good years, the expanding economy and new investments can create 900,000 or perhaps one million new jobs, leaving about 300,000 new job-seekers unemployed. In 1995, a recession year, Mexico lost 500,000 jobs, meaning that together with the 1.3 million new job-seekers, the ranks of the the unemployed grew by a total of 1.8 million in a single year.
A vast army of Mexicans are in the informal sector, the platoons of windshield washers who converge on cars at street corners and battalions of chewing-gum vendors who clog downtown sidewalks.
Still others have emigrated to the United States. During the 1960's, only about 27,000 workers left Mexico each year to establish permanent residence in America, according to Mexican Government figures. In the three decades since, the flow has multiplied by 10; it is currently about 277,000 a year, according to the binational study.
For the next 10 years or so, population growth is expected to continue to generate mass emigration and millions of new unemployed. But as the effects of the dropoff in fertility rates continue to make themselves felt, the number of people who join the job market each year is projected to fall to about 650,000 in 2010, Government demographers estimate.
If the economy continues to grow, then the number of Mexicans who emigrate to the United States each year, legally and illegally, could begin to decline, according a 1977 Binational Study on Migration. Some demographers believe, however, that because wages in the United States are often 10 times the pay for the same work in Mexico, Mexicans will continue to emigrate even when jobs are available here.
The slowing growth is bringing Mexico good news of another kind. In 1970, for every 100 Mexican workers there were 100 dependents, mostly children and a few retired people. As the children have grown up and entered the work force, this "dependency ratio" has declined, to about 60 dependents for each 100 workers. By the year 2020, the burden of nonworking dependents should decline still further, to about 40 per 100 workers.
"There's a moment in the evolution of populations when they have the absolute best structure for development, and that's the structure Mexico is developing right now," said Eduardo Arriaga, an Argentine demographer who is a lecturer at Georgetown University.
This demographic bonus gives Mexico the opportunity to increase domestic savings and with sensible economic management, could result in higher per capita economic growth.
The bonus phase of Mexico's demographic transition is expected to last for 30 years. By then, the population will be, on average, far older than it is today, and millions of Mexicans will need retirement care.
The costs of caring for the elderly will be higher, because currently most retired Mexicans live with their children. But the characteristically large Mexican family is shrinking, increasing numbers of Mexicans live alone, and in the future the elderly may not be able to count on home care provided by their children.
"The Mexican family is being transformed in crucial ways," said Carlos Welti, a demographer at the National Autonomous University. "Throughout our history, an important social safety network has been the extended family, uncles, cousins. In the future, fewer will have these relationships."

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Increased in April

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by consumers increased in April, led by auto loans and credit card debt, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Borrowing through credit cards, auto loans and other personal loans rose by $3.7 billion, to $1.335 trillion, after rising a revised $5.1 billion during March. 
 Previously, the Fed estimated March borrowing increased $1.6 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $5 billion for April.
The pace of consumer credit was rising at a 3.4 percent annual rate during April. That was down from the 4.6 percent pace of borrowing in March.
"With spending outpacing income growth, households are increasingly turning to credit to finance their purchases," Steve Wood, an economist at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco, said before the report was released.
Economists watch the Fed's report to help them gauge consumer demand. However, the Fed's report is somewhat incomplete because more people are borrowing against their homes through lower-interest home equity loans, and the Fed's statistics do not track loans secured by real estate.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $3.2 billion in April -- the largest increase since January -- after falling $400 million in March. Auto loans rose $2.2 billion after increasing $5.4 billion. Other types of installment loans decreased $1.7 billion after rising $100 million.

HEADLINE: Inquiry Grows As Rolls Fall For Medicaid

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 7

 BODY:
Concerned over the steep declines of the Medicaid rolls in New York, Federal officials are studying whether local governments across the state are improperly preventing the poor from signing up for health benefits under the program.
The Federal Government has already been examining stringent new welfare policies in New York City that a Federal judge and advocates for the poor say have prevented many poor people from getting prompt access to Medicaid coverage. 
 But now, Federal officials are trying to find out if similar problems exist outside the city and what, if anything, Albany is doing to insure that localities are not erecting improper hurdles to applications for coverage.
The inquiry was outlined in a letter that Sue Kelly, a regional administrator for the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, sent to state health officials last month expressing concerns about New York. In the letter, Ms. Kelly said that it "appears that barriers exist in the application process" for Medicaid both inside and outside New York City. The letter specifically cites long delays in approving the Medicaid applications of more than 1,000 people in Nassau County. Ms. Kelly noted that the agency would, as a result, conduct a "program review" of the state Medicaid program.
New York State officials said that they welcomed the inquiry, and that they would provide documents outlining the thoroughness of their oversight. Federal and state officials are scheduled to meet on the matter later this month. "We look forward to that meeting so that we can show H.C.F.A. the significant monitoring effort that the department has undertaken in the Medicaid program," said John Signor, a spokesman for the state's Department of Health.
The concerns of Federal officials come at a time when statistics show that many localities in New York State -- from Nassau and Suffolk Counties to the Syracuse and Binghamton areas -- have reduced their Medicaid rolls far more than even New York City.
Elisabeth Ryden Benjamin, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society who represents Medicaid recipients, called the Federal inquiry a significant development. "This is an extremely serious step," she said. "The state needs to walk very carefully because what is happening in the localities is a field full of land mines."
But some state and local administrators of the Medicaid program reject such criticism, attributing the decline to a robust economy that has provided more jobs with private health benefits to poor people.
The fate of Medicaid recipients has drawn increasing attention in New York and across the nation since 1996, when the Federal Government passed a law overhauling its welfare program. That law gave states sweeping new powers to impose a host of restrictions on their poverty programs. But that law also specified that poor people would be able to keep their Medicaid coverage even if they lost their eligibility for welfare benefits. That provision was included, in part, to encourage welfare recipients to take low-wage jobs even when employers offered them no health care benefits.
But in most states, eligibility for welfare benefits and for Medicaid have been traditionally linked, and it has taken time for states to implement procedures formally severing the two programs. As a result, leaving welfare has often meant losing Medicaid as well. Beyond that, there is a perception among many needy families that they do not qualify for Medicaid if they are deemed ineligible for welfare benefits, according to advocates for the poor.
The issue has been of particular interest in New York State, where the Medicaid rolls have decreased by 276,973, or 9 percent, since President Clinton signed the law overhauling welfare in August 1996. That decline has come as local governments, including the Giuliani administration, aggressively implemented a host of new policies challenging people's eligibility for welfare benefits.
The enrollment decline among New York's Medicaid population, now at about 2.7 million, has drawn harsh rebukes from advocates for the poor who say that many local governments have made it difficult to get Medicaid. In January, for example, a Federal district judge ruled that New York City had improperly denied applications for Medicaid from poor people because they had not complied with the city's requirement that they work in exchange for welfare benefits. The city has said it plans to improve its procedures.
But the steep enrollment decline is not limited to New York City, where the Medicaid rolls have dropped by 8.3 percent since the Federal welfare law was passed in 1996. In that same period, the caseloads have dropped by 15.5 percent in Suffolk County, 10.8 percent in Nassau County, 11.5 percent in the Syracuse area and 13.9 percent in the Binghamton area, according to state statistics.
New York is one of the few states in the nation that does not directly administer its poverty programs but rather turns that job over to New York City and the 57 county governments around the state. But the state still has the main responsibility for insuring that local governments are complying with state and Federal statutes governing these programs.
New York State officials have themselves expressed concern that Federal rules intended to preserve Medicaid for people deemed ineligible for welfare have not always been followed. In fact, last January, state health investigators visited eight welfare offices in New York City and found that four had failed to provide Medicaid applications promptly.
But that apparently has not eased the concerns of Federal officials who have the authority to impose financial penalties on the state if it is not in compliance with Federal rules.
In the letter sent to state health officials last month, the Federal Government said it had not received documentation from the state showing what, if anything, had been done to correct the problem in New York City. The letter also cited published reports from Nassau County claiming that as of January, 1,129 Medicaid applications had been pending for more than a month with the wait averaging 78 days, even though Federal law requires Medicaid applications to be processed within 45 days in most cases. "If this is indeed the case in Nassau County, it would appear to violate Federal standards," the letter says.
As part of their inquiry, Federal officials will require the state to provide documentation of "all monitoring activities" it has conducted of local government policies, as well as the minutes of any meetings that state health officials have conducted with local administrators of the program, according to the letter. The inquiry will also likely include visits by Federal officials to local welfare offices, as well as a review of Medicaid applications to determine whether they have been handled properly, according to a Federal official who asked to remain anonymous.
"The Federal Government is clearly frustrated with New York's lack of oversight of its local districts," said Anne Erickson, the legislative coordinator for the Upstate Law Project, an advocacy group for the poor that monitors poverty programs in upstate New York. "What the Federal Government is saying is that the local districts need to comply with the law."

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
From Sibelius's Civility to Contemporary Stress, at a Gathering of Finns

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

DATELINE: OJAI, Calif., June 7

 BODY:
Far-flung, numerous and sublimely dissimilar, Americans have a hard time understanding the national impulse of smaller countries. We are happily different among ourselves. For Finland and places like it, being one identifiable thing is a means of survival.
So if this year's Ojai Festival, dominated if not overwhelmed by Finnish music, seemed brazen in its patriotic self-congratulation, and if the Finnish musicians gathered here resembled more than a little a college reunion, remember that a nation's culture, adamantly promoted, can exert a force equal to its gross national product. It unites and solidifies. 
 Occupied over the centuries alternately by Swedes and Russians, Finns have survived by means of a distinctive language (like Hungarian heard through a closed door, as a friend from Budapest described it) and a stubborn folk culture. Finnish classical music came late and slowly, awakened by Sibelius and now in a flurry of productivity.
Running at the head of Ojai's talented and agreeable Rat Pack was Esa-Pekka Salonen, music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and host here for a collection of old friends: Olli Mustonen, Anssi Karttunen, Magnus Lindberg and a new-music group called the Toimii Ensemble. Mr. Salonen's local orchestra added significant support over a three-day weekend of six events. Denyce Graves sang a Finn-less recital on Sunday morning. Two weekday chamber music concerts preceded.
The visiting Finns, denizens of a more dour and Spartan natural world, looked a little pale in this botanical Garden of Eden just north of Los Angeles. But they seemed to be enjoying themselves among the live oak and sycamore, the towering eucalyptus and hydrangeas.
Mr. Salonen used the festival to promote not only his country and schoolmates but himself. Salonen compositions popped up all weekend: on Friday, "Giro," a chamber piece, and "Five Images After Sappho," a song cycle; and on Saturday, "Yta II" for solo piano, a brittle little item filled with scurrying figuration and played here by Gloria Cheng. Laura Claycomb, standing in bravely for the ailing Dawn Upshaw, sang the songs surely, and with only a trace of apprehension.
Mr. Salonen has been talking of conducting less and composing more. I hope he gives the idea more thought. As a music director he is invaluable: intrepid, brave, thoughtful, highly skilled. He gives Los Angeles a spirit of adventure music sorely needs.
If Mr. Salonen's pieces here were representative, they show an acute observer of how other people have written music in the 20th century. The leisurely chords and cascading filigree of "Giro" and the resuscitations of early-in-the-century France for the "Sappho" songs are smoothly handled, though in the latter the sequential patterns sound pretty labored. Everywhere one heard lessons from Ravel and Boulez well learned, but one looked in vain for a center to all this music, an identifiable personality, something that would certify, "I am Esa-Pekka Salonen, composer."
Mr. Lindberg possesses such a personality. His new Cello Concerto on Friday and the earlier "Kraft" on Sunday afternoon were not always likable, but they are difficult to ignore. The Cello Concerto is the Romantic spirit turned mean. If the 19th century more or less invented the display piece, Mr. Lindberg's catalogue of glissando whoops, frantic runs, plucks and whacks -- negotiated courageously by Mr. Karttunen -- stretch virtuosity to excruciating lengths. Comparing Mr. Lindberg's concerto to the Sibelius First Symphony later in the evening showed not only how music but the whole world has changed in 100 years: civilized melancholy now transformed into teeth-grinding struggle.
"Kraft" surrounded the audience with an army of traditional instruments and found objects, and banged away with chaotic vigor. This is less ensemble music than a community of sounds: like Messiaen's well-populated forest from which bird song emerges but now relocated to Main Street at rush hour. If John Adams's Chamber Symphony on Saturday was joyously raucous, "Kraft" seemed surly in contrast.
Two more Finns to talk about were Kaija Saariaho, composer of "Amers" on Saturday night (again with the busy Mr. Karttunen), and Mr. Mustonen, a pianist who earlier in the day had interwoven Bach and Shostakovich Preludes and Fugues. "Amers" behaved like a single, slowly drifting chord progression altered gradually by instrumental timbre and a repertory of glissandos, ripples and shudders. Sustaining a piece on color and decoration alone is not easy, and here it was not always accomplished.
Mr. Mustonen's mercurial approach -- with its stop-and-start impulsiveness and broad dynamic range -- made the two composers sound happily alike. The abandonment of traditional sobriety offended some, but it is not true that the siren heard approaching Libbey Bowl after intermission was an ambulance come to rescue Bach from Mr. Mustonen's injurious clutches.
There is only one correct style: the one that allows what is written to be heard and offers a strong point of view. Both elements were present here. Less authentic was Mr. Mustonen's repertory of fluttering fingers, grimaces and swooning exits from the stage.
When such foolishness bleeds the listener's attention from the music, harmless narcissism turns unhealthy. Affecting white tie and tails at 2 in the afternoon in informal surroundings may have been a comment on human artifice next to nature, but its silliness was distracting. Mr. Mustonen has talent, but there are times when children should be heard, not seen.

HEADLINE: Productivity Estimate Is A Bit Lower

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Worker productivity was slightly less vigorous in the first quarter than previously thought as pay rates picked up, the Labor Department said today.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said total inventories rose in April while sales by wholesalers rose to a record, indicating consumer spending is still strong. 
 Productivity, the output for every hour of work, climbed 3.5 percent in the first three months of 1999 instead of the 4 percent reported by the department a month ago. Though it was a slowdown from the fourth quarter's 4.3 percent gain, it still represented strong performance as the economy was entering its ninth year of expansion.
The revised productivity estimate was in line with economists' expectations. The Government earlier scaled back its initial estimates of total first-quarter economic growth, so the reduction in productivity was expected.
Unit labor costs, the amount of compensation for every unit of output, were revised to a rise of seven-tenths of a percent from three-tenths of a percent. That came after a four-tenths of a percent drop in fourth-quarter labor costs.
The revised pickup in first-quarter labor costs was still the smallest gain for any quarter since a three-tenths of a percent rise in the third quarter of 1997.
The Commerce Department report showed that inventories rose two-tenths of a percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted $288.96 billion after a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in March. The March data were revised down from an initially reported three-tenths of a percent.
Total wholesale sales edged up to a seasonally adjusted record $221.87 billion, from $221.80 billion in March, which was the previous record.
The inventory-to-sales ratio, which measures how long it would take to deplete stocks at the current sales pace, remained steady at 1.3 months worth.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDX;
Rising Long-Term Interest Rates Dampen Stocks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates hit 6 percent for the first time in more than a year yesterday after two Federal Reserve officials made comments that suggested the central bank would raise interest rates at the end of the month.
Higher interest rates and concern about the outlook for computer companies helped send stocks lower in what promises to be continued volatility ahead of the Fed policy meeting. After rising 109.54 points Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 143.74 points, or 1.32 percent, yesterday to 10,765.64. Volume was light as investors anticipated coming Government reports. 
 "The interest rate bell rings louder and stock knees get weaker," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
He said he thought that interest rates would move higher and stocks lower between now and the Fed meeting. But he said good second-quarter earnings reports and getting by the Fed rate increase would help stocks rally in July.
Until then investors will have to contend with a Commerce Department retail sales report Friday that is expected to be strong and heighten expectations of a Fed rate increase. Then next week comes the Consumer Price Index for May. If it is even moderately strong, a rate increase will seem guaranteed.
In trading yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond just slipped back under 6 percent at the end of the day, finishing at 5.99 percent, up from 5.96 percent Monday. Six percent is an important psychological barrier and going through it ought to make investors worry more in the near term about the stock market.
Computer stocks, including I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Intel, Cisco Systems and Dell Computer, led the market lower.
A report from Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said that sales and profits of personal computer makers and software companies would be hurt at the end of the year as spending on information technology was reduced as the Year 2000 -- and the possible computer problems associated with it -- approached. Many companies appear ready to delay spending not associated with solving Year 2000 problems because they do not want to start new programs that might complicate the transition to the new year.
The technology-laden Nasdaq index dropped 49.65 points, or about 2 percent, to 2,474.56, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 17.19 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,317.33.
Investors have been expecting a rate increase since last month, when it was reported that the April Consumer Price Index jumped seven-tenths of a percent and the Fed then announced that it was leaning toward raising interest rates to slow growth and curb any inflationary spurt.
But the timing of such a rate increase was not clear. Since then a series of economic reports, including the May employment report that was released Friday, have shown that the economy is still strong and that wage pressures may be growing. And that has pushed investors to betting that the Fed will act when its meets on June 29 and 30.
The comments by William Poole, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, were seen as further confirmation of this view.
At a conference at the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston, Mr. Poole said that he "would share the view" that the odds now favor higher inflation, according to Bloomberg News. According to Reuters, Mr. Poole also said that it was best that Fed policy changes "do not take the market by surprise."
Mr. Broaddus said in Amelia Island, Fla., according to Bloomberg, that the jump in the April Consumer Price Index was "the most troubling" in some time.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "There seems to be more hawkish talk coming out of Fed officials and the market is becoming more convinced that the Fed will raise interest rates when it meets at the end of June."
Analysts are now predicting a quarter-of-a-percentage-point increase in the Fed's interest rate target, which is the interest charged on overnight loans between banks. The target, known as the Federal Funds rate, is now 4.75 percent. But based on one barometer of market sentiment -- the difference between the Fed funds target and the yield on the two-year Treasury note -- some investors are expecting that the Fed will push its target up another quarter of a percentage point later in the year.
Some money managers think that if interest rates push a little higher it will be time to buy bonds again because they expect the Fed to succeed in slowing economic growth and curbing inflation, a fact that would push interest rates lower.
But Steve Holzman, the managing partner of Cypress Funds L.L.C., a hedge fund in Los Angeles, is being more cautious. He said he wanted to see data that confirmed the slowdown of the economy before jumping back in. "I would rather be in at 5.65 percent," he said, referring to the yield on the 30-year bond, "based on the fact that you saw some slowdown, than at 5.95" without that confirmation.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
National Company Tries Out New York

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
By many measures, the Trammell Crow Company is among the largest real estate-services companies in the country. But it has been conspicuously absent from New York, the nation's largest market.
That changed quietly in February, when the company opened a Manhattan office at 780 Third Avenue at 48th Street, initially to find locations in the New York metropolitan area for the national retail companies, including Borders Books, General Cinema and the Body Shop, that Trammel Crow represents. Although the current focus remains on retail, the company's chief executive, George Lippe, said he expected the office to develop into a full-service operation over the next few years. 
 "We didn't want to open with a bang," he said. "But my intent is that we will develop into a full-service office over the next three to five years." He said the intense level of competition in New York was the reason that the company had been reluctant to hang out its shingle here. But, he said, retailers who want nationwide coverage pushed the company to establish a presence.
"This was a customer-driven decision," said Michael Hirschfeld, who was hired from Equis of New York to run the Trammell Crow office here. "A lot of our customers said, 'We have requirements in New York,' so we had to be here."
The Trammell Crow Company that is now entering the New York market is vastly different from the swashbuckling band of deal makers that was once the nation's largest developer, the owner of a $15 billion empire of property.
The 1980's real estate recession brought about the collapse of the highly leveraged empire, with most of the property going to the Crow family. In 1991, the company gave up development and ownership to concentrate exclusively on offering services to help complete real estate transactions. It still does some development but only for other people, and it has no equity stake in the projects.
But it is a substantial company, with 478 million square feet of office, retail and industrial property under management. Revenues in 1998 were $517 million, up from $313 million a year earlier. The company has 5,600 people in 160 offices in the United States and Canada. Trammell Crow is publicly traded, after an initial public offering in December 1997.
Mr. Lippe said the company decided to keep its founder's name despite the financial difficulties of the early 1990's because of the good relationships developed with tenants of the buildings it formerly owned. "We had a lot of tenants and they liked us," he said. "Our brand was good with the corporate community, so we decided to keep it, even if it was difficult with lenders."
Focusing on services makes the company less subject to the notorious boom-and-bust nature of the real estate industry. When economic times are difficult and companies are looking to pare costs, one way is to turn real estate operations over to a third-party manager, a process known as outsourcing.
"The second largest cost for most corporations, after personnel, is occupancy," Mr. Lippe said. "So outsourcing actually accelerates during recessions." In choosing outsourcing, corporations are hoping that an outside company whose only business is real estate can manage those operations more efficiently than an in-house real estate department of a company whose core business is something else.
Because New York remains a corporate headquarters, the company's outsourcing services division is the next one likely to set up shop here, Mr. Lippe said. He said the company represents 72 of the largest industrial companies in the country, "and most of them have some presence in New York."
In all, Trammel Crow is managing 16,600 properties with 135 million square feet of space for corporate clients whose business is not based on real estate.
Trammell Crow also offers real estate brokerage services -- Mr. Lippe admits that New York is going to be tough to crack because of existing relationships among local brokers, landlords and tenants -- and development and investment services for companies building their own buildings and for investors in office, industrial and retail projects.
Mr. Hirschfeld said that explaining the Manhattan market to retailers who have built up their businesses in suburban locations is a big part of his job because of the population density and the high rents charged. "The other boroughs are more analogous to what they are accustomed to in other parts of the country, but Manhattan is a completely different world," he said.
One of Mr. Hirschfeld's important moves so far was hiring a team of seven brokers from the old Jones Lang Wootton firm that recently merged with LaSalle Partners to form Jones Lang LaSalle. "We got the entire retail team from Jones Lang," he said.
Mr. Lippe said Trammell Crow had grown through acquisition recently. "We have added 6 or 7 companies in the last 12 months which account for about $120 million of our approximately $600 million in revenues," he said. But he said they were bought to add specialty expertise to an already existing national network of offices, rather than as an effort to build a national company.
"Having the network helps integrate new companies into the organization," he said. "You already have the infrastructure."

HEADLINE: Auto Negotiations Are Likely to Aim fora Longer Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 8

 BODY:
With General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler scheduled to begin talks next week with the United Automobile Workers, it appears increasingly likely that negotiators will seek a national labor contract lasting four or more years, the longest such deal since the 1950's, auto executives and union officials say.
Chastened by last summer's 54-day strike against G.M. in Flint, Mich., and enjoying the soaring profits and bountiful overtime pay produced by record auto sales, management and workers appear eager to avoid another showdown this year. Serious differences could still produce a strike, but industry and union leaders alike are now using the tamest rhetoric in many years. 
 Nearly two decades of declining inflation rates have tempered union fears that workers' pay would be ravaged by rising prices during a long contract. For their part, the auto makers would welcome the ability to predict long-term costs. The current contract expires on Sept. 14.
By departing from the traditional three-year contract, the U.A.W. would also be able to avoid having the next round of auto labor talks in the summer of 2002, when the union could be locked in a power struggle. Stephen P. Yokich, the union's longtime president, must retire when his current, four-year term ends in June 2002 because he will become 65 next year. The union's rules require that candidates for the presidency, an elected position, be younger than 65, and Mr. Yokich has no heir apparent.
A longer contract would not assure labor peace in the auto industry, however. Unlike most unions, the U.A.W. won from the auto makers long ago the right to hold factory-level strikes for health and safety reasons any time, even while a contract is in force. Last year's strike in Flint involved such a walkout.
Key issues in talks to replace the current contract, which expires on Sept. 14, are certain to include job security, particularly for workers at auto parts subsidiaries that are being spun off, as well as modest changes to the auto makers' health care plans and other employee benefits, executives and union officials said in interviews and public appearances the last month.
The U.A.W. has traditionally negotiated a contract with one auto company first, and then demanded that the other two sign virtually identical pacts. The company that negotiates the first pact has an advantage, in that it can tailor an agreement to its own needs while driving up its rivals' costs. Ford and G.M. seem to have a better chance of being chosen by the union to negotiate the first agreement than does DaimlerChrysler, but no decision has been made yet, a person close to the union said.
G.M. executives in particular have softened their criticisms of the union and called for reconciliation, in the hope of avoiding another strike.
"We are working hard with all our unions to nurture a more open relationship," said John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, at the company's annual meeting on Monday in Wilmington, Del. "We want to build on common strengths, improve our cost competitiveness and work through our differences without costly work stoppages."
But G.M. has in the past shown a peculiar knack for offending the U.A.W., sometimes unintentionally. The auto maker announced today, six days before the contract negotiations formally open next Monday, that it would spend $1.8 billion to buy a commercial lending business from the Bank of New York.
Although union leaders had no immediate reaction today, they have criticized diversification moves by the auto maker, calling on the companies to invest more money in new equipment and factories instead.
All three auto makers' current, three-year national contracts with the U.A.W. expire at midnight on Sept. 14. Since the Eisenhower Administration, national auto labor contracts have lasted for three years, and the triennial negotiations have been closely followed as a barometer of wage pressures in the American economy. While the auto makers are no longer the nation's largest private employers -- Wal-Mart overtook G.M. two years ago -- the wages and benefits set in their contracts still strongly influence the rest of the manufacturing sector, which accounts for about a fifth of the nation's economic output.
Inflation and obscure accounting rules discouraged the union and the companies alike from pursuing longer agreements. Inflation caused by the Korean War ravaged the earnings power of auto workers during a five-year pact in the 1950's and prompted union leaders then to vow that future deals would not exceed three years, a decision followed until now.
Recent contracts have only partly protected workers against inflation, guaranteeing that in addition to wage increases workers will receive an extra 1 percent raise for every 2.6 percentage points of inflation. But the decline in the inflation rate has reduced union worries on this score.
Accounting rules also require the companies to charge certain pension concessions against their profits in the first year of an agreement, and the cost of these concessions rises with longer agreements. But with all three auto makers posting record or near-record profits, they are in unusually strong financial condition to take such a charge.
Mr. Yokich mentioned the possibility of a longer contract at a news conference last month. "With all the money they've got, they might be able to put enough money on that table that we have to take a 4-year or 5-year or 6-year or 10-year" contract, he said, speaking of the auto makers.
While auto executives dismiss the idea of a 10-year contract, which would limit their options through at least two generations of new cars, they have been receptive to the possibility of a 4- to six-year contract.
The U.A.W. has been quarreling with DaimlerChrysler over how much help the auto maker should give the union in organizing a Mercedes factory in Alabama and a DaimlerChrysler heavy truck factory in North Carolina. With union leaders also nervous about a showdown with German executives they barely know, the union is expected to negotiate the first contract with G.M. or, perhaps more likely, Ford.
If Ford goes first, it would probably try to work out the terms of an eventual spinoff of Visteon Automotive Systems, its auto parts unit. Such a settlement could have major implications for G.M. In previous spinoffs of smaller subsidiaries by Ford and G.M, contracts guaranteed that workers in the subsidiary could retire within the next few years with full pensions and health benefits from the auto maker, not the subsidiary.
Last month, G.M. spun off its 200,000-employee auto parts unit, Delphi Automotive Systems. A big question now is whether Ford will agree to accept huge numbers of workers back from Visteon if it is ever spun off. While Ford could use those workers in its expanding sport utility vehicle factories, G.M. has too many workers already and does not need more from Delphi. But if Ford signs a pattern-setting contract first, the U.A.W. may force G.M. to accept the same terms or face another costly strike.
