HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Calm Election Spurs a Rally In Indonesia

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, June 8

 BODY:
A day after Indonesia held its first democratic elections in four decades, the joyful clamor of voters gave way to a resounding rumble of approval from the financial markets.
Stocks in Jakarta surged 12.2 percent today, closing at their highest level since Indonesia went into an economic tailspin in August 1997. Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, strengthened to a rate of 7,700 to the dollar, extending a rally that began last week. 
 The good feelings were infectious, as stock markets in neighboring Malaysia and Singapore also recorded powerful gains. Everywhere in the region, investors seemed to view Indonesia's harmonious exercise in democracy as a milestone in Asia's recovery from economic calamity.
Given the dire predictions of election-related riots and bloodshed, such euphoria is understandable. But many analysts here said that it would be transitory. Indonesia faces prolonged political maneuvering that may leave people as baffled as ever about this sprawling country.
Nor does an election -- however peaceful -- heal Indonesia's ills, which range from shuttered banks and debt-plagued companies to jaded foreign investors who still view the country as an economic leper.
"The elections are one milestone," said Mari Pangestu, an economist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta. "But there are two or three other milestones to come. Who will lead the coalition? Who will be the next president? Who will get the economics portfolio?"
Based on early returns, the Indonesian Democratic Party for Struggle seemed likely to win the largest number of votes. But even if it wins this parliamentary election, analysts said it would have to assemble a coalition to wrest control of the Government from the ruling Golkar party and its leader, President B. J. Habibie, the protege of his predecessor, Indonesia's longtime leader, Suharto.
Still, as investors and economists weighed the implications of Monday's vote, their attention swung to the leader of the Democratic Party for Struggle, Megawati Sukarnoputri, and her economic advisers.
Mrs. Megawati, 52, said little about the economy during the campaign. The soft-spoken daughter of Indonesia's founding President, Sukarno, Mrs. Megawati ran a heavily symbolic campaign, drawing on an emotional public yearning for a return to the Indonesia of her father.
Never mind that under Sukarno, Indonesia fell into its deepest economic crisis until the current one -- with crushing government debt, soaring inflation, eroding exports and rampant smuggling. In a speech in 1964, Sukarno told the United States to "go to hell with your aid."
Despite her credentials as a nationalist, Mrs. Megawati is not about to follow her father's lead in spurning foreign money. Her party has embraced Indonesia's agreement with the International Monetary Fund, which lays out changes required for it to keep receiving the fund's money.
John Bresnan, an expert on Indonesia at the East Asian Institute at Columbia University, said he was surprised that Mrs. Megawati and other opposition figures had not tried to turn the I.M.F.'s role into a campaign issue.
"I think they have some sense of the severity of the situation," Mr. Bresnan said. "Some of the opposition notables are now close to being in a position of responsibility, and that is a sobering prospect."
Hours after the polls closed on Monday, the I.M.F. approved a $450 million loan to Indonesia, the latest installment in its $43 billion rescue package. Anoop Singh, the deputy director of the I.M.F.'s Asia and Pacific division, said today that he viewed the election as an "opportunity to intensify reform efforts."
In addition to heeding the I.M.F., advisers to Mrs. Megawati say they are committed to a free-market strategy that welcomes foreign investment. But that does not mean Mrs. Megawati's aides do not harbor provocative ideas.
Kwik Kian Gie, an economist who is perhaps Mrs. Megawati's most influential adviser, recently proposed fixing Indonesia's currency at an exchange rate of 5,000 rupiah to the United States dollar. Without a stable rupiah at that level, he says, Indonesia's economy will continue to stagnate because the rupiah's weakness and unpredictability have hurt the purchasing power of consumers.
"This proposal is certainly not for the current Government, which evidently cannot create stability, but for the Government resulting from the coming general election," Mr. Kwik wrote in The Jakarta Post.
Because Mr. Kwik is mentioned as a future Finance Minister, his ruminations about the rupiah have alarmed some business leaders here. Indonesia struggled to maintain a fixed exchange rate early in the Asian crisis -- abandoning the effort after it squandered foreign reserves by spending enormous sums of dollars to buy rupiah. Beyond the currency issue, some executives here said the Democratic Party for Struggle has a more active bent than the other major parties.
"We have some concern that there is a central-planning bias and an unwillingness to let the market take over," said James W. Castle, a consultant and member of the American Chamber of Commerce here. "We've tried to tell them that the regulations of the Suharto Government were fairly good. The problem was corruption."
Before the next Government adopts any innovative policies, investors said it must tackle Indonesia's pervasive cronyism and a legal system that leaves foreign banks and other creditors queasy.
"I just don't see how any bank in Frankfurt or New York would get approval to make new loans to Indonesia," said Bill Kaye, senior managing director of the Pacific Group, a Hong Kong asset management firm.
Mr. Kaye said investors would hesitate to pour money back into the country until they saw evidence that bankruptcy courts here were treating creditors consistently. But doing that will involve challenging some of the most politically connected business tycoons in Indonesia.
There is no question that a resurgent stock market and a strengthening currency will help Indonesia solve its problems. As asset values rise, it is easier to overhaul debt-laden conglomerates. And that, in turn, eases the cost of bailing out Indonesia's banking system, now estimated at more than $40 billion.
Despite the problems facing Indonesia, some experts said they did not want to diminish the psychological lift that the economy would enjoy simply because the elections were so remarkably peaceful.
"If you can make people feel safe, a lot of Indonesian money that went abroad will come back," said Rizal Ramli, a prominent economist. "People want to be given a reason to come back to this country."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
It Was a Whole New Game, and the Stakes Were High

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS and JUDY BATTISTA 

 BODY:
The players union of the Women's National Basketball Association overwhelmingly ratified a labor contract last month, the first in women's professional team sports in the United States. The players won increased salaries, year-round health coverage, including maternity leave, a matching 401(k) program and limited job security for veterans.
But many of the W.N.B.A. players agree that the process of insuring labor peace and jobs for the next four years was a lot rougher than they expected. 
 Nearly three months of bargaining revealed an inexperienced union at odds with itself, its leadership and management, insecure in the knowledge that it stood to lose as much as it might gain.
"As women basketball players, we weren't really experienced in dealing with things like the union, the league and collective bargaining," said the Houston Comets' Cynthia Cooper, the league's two-time most valuable player.
But the union also faced an issue it could not control: 90 fellow pros were out of work because the rival American Basketball League had folded in late December. As the W.N.B.A. prepared for its third season, the pros no longer had the option of playing in another American league.
"We had no bargaining power," said Rebecca Lobo, the Liberty forward and a member of the negotiating committee. "As soon as the A.B.L. folded, we had no leverage. "We went in there and just tried to get the best thing we could get. And I think we did a good job."
The union wanted to limit the number of A.B.L. players allowed into the W.N.B.A., while the league wanted no restrictions.
"It was extremely difficult because we had to continually justify, not only to ourselves, but to our friends in the A.B.L. and the public, the general position that we took," said Coquese Washington, the Liberty forward who emerged as one of the most vocal player representatives. "As a union that organized before the A.B.L. folded, we had a constituency that had issues to be met, and job security was an issue before the A.B.L. went under."
In the end, the W.N.B.A. expansion teams in Orlando and Minnesota were allowed to have five A.B.L. players each. The other 10 W.N.B.A. teams were limited to three each, either as draftees or free agents. After this season, there will be no limit on signing A.B.L. players and in 2000 four more teams will join the league, creating an additional 44 jobs for players.
Other bumps in the negotiations were predictable once the women voted last November to align themselves with the National Basketball Players Association. By the time the women started negotiating their contract with the league, the N.B.P.A. had just ended its contentious labor dispute with the National Basketball Association, which owns and operates the W.N.B.A.
"We feared being shut down all together and alienating fans of the league," said Lisa Leslie, the star center for the Los Angeles Sparks.
Given the tangential concerns -- plus the players' labor inexperience -- their mistakes were inevitable.
"People who are new at collective bargaining always make mistakes," said Richard Hurd, professor of labor studies at Cornell University. "If you're negotiating an established contract, then you go over every word and see if you can improve it. With a first agreement, things slip by."
The union, for example, did not raise the issue of how players from the A.B.L. would be classified upon joining the league. Union leaders assumed the players would be considered veterans, which would entitle them to be paid at a higher scale. The league viewed them as rookies.
The dispute was one of a handful of issues that on April 22 led to the collapse of an agreement in principle reached between the league and the union eight days earlier. What happened next caught the union off guard: the league issued a news release accusing the union of reneging on key terms of the agreement and making new economic demands. It also postponed the April 27 draft.
When the W.N.B.A. made those announcements, the union's top three officials were out of town. Some of the players learned of the developments in news reports.
A small but vocal group of players made it clear to the negotiating committee that they weren't prepared to walk out over a few lingering contract demands. Among the issues was a league stipulation that players would not be allowed to play for the season if they had not signed a contract by May 14, the start of training camp.
"When the draft was canceled, that really caught my eye," said Nikki McCray, a guard for the Washington Mystics. "That's when everybody just got together and said, 'Look, what's at the table right now is not worth us losing our season.' We didn't want to start the season with negative energy from our fans."
The players said they were hearing one thing from the union, and reading another from management.
"I never knew which side to listen to," said Rhonda Blades, who plays for the Mystics. "I would listen to the conference calls, but it was hard to know who to trust."
Some players also had a hard time trusting the union leader they inherited: Billy Hunter, the head of the N.B.P.A., who played an integral role in organizing the women but was better known for his role in the N.B.A. lockout.
"I was seen, or at least, I was characterized as being somewhat of an impediment to the negotiations," said Hunter, who participated in only a half-dozen negotiating sessions. "I felt it was incumbent on my part, and probably in the best interest of the women, to remove myself from the scene. So while I was involved, I just wasn't out front."
But his conspicuous absence led to accusations, from some players and advocates of women's pro sports, that he was neglecting the women.
Hunter said he was briefed on everything that took place. By the time he appointed Pamela M. Wheeler as director of operations for the W.N.B.A. players association on March 30, most of the groundwork for the contract was already in place.
"It was important to the women to have a woman there," Hunter said about Wheeler during the final stages of negotiations, which also involved Valerie B. Ackerman, the W.N.B.A.'s commissioner.
"I wasn't operating in a vacuum," Wheeler said. "I was armed, not only with the necessary tools from Billy, but his confidence in my ability to help arrive at a bargaining agreement. We also had extremely competent attorneys from the N.B.P.A."
Yet others were disappointed in the players' decision to accept the men's union. The Women's Coaches Association, which has 4,500 members in the collegiate and professional ranks, felt it could do more to champion the needs and concerns of the women of the W.N.B.A.
"They are not up on the personalities of women's basketball, the coaches, the players, not just the athletes but the movers and shakers of the game," Beth Bass, executive director of the Women's Basketball Coaches Association, said about the men's union. "This is the very thing our association was worried about. You get people involved that don't understand the history of game, and especially the women's game. The men's game is different from the women, especially in development."
And as a new union, the women were completely dependent upon the men of the N.B.A. for funding and staff. The women didn't have the luxury of holding out with the men footing the bill.
Considering the logistics of briefing 132 athletes, some playing overseas, and facing a deadline imposed by a season timed to the N.B.A.'s off season, the union said it was proud reaching an agreement in less than four months and walking away with something to please most, if not all.
Next time around, however, the players hope to do things differently.
For starters, Lobo would like to get rid of some of the lawyers.
"When you have six or seven lawyers on each side involved," Lobo said, "you're in for a lot of, 'What does this word mean?' The negotiations would have been good, if you had a player who really had a good handle on things, a bright attorney with Val and a bright attorney with the union."
Even better, Lobo suggested, would be a change in scenery.
"In three years, when we have to renegotiate, we should all go out on a golf course and get the deal done," she said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 389 words

HEADLINE: Half-Measures for Poor Nations

 BODY:
In 1996 the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund began a program that was supposed to help the world's poorest nations escape their debt traps. Dozens of nations spend up to 60 percent of their budgets for interest on foreign debt that will never be retired -- leaving little for the basic health care and education needed to reduce poverty. But the debt reduction program has been too stingy. This month the world's richest countries will decide how much to increase it. The proposals offered fall far short of real relief.
Debtor countries, mostly African, largely owe money that lenders pushed on eager governments decades ago, in part to cover commercial loans. The current relief program has several problems that the wealthy nations, known as the G-7, say they want to fix at their summit meeting in Cologne, Germany, on June 18. One is that the standards for qualifying -- six years of adherence to an I.M.F. reform and austerity plan -- are so strict that only Uganda and Bolivia have seen any reduction in their payments, and that has been negligible. Another is that the I.M.F.'s austerity requirements have forced countries to cut basic social services. 
 Washington's limited plan, which will probably win support from the other G-7 countries, would allow countries to qualify for debt relief more quickly, focus the I.M.F. on the importance of spending on the poor, and allow several new countries to qualify. The Administration says a wider plan is unlikely to win over Congress or other nations -- Japan and France are the biggest creditors.
Congress may be more supportive than the Administration thinks. About 50 House members from across the spectrum back a plan sponsored by Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, to provide deeper relief and help insure that the money is better used. A Harvard economist, Jeffrey Sachs, argues that the World Bank and I.M.F. have the reserves to forgive all they are owed by poor nations.
Debt forgiveness must go to those who earn it through sound economic policies and well-targeted social programs, but the Administration's proposal would allow only a handful of countries to spend more on basic health and education needs. It is heartless to argue that the United States or the I.M.F. cannot afford to lift a burden now borne by the children of Mali or Zambia.

HEADLINE: Ambitious Plan to Rebuild Staten Island Ferry Hub

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected today to announce an $81 million project to rebuild the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry as a sleek new transportation hub.
The project, to be paid for with $61 million in city money and $20 million in Federal transportation assistance, would put Staten Island in the vanguard of several ambitious efforts to rebuild declining areas of the New York City waterfront as centers of commerce, waterborne transportation and recreation. 
 The terminal project is to be the first phase of a sweeping redevelopment plan for the Staten Island waterfront. Besides a new ferry terminal, which is to include a small shopping concourse, the Giuliani administration has thrown its political weight and financial support behind several proposals on adjoining Staten Island waterfront parcels. They include plans for a minor league baseball stadium for a New York Yankees farm team, more retail development and two new museums.
The terminal project was described yesterday as the linchpin of a long-awaited turnaround for Staten Island.
"This is going to create a giant new destination for both tourists and New Yorkers," said Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine, who described the new terminal and its shops as a "galleria something like Grand Central Station."
Several city officials said yesterday that the terminal project, unlike the stadium and museums proposed for Staten Island, could be built without the environmental and planning review requirements that face most large projects because it would not introduce a new use for city-owned property.
Although Mr. Levine declined to discuss details, he said a city plan first proposed under Mayor David N. Dinkins in the early 1990's to reconstruct the Staten Island ferry terminal at the foot of Whitehall Street in Manhattan would be announced soon. "That project will happen, but it's an announcement for another day," he said.
On Staten Island, Guy V. Molinari, the Borough President, said yesterday that the St. George terminal project would provide vital economic stimulation and fresh impetus for the other developments planned on the St. George waterfront.
"I've never seen as much happening at once," Mr. Molinari said. "Up to now, all we've had is stuff coming down, and we are looking at an extraordinary array of waterfront developments side by side."
He said construction of the new terminal should begin by this fall and be completed sometime in 2002.
According to plans provided by the project's architect, the New York firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the new St. George Terminal would provide passengers with a larger, lighter and technologically advanced waiting room that would lie beneath the structure's most dramatic architectural element, an arched ceiling resting on huge panels of glass.
A separate section of the terminal, also featuring large windows, is to house about a dozen restaurants and shops.
Although the terminal's five ferry berths and passenger loading areas would not be moved, the plan calls for a public rooftop esplanade facing lower Manhattan, improved traffic circulation for motorists dropping off ferry passengers and new escalators and wider platforms to improve access to the Staten Island Railroad, which has a station at the base of the ferry terminal.
Mr. Molinari said the shopping area to be included in the new terminal was being designed as a first installment in what may become a far larger retail concourse, which could be built just south of the terminal by private developers on city-owned property.
If built, that concourse would separate the terminal from the 52-acre site designated by both the city and Mr. Molinari's staff over the last year for a stadium to be leased to Sandlot Sports, a company partially controlled by relatives of the Yankees' principal owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, and operated as a Class A league franchise of the Yankees. Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum has also prepared the plans for that project.
The city, through its Economic Development Corporation, has already committed $12.5 million to the minor league baseball proposal in its purchase last year of the site, a former rail yard now used as a parking lot. Mr. Giuliani has also promised that the city will pay for construction of the proposed stadium, estimated to cost $29 million.
The two museums proposed near the new St. George terminal have more difficult financial hurdles to overcome. One would be the National Lighthouse Center and Museum, proposed for a 10-acre site just north of the ferry terminal by a national organization of lighthouse preservation groups. Although $5 million has been promised in city and state support, the lighthouse groups must raise an additional $15 million to cover the project's projected budget.
The other museum is being proposed for a site south of the ferry terminal by the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, which hopes to build an exhibition space devoted to the history of New York Harbor. The New York State Dormitory Authority has promised to back $40 million in bonds that would be issued by the arts institute, but that would not cover the project's projected budget of $55 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Auto Makers and Union Eager for Long-Term Deal
With General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler scheduled to begin talks next week with the United Automobile Workers union, it appears increasingly likely that negotiators will seek a national labor contract lasting four or more years, the longest such deal since the 1950's, auto executives and union officials said.
Chastened by a strike last summer against G.M. and enjoying the soaring profits and bountiful overtime pay produced by record auto sales, management and workers appear eager to avoid another showdown this year. The U.A.W. would also be able to avoid having the next round of auto labor talks in the summer of 2002, when the union could be locked in a power struggle after the retirement of its president, Stephen P. Yokich. Page C2. 

Curiously, Intel Agrees to Limit Jobs
In an unusual arrangement that reflects both the flush national economy and Oregon's particular obsession with controlling sprawl, Intel has agreed to pay a fee if it exceeds a ceiling of 1,000 new manufacturing jobs on top of the 4,000 it already has in Washington County, part of the Portland metropolitan area. A18.
 
More I.B.M. Testimony on Microsoft
A Microsoft executive told I.B.M. privately in 1997 that the computer maker would pay a lower price for Microsoft's Windows operating system if it did not ship a competing Internet browser, an I.B.M. executive, Garry Norris, testified in the Microsoft antitrust trial. C6.
 
Replay Networks in Panasonic Deal
Replay Networks has signed an agreement with Panasonic Consumer Electronics to make its new digital video recorders systems and have them in stores for the Christmas shopping season. The set-top boxes blend the power of computers with television. C9.
 
 
Prescription Plan Draws Skepticism
Drug industry and insurance executives reacted with skepticism to White House plans for a new prescription drug benefit for all elderly Americans. Drug manufacturers said they did not believe the assurances of Administration officials that the proposal would not lead to price controls on drugs. C6.
 
G.M. to Buy Bank of New York Unit
General Motors agreed to buy Bank of New York's commercial lending unit for $1.8 billion as the auto maker diversifies its holdings and the bank continues to specialize its operations. For Bank of New York, the deal fits a pattern of concentrating on fee-based operations. Its shares rose $2.375, to $37.0625, while G.M. fell $1.375, to $67.75. C6.
 
Lawyer Panel Backs New Alliances
In a move that would transform how legal services are provided, a special panel of the American Bar Association recommended abandoning decades-old rules that have prevented lawyers from setting up partnerships with accountants, consultants and other professionals. C6.
 
Air Passengers Told to Be Punctual
With the airline industry's on-time performance lagging, US Airways is the latest carrier to require passengers to board planes at least 10 minutes before scheduled departure -- or risk being left behind. Business Travel. C9.
 
Cathay Pacific Grounds Flights
Cathay Pacific Airways grounded more than half its flights in a bitter dispute with pilots who have been calling in sick over a demand by the carrier to accept pay cuts averaging 7 percent or quit with six months' pay. C4.
 
Productivity Figures Revised
Revised figures showed that worker productivity rose 3.5 percent in the first quarter, less than the 4 percent previously estimated. C2.
 
Change-Over at Economic Council
White House officials said that they would most likely nominate Martin Baily, a partner at McKinsey & Company, to succeed Janet L. Yellen later this year as head of the Council of Economic Advisers. Ms. Yellen plans to leave this summer to return to teaching. C9.

HEADLINE: Alexander Treks Uphill In Faltering Campaign

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: MARYVILLE, Tenn.

 BODY:
The last time he ran for President, Lamar Alexander saw no need to parade before voters his membership in the elite fellowship of Eagle Scouts. To any son of the modest, contented town of Maryville, in the hills of eastern Tennessee, it would have been a vainglorious declaration, made creaky by the rustle of ancient merit badges.
But this time around, the self-effacement is over, jettisoned with the flannel shirts and statewide hikes. Suddenly, Mr. Alexander has decided he has every reason to inform voters of his Eagle Scout award, his impeccable family life, his respectable record as a two-term governor of Tennessee. Convinced by a year of Washington scandal that his moment has finally arrived, he does so with little prompting. 
 "Back in 1974, Ray Blanton beat me by calling me Richard Nixon's choirboy," Mr. Alexander said in an interview, referring to the disgraced former Governor of Tennessee. "But four years later, after people found out he was selling pardons for cash, they decided electing a choirboy wouldn't be so bad. And this year, people are looking for character again. They come up and tell me they want someone who will restore decency to the White House."
The personal failings of President Clinton have created a new theme for Mr. Alexander's second Presidential campaign, which until recently had threatened to sound very much like his earnest but lackluster effort in 1996. His proposals to decentralize education and lower taxes, impassioned as they sound, have yet to arouse many voters, and his fund-raising has fallen so far below expectations that it is threatening the viability of his campaign.
He has plowed and seeded Iowa and New Hampshire for seven years, but much of his organizing work has been washed away by the leading Republican candidate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who has considerably less governmental experience than Mr. Alexander but a much better-known name. Many party leaders on whom Mr. Alexander had counted have embraced Mr. Bush, who is attracting so many Republican dollars that Mr. Alexander's campaign has been forced to lay off senior staff members just to stay alive.
And so Mr. Alexander is going beyond most of this year's mainstream challengers in using the Lewinsky scandal and its moral repercussions as a broad cudgel to batter the Clinton Administration -- and by extension, Vice President Al Gore -- on diverse topics like Kosovo and Littleton, Colo.
Mr. Clinton, he says, has "destroyed the nation's confidence in its Government" and squandered the moral authority he needs to wage war and heal the wounds of the school shooting. Mr. Gore, as the President's "head cheerleader," is no less guilty because of his support and continued praise for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Alexander said, adding an aphorism: "He can't take all the credit for Mr. Clinton's economy and none of the blame for his misconduct."
 
Savoring the Contrast With an Opponent
Of course, if Mr. Alexander's straight-backed persona also presents a contrast with the dimly lighted background of Mr. Bush, that will not bother him a bit.
"I expect all of us in the field will get asked lots of questions about our background," he said recently, driving a visitor around the placid neighborhood in Maryville where he grew up and took piano lessons. "And I for one intend to answer those questions. I don't expect I'll have very many to answer."
He wants desperately to be asked, though, and quickly. As cheery and confident as Mr. Alexander sounds, his campaign is in danger of starvation. Though he has stump appeal and one of the best fund-raisers in the Republican Party, he has not been able to draw nourishment from the party's donors. The reason might be summed up in one of the maxims that punctuate his life and fill the self-deprecating and amusing "Little Plaid Book" he published last year: "If you want to be noticed, don't ride in a convertible with Dolly Parton."
In this case, it is Mr. Bush who fills the role of the siren, and it frustrates Mr. Alexander to no end that so many Republicans are betting on a well-known name. He had hoped to raise about $7 million by now, but was expected to report less than $2.5 million in his second-quarter filing later this month.
Over the last week, he has been forced to lay off four of his most senior staff members, including the directors of research, communications and legal affairs. It was a painful admission for a candidate desperate to radiate confidence and momentum, particularly when he was still trying to convince his supporters that his single-digit poll ratings meant nothing at this early stage. Now, he must bet his entire treasury on the two states with the first voices of 2000, Iowa and New Hampshire, all the while praying for Mr. Bush to bungle his lead.
The strategy remains plausible, however, particularly given Mr. Bush's reticence so far in outlining his positions, and in the absence of any other nationally known, tested Republican in the race. By most reckonings, the Alexander campaign is the best organized in Iowa, with most of the county leaders as well as the popular former Governor Terry E. Branstad supporting him. Mr. Alexander announced today that he had volunteer organizations set up in each of the state's 99 counties, more than any of the other contenders. That actually counts for something in Iowa, where voters have to be persuaded to come out on a winter night, but it is hardly a guarantee of success.
"He has been visiting here regularly for the last seven years, and historically that has made a difference for some candidates who are not that well known," said Hugh Winebrenner, a professor of public administration at Drake University in Des Moines and author of a book on the Iowa caucuses. "The flip side is that he's got to have some good news at some point, because in the end it's enthusiasm that puts you over the top."
Mr. Alexander prefers, of course, to take the long view, and counsels skeptics to "remember the fable of the tortoise and the hare."
 
Seeking an Audience Beyond the Countryside
Mr. Alexander's third-place showing in Iowa in 1996 brought him considerable money and attention, at least until he was shot down in the New Hampshire primary by Bob Dole, and Mr. Alexander dropped out a few weeks later. Now, he is staking seven years of work on the hope that something like his third-place showing will happen again, that his unassuming personality will play well in Iowa and attract a quick pivot of the national attention.
"Anybody who grew up in Maryville, plays the piano, was an Eagle Scout and goes to church, is going to do well in Iowa, and not badly in New Hampshire," Mr. Alexander said. "Iowa and New Hampshire suit me fine."
The real question, of course, is how he will fare in those parts of the nation that do not share the open countryside, the comfortable porch swings, the uncynical outlook of his hometown or the rural precincts of Iowa. Though he is not as conservative as Ronald Reagan, he frequently invokes Mr. Reagan's optimism and thematic use of the Presidency as his models, soothing his listeners with slightly dreamy descriptions of how the country could return to small-town values. But without Mr. Reagan's magnetism, his words may play differently in large cities.
"When I was growing up, parents and teachers were deeply involved in the lives of children," Mr. Alexander said in a speech a few weeks ago at an outdoor festival in Elizabethton, Tenn., population 13,289, explaining why so many of today's children seem to be lost. "There were nosy neighbors who watched us as we went to school, teachers who knew they had authority from the community to teach us right from wrong as well as math and English. There were choir masters and scoutmasters and churches open so many days a week that it seemed like Sunday came every other day. That is not nostalgia, it is a tried and true recipe for helping our children."
 
Conceding Charisma To Other Candidates
He is not a wooden speaker; his delivery is crisp and effective, particularly with like-minded crowds, but he rarely sets his listeners vibrating with an emotional connection. As frustrated as he is with Mr. Bush's outsized silhouette, the worst thing he can say about him is that the Texas Governor is untested.
One Republican Party official who has worked with Mr. Alexander said he could probably outspeak Al Gore or Bill Bradley, the former New Jersey Senator who is running for the Democratic nomination, but would have trouble against a more charismatic candidate.
"He's a dear and wonderful man, but he can be in a room two hours before you know he's there," the official said. "It's hard to define, but he needs more of that star quality people have come to expect."
Mr. Alexander, who is 58, seems aware that he is no firebrand, but he argues that people have grown weary of charisma. This is not an unfamiliar argument; it has been made many times over the years by similar candidates, and is also being used by the Gore and Bradley campaigns. But it is central to Mr. Alexander's conception of himself, and this year he has decided to forgo the gimmickry of the plaid shirts, which were originally designed to help him stand out, and concentrate on the things he does well.
"I don't intend to try to manufacture an issue just to capture the headlines," he said, referring to the publicity surrounding Elizabeth Dole's embrace of gun control. "That wouldn't work; people would see through it. The best course for me is to remember the fable of the tortoise and the hare, and organize the counties and raise enough money, and practice my speeches and have a good time. And hopefully the day after the Iowa caucuses, everyone in the country will know who I am. So I'm going to have to be patient."
Those who listen will hear a firmly etched manifesto of moderate grass-roots conservatism, presented in an easygoing Presbyterian style, all common sense and good will. He is convinced that with less interference from Washington, the parents, school boards and local elected officials around the country can find their own solutions to educational problems. He no longer advocates the dismantling of the Department of Education, aware that such a proposal sounds a bit strange coming from a man who was President George Bush's Education Secretary. But he still wants to help families by giving children $1,500 scholarships and letting them choose their own school, public, private or charter. He favors breaking the power of teachers' unions and Federal bureaucrats.
"Al Gore thinks he knows what's best for this country," Mr. Alexander says in every stump speech. "What I want to do is bring out the best in this country."
It takes him about 20 seconds to go from denouncing the Littleton shootings to demanding an end to the marriage tax and a tripling of the child deductions, certain that a restructuring of Federal tax policy would strengthen families as much as the economy. He does not favor an amendment outlawing abortion and says he could support some Federal gun-control legislation, but also supports a missile defense system and wants no limits on campaign fund-raising from individuals. Though he was a clerk for the late Federal Judge John Minor Wisdom, one of the authors of modern affirmative action, he opposes any form of racial preferences and says the Clinton Administration has talked too much about race and too little about unity.
Mr. Alexander is annoyed by the suggestion that he is unusually persevering, suspecting the implication that his cause is hopeless, and correctly points out that Mr. Reagan and many other politicians tried more than once for the Presidency. He is clearly propelled by a sense that he has trained for the Presidency, and seems mystified that the country might not want to make use of the skills he developed in the Tennessee Statehouse, at the helm of the University of Tennessee and in a day-care business that made him a wealthy man after drawing on his contacts as Governor.
"By this age, I pretty much know what my skills are, and I felt like when I was Governor, I was really at the peak of my performance in making the most contributions I could make," he said. "I just feel that this is what I should be doing. My character and demeanor, which wouldn't be suited to every set of times, might be, as it turns out, very well-suited to these times."
